HEADLINE: Another Departure at First Boston in Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 23

 BODY:
CS First Boston's Asian operations today lost its second top executive in the last three weeks, just as the troubled international investment banking firm begins to put a new strategy in place.
CS First Boston said that Keisuke Inaba, who had been president of the firm's Japanese subsidiary, resigned to take a senior position with a rival, UBS Phillips & Drew, the securities division of the Union Bank of Switzerland. CS First Boston is the securities subsidiary of Credit Suisse, another big Swiss bank.
Mr. Inaba's resignation occurred two weeks after the departure of James M. Walsh, who had been chief executive of CS First Boston's Japanese division, which now has more than 400 employees. 
 
Move Away from Stock Trading
Both men, who were popular in the tight-knit Tokyo securities community, were said to have been unhappy with the changes being put in place by the new head of the firm's Asian operations, Allen D. Wheat.
Mr. Wheat has said he is planning to push the firm heavily into several complex, global businesses, like currency swaps, interest rate swaps and specialized stock options. All these businesses will tie the securities firm in more closely with Credit Suisse and will steer it away from stock and bond trading.
These new businesses rely heavily on computers and careful long-range analyses, rather than Wall Street's traditional style of securities trading and sales using intuition and split-second timing. The newer businesses tend to produce smaller, but less volatile, profits, something that many securities companies are finding attractive after the wild profit swings most experienced during the latter half of the 1980's.
Mr. Wheat joined CS First Boston in February from the Bankers Trust Company, along with nearly 20 other Bankers Trust officials in Tokyo and London. Mr. Walsh was a longtime CS First Boston executive who had worked in London and New York, in addition to Tokyo. Mr. Inaba joined the firm in 1987 from Kidder, Peabody & Company, where he had been Tokyo branch manager.
 
Struggle to Regain Momentum
Clearly, more change rather than less is in store for CS First Boston, as the once-powerful securities firm struggles to regain its momentum after a tumultuous two years.
''We do have a very ambitious set of goals,'' Mr. Wheat said in an interview today. ''It is inevitable that that would create some resentments. We need people who are committed 100 percent to this strategy.''
Mr. Wheat added that Mr. Inaba had had misgivings about remaining with the firm from the time he arrived in February. ''In Kei's case, I was disappointed that he left,'' Mr. Wheat said, using Mr. Inaba's nickname. ''But I got tired of trying to coax him to stay.''
Mr. Inaba said in a statement that he felt ''it is time to move on to new challenges.'' He was said to be in New York and could not be reached for further comment.
 
Plan to Lower Borrowing Costs
After suffering an outflow of talent from its investment banking division, Credit Suisse acquired the minority interest in First Boston that it did not already own. Since that was completed last year, it has been struggling to bring in new management and stem the loss of professionals.
Mr. Wheat arrived earlier this year at the Asian division and the keystone in his strategy will be the formation next month of a special purpose banking subsidiary in London, which will be controlled by Credit Suisse.
This division will, in effect, permit CS First Boston to use Credit Suisse's top rating with the credit agencies to borrow capital and engage in certain complex transactions far more cheaply than it could on its own. These cheaper borrowing costs will be central to the new swaps and other sophisticated businesses that Mr. Wheat plans to build.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 27, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about CS-First Boston's Asian operations misstated the ownership of CS-First Boston Inc. It is 44.5 percent owned by CS Holding, which also owns Credit Suisse, the large Swiss bank. The remaining shares in CS-First Boston are held by management and by institutional investors.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Higher While the Mark Declines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against most major currencies yesterday, benefiting from weakness in the West German mark.
Speculation that United States interest rates will move higher as the economy continues to expand also encouraged dollar buying, dealers said.
Gold prices were mixed, rising in New York after falling in some overseas markets. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for April delivery settled at $378.90 an ounce, $2.30 higher than Friday's close. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $378.65, up $2.40 from Friday's late bid. 
Ronald Holzer, chief currency dealer at Harris Trust in Chicago, said the mark was sold heavily amid worries about the consequences of planned German unification.
The Governments of East and West Germany have said they will merge their economies completely on July 1 as a prelude to full unification, expected next year. But a final agreement on linking their currencies has not been reached.
 
Effect of Lithuania Embargo
The dollar also benefited from news of growing oil shortages in Lithuania caused by the Soviet economic embargo on the republic. Also contributing to the dollar's strength were expectations of domestic economic growth accompanied by rising credit costs. Higher interest rates in the United States would enhance returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to lift demand for dollars.
It was anticipated that a report due today on orders for durable goods and a report Friday on the gross national product would confirm that the economic expansion has staged a modest revival.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 157.55 Japanese yen, from 157.60 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it was unchanged. In New York, the dollar settled at 157.55 yen, up from 157.50 yen on Friday.
The British pound rose to $1.6365 in London, from $1.6357 late Friday. Later in New York, the pound dipped to $1.63565 from Friday's $1.6388.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6995 West German marks, up from 1.6872; 1.4935 Swiss francs, up from 1.4895; 5.7020 French francs, up from 5.6655; 1,246.75 Italian lire, up from 1,238.20, and 1.16155 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1628.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Bush Delays Action on Lithuania, Not Wanting to Harm Gorbachev

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
After conferring with allies and Congressional leaders, President Bush today delayed carrying out a threat to take action against Moscow for tightening its chokehold on Lithuania, fearing sanctions might undermine President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and worsen the Baltic crisis.
The decision, supported by European allies and some leading members of Congress, reflected Mr. Bush's own inclination not to move against Moscow in hopes of buying time for the Soviet Union and Lithuania to resolve their differences over the Baltic republic's declaration of independence. Mr. Bush has not been under any groundswell of public pressure to act against Moscow.
His decision today reflected a complicated equation of political pressures that the Administration has avoided spelling out in public. While it is eager to take a strong stand supporting Lithuanian independence, the United States does not believe that trying to force immediate independence is worth risking progress on arms control, upsetting the evolution in Eastern Europe or jeopardizing Mr. Gorbachev's domestic political position. 
Appearing before agriculture writers today at the White House, Mr. Bush said his inaction was motivated by a fear of provoking the Soviet Union at a tense moment. ''I may do something imprudent,'' Mr. Bush said. ''I am concerned that we not do anything that would cause the Soviet Union to take action that would set back the cause of freedom around the world.''
Some members of Congress said today that economic sanctions are in order. But after a White House meeting with Mr. Bush, most of those who attended backed the President.
The House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said Mr. Bush was acting properly in seeking to promote a dialogue between Soviet and Lithuanian officials. ''There is not any action that I believe at this point could be taken which would be a constructive one in the way of sanctions or other activity,'' Mr. Foley said.
Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, praised Mr. Bush for ''recognizing that if the situation is escalated it could be of mutual damage.''
Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, said there would be strong Congressional support if Mr. Bush took action against the Soviet Union, but commended him for his ''care and prudence.''
Although there was clearly no wave of Congressional or public pressure for Mr. Bush to act, the Administration kept the option of sanctions open in case the Soviet pressure increased. But Mr. Bush has now backed off twice from lines he had appeared to draw on Soviet behavior on Lithuania, and the White House said the situation would have to worsen dramatically before he imposed sanctions.
''It probably would be more than one or two things that would move us to a decision now,'' a senior Administration official said. ''Clearly more measures, or intensification of measures by the Soviets, failure of any dialogue to emerge, these would be considerations. But you shouldn't take that as a checklist.''
 
Meets With Advisers
Some Administration officials had expected Mr. Bush to announce limited action against the Soviet Union today after the morning conference with Congressional leaders. The options he has been considering involve the suspension of one or more of the negotiations now under way over trade concessions sought by Moscow.
Pressure to act built late last week when the Soviet Union began stepping up its sanctions against Lithuania by cutting oil and natural gas supplies. ''I think that the initial instinct when the Soviets imposed the sanctions late last week was that the time had come to take action,'' a senior official said.
Mr. Bush met with senior national security advisers Monday evening and received a report from a round of intensive weekend diplomacy that spelled out strong European opposition to sanctions, officials said.
As late as Monday evening, some Administration officials were still expecting Mr. Bush to take some action against Moscow. But the description of European opposition plus a reading of Congressional sentiment prompted Mr. Bush to decide later Monday not to impose any immediate sanctions, officials said. He and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have been extremely reluctant to impose sanctions, hoping that Moscow and Lithuania could work out their differences.
Mr. Bush, speaking to the agricultural group, said he thought Americans supported his approach, ''and I say that with total appreciation for the strength of the feeling that Lithuanians in this country have about their own freedom.''
''But I also am concerned about the freedom of Poland,'' he added. ''I was concerned about the evolution of freedom in the other Baltic states, whose incorporation we haven't recognized.''
 
Damage to Gorbachev Considered
Administration officials said today that Mr. Bush feared that taking action against Moscow could interfere with German unification and the Soviet military withdrawal from Eastern Europe. Another concern, emphasized in particular by West Europeans, was that sanctions could undermine Mr. Gorbachev's domestic position.
Finally, a suspension of talks on such issues as a trade agreement, investment, tax arrangements and Soviet membership in international financial organizations would block steps the Administration believes would foster a market economy and political pluralism in the Soviet Union, officials said.
A senior official said: ''There is a very genuine, sincere sympathy for Lithuania's desire for self-determination and for their own identity and the importance of our sticking to our principles. By the same token, Bush looks at what Gorbachev has accomplished in the Soviet Union and in Eastern Europe in particular, and there are huge equities at stake here.''
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the United States had been encouraged by signs of ''flexibility'' in recent Soviet statements and that Mr. Bush did not want to interfere with arms control talks or the schedule for the next Soviet-American summit. ----K.G.B. Sends Reinforcements MOSCOW, April 24 (AP) - Lithuania's President accused the United States today of selling out his rebellious Baltic republic in its confrontation with the Soviet Government.
After President Bush's announcement that he had delayed the imposition of sanctions against the Soviet Union, President Vytautas Landsbergis issued an angry statement from Vilnius.
''Can the freedom of one group of people be sold for the freedom of another? What then is the idea of freedom itself?'' he said.
''This is another Munich,'' he said, referring to the 1938 pact by which France and Britain allowed Nazi Germany to take control of Czechoslovakia.
Also today, the Kremlin reinforced K.G.B. border guards in Lithuania today, and The Soviet press agency Tass reported a gunfire attack Monday night on a Soviet Army barracks in Vilnius, Lithuania's capital, but said no one was hurt.
Tass quoted Maj. Aleksei Kirichenko of the Soviet Army as saying a shot was fired at an open window about 10 P.M. when soldiers were already inside the barracks. It said the bullet smashed a window on the opposite wall.
Lithuania hopes to make up for some of the supplies Moscow has cut with imports from abroad. But the K.G.B.'s announcement that it was adding personnel and equipment to guard the republic's border appeared designed as a warning against such a step.

HEADLINE: Milken Defends 'Junk Bonds' As He Enters His Guilty Plea

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Apologizing for his crimes but defending the ''junk bond'' market he created, Michael R. Milken pleaded guilty yesterday to six felony charges of securities fraud and conspiracy. The 43-year-old financier agreed to pay $600 million in fines and penalties.
Mr. Milken had long maintained his innocence and had not let the pressure of the Government investigation show in public. But yesterday, during his 35-minute appearance in a packed Manhattan courtroom, Mr. Milken broke down and cried, saying he had ''hurt those who are closest to me.''
In his statement to the Federal District Court, Mr. Milken admitted that he had committed several illegal acts in cooperation with others intended to enrich his firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and to help the firm complete trades for itself and its clients. 
''I transgressed certain of the laws and regulations that govern our industry,'' Mr. Milken said. ''I was wrong in doing so and knew that at the time and I am pleading guilty to these offenses.'' [Text of statement, page D8.]
In essence, Mr. Milken admitted to cheating some Drexel customers, aiding others in the violation of securities and tax laws, and manipulating the securities market to benefit a client.
 
The Largest Prosecution
The plea by Mr. Milken brings to a close the largest criminal prosecution in Wall Street history. He agreed to the plea and the largest monetary penalty ever last week.
Mr. Milken, the former head of the junk bond division at the now-defunct Drexel, had been at the center of the giant Wall Street inquiry that bloomed in 1986. In November that year, Ivan F. Boesky, the former stock speculator, agreed to settle insider trading charges, pay a fine of $100 million and provide evidence about other wrongdoing on Wall Street. The junk bond market Mr. Milken pioneered financed many of the corporate takeovers of the 1980's.
Mr. Milken will be sentenced on Oct. 1 and faces a maximum prison term of 28 years. Securities lawyers say they expect his prison term will not exceed five years.
Mr. Milken appeared in a courtroom that was overflowing. The walls were lined with officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the United States Attorney's office, lawyers and reporters. Mr. Milken's wife, Lori, sat in the front row of the courtroom next to his brother, Lowell Milken had been indicted in the case, but the charges against him were dropped as part of the settlement.
Throughout most of the proceeding, Mr. Milken remained stoic, staring intently at the judge with his hands folded at his waist, while answering a litany of questions to assure the judge that his plea was being voluntarily given and that he was aware of the maximum possible sentence.
Only once did he divert from quickly answering the questions with a curt ''Yes, Judge,'' or ''No, Judge.'' When asked if he was making his plea under any force or threats, he hesitated for a few seconds and then replied, ''No.''
Reading from his statement, Mr. Milken said, ''This long period has been extremely painful and difficult for my family and friends as well as myself. I realize that by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me.'' Mr. Milken hesitated as tears began to well in his eyes, and he placed his right index finger under his nose.
 
'I Am Truly Sorry'
''I am truly sorry,'' he continued, his face reddening. He then uttered while sobbing, ''I thank the Court for permitting me to add this apology and for its fairness in handling this complex case.''
Mr. Milken's lawyer, Arthur Liman, then put his arm around his client and raised his hand slowly to the judge, indicating that his client needed a moment to recover. Judge Kimba M. Wood then thanked Mr. Milken for his statement, and he sat down.
Seconds passed until Mr. Milken regained his composure, drinking from a plastic cup of water. He then stood again, and Judge Wood said, ''Mr. Milken, how do you plead?''
With his voice cracking with emotion, the financier replied, ''Guilty, Your Honor.''
The charges to which Mr. Milken pleaded guilty involved a series of illegal transactions with Mr. Boesky, as well as other illicit deals with David Solomon, a former junk bond trader and founder of Solomon Asset Management. The charges portray a man who ignored some legal restrictions in an effort to benefit his firm and clients of his division.
 
Inaccurate Filings
Mr. Milken engaged in a conspiracy that allowed Mr. Boesky to violate the rules on capital that governed his stock trading firm, as well as to file inaccurate financial statements to Government regulators. He also conspired with Mr. Boesky to inflate the price of a stock to benefit one of Drexel's clients.
In addition, Mr. Milken entered into an illegal agreement with Mr. Solomon under which the cost of some trades was misstated to repay Drexel for the cost of paying commissions on those trades. Also, he conducted a complex series of trades that allowed Mr. Solomon to illegally claim losses to reduce his 1985 Federal income tax return.
None of the crimes to which Mr. Milken pleaded guilty involved illegal activities in the junk bond market, but rather in other securities markets. In his court statement, which was approved by the Government, Mr. Milken said the crimes were ''not a reflection on the underlying soundness and integrity of the capital markets in which we specialized.'' He added: ''Our business was in no way dependent on these practices.''
After the hearing, Mr. Liman read a statement on the steps of the courthouse, saying the charges described were ''instances in which Michael went too far in helping clients'' and an arrangement ''to recoup expenses incurred by Drexel.''
He said, ''It is Michael's hope that in the long run, history will see his violations in context and judge him not just on the basis of his lapses, but on the basis of the contributions that he made to the economy.''
One trader who was caught up in the scandal that enveloped Wall Street after Mr. Boesky began to turn over information to the Government said he was not surprised by Mr. Milken's fate.
 
'What They Deserved'
''It's anti-climactic,'' said Boyd L. Jefferies, a former stock trader who is on probation for engaging in illegal activities with Mr. Boesky. ''I don't think anybody in this whole thing has gotten anything but what they deserved.''
Mr. Jefferies added: ''When I was doing these favors for clients, I knew I was breaking the law. We all knew we were breaking the law.''
While the charges Mr. Milken pleaded guilty to were serious, some securities lawyers expressed surprise yesterday at how mild they turned out to be. Mr. Milken did not plead guilty to insider trading or racketeering, the two most serious crimes in the original indictment in March.
Mr. Milken agreed yesterday to pay $600 million in fines and penalties to settle both the criminal case against him and the civil case brought in 1988 by the Securities and Exchange Commission. He will pay $200 million in fines and, as part of the S.E.C. settlement, will set aside $400 million to satisfy civil claims that have been filed against him.
Despite the fines and penalties, Mr. Milken will remain a rich man. He was paid more than $1.1 billion dollars by Drexel from 1983 to 1987, and earned income from his large number of investments as well.
In his statement, Mr. Milken also described his personal relationship with Mr. Boesky. Mr. Milken said his dealings with Mr. Boesky constituted less than 1 percent of the business of Drexel's junk bond unit.
 
They Were Not Friends
''He traded in stocks, and I traded in bonds or their equivalent,'' Mr. Milken said. ''But because he was a major factor in the securities markets, he had the potential to become a more significant account.''
Mr. Milken said he and Mr. Boesky ''were not social friends, and had little in common.'' He added: ''His philosophy of business was different from mine. The relationship started as an arms length and correct one.''
But over time, Mr. Milken said, the two men began to enter into transactions that violated the law.
After the hearing was over, Mr. Milken left the courtroom through the judge's chambers. Unlike last year when he pleaded not guilty to the original indictment, there was no crowd of supporters waiting for him outside the courthouse. A handful of people did cheer for him, but others also booed as he left.
In its court filings, the Government said it would drop all criminal charges against Mr. Milken's brother, Lowell, as well as all civil charges brought against him by the S.E.C., Despite the personal benefit, Lowell Milken attempted to persuade his brother for more than two hours last Thursday not to plead guilty, his lawyer, Michael Armstrong, said.
 
Deterrent Effect
Government officials said the strong efforts in the Milken case should have a significant deterrent effect on white-collar criminals. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the Milken prosecution sent a strong message that ''white-collar criminals are never so powerful or clever that they cannot be caught by diligent and persistent law enforcement efforts.''
Unlike other Wall Street executives who have agreed to plead guilty, Mr. Milken is not required to begin immediately to provide the Government with details for its investigations. He will be interviewed by the Government after he is sentenced and is expected to be called to testify before grand juries. He has waived his Constitutional right to refuse to answer questions because he might incriminate himself and has been granted immunity from further prosecution in the case.

LENGTH: 935 words

HEADLINE: After Gains of 80's, Northeast Is Lagging In the Growth of Jobs

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
After years that brought some of the sharpest economic gains since World War II, the Northeast is now trailing the rest of the nation in job growth.
In a ranking released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, seven of the nine states from Pennsylvania to Maine were in the bottom 10 in employment growth in the two years ending last December. Only one Northeastern state, Pennsylvania, was in the bottom 10 in job growth in the previous seven years.
Economists attributed the Northeast's decline to a labor market that tightened significantly in the mid-80's; to the sputtering of two driving economic forces, the financial industry in New York City and the high-technology companies concentrated around Boston; to continuing losses of factory jobs, and to a construction industry that is sagging in much of the region. 
The economists also said the standings reflected that Northeastern states were well developed, with mature economies, and thus have less room to expand than less-developed regions.
''The economic renaissance of the 1980's is now history,'' the regional commissioner of labor statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, said yesterday in a telephone interview. Mr. Ehrenhalt, who compiled the ranking of total nonfarm employment state by state, said it showed that a slowdown that started earlier in the region than in the rest of the nation was also ''hitting here harder than in the country as a whole.''
The standings represent a sharp turnaround in the fortunes of the Northeast, which accounted for 18 percent of the new jobs in the 80's, double its share in the 70's.
Although eight of the nine states gained jobs in the last two years, their employment growth was generally much lower than earlier in the decade. In New York State, employment, which had been expanding 2.4 percent a year from 1982 to 1987, grew 1.4 percent in 1988 and 0.5 percent last year.
Employment in the country as a whole grew at an annual rate of 3.2 percent from 1982 to 1988 before dropping to 2.3 percent in 1989, according to the labor statistics bureau.
For the Northeast, the survey results were reminiscent of the 70's, a bleak period in which six of the nine states were ranked in the bottom 10 in the nation in employment growth. New York was the sole state in the nation that failed to gain jobs in that decade.
 
Strength in the Northwest
In contrast, Western states, particularly the Northwest, were among the nation's strongest in the last two years, the survey showed. Seven of the top 10 states in job growth were in the West.
Robert A. Dye, director of state forecasting for the WEFA Group, a forecasting organization in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said a ''key constraining factor'' for Northeastern states was the supply of labor, which began to tighten in the mid-80's. ''Firms simply can't expand unless there's the available labor pool to fill the jobs,'' he said.
Mr. Dye also noted that the Northeastern states ''simply are going to show much less potential for new growth than less-developed states like in the Northwest.''
He said that states like Nevada, which rose from fifth in the nation in job growth earlier in the decade to first in the last two years, had ''a lot of potential for very high growth rates because they are starting from a low base.''
 
Extended Manufacturing Decline
Similarly, Washington State, which moved to 3d from 18th, was propelled by a boom in the aerospace industry, which is concentrated there.
The deputy director of research for regional affairs at the Federal Reservee Bank of Boston, Lynn Browne, said she believed the downturn in the Northeast was largely related to the decline in the construction and real-estate industries.
''But you could say one reason for that decline is the extended decline in manufacturing and the slow population growth,'' she said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt also stressed the continuing decline of manufacturing. A report accompanying the survey noted that factory jobs in New York declined 3.5 percent in the last two years and that in the 80's the state lost 300,000 such jobs.
 
Prospect of Higher Taxes
Other factors cited by economists for the decline included military cutbacks that affected employers in Connecticut and on Long Island and the high cost of real estate, wages and energy in the region.
Mr. Dye said nearly all state governments in the Northeast faced budget shortfalls. Such problems, which were made worse by the sluggish economy, will likely lead to tax increases in a region already known for its high taxes.
Whatever the factors, the downward movement of the Northeastern states from one survey to another was striking. Vermont dropped to 31st from 8th in the survey covering the first part of the decade; New Jersey, to 41st from 16th; Massachusetts, to 49th from 17th; Connecticut, to 47th from 19th; Rhode Island, to 48th from 25th; New York, to 45th from 27th, and New Hampshire, to 50th from 3d.
Pennsylvania edged down one place, to 42d. Alone in the Northeast, Maine improved its rank, moving to 9th from 10th. Mr. Dye said Maine's gain of 7.5 percent probably stemmed from a pickup in shipbuilding.
The survey showed that the prosperity of the early and mid-80's bypassed some parts of the nation. From December 1979 to December 1987, five states lost jobs, Iowa, Louisiana, Montana, West Virginia and Wyoming. Some of those recovered in the last two years.
Just New Hampshire lost jobs in the last two years. It lost nearly 5,000 jobs, about 1 percent of its total employment. Ms. Browne attributed the drop to sharp declines in construction and manufacturing.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Experts Fear a German Inflation Rise

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
It is widely agreed that Bonn's decision to ground a German monetary union on a one-for-one exchange of currencies will make East Germans very happy indeed. And by pleasing East German voters, the concession is likely to serve the immediate interests of West Germany's ruling party, the Christian Democratic Union.
But the economic implications of the deal are not so easily pinned down. According to Jan Vanous of the PlanEcon consulting firm in Washington, the inflationary impact of increasing the cash value of the savings of East Germans is likely to be small and transitory. But many economists do worry, however, that the decision to set the wages and pensions of East Germans far above the rates justified by labor productivity will set off a spiral of inflation and unemployment that will be difficult to check. 
 
Economy Five Times Larger
Much will depend, they argue, on the speed at which the East German economy is integrated into West Germany's, which is five times larger. And that, in turn, will critically depend on the flexibility of wage rates in the east and the willingness of West German taxpayers to subsidize East German living standards during the transition.
As Germans have discovered in the last months of debate, the choice of currency exchange rates poses an excruciating economic dilemma. Warwick McKibbin, an analyst at the Brookings Institution in Washington, says that if East Germany hopes to attract investment, the exchange rate must reflect the low productivity of East German enterprises and workers. But if wage rates remain as low as productivity dictates, the best and brightest workers will emigrate west, stripping the east of its most notable resource.
 
Resistance Unlikely
Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the West German Government responded with a compromise whose political virtues are clearer than its economic implications. The plan, which is unlikely to meet much resistance from the newly elected conservative Government of East Germany, would give individuals the right to exchange 4,000 East German marks in savings for 4,000 West German marks, worth about $2,400. Personal savings in excess of 4,000 East German marks, as well as other financial assets of individuals and enterprises, would be exchangeable at the rate of two East German marks for one West German mark, however. That rate more or less reflects the relative purchasing power of the two currencies.
The one-for-one rate, most economists agree, represents a windfall of 50 billion West German marks for the 16 million East Germans: indeed, they are currently obliged to pay about five East German marks per West German mark on the black market to buy scarce and much treasured West German consumer goods. But according to Mr. Vanous of PlanEcon, the likely inflationary effects of this financial gain have been exaggerated.
He predicts that many East Germans will hoard the cash until they are certain their employers - and their jobs - will survive the economic transition. Even if they were to spend the entire gain, the inflationary impact on the 2.3 trillion mark economy of West Germany would be modest. In any case, the impact would be transitory: West Germany's conservative central bankers would probably tighten credit in response, making it impossible for West German companies to maintain higher prices.
The more perilous imponderable is the impact of the plan on East German production costs. Bonn is calling for East German wages to be reset in West German marks at a one-to-one rate. That would give East German workers a big boost in purchasing power, encouraging them to stay on the job rather than moving west.
As Mr. Vanous points out, though, it would push wages far out of line with labor productivity, which is just one-third the level of West Germany's. If these excessive wages were maintained, many, if not most, East German enterprises would go bankrupt, and West German companies would have little incentive to invest in a distorted economy.
The collapse of East German output would presumably bring wages down. But that process could prove slow and painful, Mr. McKibbin says, as East German workers, with the support of West German labor unions, resisted the pressure. And the crisis might well bring on a general inflation: Pressed to cope with high unemployment in the east and wholesale migration to the west, Bonn might well decide to bail out East German enterprises with subsidies and easy credit.
The least painful way out of the trap, Mr. McKibbin contends, would be for West Germany to accept the political and economic imperative and simply subsidize East German living standards during the transition - and then raise taxes to pay for the subsidies.
 
Curb on Flow of Migrants
Wage subsidies would satisfy East German demands for higher incomes, staunching the westward flow of migrants. But they would manage the task without discouraging investment or pricing the struggling East German businesses out of the market.
There is a catch, however - a couple of catches. Wage subsidies high enough to make a difference would be very costly, perhaps 2 or 3 percent of West German income. Taxes would have to be raised commensurately. And once wage subsidies were in place, moreover, they might be very difficult to remove: Modern economic history is replete with transitory benefits that became permanent entitlements.
But according to Mr. McKibbin, the alternatives are even less attractive. One way or another, West Germany must absorb millions of new citizens -and voters - who harbor unrealistic economic expectations. And in the end, he says, it will likely prove far less costly to fulfill those expectations temporarily than to crush them under the anvil of unemployment or inflation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Chiles Transforms Florida Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 19

 BODY:
Less than two years ago, Lawton Chiles stunned Florida voters and political veterans by complaining of ''burnout'' and promptly retiring from the United States Senate. Now he has caused another stir, this time by declaring he wants to be Governor of Florida.
His surprise announcement April 12 almost immediately turned a lackluster campaign into a high-profile contest in which Mr. Chiles promises to raise a broad range of national issues, including whether the political system itself needs significant reform. He is pledging, among other things, to accept no more than $100 from each campaign contributor. The legal limit is $1,000 from an individual and $5,000 from a political action committee.
''Just by entering the race he's made it a national-level campaign,'' said Senator Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat who says he will make no endorsement in the party primary but who is a longtime friend and colleague of Mr. Chiles's. 
Opinion polls show that Mr. Chiles's entry into the race almost instantly made him the front-runner for governing one of the largest, fastest-growing and most politically influential states.
 
Gains in Congress Expected
And Florida will probably be an even richer prize soon, since it is expected to receive four more Congressional seats, for a total of 23, under the reapportionment that will follow the 1990 census.
If Mr. Chiles does not falter, he is expected to defeat his rival, Representative Bill Nelson, in the Democratic primary in September. The Republican incumbent, Gov. Bob Martinez, is favored to win his party's nomination.
Mr. Chiles's critics, most of them Republicans, contend that he is a vulnerable opponent. They note particularly Mr. Chiles's acknowledgment of having suffered from depression, for which he is still taking the prescription drug Prozac. Governor Martinez's campaign managers have demanded that Mr. Chiles make public all of his medical records, something he has resisted.
Mr. Nelson too has made Mr. Chiles's health an issue. Criticizing Mr. Chiles for retiring from the Senate, Mr. Nelson declared recently, ''He walked away from that responsibility.'' A Retread Democrat? Republican analysts add that Mr. Chiles has also admitted trying marijuana many years ago, and they sum him up as a retread Democrat in an increasingly Republican state.
''I am looking forward to Chiles' being the last hurrah of what had been a dominant Democratic Party,'' Mac Stipanovich, the Republicans' chief campaign strategist, said.
Such talk does not appear to ruffle Mr. Chiles. Accompanied by Buddy MacKay, his running mate for Lieutenant Governor, Mr. Chiles, who is 60 years old, spoke of his plans and his prospects in an interview on the back porch of his ranch-style home here.
He said his re-entry into politics had been spurred by a profound sense that the world had changed while American politics remained mired in the past: ''You see the people of Eastern Europe saying they want to emulate Jefferson, Madison and Lincoln. And what do we tell them about? Political action committees, how to dodge the issues and the need to poll daily.''
 
'A New Spirit Loose'
''I think there is a new spirit loose in this land,'' the former Senator said, sounding an increasingly common Democratic Party theme. ''Just as elsewhere, there is a search for faith among people, people who want to be empowered. Why can't Bush see that? Why can't the Republican governors see that?''
Mr. Stipanovich dismissed such pronouncements. He noted that Floridians had overwhelmingly voted for Ronald Reagan and for George Bush.
Mr. Stipanovich emphasized that Governor Martinez would make public his full health records, noting that so far Mr. Chiles had released only some records and had refused to make public his full records from 1988 and 1989.
Mr. Chiles said he had suffered acute insomnia, mood changes and loss of appetite starting in 1988. He said he had never been suicidal.
Five months ago, he said, his doctor began treating him with Prozac, a drug widely prescribed to treat depression. Mr. Chiles said he believes he is cured, adding that he expects to stop taking Prozac very soon.
 
The Issues He Sees
He pledged to wage a campaign that would challenge many of the reigning dogmas of politics. He said the politics of the near future would be based on fiscal conservatism, a new sense of ethics, education, nurturing the family, protecting the environment, planned economic growth and greater emphasis on local issues.
As a corollary, he contended, elections and government will be wrested from the domination of political action committees, lobbyists, Washington bureaucrats, poll takers and television. He likened his years as a Senator to the drudgery of ''churning butter - the harder you churn, the harder it gets.''
To put his vision into practice, Mr. Chiles says he will limit contributions to his campaign to $100 per donor to encourage wide voter participation. Democratic strategists say Mr. Chiles will need 30,000 to 100,000 contributors. Small Ideas, Big Money? Depending on whom you talk to, the $100 limit is either the most naive or the shrewdest gamble in a political season that has been much noted for big money, slurs, small ideas and, seemingly, jaded voters.
Mr. Stipanovich, as well as Democratic Party consultants, say Florida is a sprawling state of largely faceless suburbs in which a successful candidate normally needs a lot of money to pay for television advertising.
But Mr. Chiles has based a notable career on alchemizing a seeming ''aw, shucks'' naivete into the ready ore of willing votes for winning elections.
In 1970, he won election to the Senate, along with the lasting sobriquet of ''Walkin' Lawton,'' by striding across 1,000 miles of Florida to say ''Howdy.''
 
Headed Budget Committee
In Washington, he won high marks, rising to head the powerful Budget Committee before leaving the Senate at the end of 1988.
Mr. Chiles remains one of the best-known and most popular political figures in the state, and there are signs that Republicans are more than a little flustered by his entry.
Several polls and political analysts of both parties suggest that Governor Martinez is extremely vulnerable after four years of political missteps.
Early in his term, Mr. Martinez vociferously supported a new tax on services, like those provided by lawyers, doctors and accountants, only to reverse himself when the going got rough. Later he called a special state legislative session to restrict access to abortion, and was humiliatingly turned down by state legislators.
An economically rich state of low taxes and more than 300,000 newly arriving residents each year, Florida is suffering from an inability to raise revenue for deteriorating highways, for education and for other social and economic development. The ''Sunshine State,'' despite its affluence, is among the nation's leaders in adult illiteracy, high school dropouts and infant mortality.
 
Help From White House
Republican worries about Mr. Martinez appear to have helped prompt President Bush to twice jet down to extol the Governor's virtues.
In addition, Mr. Martinez's campaign has already spent more than $1 million on television advertisements, which appear to have done little to bolster the Governor's standing.
But Mr. Stipanovich said he was not worried. ''I've got more than $6 million tucked away in the bank, and I expect we'll have at least $12 million to fund the campaign,'' he said.
''Money, money, money,'' retorted Mr. Chiles. ''That's the classic politics of the Reagan-Bush age. We're here to give people an opportunity to change that.''

PUB-DATE: April 25, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1393 words

HEADLINE: Many Interests at Stake as Farm Act Is Rewritten

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Addressing a trade group the other day, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter complained that he had ''taken a lot of flak'' for supposedly seeking to cut farm subsidies by $1.5 billion when he actually favored a $2 billion increase.
But after the speech he said it would be a good thing if American farmers could become less dependent on the Government without quite bringing himself to say they are now too dependent on Government subsidies. As a Nebraska farmer himself, he knows that opinions on subsidies are very subjective.
The ears of the lawmakers are being filled with more divergent views than ever. Congress began heavy bargaining this week in its twice-a-decade rewriting of the rules governing what remains one of the most efficient American businesses in terms of production. And with a concerted interest from urban lawmakers in cutting back on what they feel are overgenerous and ill-targeted subsidies. 
The debate this time is also being conducted as the Bush Administration seeks to eliminate subsidies for agriculture products around the world through an international agreement.
 
Reagan Legacy an Expansion
But so great is the subsidy momentum that American agriculture stands out as the one major domestic area in which the legacy of Ronald Reagan's Adminmistration is vast expansion of the Government's role rather than reduced Government involvement.
In the 1980's, crop subsidies cost the Government $133.5 billion, with $89 billion of that spent since 1985, when Congress last rewrote the farm law, passing amendments intended to control production to prevent huge surpluses by lowering Government subsidies for farm products.
Under the farm subsidy program, which applies to 14 farm products, the the Government pays cash to farmers for every bushel they produce - the payment for corn, for example, is about $1 a bushel - in exchange for a promise that they will leave a specified amount of land fallow. While the 1985 legislation lowered the price the Government paid the farmers for a bushel, more farmers joined the program, bringing the record subsidies.
But as crop prices rose sharply in the wake of the 1988 drought, farmers have earned record incomes and subsidies have fallen over the last two years.
The Administration proposed spending $10.2 billion on price and income supports next year, a reduction critics said represented a cut of $1.5 billion from the $11.7 billion that would probably be spent under long-standing budget policy assumptions. Mr. Yeutter contends that the $10.2 billion should properly be compared with a lower outlay projected at $8.2 billion for the current fiscal year.
 
'It Has Become Addictive'
As an increasing share of agriculture comes under Federal benefit programs in a period of general budget stringency, some economic experts are arguing that farming has developed an undue dependence on Government aid. Eight years ago, for example, less than 30 percent of the nation's corn acreage was enrolled in Government benefit programs. By the 1986-1988 period, the participation rate rose to 88 percent before easing a bit last year. Benefits seem likely to be extended this year to soybean growers, who have previously sought little from the Government.
''It has become addictive,'' said Robert L. Thompson, dean of agriculture at Purdue University. ''It is extremely difficult to scale down subsidies to farmers when you've had 50-plus years of them,''
In addition to the direct costs, the subsidies and controls on supplies tend to raise the prices that the nation's consumers pay for food. For example, in the case of peanuts, American consumers pay well above what foreigners pay for the same peanuts.
While Congress, the Administration and farmers all seem satisfied with the level of Federal support in this election year, the 1990 farm bill is expected to arouse intense debate over the allocation of this money. Already, the Subcommittee on Wheat, Soybeans and Feed Grains has been caught up in budget-breaking proposals that will probably be undone before the full Agriculture Committee starts its deliberations early next month.
 
Challenge From Urban Areas
This year's farm bill will also be spiced by an rare challenge from legislators representing urban and suburban districts who have tired of the near monopoly that farm-state colleagues have long exercised over the legislation.
In the past, a member like Representative Silvio O. Conte, a Massachusetts Republican, would assail an individual program like the $100 million in support of the nation's beekeepers in 1988, but the far bigger sums for corn and other major crops have gone largely uncontested. Farm-state legislators have long proved extremely skilled at forming alliances with urban legislators with constituents interested in benefits like food stamps and school lunches.
But this year Representatives Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, and Dick Armey, a Dallas Republican, are recruiting members they hope will bring drastic reductions in programs like the $100 million or more in annual subsidy for producers of wool and mohair. Wool has not been designated a strategic material for 30 years and much of the money goes to large meat companies. The group wants to curb the major subsidy programs as well.
''This is the first time that a coalition from outside is going to scrutinize the farm bill,'' Mr. Schumer said. He sees the group as filling a hole in the Congressional system in which a few million farmers have long exercised exceptional political power. One Government survey found that barely 10 percent of the House members represent districts with dominant agricultural sectors.
The Schumer-Armey strategy will emphasize applying a means tests to subsidy payments. Critics complain that many big subisidies are going to large farming corporations. In addition, many family farming operations have avoided maximum limits by subdividing their farms.
 
Drive for End of Subsidies
One of the most delicate tasks for the United States will to maintain its drive for an end to all agricultural subsidies deemed to distort trade while maintaining, or even expanding, its own.
In February, when the Administration unveiled its farm proposal, the European Community's Agriculture Commissioner, Ray MacSharry, promptly assailed it as ''sending the wrong signal'' in a year in which the Uruguay Round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is to complete its work. Mr. McSharry complained specifically that Washington sought to ''increase the destabilizing effects of an aggressive'' policy to subsidize exports, a major feature of the 1985 farm bill.
Rather than to see the United States pass a new five-year farm bill that might be difficult to amend if the negotiations are successful, the Europeans would prefer that a stop-gap measure be passed here and then fresh legislation be drawn in light of any agreement.
Secretary Yeutter said, ''I don't see any inconsistency there at all,'' adding that the the United States will not engage in ''unilateral disarmament.''
 
'A Worldwide Intention'
John A. Schnittker, a private consultant, says that while many of his colleagues doubt the goal will be achieved, he remains optimistic. ''There is a worldwide intention of governments to reduce trade-distorting subsidies,'' he said. ''I see this as the wave of the future.''
At the same time, environmentalists are seeking to limit the use of fertilizers, pesticides and other chemicals as a way to protect water supplies and fresh foods. This could possibly threaten Government subsidy payments, as farm programs support crops that use heavy doses of chemicals and are associated with severe soil erosion.
''The programs reward farmers for specializing in program crops year after year, resulting in further soil depletion and pest problems, which in turn lead to a greater need for agrichemical inputs,'' a study by the General Accounting Office states.
There is also a proposal to expand the coverage of a provision of the 1985 law that bars farm program benefits for farmers who convert wetlands into tilled fields.
But Congressional sources expect the environmentalists will not make major headway until the next farm bill, and when they do they will rely heavily on possibly expensive incentives rather than prohibitions.

HEADLINE: The Bush Message to Vilnius: Talk

 BODY:
For days, Administration officials have been floating stories suggesting that the United States would impose sanctions against the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania. Yesterday President Bush did the right thing - nothing. And he chose to do it at the right time.
Mikhail Gorbachev has now made clear that he is asking Lithuanian leaders to suspend their declaration of independence, not to withdraw it, and to proceed toward expedited independence based on the Soviet Constitution. That represents a fair basis for talks between Moscow and Vilnius and it deserves support, not sanctions, from the West. 
Dialogue is what Mr. Bush has been urging for weeks. And to those who had been pressing him to hit Moscow with economic sanctions, he responded: ''I am concerned that we not do anything that would cause the Soviet Union to take action that would set back the cause of freedom around the world.''
It may be hard to get the full impact of this message across to the Lithuanians. As long as some leaders in Vilnius think they can establish their independence instantly by precipitating a world crisis, there's little incentive for them to settle even for reasonable dialogue. The Lithuanian people are already feeling the bite of Moscow's oil and natural gas squeeze. But some Lithuanian leaders may have calculated that the Soviet embargo would compel the West to retaliate, even at the risk of a crisis, forcing the West to rush to their side. These leaders would have been encouraged by the recent reports implying that Mr. Bush was about to suspend Soviet-American trade and commercial talks.
The mystery is whether Mr. Bush or any of his top aides ever really contemplated such a step, and if so, why. Polls show Americans do not want to sacrifice support for Mr. Gorbachev's reforms in order to press for immediate Lithuanian independence. Almost all European leaders and influential members of Congress feel the same way.
Instant independence for a ''captive nation'' is a seductive but oversimplified cause. President Bush has wisely and consistently resisted it. He has urged Moscow to move along toward Lithuanian independence - and Mr. Gorbachev has been doing that. Now Mr. Bush is sending the Lithuanians two signals as gracefully as he can: The United States won't precipitate an East-West crisis over Lithuania. The time has come to talk to Moscow.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua's Second Revolution

 BODY:
Nothing happens tidily in Nicaragua. That's conspicuously true in today's landmark transfer of power from President Daniel Ortega to his conservative opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Her succession is marred by defiance among the Sandinistas and die-hard contras, paralyzing strikes and unresolved arguments over the armed forces. Still, today marks a wonderful change in climate for Nicaragua and all the Americas. 
After a decade of brutal conflict, Nicaraguans can now glimpse the promise of peace and economic recovery. This is a yearning no leader can ignore. If the Sandinistas were confounded by Mrs. Chamorro's victory, so were people who insisted that only force would end Mr. Ortega's one-party autocracy. Regional pressure for peace, a shift in U.S. policy, a fading cold war - all this, combined with fatigue, has banked the fiery passions that made Nicaragua a battleground.
It would be unwise to expect miracles from Mrs. Chamorro. She leads a divided coalition and inherits an economy ravaged by war, sanctions, inflation and mismanagement. Her country has little experience with democracy. The Government contains some of her most dogmatic adversaries. But she and her team won a fair election and negotiated a transition, though the roughest patch remains -deciding finally whether to retain Humberto Ortega, the outgoing President's brother, as interim chief of the armed forces.
A democratic process is now in place for settling arguments without bloodshed. As the widow of the La Prensa editor whose murder in 1978 ignited Nicaragua's first revolution, Mrs. Chamorro personifies the cause of freedom. But elections and an unfettered press alone can't create jobs or grow crops. Her new Government needs and deserves U.S. help, beginning with the $300 million aid package still languishing in Congress.
President Reagan sought ceaselessly to crush the Sandinistas through a proxy insurgency. The war divided Americans without resolving the argument over its wisdom or morality. It produced the Iran-contra scandal. And it left Nicaragua's economy in ruins.
President Bush chose a different course. He compromised with Congress on ending arms aid to the contras and supported the regional peace initiative that led to Mrs. Chamorro's victory.
Such bipartisanship bodes well for Nicaragua - but only if those in Congress who opposed the war now vote for reconstruction. Their support is a debt owed to a neighbor striving to secure a democratic revolution.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Helping Migrant Students Beat the Odds in School

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARLIER, Calif., April 18

 BODY:
All her life, Christina Garza has worn the path between this small agricultural town and Texas, moving with her parents and the crops.
From April until October, her parents thin peaches and pick grapes here, near the city of Fresno. When night school is available, Christina, who is 18 years old, works in the field from 6:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., dashing home for a shower and five hours of school.
In California, Christina studies from one set of textbooks under one group of teachers with one set of friends. In the fall, another harvesting season beckons in Texas - along with another set of textbooks, another group of teachers, and schools that do not honor the independent-study program California offers to help her make up missed credits. 
Christina is one of the lucky migrant students who have managed, through hard work and help from special state programs, to excel in school and aim for college. But educating the 168,000 children of migrant workers in California (nearly a third of the estimated half a million such students nationally) poses a formidable challenge.
Most come to school from Spanish-speaking homes, and lag behind in English. Many face pressure to stay home to care for younger children, or to work to bring home more money for families in desperate need. Many of their parents are too exhausted after long work days to deal with teachers, or are wary of communication with school officials.
 
Measuring the Problems
Statistics are hard to come by because migrant children change schools so often, although a computerized transcript service in Little Rock, Ark., is helping to keep track of their performance. Robert Welty, a consultant in California's migrant education office, said 78 percent of California's migrant schoolchildren had limited English abilities in kindergarten. The rate improves slightly by senior year of high school, when 49 percent still have trouble with English.
Almost one-third have to repeat a year of kindergarten. Eighty-one percent score below grade level in reading, and 67 percent score below grade level in mathematics. Dropout rates are high, reaching 70 percent in some parts of the state. They average 37 percent, higher than California's statewide rate of 22 percent but better than a national migrant drop-out rate estimated at about 50 percent, Mr. Welty said.
Some problems are unique to migrant students: teachers who give up on them because they appear in their classrooms for only a few months at a time; teasing from children who see them as outsiders; school transcripts and health records that get lost along the way.
Alia Espinosa, a daughter of migrant workers who now counsels migrant students and their parents at Parlier High School, tells of children placed in one grade in California and a different grade in Texas in the course of one school year, of families so poor they had to ask for what a napkin was used for, of countless visits home to parents without telephones in migrant camps.
California is among the leaders in devising ways to help these students, with a range of programs designed to bolster their shaky self-confidence, enlist their parents, introduce them to college life, pair them with successful former migrant students, allow them to make up for classes missed because of parents' moves, and improve weaknesses in English, reading and mathematics.
 
Buses Sent to Camps
In California, these programs are voluntary, intended to supplement public education, which is open to them whether or not their parents are citizens. Migrant students attend regular public schools, which send buses and parent-liaison workers to the camps to make sure students get to school.
The main thrust is not to go over what is already taught in school, said Randolph Guerrero, himself a child of migrant workers who now runs a new arts program for migrant students. Instead, the programs offer extra help.
In the town of Santa Fe Springs near Los Angeles, Josefa Wann tries to teach students whose moves from place to place leave them painfully shy and academically behind. She holds up a painting entitled ''The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere,'' a dark, futuristic work enlivened by the flash of light from a church steeple and a winding road.
Then she shows a Van Gogh landscape, bright and pastel and impressionistic. The children quickly identify shapes in the paintings, understand the use of light to delineate time of day and mood, and immediately recognize the name of Van Gogh -''He's the one who cut off his ear.'' They hear the story of Paul Revere and then compose their own landscapes in watercolors - combining history, geometry and art appreciation in one lesson.
Mrs. Wann, who is being trained in the special arts education program run by Mr. Guerrero for the Los Angeles County Office of Education, finds that art can be a way to reach migrant children who are shy of speaking out. ''At the beginning, they may not talk to me,'' she said. ''But if I ask them, 'Make a picture of your family,' then that's the first step to communication.''
 
Learning From California
California was a pioneer in allowing students like Christina to make up for lost classroom time by giving her credit for supervised independent study, a program that has now spread to several other states. And the state is using a reading program designed in New Zealand to help Jairo Rios catch up with his second-grade classmates. Jairo sits on a folding chair in a tiny trailer that shakes every time someone moves. His teacher at Pacific Union Elementary School, Carol Strum, is quiet as he reads from a book called ''The Long, Long Tail.''
''There is a tail on the steps,'' he reads, hesitating slightly.
''Look at that word again,'' Mrs. Strum says. ''Look at the ending.'' ''Stairs,'' he says. At the end of his half-hour session, Jairo chooses two books to take back with him to his classroom and two to take home to read to his parents. This is one way the program reaches out to parents, who may get more exposure to spoken English this way and a better understanding of what their children are learning.
Four weeks ago, Mrs. Strum said, Jairo could barely read. ''That one-on-one is wonderful,'' said his regular teacher, Sherry Wood, who cannot spare much time from her busy classroom for intensive personal reading instruction. ''It's really helped children I know would have been lost.''
Students like Christina Garza are the success stories, but not all do so well against the odds they face. Christina knows 12 classmates, pressed by their parents to help them in the fields, who have not returned to school this year. ''The kids say, 'I came here to work,' and I can't get this idea out of their minds,'' Mrs. Espinosa said. ''They say, 'Who will buy me new clothes if I don't work?' ''
In general, said Mr. Masla and Robert L. Allen, Fresno County's administrator of migrant education, it is harder to persuade older children to take advantage of the migrant programs, but those that do are often the best students, like Christina. To reach out further, Fresno and some other counties offer programs for low-achieving junior high and high school students, programs like Goals for Youth, in which former professional football players encourage them to set weekly goals they can meet, as well as take field trips and talk with them. Other programs place such students on college campuses for a few weeks in the summer. The programs have helped lower the dropout rate in Fresno County, Mr. Allen said.
Yet the economic pressures still keep many older children out of school. Versava Pena is a 29-year-old mother of two children who has worked in the Parlier fields in harvesting season for more than 10 years. In October, she and her husband return to Texas, where they go on welfare until they can return to California and find work. They earn $4.25 an hour picking grapes or $4.35 an hour thinning peaches, working at least nine hours a day.
In many ways, Mrs. Pena is lucky. In Parlier she has a clean apartment with running water, electricity, refrigerator, stove and a nearby coin laundry. The apartment costs $3.75 a day, and she can put her young son Roel in day care at the camp at 5 A.M. and go to work. But she and her husband barely earn enough to pay the bills.
But despite the efforts Mrs. Espinosa and others make to reach out to parents, Mrs. Pena does not seem to know about the special programs her third-grade son can get as a child of migrant workers. ''I don't think he gets extra help,'' she said. ''I haven't heard of any problems.''
She is worried about the toll the family's moves take on his grades and reading ability. But by the end of the day, when she is worn out from work, she must still cook and clean and care for her children. There is not much time for parent meetings.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1107 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Black Identity vs. Success and Seeming 'White'

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

 BODY:
Many black students may perform poorly in high school because of a shared sense that academic success is a sellout to the white world, according to a study by two anthropologists.
This phenomenon may be one of the subtlest and most insidious among the many social and economic factors that contribute to generally lower academic performance by blacks than whites, said one of the anthropologists, Signithia Fordham.
''Fear of acting white and fear of becoming the other was a motivating factor in underachievement in the school context,'' said Miss Fordham, describing her two years of research at a predominantly black high school in Washington. ''Schoolteachers and school officials didn't understand how difficult it was.'' 
The study by Miss Fordham, who teaches anthropology at Rutgers University, and John U. Ogbu, a professor of anthropology at the University of California at Berkeley, has caused debate among educators, adding to already widespread disagreement over the causes of underachievement among black students.
 
Reaction of Educators
James Comer, a professor of child psychiatry at Yale University, said black youths internalized messages about being black that were transmitted by society.
Professor Comer said fear of ''acting white'' could be a factor among ''non-mainstream-oriented poor black children,'' but not among middle-class black children.
On the other hand, Wade Nobles, director of the Center for Applied Cultural Studies and Educational Achievement at San Francisco State University, said black underachievement in education cut across socioeconomic lines.
If fear of ''acting white'' does play a role, Mr. Nobles said, it comes in a context in which ''black children learn relatively early that their attempt to achieve is not rewarded in the school system.''
At high schools like the one studied by Miss Fordham, teachers and students tended in interviews to express far more concern about the larger socioeconomic factors that bear on academic performance. Poverty, broken homes, a low level of education among parents, an absence of parental involvement and poor societal role models were described as major causes for underachievement.
 
Context for Problem
Miss Fordham said it was precisely in this context that the problem she describes arose. ''If it weren't for those other things, the poverty and the unemployment, the lack of access to the world of success, I don't think the fear of acting white, the burden of acting white, would be a problem,'' she said. ''Kids are worried about being cut off by their own community and uncertain about being accepted by the other community.''
According to the study, which was published in 1986 and Miss Fordham is now expanding into a book, ''What appears to have emerged in some segments of the black community is a kind of cultural orientation which defines academic learning in school as 'acting white,' and academic success as the prerogative of white Americans.''
The study argues that this grows out of the low expectations that white Americans have of blacks, low expectations that have taken root among the blacks themselves.
At Capital High School in Washington, Miss Fordham, who is black herself, said she found that it was important to the students to maintain a black identity. To this end, she said, some black students shunned schoolwork.
 
'White' Behavior Avoided
''They chose to avoid adopting attitudes and putting in enough time and effort in their schoolwork because their peers (and they themselves) would interpret their behavior as 'white,' '' the study said.
Along with academic success, it listed more than a dozen other types of behavior that the students considered ''acting white.''
These included speaking standard English, listening to so-called white music, going to the opera or ballet, studying in the library, going to the Smithsonian Institution, doing volunteer work, camping or hiking, putting on airs and being on time.
Those students who do work hard in school often adopt strategies to camouflage the fact, like excelling in sports or clowning or acquiring the protection of a bully, the study said.
This assertion met with some skepticism from other educators, including Bill Bibbiani, director of research and testing for the Pasadena Unified School District in California. He said hard-working students of all races had been taunted as grinds and nerds.
''I don't know that black people have cornered the market on teasing people about academic achievement,'' said Mr. Bibbiani, who is white.
At Pasadena High School, a racially mixed school, some administrators said the study matched some of their experience.
 
'Do Not Want to Seem White'
''I have talked with students over the years who do not want to identify with white society,'' said Kathy Lesley, an assistant principal who is black. ''I have run across blacks who do not want to seem white. If they achieve, they might fall into that category.''
Echoing the opinion of several teachers and black students interviewed at the school, Larry Cash, a dean of students who is also black and whose father shined shoes for a living, said black students should not worry about things like ''acting white.'' Instead, he said, they can profit from applications of the same kind of determination and parental encouragement as any other students.
Nevertheless, Mr. Cash agreed that black students often suffered from an absence of black role models of academic achievement, and said this might contribute to a sense that academics was a white province.
He said that for this reason he wanted his own sons to attend an all-black college for at least one year. ''I want them to see that there are a lot of black people out there doing something, that there are a lot of black educated people,'' he said.
In their study, Miss Fordham and Mr. Ogbu agree that their findings should be considered in a context of other factors that affect the academic performance of black students.
She said ''the kids got two contrasting ideas from the civil rights movement, which sought integration, and the ensuing black power movement, which sought to strengthen black identity: ''They are seeking integration, but they fear the thought of not being themselves any more.''
At the same time, she said, there was an assumption among many whites that integration meant accepting white values.
''The message was: 'You've got to act white in order to succeed. You've got to be a carbon copy of us,' '' she said. ''I believe that resistance is at the heart of black life in America. Black children resist these efforts to make them white.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Harvard Picks Rosovsky For Post of Acting Dean

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24

 BODY:
Henry Rosovsky, one of the most respected figures in American higher education, has been named acting dean of Harvard University's Faculty of Arts and Sciences, resuming a job he left six years ago.
He is replacing A. Michael Spence, who resigned unexpectedly last month to become dean of the Stanford University Graduate School of Business, while a permanent replacement is sought. 
The appointment of Mr. Rosovsky, a 63-year-old economist, was greeted with enthusiasm by many professors and administrators at Harvard. As dean of the faculty from 1973 to 1984, Mr. Rosovsky guided the biggest reform of Harvard's curriculum in decades, and helped bring the university's budget under control.
In making the announcement today, Harvard's president, Derek Bok, said, ''To my great relief, Henry Rosovsky has agreed to assume this responsibility.'' Mr. Bok said Mr. Rosovsky would assume his new duties on July 1.
''It's what we need most in this very difficult sitution created by Mike Spence's sudden departure,'' said Roderick MacFarquhar, a professor of government who is on a newly created committee to find a replacement for Mr. Spence.
Mr. Spence's resignation caught Harvard by surprise and touched off some resentment toward him, in part because the university is planning a huge fund-raising campaign, with a reported goal of $2 billion, and Mr. Spence would have been a key figure in the drive.
Mr. Rosovksy played down the significance of his return to the dean's office. ''My son compared me to Dwight Evans,'' the aging right fielder of the Boston Red Sox, Mr. Rosovsky said. ''He said I'm too old to play regularly, but I can step in as a designated hitter.''

INDUSTRY: SIC2731 BOOK PUBLISHERS; 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
About Education

BYLINE: By Fred M. Hechinger

 BODY:
Why is college so expensive? The question won't go away until parents get more believable answers.
''At some point, families will become sensitive to the price,'' writes Arthur M. Hauptman. ''We are close to that point now.''
Mr. Hauptman is not a spokesman for disgruntled parents. On the contrary, he is a consultant to the American Council on Education and the College Board, which together sponsored the study, ''The College Tuition Spiral'' (Macmillan Publishing Company). The two organizations are insiders, representing the colleges, rather than outside critics. 
College tuition in the 1980's rose drastically, often at more than twice the inflation rate. In 1981, the peak year, the increase neared 13 percent.
The study identified some reasons why costs skyrocketed.
Faculty salaries had to be raised to protect the quality of teaching and research. In the 1970's, while colleges had to cope with rising fuel costs, health insurance and other expenses, faculty members lost nearly 20 per cent of their purchasing power.
As the college-age population dwindled, recruiting became more important and costly, and efforts to increase the number of students from minority groups added to the cost.
As Federal student aid declined, more of the tuition paid by those who could afford it had to be used for scholarships - a kind of Robin Hood policy of taking from the rich to give to the poor. Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board, while conceding that colleges would ''have to cut corners somewhere,'' expressed concern that ''aid to needy students could suffer.''
Colleges also point to the high cost of libraries and modern science equipment.
Still, families who are already struggling with inflated housing costs are less patient with explanations, as the annual cost of attending a prestige college creeps up to, and beyond, $20,000, and state university tuition rises as well. The study's sponsors warn about an impending revolt against further increases.
Some colleges, Mr. Hauptman found, have begun to put brakes on tuition. He cited Harvard and Stanford, which imposed hefty increases in the last decade but are planning rises of only 5 or 6 percent in the coming academic year.
While studies conducted on behalf of the higher-education establishment tend to justify or at least explain the high price tag, parents can be expected to ask whether there is any fat in the budget.
One area likely to come under scrutiny is the growth of the campus bureaucracy. A recent report in The Chronicle of Higher Education, a weekly publication, shows dramatic increases in the support staffs of colleges - by more than 100,000 people, or 61 percent, from 1975 to 1985. These are people with academic degrees but without teaching or research functions. They include financial aid counselors, specialists dealing with problems of minorities and the handicapped, auditors, lawyers, coaches, and systems analysts. They do not include executive, administrative, and managerial employees, whose ranks also grew, by 17.9 percent.
In the same period, the number of full-time faculty grew by only 5.9 percent, and service and maintenance personnel actually declined by 4.9 percent. Student enrollment went up by about 9.5 percent.
Part of the reason for the growth in managerial and support staffs, administrators say, is the need to comply with growing state and Federal regulations and to cope with litigation. Others cite many new services to students with special needs, like remedial help and special counseling.
Fund raising, too, does not come cheap.
Still, even some insiders admit that there is academic bloat. Robert V. Iosue, president of York College in Pennsylvania, told The Chronicle, ''Everybody wants to blame somebody else for their inability to control their own appetites.''
Some trimming has begun. In February, Stanford University announced it would reduce its budget by $22 million over 18 months, with emphasis on cutting nonacademic staffs and simplifying administration. Dartmouth plans to eliminate 52 administrative jobs.
The problem of bureaucratic bloat, some observers say, is not confined to education; it is a part of American life. In his recent book, ''Flashbacks: On Returning to Vietnam,'' Morley Safer reported that at one army post near Saigon 22,000 Vietnamese were employed as support staff for 26,000 Americans who were themselves supposed to have been support troops.
Tomorrow's parents may hope that the tuition rise can be stemmed through draining some fat from college budgets. But state and Federal governments could help by making more financial aid available to needy students. This would reduce the pressure on colleges to play Robin Hood, and help them to be able to stop charging high tuition of middle-class parents and students to finance the education of the poor.
