HEADLINE: Freshness, Convenience: Juice for Today's Tastes

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
STICKER shock is what orange juice producers have been calling the reaction of shoppers who recoil at prices resulting from a devastating freeze just after Christmas.
The effect on the pocketbook has been compounded as consumer preference has shifted from cheaper frozen concentrate to more expensive ready-to-drink chilled juice. Prices for chilled juice, both pasteurized not-from-concentrate and reconstituted, now range generally from $2.99 to $3.99 for 64 ounces, a half-gallon, in many markets. Frozen orange juice concentrate costs about $1.75 to $2 for a 12-ounce can that makes 48 ounces of juice. During the past 20 years, sales of ready-to-drink chilled juice have been steadily increasing, finally topping frozen concentrate in 1986. Chilled juice now accounts for 57.7 percent of sales in the $3 billion orange juice industry.
''It represents a total reversal of consumer buying habits,'' said Karl Maggard, the senior vice president for sales for Tropicana Products, Inc., a division of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Limited, Today the typical supermarket devotes a vast amount of space in the dairy case to as many as a dozen different kinds of chilled orange juice, both national brands and private label. Some brands are sold in the produce department. Three kinds of products have emerged in the chilled juice category: pasteurized, reconstituted and fresh unpasteurized. 
When tasted at The New York Times, the pasteurized and reconstituted ready-to-drink juices failed to measure up in flavor to juice that had been freshly squeezed and consumed within 30 minutes.
The juices were compared with freshly squeezed orange juice because advertising for these products emphasizes their freshness. Even the unpasteurized fresh juice sold in plastic bottles in the produce section and costing twice the price of the other chilled juices was judged to be inferior to the truly fresh.
To many Americans ''fresh'' orange juice has come to mean juice from a freshly opened container. While there might be a slight decline in sales because of high prices, said Pierre Ferrari, the senior vice president for consumer marketing for Coca-Cola Foods, once the initial shock over prices wears off, consumers are expected to go right on buying chilled juice and not switch back to frozen concentrate.
''Convenience and perceived freshness are extremely important to today's consumers,'' said Michael Bellas, president of Beverage Marketing Corporation, a research and consulting firm. ''They don't even want to be bothered mixing.''
Chilled juice, said Mr. Maggard of Tropicana, ''has reached a point in acceptability that people will buy it no matter what because it has become a household staple.''
Mr. Maggard went on, ''Our consultants have been assuringus that despite the price increases, the product category will continue to maintain its position vis-a-vis frozen concentrate.''
He also suggested that consumers concerned about water quality may be driven to buying chilled juice because it does not have to be mixed with tap water.
The most popular is juice that is squeezed and pasteurized, then bottled and shipped to market. The juice is often held in storage, frozen, then thawed before being pasteurized, bottled and shipped in order to assure supplies during the off-season.
Tropicana, made since 1947, is the leading brand. Minute Maid Premium Choice, introduced by Coca-Cola Foods in late 1988, is in second place, followed by Fresh 'n Natural, a brand packed by a cooperative in Florida and owned by Citrus World Inc. These brand rankings were confirmed by Mr. Bellas.
Reconstituted juice, the second most popular category, is made by diluting frozen orange juice concentrate in the processing plant with purified water, then bottling it. Minute Maid is the leading brand. Tropicana's reconstituted juice is in second place, with Citrus Hill by Procter & Gamble in third.
Another form, sold as fresh, unpasteurized juice, commands a tiny fraction of the market. Oranges are squeezed in Florida, and the juice is shipped in bulk to be bottled in the marketing area.
Sales of chilled juice are strongest in the Northeast, which accounts for 40 percent of total sales, and especially in the New York area, where 17 percent of the juice produced in the United States is consumed. ''New York is the epicenter of juice consumption,'' Mr. Maggard said. ''We call it the citrus bowl.''
''New York was the original sales area for Tropicana when it first came on the market and that's where the habit of drinking chilled juice became ingrained,'' he added.
Although Minute Maid is the leading brand of frozen concentrate and outsells Tropicana on the West Coast, its Premium Choice not from concentrate is only sold in the Northeast and in Florida.
''We introduced Premium Choice because we saw there was a large and profitable market in the East that was basically controlled by a single brand and we saw an opportunity there,'' said Mr. Ferrari of Coca-Cola Foods.
Many of the chilled juices come in a strained variety, preferred by children, and one with bits of pulp, preferred by adults.
Not-from-concentrate juices are often called premium. ''The experts find the products to have a fresher, fruitier taste,'' Mr. Ferrari said. While the juice is not evaporated using a heat and vacuum process, the way frozen concentrate is, it is still heated during the pasteurization process. ''People call it fresh but it's technically not fresh juice because it has been pasteurized,'' Mr. Maggard said.
Chilled juice is not only more expensive, it is not necessarily better tasting and comes packed in large plastic-treated cartons or plastic half-gallon bottles instead of small cardboard cans. It also may be less nutritious than frozen concentrate.
The United States Department of Agriculture says that about six ounces of chilled juice provides 66 milligrams of vitamin C compared with 78 milligrams in six ounces of frozen concentrate or 100 milligrams in fresh squeezed. The recommended daily allowance for vitamin C is 60 milligrams.
''And toward the end of its longer shelf life the pasteurized juice will deliver even less,'' said Mr. Ferrari.
But Chip Bettle, senior vice president for technology for Tropicana, said special packaging introduced in the past four years prevents loss of vitamin C for pasteurized juice in an unopened container. ''The Government's data may have been developed before this packaging was fully in use by the major brands,'' he said.
Nutrition aside, when it comes to beverages that can be kept on hand in the refrigerator ready to drink, chilled juice still may be one of the best.
When tasted, the juice that was considered most like fresh was Just Pik't, a brand that is squeezed fresh in Florida, then frozen without further processing. It is sold in the frozen food section of markets around the nation. It was sweeter tasting than the fresh juice, but it tended to separate faster and actually seemed a bit pulpier.
At one time Just Pik't, which costs $1.99 to $2.19 nationally for 33 ounces, was considerably more expensive than chilled juice. But the recent price increases for chilled juice have made it more competitive. ''Instead of increasing our prices we have stopped offering promotions,'' said Steven Smith, president of Fresh Juice Inc. in Great Neck, N.Y., which makes the product.
Because of the freeze, the 1989-1990 harvest amounted to 103.1 million boxes of oranges as of April 10, compared with 146.6 million boxes for that date for the 1988-89 crop. Experts with the Florida Department of Citrus refused to predict the dimensions of next season's crop but they estimate it will again be small.
''We anticipate a continued limitation,'' said Dr. Robert Behr, economic research director for the department. ''It will be a good two years before we can expect any normalization.''
Dr. Behr and others stress that by next year quality should improve because unless there is another serious freeze, processors would not have to use any fruit that was damaged in the freeze. Since the late 1970's, the Florida citrus industry has gradually been moving south, below the freeze belt, and will probably continue to do so.
In the meantime, any shortfall in Florida production is made up, increasingly, by frozen concentrate from Brazil. The amount used this year was double last year. To further capitalize on the Florida shortage, Brazilian producers raised prices by more than 50 percent this year.
''The availability of the foreign crop has prevented orange juice from being as expensive as wine,'' said Harvey Haller, executive vice president of Haller Brothers Corp., a packer and processor in Winter Garden, Fla. ''The demand is increasing but supplies are lower than what they were at the beginning of the decade.''
The demand for chilled not-from-concentrate juice has increased the pressure on the Florida crop. In 1987-88 less than 20 percent of the crop was used to make chilled juice, which this season will account for close to 30 percent.
''It's our fondest hope that the trend toward chilled juice will continue because it means the juice has to be produced in Florida,'' Mr. Haller said. ''It's our one insulation against foreign competition.''

PUB-DATE: April 25, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 1; Living Desk

LENGTH: 1640 words

HEADLINE: How Do You Fix A Broken Planet?

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

 BODY:
PATTY FREEMAN DORSON is not unlike many other Americans trying to do their part when it comes to the environment.
She separates glass bottles from her family's trash so they can be recycled and asks for paper bags, rather than plastic, at the supermarket checkout counter.
Still, Mrs. Dorson, a 34-year-old Indianapolis lawyer, is confused about what else she can do to ''save the planet,'' particularly after she discovered that the more expensive ''photodegradable'' garbage bags she used to buy are no more beneficial to the environment than other kinds.
''It's hard to know what to do,'' said Mrs. Dorson, whose husband, Roland, spent Earth Day planting lilies and raspberries in the backyard. ''It's all so overwhelming.'' 
Earth Day 1990 has come and gone, and there is no question that a subtle but powerful change has taken place across the country in how Americans perceive the dangers facing the environment and what they are prepared to do to help. Survey after survey conducted in conjunction with Sunday's Earth Day festivities found that the environment ranks with unemployment and the economy as a major national concern. According to a recent New York Times/CBS poll, for example, 71 percent of Americans said they would be willing to pay higher taxes to clean the environment and 56 percent said they favored protecting the environment even if it meant a loss of jobs in their communities.
But as debate continues over long-term solutions and confusion mounts about just how effective individuals can be, environmentalists and others say they are concerned that the public may become apathetic and disillusioned about the environment, as it did about the energy crisis.
''What worries me is that people will say the heck with it and turn away,'' said Barry Commoner, one of the early leaders of the environmental movement and the author, most recently, of ''Making Peace with the Planet'' (Pantheon Books, $19.95).
The problem is that now that Americans have been made aware of the staggering problems facing the environment and are actually taking steps to do their part, they want to be assured that their efforts have an impact. Claims by manufacturers trying to tap environmental concerns with promises that certain products are ''environmentally friendly'' when in fact many are no different from other products have added to the confusion. (Some manufacturers counter that they are helping to clarify the issue with such labels and that, compared to other products, theirs are indeed ''environmentally friendly.'') The confusion has been magnified by disagreement among scientists about solutions. The growing awareness, for example, that garbage buried in landfills does not decompose even after long periods has set off alarms with consumers, who feel they have been misled. So have conflicting claims over the biodegradibility of plastics.
''We have a real sense of a need to be good to the environment and to do our part, but there is a real sense of confusion as to what our part is,'' said Dr. William L. Rathje, professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona and director of the Garbage Project, which has been digging up landfills across the country for the past 17 years in to determine just what happens to the nation's garbage over time. ''There is a crisis mentality that we have to act now. But we have no information on how to act.''
Kevin Hardie, executive director of the Central States Glass Recycling Program, a nonprofit office providing information about recycling to communities in Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin, says confusion among scientists and conflicting commercial claims directly affect the public.
''People want to do the right thing,'' Mr. Hardie said. ''But they don't know what the right thing is.''
Amy Burger, a 40-year-old homemaker and mother of two living in Montclair, N.J., for example, is confused about whether any plastic in products she buys at her local grocery store is truly recyclable. (According to the Environmental Defense Fund, a nonprofit environmental organization in Washington, only 1 percent of all plastic produced in this country is actually recycled - despite many manufacturers' claims - because there are so few plastic recycling plants.) This misconception about plastics underscores an even larger misunderstanding about recycling. Just because a consumer sets aside paper, glass, aluminum cans or anything else for recycling does not necessarily mean that these goods are actually recycled. Barry J. Cutler, director of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection, said the recycling of products depends largely on whether there are enough recycling plants available in a particular locale.
Debbie Romano, a writer living in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, is confused about what commercially available cleaning products, if any, are ecologically sound. Some environmental groups urge boycotting all commercial cleansers and using only natural ingredients like vinegar and baking soda. A spokesman for the Clorox Corporation, which manufactures chlorine bleach and other cleaning products, countered by saying consumers should have a choice in such matters and should be made aware that certain chemicals in commercial cleansers serve as disinfectants as well as having other advantages.
Rae Evenson, who works part time in her husband's dental office in Houston, Minn., is confused over recycling claims being made on packages of cups made of plastic foam. ''I'm trying to be conscientious,'' Mrs. Evenson said. ''But it's hard to know what to do.''
Kevin Kelleher, recycling coordinator for the county where Mrs. Evenson lives, says the cups are not recycled. But when citizens in his community separate them out of the trash for recycling, Mr. Kelleher instructs his workers to pick them up because not to do so ''would be a slap in the face.'' The cups are sent to a landfill.
For all of these Americans, daily life has become a balancing act between their desires to help the environment and their needs for personal convenience at a time when experts themselves disagree.
There is sharp disagreement, for example, over whether recycling or making products biodegradable is the more appropriate avenue for the nation to pursue in solving the nation's solid waste crisis. So is the issue of creating additional landfills or using incinerators. Overwhelmed, perhaps, by these larger issues as well as by such cosmic notions as saving the rain forest or repairing the damaged ozone layer, many Americans nevertheless seem to be making their peace with the issues, adopting behavior they hope will ultimately prove beneficial.
It was not until she became pregnant last year, for example, that Mrs. Dorson of Indianapolis had to come to terms with disposable diapers. Despite her desire to help reduce the nation's solid waste, Mrs. Dorson decided in favor of the disposable diapers for convenience. There is some thought that cloth diapers present other dangers to the environment if they are washed in certain strong detergents, but Mrs. Dorson says she still feels guilty about her decision and, to compensate, she now drives five miles a week to take her glass bottles and aluminum cans to the nearest recycling plant.
''It seems like such a small thing,'' Mrs. Dorson said. ''But at least it's something. It does help your conscience.''
In Montclair Mrs. Burger, who on Earth Day took her family to church where the congregation planted a tree, buys orange juice in cartons at her supermarket and then transfers the juice at home into reusable plastic jugs to reduce her use of plastics. She no longer uses paper napkins or plastic eating utensils in an attempt to teach her children that ''less is more.''
''It is the little things,'' Mrs. Burger said, adding that only by reducing the amount of garbage consumers produce can the country ever gain mastery over its solid waste problem. ''It is how you lead your daily life more than telling the children. You're doing it. You're living it.'' Richard Denison, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington, which has helped encourage such consumer awareness, said, ''Everyone can take a small step.''
But it is just these small gestures that other environmentalists, like Mr. Commoner, say offer Americans a false sense of accomplishment.
''It confuses feeling good with having an influence on the problem,'' Mr. Commoner said, arguing that the real power individuals wield is not at their garbage cans but rather in their banding together to demand changes in corporate boardrooms, in much the same way that individuals and groups refused to buy tuna and forced major companies to change the way fish are caught.
Indeed, Mrs. Romano of Brooklyn took her family to the beach for Earth Day. She took along four paper bags so that she, her husband and their three children, could do their part for the day by helping to clean up the beach. But when they arrived at the beach at Jacob Riis Park in Brooklyn, it was so filthy with debris that they just turned around and left without picking up so much as a can.
''There was too much to do,'' said Mrs. Romano, expressing the kind of frustration many Americans feel in the face of such large-scale environmental problems.
As for the future, most experts agree that much will depend on what course the Government ultimately takes on solid waste disposal. Research continues, but in the meantime some fear that the public may turn its attention to other things.
''Ultimately it will depend on the nation's leadership,'' said Dr. Theodore Roszak, a social historian at California State University at Hayward and the author of ''Where the Wasteland Ends'' (Celestial Arts, $14.95). ''Otherwise all this interest in the environment could be a fad that will come and go.''

SECTION: Section C; Page 12, Column 3; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: Portrait of a Collector: Walter Annenberg

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.

 BODY:
Walter H. Annenberg, publisher, philanthropist, former Ambassador to Britain and high-rolling art acquisitor, doesn't really mind that the J. Paul Getty Museum bagged van Gogh's ''Irises'' in a recent transaction with Sotheby's. ''I like my irises better,'' he said, pointing to a big, lush Monet canvas, ''The Path Through the Irises,'' hanging over a white couch in a sitting area of his Astrodome-sized house here. ''I wouldn't swap them for van Gogh's irises.''
Mr. Annenberg would not confirm reports that he was a heavy bidder on the van Gogh at the 1987 Sotheby's auction when it was sold for a record $53.9 million to the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, who later had to give up the painting because of financial troubles.
There is no van Gogh shortage, however, at Sunnylands, the luxuriant Annenberg oasis in this desert country. The Ambassador, as he likes to be called, and his wife, Leonore, have five of them, including a floral study similar to ''Irises,'' but whose subject is roses. 
The van Goghs, together with six Monets, six Renoirs, eight Cezannes and works by Fantin-Latour, Degas, Vuillard, Toulouse-Lautrec, Gauguin, Seurat, Picasso, Braque, Bonnard, Rodin, Giacometti and Arp, are part of what J. Carter Brown, the director of the National Gallery of Art, calls ''one of the world's greatest collections of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art.'' To Whom Will It Go? But about the eventual fate of his collection, the 82-year-old philanthropist is cautious. ''There are two choices of what to do with it,'' he said in a recent interview. ''Either put it up for auction or give it to a great museum. You should have the intuition to know which I'd do.''
He has said he would not divide his collection. What museum it would go to, if it did, has fueled much speculation in the fiercely competitive curatorial world. The three most likely candidates are the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
Mr. Annenberg has long had ties with each. He is a trustee of the Metropolitan, Mrs. Annenberg is on the board of the Philadelphia Museum and he is a trustee emeritus of the Metropolitan. As a founding member of the Patron's Fund of the National Gallery, he has given it substantial cash gifts, and has been a member of its collectors' committee from 1975 to 1981. His Washington attachments, his avowed patriotism and the prestige of the National Gallery could also help land the collection.
Last fall Mr. Annenberg gave $20 million to the three institutions for acquisitions: $15 million to the Met and $5 million each to the other two. There are those who say that the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, where the collection will be shown this summer, should not be ruled out either, since Mr. Annenberg is very fond of Southern California.
 
'He Is a Man of Grand Gestures'
''It's just too early to call it,'' said Joseph J. Rishel, the curator of painting and sculpture before 1900 at the Philadelphia Museum, who organized the touring Annenberg show that opened there last summer. ''He is a man of grand gestures that are in no way predictable.''
If he did give his collection to a museum, Mr. Annenberg said, he would insist that it be kept together. ''There'll be no lending, no deaccessioning,'' he said. ''I have to be very careful. I've spent years worrying about my things. They have great quality uniformly, and I'd be very unhappy if things were pushed out. I couldn't abide that.''
He has given up the idea he had once had of opening his own museum, he added. ''But because of the historic figures who have stayed at Sunnylands, we may set it up as something of a historic house with copies of all the art. I'd leave the furniture and everything else in place except the pictures.''
''We've had five Presidents here,'' said Mrs. Annenberg, a former United States chief of protocol. ''I'd turn over in my grave if it became a golf club.''
Over lunch, served by a snappily uniformed butler, Mr. Annenberg talked of his conviction that museums should serve as educational institutions not only for scholars but also for ''the broad masses.'' He is still stung by the furor over his proposal, in 1976, to give $20 million to the Metropolitan Museum for a communications center to disseminate information about art to a wide audience through films, tapes, slides, reproductions and other devices. After clamorous art world and community opposition to the plan on grounds that the Met would be overextending physically and downgrading intellectually, he withdrew the proposal.
 
'Something for the Public'
''I wanted to do something for the public,'' he said, ''and I still believe in that idea of making all of the world available to all peoples.''
Mr. Annenberg has stepped up his picture buying since 1988, when he sold his publishing empire - TV Guide, Seventeen and The Daily Racing Form - to Rupert Murdoch for $3 billion. Asked what he thought of the soaring prices in the art world over the last decade, he shrugged. ''It's a matter of simple economics - increasing demand and shrinking supply,'' he said. ''So great quality will only go up in value. I don't think prices will go down. I do believe there'll be a day when we'll see a $75 million to $100 million painting at auction.''
Of his collection, Mr. Annenberg said: ''I must have quality. An interest in art grows in you and it takes over. My wife and I set out to get things that we genuinely loved and respected and wanted to live with.''
In pursuit of this aim last fall the couple spent $40.7 million for a 1905 Picasso, ''Au Lapin Agile,'' at a Sotheby auction, and they proudly showed photographs of two more recent acquisitions, paintings by Braque and Fantin-Latour, that were about to be added to their crowded walls. Why Art Is Better Than Securities ''I sold stock to buy the Picasso and these other things because they're much better to look at than securities in a box,'' said Mr. Annenberg, whose charitable donations this year included $50 million to the United Negro College Fund.
The new Braque purchase, a 1939 painting called ''The Studio,'' had first been seen by the couple 35 years ago. ''We loved it but we were too young in those days for modern art, too inexperienced,'' he said. ''I'd been dreaming about it for years as one of my major mistakes, and when I saw the Picasso-Braque show in New York, I began to think about it again. We made inquiries and found out that the Acquavella Gallery in New York had it for sale.''
The Braque, the Picasso and the Fantin-Latour will be added to a show of the Annenberg collection that opens May 6 at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and on Aug. 16 at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. It will be seen in New York at the Metropolitan Museum in the summer of 1991.
The loans, the Annenbergs say, are an exception. They like to keep the paintings at Sunnylands, where they spend four and a half months of the year. At Inwood, their home outside Philadelphia, they have Chippendale and Adam furniture and Lowestoft porcelain to contemplate.
The desert house is an airy extravaganza of glass and Mexican lava-stone walls, pink marble floors and clustered plantings intended to convey an ''outside-inside'' feeling. It sits on a manicured patch of rolling green terrain: 205 acres replete with trees, hills, ponds and waterfalls not exactly native to the desert. The well-guarded spread, on Frank Sinatra Drive in this exclusive estate and country club area, includes a nine-hole golf course.
The English countryside effects were achieved by sod, irrigation and a good golf course architect, Mr. Annenberg explained. ''With the land we bought the water rights,'' he said. ''But then people around here began complaining they couldn't use their sinks and toilets so I sold the rights and got more than what I paid for the land. Then we sank wells.'' Making a House A Part-Time Home The house has ''matured'' since they built it in the early 1960's, explained Mrs. Annenberg, who is affectionately called Mother by her husband. ''When we left London the choice was to put the paintings here or in Philadelphia,'' she said. ''Walter said here. And the collection has changed the house.''
Most of the works are concentrated in the rambling public areas of the house. They mingle with Chinese jades - including a Chien Lung bullock named Walter by Mrs. Annenberg - and porcelains, Meissen jars, Steuben glass and other decorative objects. Mr. Annenberg has a fond relationship with them. ''This is my family. I adore these things,'' he said.
Stopping in front of the new Picasso, whose subject is a harlequin at the cafe called Lapin Agile, he gleefully pointed to a pair of frisky Chinese porcelain rabbits he had placed as accents beneath it.
Stroking a small torso of white marble by Arp that turns on a stand, he eased it around to show its evolution from a slim nude to a pregnant woman. ''What mad person but an artist would think of that?'' he said. ''He really had the power to express something.''
And he revealed his discovery of a correspondence between a Cezanne still life and a landscape. As he sees it, a fold in the napkin surrounding a dish of apples in the still life, hung on one wall, echoes the incline of Mont Saint-Victoire, the artist's obsessive landscape motif, in a watercolor hanging across the room.
He laughingly recalled the purchase, some years ago, of another Mont Saint-Victoire by Cezanne, this one an oil. The New York dealer Wildenstein & Company ''wanted $450,000 for it, and my friend Bobby Lehman was stringing them along,'' he said, referring to the late collector whose holdings now occupy a wing named for him at the Metropolitan Museum. ''Then I bought it, and he pleaded with me to sell it to him. I said, 'Bobby, you blew it!' '' First Purchases: Van Gogh and Monet It was one of his seven sisters, Enid Annenberg Haupt, who started him on collecting, Mr. Annenberg recalled. His first purchases, ''at least 40 or 45 years ago,'' were van Gogh's ''Olive Trees'' and Monet's ''Stroller,'' a portrait of the artist's stepdaugher, Suzanne Hoschede. In 1983 the collection was substantially bolstered by Mr. Annenberg's purchase of 15 works from Mrs. Haupt's own holdings, among them such prizes as Cezanne's ''Portrait of Uncle Dominique as a Monk,'' Gauguin's ''Siesta'' and Matisse's ''Odalisque With Gray Trousers.''
If Sunnylands is something of a shrine to art, it is also a shrine to British royalty and to the Presidents with whom the Annenbergs have had connections. He served as Ambassador to Britain from 1969 to 1974. The sitting area and what the Annenbergs call their ''room of memories'' are filled with photographs and other souvenirs of the royal family. Framed and hanging on the walls of a corridor outside the room of memories are a series of Christmas cards from the Queen Mother, and a group of invitations focused on the wedding of the Prince and Princess of Wales.
Also in the room are photographs of Presidents and candidates supported by Mr. Annenberg, among them Wendell L. Willkie, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Lyndon B. Johnson, Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford and Ronald Reagan.
In the same room hangs a stark 1978 portrait of Mr. Annenberg, looking flinty but noble, by his friend Andrew Wyeth. For the portrait, he is garbed in a choir robe, a cherished at-home outfit. He acquired it, Mr. Annenberg explained, from Whipple, makers of church garments in London. ''We went to a service at Westminster Cathedral and admired the way the choir was dressed,'' he recalls. ''We found they had just got new robes from Whipple, so we went there and ordered a pair for ourselves. They are the most comfortable things in the world for wearing around the house.''

HEADLINE: In Books, Greed Is Out; The Environment Is In

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
If the books people are buying are an indication, a new decade has already ushered in a new mood in America.
Gone from best-seller lists are the books of businessmen like Donald Trump and Lee Iacocca, whose first-person accounts of their successes sold millions of copies and made the authors icons of the 1980's. In their place, a host of successful books have emerged about the newly perceived greed of the last decade, and about the need to place environmental concerns above personal acquisitiveness and unfettered industrial expansion.
Several books scheduled for publication question the legacy of Ronald Reagan. Among them are ''Disorder and Decline: Crime and the Spiral of Decay in American Neighborhoods,'' by William Skogan (Free Press), ''The Politics of Rich and Poor: Wealth and the American Electorate in the Reagan Aftermath,'' by Kevin Phillips (Random House), and ''The Worst Years of our Lives: An Outsider's View of the 80's,'' by Barbera Ehrenreich (Pantheon). 
''What we are seeing in the books that are selling is the turnaround from the celebration of greed to the denigration of greed,'' said Linda Grey, the president of Bantam Books.
 
Heroes No More
Gary Del Vecchio, president of Doubleday bookstores, said the absence of best-selling business biographies or autobiographies had become a subject of discussion at Doubleday stores. Noting the success of several books on the environment, he said, ''We are seeing an absolute change in the things that readers are focusing on.''
Howard Kaminsky, chief executive of the Hearst Trade Book group, asked: ''What businessmen as heroes are left?''
Publishers perceive a new mood of questioning about exactly what happened during the Reagan years -specifically, whether the making of big fortunes on Wall Street and a rash of debt-financed consumer spending masked deep underlying problems like sagging national competitiveness and the growing gap between rich and poor.
''People feel like they are waking up experiencing the hangover after a smashing good drunkfest,'' said Steve Wasserman, the editorial director of Times Books. ''In the cold morning light, they are assessing a country that seems adrift at a time when all political and economic assumptions are up for grabs.''
Some publishers, including Ms. Grey of Bantam, said they believe it was Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' published in 1987, that initiated the shift to a more critical focus on the Reagan years. More recently, the talk of the New York book-party circuit has been two best-selling books that take critical looks at the frenzied deal-making on Wall Street in the 1980's: ''Barbarians at the Gate,'' by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar (Harper & Row), and ''Liar's Poker,'' by Michael Lewis (W. W. Norton).
 
Saving the Earth Is Popular
This mood of reassessment has also helped make the environment and ecology hot topics in publishing, analysts say. Dozens of books on the subject have been, or are scheduled to be, published.
''A lot of the psychic energy that went into political protest is now finding in the environment an outlet that provides the same sort of pleasures and sense of moral justification,'' said Erwin Glikes, president of the Free Press.
The most successful of the books has been ''50 Simple Things You Can Do to Save the Earth,'' self-published by the San Francisco-based Earthworks Press, co-owned by John Javna and Julie Bennett. This has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 12 weeks.
A follow-up book, ''50 Simple Things Kids Can Do to Save the Earth,'' has just been published by Andrews & McMeel, a Kansas publisher, and has had very brisk initial sales, he said.
Donna Martin, vice-president of Andrews & McMeel, said the books were so successful because they suggest something positive people can do about the environment. ''We've been having weird weather here in Kansas - a warm January and now Easter cold, and in the popular perception that's linked to the Amazon burning, the greenhouse effect and acid rain,'' she said. ''People want to get involved. There's a turn from the 'me' to the 'we' decade.'' Another publisher suggested this was the ''re'' decade - one obsessed with recycling.
''Chico Mendes could be a hero for the 90's,'' commented one publisher, referring to the slain Brazilian rubber tapper about whom two books are to appear soon.
 
A Sequel by Trump
Others think business books still have big potential, despite their current slump. Mr. Trump, whose first book, ''The Art of the Deal'' (Random House) has sold more than two million copies, has a second book, ''Trump: Surviving at the Top,'' also scheduled to be published by Random House later this year. ''It's deeper and more poignant than my first, and I think it will do even better,'' he said. Asked about the success of ''Barbarians'' and ''Liar's Poker,'' Mr. Trump said, ''People love reading negative things about successful people.''
Whether or not the new Trump book does well, several publishers said they believed the first book that really addresses America's new questioning mood, and offers solutions, could be very successful. ''People are floundering for a vision, and nobody has yet articulated it,'' Mr. Wasserman said. Mr. Kaminsky said there was thirst for ''a new motivational hero.''
And Mr. Glikes of The Free Press added: ''There is a sense of gridlock in the country, of a pious concern masking the fact problems are not confronted. The first book to really confront them could be very big.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Milken's Plea Reflects Ethics of Drexel in 80's

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Michael R. Milken, the dethroned king of ''junk bonds,'' admitted yesterday that he had cheated some customers, rigged the prices of some stocks and bonds, and engaged in sham transactions designed to fool Federal regulators and help a crony avoid paying taxes.
The six felonies that Mr. Milken acknowledged did not include many serious charges, such as insider trading, that the Federal Government brought last year when it indicted the celebrated financier. These allegations, which went well beyond the wrongdoing that Mr. Milken confessed to, were dropped in the plea bargain that he accepted.
But Mr. Milken's guilty plea nonetheless provided a stark view of the ethical standards that prevailed at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. during the soaring years of the 1980's, when Mr. Milken and his empire of junk were making Drexel perhaps the most powerful firm on Wall Street and certainly the most feared. In 1987, Mr. Milken was paid a stunning $550 million, not counting profits on his investments. 
 
Cutting Legal Corners
The charges he admitted paint a picture of a man who, however brilliant and however wealthy, was willing to cut legal corners in pursuit of further profit. But whatever the portrait of Mr. Milken, nothing that he pleaded to yesterday either proved or disproved that the junk bond phenomenon was bad - although evidence abounds that it enabled many companies to go further into debt than now appears to have been prudent.
''Our business was in no way dependent on these practices,'' Mr. Milken said of the illegal acts he admitted. ''Nor did they comprise a fundamental part of our business and I regret them very much,''
By happenstance, Mr. Milken's plea - and the imprisonment that will almost certainly follow - come as the junk bond market is reeling from defaults by companies unable to pay their debts. Those defaults, only some of which involved securities sold by Drexel, reflect the general weakening of credit standards during the 1980's, as lenders stood willing to finance takeovers of companies that could not earn enough money to pay interest on the loans.
None of the charges against Mr. Milken or the Drexel firm (which previously pleaded guilty to six felony counts covering some of the same ground) asserted that buyers of junk bonds were defrauded because the deals were defective. To the contrary, investors were given written information describing the bonds as very risky. But those warnings were ignored by buyers hungry for high interest rates.
Now, with the series of defaults having scared investors, junk bond prices have fallen sharply, and it is very difficult to sell a new issue of junk bonds. Some nostalgically think that the junk bond market would still be humming if only Mr. Milken were back at his desk in Beverly Hills, Calif., working long hours and finding ways to place hard-to-sell bonds. But it is hard to imagine what he could have done that would have enabled Robert Campeau's Federated Department Stores or Merv Griffin's Resorts International to find the cash to pay its bills.
So the acknowledged felonies do not demolish the widespread assessment of Mr. Milken as the most influential financial innovator of his day. But they do leave an impression that is very unflattering to a man who hoped to become known as the pioneer whose ideas would solve the third world debt problem.
In a less lofty vein, the aspiring financial statesman has now admitted that he shortchanged Drexel's customers. To pay higher commissions to Drexel brokers, he routinely overcharged a mutual fund when that fund bought bonds from Drexel, and he paid too little to the fund when it sold bonds.
That fund, the Finsbury Group Ltd., had been created by Drexel and was sold to overseas investors by Drexel brokers. In effect, the practice stole money from the fund shareholders -the Drexel customers - and gave it to the brokers. The amounts in each trade were small, but they added up to 1 percent of the fund each year, a substantial amount.
As part of an encompassing conspiracy charge, Mr. Milken also admitted to manipulating securities prices. In one case that the Drexel firm acknowledged, though not specifically referred to in Mr. Milken's plea, the manipulation was said to have cost a corporate client a lot of money by driving down the price of its securities just before an offering. Drexel evidently thought that step would make the securities easier to sell and assuredly profitable.
When Ivan Boesky needed to have some stocks taken off his hands so that he could comply with Securities and Exchange Commission rules, Drexel and Mr. Milken admit they obligingly did so, with Mr. Boesky guaranteeing them against losses. When Drexel needed Mr. Boesky to buy and hold some securities, he complied, obtaining similar guarantees. In each case, Mr. Milken admitted aiding Mr. Boesky in filing false reports regarding the transactions.
When David B. Solomon, the money manager who ran the Finsbury Group, concluded in late 1985 that he wanted to pay less taxes, Mr. Milken obligingly arranged for Drexel to sell some bonds to him for $3.1 million and to buy them back a week later for $2.1 million. That created a tax loss for Mr. Solomon, but Mr. Milken promised he would find good investments for him that would more than make up for it. He did so.
The Government previously accused Mr. Milken of twice arranging for Drexel to buy or sell large blocks of securities in order to profit from pending transactions that he had learned about as the investment banker for companies involved in the transactions. But those charges were dropped as part of the plea.
It was Mr. Boesky, once the most prominent speculator in takeover stocks, who provided much, but not all, of the evidence against Mr. Milken. Mr. Boesky was recently released from prison after serving a sentence for violating securities laws.
Mr. Milken, in his statement in court, emphasized that transactions with Mr. Boesky ''never approached 1 percent of the business of our department.'' What is not known, and may never be known, is whether the fraudulent activities that Mr. Milken admits conducting with Mr. Boesky were aberrations at Drexel, or whether they stand out only because Mr. Boesky chose to testify about them after he was caught.
Mr. Milken, who is 43 years old, went to work for a predecessor firm of Drexel as a young graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, having done a study there that concluded that a diversified portfolio of bonds rated below investment grade - the bonds now known as junk bonds - generally ended up being a good investment because the high interest rates paid more than offset losses from defaults.
In those days, virtually all the junk bonds outstanding were ''fallen angels,'' bonds that were believed to be of high quality when they were issued but that had run into trouble because of business reversals for the company that issued them.
Mr. Milken gained early fame by trading those bonds and persuading customers to buy them. He gradually moved to underwriting new issues for smaller firms that could not qualify to issue investment grade bonds, but for which there might be good business prospects. Such companies as Turner Broadcasting, the cable television giant, and MCI Communications, now the second-largest long-distance telephone company, borrowed money through Drexel-issued junk bonds.
Big profits on early junk bonds brought in buyers and created a demand for more bonds. Drexel filled that demand, and credit standards gradually began to deteriorate. ''Bonds were issued to finance nothing more than speculation on the price of companies,'' Hugh Johnson, a market analyst at First Albany Securities, said yesterday. Those bonds could be paid off only if the companies in question, or large parts of them, could be sold for ever-higher prices.
''On Wall Street, there is a rule that every good idea must be driven into the ground like a tomato stake,'' said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a magazine that has been critical of Mr. Milken for years. ''Junk bonds were good ideas that became dangerous ones.''

HEADLINE: Reports Stir Fears Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Government reports provided fresh evidence today that the economy has successfully skirted recession but that it now confronts a problem of stepped-up inflation that may prompt the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy this spring.
Orders for durable goods jumped by 6.7 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today, largely because of sharp, unexpected gains in orders for aircraft and motor vehicles.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said wages, salaries and other benefits rose by 5.5 percent in the 12 months that ended in March. The rise in the Employment Cost Index was the most rapid in nearly six years. Employee compensation -pay and fringe benefits - is one of the main determinants of the inflation rate. 
 
Mixed Interpretations
Analysts expressed various degrees of anxiety about the reports, but a typical comment was that of Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation in New York.
''They add up to an economy that's continuing to show signs of strength, with no relief on the inflation front,'' he said. Mr. Beck said that as a result, the Federal Reserve was more likely to decide in the fairly near future to raise interest rates a notch to counter inflation. The central bank's chief policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, is to hold its next formal meeting on May 15.
Other analysts acknowledged that the economy appears markedly stronger than it did a few weeks ago and that inflation needs to be closely watched. But they said no sign of a boom existed and that prices were not showing any real acceleration.
Lyle E. Gramley, the chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington and a former governor of the Federal Reserve, noted that excluding the transportation sector, durable goods orders were up only by 2 percent. The March increase in durable goods, big-ticket items expected to last at least three years, followed a revised 2.3 percent rise in February and was the largest monthly gain since a 7.4 percent rise in December 1988.
 
Backlog at Jet Makers
Aircraft orders will take a particularly long time to have any economic impact since producers, especially the Boeing Company, have large backlogs. Unit labor costs, Mr. Gramley added, still appear to be consistent with a 4.5 percent consumer inflation rate of the last three years.
As a result, the Federal Reserve ''can probably wait and do nothing for six months,'' Mr. Gramley said.
A similar message was offered by Gordon Richards, the economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, another Washington-based industry group. ''The surge in durable goods orders is misleadingly high,'' he said, because of aberrational rebounds in aircraft and automobiles. Mr. Richards also noted that orders increases in February and March did not fully offset a 10.5 percent plunge in January.
''These figures support the view that the economy may experience something of a 'false start' in the second quarter, as business activity picks up due to a series of one-time factors,'' Mr. Richards said. ''However, continued high interest rates, coupled with signs of an impending increase in interest rates overseas, make it likely that the rise in growth will be unsustainable, leading to renewed sluggishness in the third quarter.''
 
G.N.P. Due on Friday
On Friday, the Commerce Department will publish its first estimate of gross national product for the first three months of the year, with most analysts expecting an annual growth rate of 2 percent to 3 percent. Output grew at a 1.1 percent rate during the final quarter of last year.
The majority of economists, unnerved by today's reports, were distressed at the Employment Cost Index, which Norman Robertson of the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh called ''a little ominous.'' Private-sector compensation in health services, for example, has edged up to 7 percent over the last 12 months while educational services have reached 6.4 percent.
But Mr. Robertson contended that while the overall core rate of inflation had now climbed to 5 percent, the Fed might still be reluctant to tighten policy next month. Service inflation, he said, is less affected by higher interest rates than commodity inflation. Moreover, the Fed might be reluctant to raise rates when housing is in poor shape and when the dollar is overly buoyant in world currency markets.
 
Higher Health Costs
Fringe benefits - mainly health costs soaring by 12.1 percent - drove the year-over-year Employment Cost Index up by 5.5 percent in the March quarter, up from 5 percent last December and from 4.8 percent in March 1989. Fringes advanced by 7.2 percent over the latest year, and the rise would have been 5.9 percent without health benefits and 5.7 percent without health and the January rise in the Social Security payroll tax.
Wages and salaries, on the other hand, remained steady at a growth rate of 4.4 percent for the 12 months through March, for calendar 1989 for the 12 months that ended in March 1989.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Soviet Economy: Red Storm Ebbs

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
JUST how much are Soviet consumers really suffering? Alfred Volkov, a researcher from Moscow's Academy of National Economics, replies with a story about the quality of food in state-run markets: Criminals vowing not be be taken alive, he quips, now carry a piece of sausage to swallow in case they are cornered by the police.
Grim jokes about the parlous state of the Soviet system are as old as the gulag. What was startling about this one was the setting in which it was recounted and the composition of the audience.
Mr. Volkov, along with a dozen other senior Soviet economic researchers, was a guest of the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative Washington research group. The object of their on-the-record meeting at the Airlie Conference Center, deep in the horse farm country of Virginia: to compare notes with representatives of the devil incarnate, the Central Intelligence Agency. 
What was perhaps even more startling to the uninitiated was the division of opinion among the conferees. Children of the cold war might assume that the Russians would end up on one side, Americans on the other. In fact, the breakdown was establishment versus anti-establishment, with both Soviet and American critics stumbling over each other to show that both the C.I.A. and Goskomstat, the Soviet statistics agency, had overestimated the size and growth rate of the Soviet economy.
Soviet authorities have never published income statistics with much credibility in the West. Until very recently they did not even bother to explain the precise meaning of their numbers; nor, apparently, did they follow research conventions permitting outsiders to second-guess their results. But that has not deterred the C.I.A.'s in-house economists or the agency's academic consultants, respected scholars including Gertrude Schroeder of the University of Virginia and Abram Becker of the Rand Corporation. Their estimates, assembled from raw Soviet data and released over the years by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, have had wide influence in policy debates over Soviet economic prospects and military intentions.
The C.I.A. figures suggest that Soviet output and living standards rose substantially from the end of the war through the mid-1970's. But according to the agency, the Russian economic bear was never as formidable as Soviet bureaucrats and American cold warriors believed. Soviet growth rates were roughly in line with American rates - an adequate if unimpressive performance for an economy with a well-educated work force that was starting from a very low base of development.
Moreover, as Ms. Schroeder noted at the conference, the C.I.A. made an early and correct call that the Soviet economy would hit a wall in the late 1970's: the growth rate for living standards tumbled to just 1 to 1.5 percent annually, widening an already yawning gap with the West. According to the C.I.A., Soviet citizens now live about as well in material terms as Portuguese or Greeks.
Even the C.I.A.'s bearish numbers, however, have been viewed skeptically by independent American analysts, including Igor Birman of the Foundation of Soviet Studies in Maryland. Mr. Birman, who plainly savors his reputation as a gadfly, argues that by the mid-1970's the Soviet G.N.P. was just one-third that of America's, in contrast to the estimate of one-half offered by the C.I.A. Yet more striking, he believes that individual living standards were just one-fifth that of America's - and presumably they have grown worse in relative terms over the last decade.
Enter the new Soviet economists, propelled by the heady winds of glasnost. Rather than disputing the iconoclastic Mr. Birman's findings, Yuri Dikhanov of the Soviet Academy of Sciences has gone to heroic technical efforts to confirm them. In a tortuous extrapolation using the Hungarian economy as a benchmark, he estimates that Soviet consumption per person averaged just 20 percent that of Americans' in 1985.
His academy colleague, Victor Belkin, went even further: After accounting for the very low quality of Soviet goods and factoring in waste on a scale inconceivable in the West, he estimates that Soviet G.N.P. per capita is now less than one-seventh of America's. Soviet citizens, it follows, have roughly the material living standard of the Chinese.
It is far from clear that Mr. Belkin is right. As most of the conferees agreed, the lack of hard data makes it possible to defend a wide range of soft estimates. What is clear is that the strange times are breeding strange bedfellows. The C.I.A. and Goskomstat have, in effect, become the principal defenders of conservative scholarship in the field - and, implicitly, of the view that the Soviet economy remains a force to be reckoned with.

HEADLINE: 2 Chemical Makers' Net Off

 BODY:
The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's second-largest producer of chemicals, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income plunged almost 38 percent because of higher costs for raw materials and lower prices for some products.
The Monsanto Company, whose products include chemicals, said its profits in the quarter fell nearly 13 percent because of soft conditions in the automobile industry and a seasonal slowdown in agriculture. 
Dow's net income totaled $462 million, or $1.71 a share, compared with $743 million, or $2.72 a share, in the comparable period last year. Its sales increased 9.3 percent, to $4.9 billion, from $4.48 billion, reflecting recent acquisitions and strong volume gains, the company said.
Analysts said they had expected Dow's earnings to be affected by recent price declines for some chemicals and plastics. They also said the company's results reflected slower growth in the overall economy. But they added that Dow's business in consumer specialty products would probably grow.
Dow, based in Midland, Mich., said its operating income for chemicals and performance products, which include absorbents and air-separation systems, dropped 43 percent in the 1990 quarter.
Meanwhile, the St. Louis-based Monsanto said it had profits of $194 million, or $2.95 a share, down from a record $222 million, or $3.24 a share, in the 1989 period. Its revenues were flat, at $2.28 billion, compared with $2.26 billion.
Monsanto's drug unit, G. D. Searle, showed a $4 million profit, compared with a loss of $8 million in the first quarter of 1989, and the Nutrasweet Company, also owned by Monsanto, had slightly lower profits because of the cost of introducing its new frozen dairy dessert, Simple Pleasures.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Named Chief At Cincinnati Milacron

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Cincinnati Milacron Inc., a leading machine tool maker, announced yesterday that it had named Daniel J. Meyer chief executive, ending the long leadership of the founding Geier family at the company.
Mr. Meyer, 53 years old, who is also president, will assume his new responsibilities immediately, succeeding James A. D. Geier. Mr. Geier will continue as chairman until he reaches age 65 at the end of the year, at which time he will retire.
Mr. Geier is a grandson of Frederick A. Geier, co-founder of the Cincinnati-based company, which was established in 1884. Mr. Geier's grandfather was president from 1905 to 1934. His father, Frederick V. Geier, took the reins in 1934 and retired as chairman in 1963. 
In a statement, Mr. Meyer said, ''I wish to acknowledge the importance of continued strong support from Milacron employees and from the Geier family, which has guided this company for over a hundred years.''
Mr. Meyer is a longtime Milacron executive who has no plans to depart radically from the company's recent strategies. ''I do not see the company changing direction,'' he said yesterday. ''We will be focusing on improving its worldwide competitive position in its core businesses.
Mr. Meyer joined Milacron in 1969 as director of corporate accounting and worked on the finance side for much of the time. He was named president in 1987, a year in which the company and the industry were being battered by foreign competiton.
Cincinnati Milacron reorganized in the last two years, seeking higher quality and productivity in its factories.
Mr. Meyer said the company had been looking to the aerospace industry, especially the commercial side, to offset lagging automotive orders. The company is also looking to Europe, where it operates in the Netherlands, Britain and Austria, and is exploring Eastern European opportunities.
''We're cautious about some of the immediate opportunities there,'' Mr. Meyer said, ''but at the same time we don't want to miss any.
Mr. Meyer holds a degree in electrical engineering from Purdue University and an M.B.A. from Indiana University. Before joining Milacron he worked for Touche Ross, the accounting firm, as a management consultant.

HEADLINE: Control Data Net Up by 94%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 24

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation reported today that its first-quarter profit rose by 94 percent from a year ago because of a huge after-tax gain from its reorganization, but the revenue of the scaled-down computer company declined sharply.
Net income for the first three months of 1990 totaled $6.8 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with earnings of $3.5 million, or 8 cents, in 1989. Revenue, however, dropped by half from the 1989 quarter, falling to $421.6 million from $843.5 million.
The latest results included a $5.8 million gain from the company's reorganization. Control Data sold or discontinued several operating units, including its Imprimis disk drive subsidiary and its maintenance business. It also laid off 7,750 workers last year, and replaced its chief executive officer, Robert M. Price.
Lawrence Perlman, who took the helm of Control Data in January, said that ''apart from restructuring gains and charges, Control Data has now been profitable for three consecutive quarters.''
''Although the first quarter traditionally has not been a strong one for Control Data, earnings were stronger in several businesses than we had anticipated,'' he added. ''Business Management Services sustained its revenue and earnings growth, and Computer Products continued to make progress.''
The company posted a net loss of $680.4 million in 1989, the worst in its 32-year history.

HEADLINE: Moody's Reviews Ratings Of 2 Giant Japanese Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The top triple-A ratings for long-term borrowings of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. and the Fuji Bank Ltd., the largest and fourth-largest banks in the world, are under review, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.
Moody's said the ratings for short-term borrowings of the two Tokyo-based banks remained at the highest level of prime-1 and were not under review.
Dai-Ichi Kangyo and Fuji are both strong operations over all, Moody's said, and a rating reduction, if any, would not be substantial for their borrowings of more than a year. A lower rating would, however, tarnish the banks' image in capital markets, including the markets for interest-rate and currency swaps. 
 
Interest-Rate Risks
Because rising interest rates in Japan have reduced bank earnings, Moody's said the two banks need to show that they have plans to control their interest-rate risks in the future. Deborah Kinzer, a senior analyst at Moody's, said deregulation of the financial system in Japan had resulted in banks raising the interest rates they pay on consumer deposits more rapidly than the interest rates they charge borrowers.
Japanese bank earnings for the year ended March 31 are expected to be announced in May or early June.
Dai-Ichi Kangyo operates the largest branch system of any Japanese bank and has assets of $430 billion, nearly twice the level of Citicorp, the largest American banking company. But Moody's said Dai-Ichi Kanyo had a long-term problem of controlling the costs of its branch banking system. Because its expenses are higher than other large Japanese banks, Moody's said, the earnings of Dai-Ichi Kanyo are more vulnerable when rapidly rising interset rates narrow the profit margin from lending.
 
Real Estate Exposure
Moody's said a rating review of both banks was justified because of their exposure to Japanese real estate. The rating agency has said it is worried about the possibility that real estate prices might decline.
Although data were not available on the extent of their risk, Ms. Kinzer noted that the real estate exposure of the two banks was not as great as that of the Yasuda Bank and Trust Company, the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation and the Mitsui Trust and Banking Company. The credit ratings for these Japanese banks were lowered earlier this year.
At Fuji Bank, Moody's said it was also concerned about the risk of loss on loans made in the United States to finance corporate takeovers.
Ms. Kinzer said the recent decline in the Tokyo stock market was not a consideration for Moody's because only a small part of each bank's stock holdings was counted when measuring their financial resources.
Masahiro Nagayasu, the manager of the New York branch of the Fuji Bank, said he was puzzled by the Moody's review because other large Japanese banks were vulnerable to losses on real estate or loans for American corporate takeovers to the same degree, or more, than Fuji. He added that Fuji bank had recently created a new group to use financial futures and options to control the risk of rising interest rates.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower But Rises Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against all major currencies yesterday except the Japanese yen, which weakened considerably.
Gold prices finished lower in the United States after moving higher abroad.
Foreign exchange dealers said trading was moderately active and most of the attention was directed toward the yen. Japan's currency slumped across the board, benefiting the West German mark, the Swiss franc and other currencies. 
There was no news from Japan to account for the heavy yen selling. Dealers said an underlying bearish outlook for the yen, which had been temporarily suppressed, reappeared. The low level of that country's interest rates relative to those of Japan's trading partners accounts for some of the yen's troubles.
The dollar's losses against everything but the yen came despite a strong report on orders for durable goods. March bookings for durables, which are items expected to last three or more years, posted the largest increase in more than a year, jumping 6.7 percent.
But the report had little influence on the dollar and traders were said to be more interested in the report on the gross national product due Friday, which will be the first comprehensive assessment of economic activity in the first quarter.
By late in the afternoon in London, the dollar was quoted at 1.6930 marks, down from 1.6960 marks late Monday. It stood at 1.6980 marks late in New York, down from Monday's late level of 1.6995.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.60 yen, to a closing 158.15 yen. It was quoted at a higher rate of 158.59 yen later in London. In New York, the dollar ended at 158.95 yen, up from 157.55 yen on Monday.
Also in London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6345, compared with $1.6365 late Monday. Later in New York, sterling dipped to $1.6347, from $1.63565 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.4875 Swiss francs, down from 1.4935; 5.698 French francs, down from 5.7020; 1,244.75 Italian lire, down from 1,246.75, and 1.15955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16155.
Selected dollar rates late in Europe, compared with levels late Monday, were: 1.4865 Swiss francs, down from 1.4925; 5.6795 French francs, down from 5.6930; 1.9100 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9090; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.00, and 1.1590 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1610.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rising Interest Rates Spur A Drop in Precious Metals

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of precious metal futures fell yesterday, reflecting a general lack of interest in gold and silver in the face of rising interest rates.
On other commodity markets, copper futures rose sharply and grains and soybeans retreated, while energy futures were mixed and livestock and meat futures finished likewise.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold futures settled $3 to $3.10 lower, with the April contract for delivery at $375.90 an ounce. Silver finished 10 cents lower, with May at about $5 an ounce. 
On the Mercantile Exchange, platinum futures fell $6.50 across the board, with the July contract settling at $487.80 an ounce.
The retreat followed a strong rally on Monday in the platinum market, which had been linked to speculation that Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress, was preparing to take a more militant stance against apartheid, posing a threat of possible platinum supply disruptions.
The rumors about Mr. Mandela were discounted yesterday and as platinum futures fell, the gold and silver markets followed, said William O'Neill, the research director with Elders Futures Inc. in New York.
The precious metals markets kept tumbling, though, even after platinum selling dwindled. Mr. O'Neill said the weak tone reflected the outlook for higher interest rates, which tends to discourage demand for precious metals.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper futures climbed strongly amid a resurgence of buying on indications of tight supplies available for delivery against the April contract, which expires tomorrow.
Further buying was inspired by a report that officials of the Codelco Copper Company in Chile had lowered their estimate for 1990 production from the country's state-owned copper mines to 1.2 million to 1.25 million tons, from an earlier estimate of 1.29 million tons.
Copper settled 1.8 cents to 4.9 cents higher, with April at $1.24 a pound.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, the prices of grain and soybean futures fell substantially, led by a technically inspired selloff in the soybean market, analysts said.
Oil futures finished mixed on the Merc before the American Petroleum Institute released its weekly stocks report after the close. The report showed an expected increase in American refinery activity, a fairly large 1.2-million-barrel increase in United States oil stocks, a 926,000-barrel drop in gasoline stocks and a 752,000-barrel decline in heating oil stocks.
The buildup in crude stocks extends a pattern of oversupply that has been linked to overproduction by the 12 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. But the higher refinery activity is a seasonal factor that may offset the market effect of the rise in oil stocks.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirror Net Down 33%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 24

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit fell by 33 percent, while revenues rose by 3.3 percent.
The company cited an advertising slowdown at its Northeastern newspapers, consumer magazines and broadcast television operations, and higher promotional costs and higher circulation that pushed up operating costs at The Los Angeles Times. 
For the quarter ended April 1, Times Mirror's earnings fell to $46 million, or 36 cents a share, from $68.8 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenues rose to $875.2 million from $846.9 million.
''Although our professional publishing and cable television operations achieved solid earnings growth during the quarter, their performance only partially offset the marked deterioration in our newspaper publishing segment,'' said Robert F. Erburu, Times Mirror's chairman and chief executive.
 
Ad volume was slow at the
Northeastern newspapers, with Newsday and New York Newsday suffering from a depressed New York economy, Times Mirror said.
Times Mirror said its companywide circulation, as reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations but not yet verified, rose by 4.1 percent for the daily papers and by 3.2 percent on Sunday over the last six months.

HEADLINE: He Can Milk 'Em, But He Can't Hide

BYLINE: By Benjamin J. Stein; Benjamin J. Stein, a lawyer and economist, writes frequently on financial issues.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The deed, apparently, is done. Michael Milken, the premier financial swindler of all time, is being given a plea bargain.
A $600 million fine may seem large, but in fact it will be trivial to him. His prison sentence is likely to be less than is given to petty income tax cheats. While he has supposedly agreed to provide information for related investigations, he is under no obligation to do so, since the Government has already settled his case. And he has bought immunity for his lawyer brother, Lowell. 
In short, Michael Milken is off the hook. The Houdini of the legal system has gotten out of the locked trunk.
Never mind that the collapse of savings and loan institutions, stuffed with Mr. Milken's worthless junk bonds, will cost the ordinary taxpayer billions that might have gone for medical care or retirement. Never mind that Mr. Milken's money came from the sweat and sacrifice of ordinary people.
So small is Mr. Milken's punishment that it constitutes nothing less than a pardon from President Bush, who would have to approve this deal himself. Never mind. This is what always happens when the big guys' interests are weighed against the little guys'.
Still, there is one little thing that might be done to soothe the burning hurt of the injustice of the Milken plea bargain: open the grand jury transcripts and the grand jury exhibits.
Of course, the Milken lawyers will demand that they be sealed. It's their right, after all, because their client is rich. But maybe, just maybe there are other interests. Maybe the public might be allowed a chance to see a little more into the world of Michael Milken before he disappears into well-upholstered legend.
There is much that the public needs to know. For example, who in Government were his protectors? Who knew about what he was doing and when did they know?
It's a matter of public record that staffers at the Securities and Exchange Commission investigated the Milken junk operation repeatedly through the 1980's and recommended action. It never happened until 1989. Why? Who was protecting Mr. Milken at the S.E.C. and why?
It is a matter of public record that Drexel was raising capital for the circle of savings and loan institutions that then turned around and bought its now largely worthless junk bonds. It's a matter of record that Federal Home Loan Bank Board staff people were suspicious of these transactions, at least insofar as they applied to the failed Lincoln Savings & Loan, run by the infamous Charles Keating. And they held these suspicions for at least the last five years. Who at the Bank Board was working for Mr. Milken and the junk bond industry?
It has now been reported thoroughly that organized crime elements were major players in the looting of America's savings and loan institutions. By an eerily similar token, a number of the names that turn up as long time Milken pals and supporters (as in ''Mike Milken, We Believe In You'') have repeatedly been described over time, and in major publications, as organized crime honchos. Of course, Mr. Milken's company, Drexel Burnham, was also the preferred financing entity for the casino industry.
Something is going on here. If organized crime was linked in a big way to Drexel and Mr. Milken, this is well worth knowing. Grand jury testimony might give leads that could help us to understand just who is running American finance. If it's organized crime, that has some bearing on whether sensible people want to invest in certain entities. If not, that's important, too. Maybe it is all just a fantasy. Let's have a look.
Many of these items may be false trails, may not even involve crimes. Maybe much of what swirls around Mr. Milken is just fog and filthy air.
But the missing billions, the taxpayers socked to make Mr. Milken rich, the savings and loan disaster he helped to engineer, the Government in his pocket for far too long - these are real. The plea bargain is insult enough on top of this injury. Let's get a look at the grand jury transcripts.
The Government is clearly not eager to represent the people on this one. Maybe, with the grand jury data, we can start to defend ourselves against the next Milken, who may be jauntily stepping our way.
