LENGTH: 1009 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey Voters in Revolt Against Soaring School Taxes

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 25

 BODY:
Voters in nearly half the school districts in New Jersey soundly rejected budgets in elections on Tuesday in the most sweeping revolt against soaring taxes since the state was forced to change its financing of education 14 years ago.
In many of the 263 districts where budgets were defeated, property taxes would have risen as much as 40 percent. The revenue would have covered increased costs and replaced millions of dollars in state aid lost as the state government struggles to close its own budget deficit of more than $600 million.
 
Back to Municipal Officials
With the rejection of 48 percent of the budgets - many by 2-to-1 ratios - the state's budget problems are sure to be felt by students, parents and teachers in the districts as the defeated budgets are returned to municipal officials, who will decide whether they should be reduced and, if so, by how much. 
In some instances, school officials said, teachers will be laid off, schools closed and programs cut to keep the budgets balanced without raising taxes too high.
''A lot of teachers and staff are going to be put out of work,'' said Dr. Edwin Oskamp, superintendent of the Andover Regional School District in Sussex County in the northern corner of the state, where the budget was defeated. ''There's going to be lean years ahead.''
Education officials said it was the prospect of higher property taxes on top of Gov. Jim Florio's announced plans to increase sales and income taxes that brought out voters in greater numbers than for any school election in 10 years. Of the 3.8 million eligible voters, 15.8 percent participated.
Because they are the only budgets voted on directly by taxpayers, school budgets often bear the full brunt of anti-tax sentiments.
Mr. Florio, whose proposed budget would cut aid to the districts by 16 percent under the state's formula, said in a statement the election results were ''a strong signal from people who are fed up with New Jersey's growing overreliance on local property taxes to pay for education.''
The fate of the financing system is before State Supreme Court.
In his budget plan, which is to be voted on by the Legislature, Mr. Florio has offered a program for property-tax relief under which income and sales taxes increase and property taxes could decrease as much as $500 a year for people meeting income restrictions.
 
Problems in the Northeast
Education experts said the elections on Tuesday represented a taxpayer revolt that could be repeated in other Northeastern states where the economy has slowed, housing values are sinking, frustration over educational achievements is growing, and more people with grown children are voting on the budgets.
''There's no reason why what happened in New Jersey couldn't happen in other states, especially in the Northeast,'' said C. Kent McGuire, a professor of education at the University of Colorado and a senior policy analyst for finance at the Education Commission of the States. ''When there's uncertainty and confusion and discontent at the district level, it's hard for local boards to sell these tax increases.''
This is the fifth year in a row that the percentage of budget defeats has increased. Last year, 39 percent were rejected. The 48 percent rejection rate is the highest since 1976, when 58 percent were defeated, In some of the 21 counties, substantially more than half the budgets were rejected. One of the lowest rates was in Burlington, where 10 of 38 passed. In Union, 4 passed and 16 were rejected. Bergen County, the state's wealthiest, saw 38 of 73 budgets defeated. Last year, 45 were rejected.
 
Series of Rising Expenses
The executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association, Octavius T. Reid, said voter backlash stemmed from a reaction against taxes, not against quality education, adding, ''People just said, 'Ouch, I can't afford it.' ''
Several superintendents said they had been hampered by rising costs for employee benefits and new state and Federal regulations on environmental hazards like leaking fuel tanks. The primary reasons so many school boards had asked voters to accept big tax increases was to cover the loss of state subsidies.
In Midland Park, a residential borough of 7,400 people in Bergen, state aid was cut $220,000 below the anticipated $1.09 million. When the cut was combined with an 11 percent budget increase, taxpayers were asked to accept an average raise of $440 a year in property taxes.
John B. Casson thought that was too much. ''It was an unconscionable increase,'' said Mr. Casson, a police lieutenant. He has two sons in elementary schools. ''But where do you draw the line?'' he asked. ''There's probably some fat that could be taken out of budget.''
 
Passage in Newark
Voters in Newark, the largest district in the state, approved their budget, despite a vigorous campaign against it by Mayor Sharpe James, who said it was too high.
In Willingboro, a middle-class suburb of more than 40,000 people south of Trenton, voters turned down a budget that would have increased property taxes 40.5 percent. Business Administrator Wayne W. Thomas said the proposed increase was so large because the township would receive $1.5 million less in aid than anticipated.
When budgets are defeated, they are submitted to local officials for negotiation. The officials can decide to overrule the voters and accept the budget as proposed, or they can specify cuts to reduce it. If the municipal officials and the Board of Education reach an impasse, the State Education Department may resolve it. The budgets have to be in place by the end of next month.
The defeats of so many budgets in communities rich and poor, big and small, points once again to an underlying dissatisfaction with the financing of public education here, primarily through property taxes, officials said. The system has been under attack for almost 20 years. In 1976, the State Supreme Court ordered public schools closed until the Legislature devised an alternative, which was the state's first income tax.

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL CITES JAPAN'S PROGRESS ON OPEN MARKETS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Japan should not again be cited for unfair trading practices, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, told Congress today, disclosing that Washington and Tokyo had reached agreement on the last major item on their current trade agenda.
Japan has ''moved further this year than any other country'' in opening its markets, Mrs. Hills said. Citing Japan under the ''Super 301'' provision of the tough 1988 trade law again would impede further progress, she added.
The accord announced today, the culmination of a negotiating process set forth by that law, involved wood products and is expected to raise American exports to Japan by $1 billion a year. Under earlier accords, which are expected to increase annual exports by $700 million, Japan agreed to open its markets for American supercomputers and satellites. In Tokyo, the announcement was viewed favorably. Ignoring of Law Seen The comments of Mrs. Hills before the Senate Finance Committee elicited challenges from most of the Senators present who contended that only constant pressure yielded results. 
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the panel and was one of the sponsors of the 301 provision of the trade law, argued that the Administration would be ''ignoring'' the 1988 law and could ''poison the well'' for Congressional consideration of trade accords that it is expected to seek later with the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, China and members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a Geneva body that promotes trade liberalization and resolves trade disputes.
Mr. Bentsen, who takes a hard line on Japan, issued an unusually stern rebuke, contending that the constitutional form of government ''cannot work if the Administration refuses to implement laws.''
On the other hand, both Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's trade subcommittee, and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon termed the wood products pact ''significant.'' Because of the prominence of wood-producing industries in their states, both had taken leading positions demanding Japanese liberalization. The two Senators said they had spoken with industry representatives who welcomed the accord.
Senator Packwood, the ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, was among the few Senators at today's session to speak out against citing Japan.
President Bush has been caught between his reluctance to offend powerful lawmakers and his desire to reward his new friend, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, whose undertakings at a meeting with the President last March in California have led to the spate of accords, including today's on wood.
 
Change in Dynamics Seen
In addition to the successful conclusion of trade agreements, the Administration's tilt against branding Japan results from changing political dynamics, many analysts believe.
While many Americans still think that Japan does not play fair in world trade and is seeking commercial hegemony with its vast surpluses, the resentments are not as intense as last year, the analysts say.
According to William T. Archey, vice president, international, of the United States Chamber of Commerce, ''What's different this time round is the political imperative doesn't have the same oomph.''
A declining trade imbalance with Japan and the fact that Japanese surpluses are financing American budget deficits are among attentuating factors.
 
Cabinet Meeting Scheduled
Later Mrs. Hills told reporters that the Administration had yet to make its final decision on whether to name Japan as an unfair trader. A first Cabinet meeting on the issue is scheduled for Thursday morning. But Administration officials said was unlikely that her position would be reversed.
The law gives the Administration some discretion in naming countries that will be subject to Super 301 procedures. Congress can ''jawbone'' the President, but short of enacting new trade legislation it cannot overrule his decision. Among the criteria the President must consider is whether it is in the United States' overall interest to name a country.
Already in Mrs. Hills's camp, Administration officials said, are Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Michael J. Boskin.
But Mrs. Hills insisted that ''we are not backing off, or taking the pressure off.'' She said that the talks aimed at overcoming the pervasive policy and cultural obstacles confronting foreign business in Japan, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, had achieved significant preliminary results perceisely because they were proceeding outside the 301 process, which carries the threat of sanctions.
''I must be given a small amount of discretion to be able to tell members of this committee where I think the tools ought not be used and where they should be used,'' Mrs. Hills said.
She added that she wanted ''to very surgically use the tool of Super 301 in a manner that is so careful that in balance it does not cause a distraction or, in fact, a permament impediment to achieving our multilateral goal'' of opening markets.
 
First Step in Process
Citing a country is the first step in a process that could lead to reprisals in the form of 100 percent duties on a country's exports to the United States, if improvements in what the United States considers unfair trade practices are not made.
Monday is the statutory deadline for citing countries for ''priority'' negotiations under the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, reflecting practices that pose, according to the law, ''significant'' barriers to American exports.
Japan was named under the Super 301 law last year for its closed markets in satellites, supercomputers and wood products. Today's pact, under which Japan would alter product standards, building codes, product certification and tariffs in ways to accelerate the flow of wood imports, means that Japan has now reached agreements in all three sectors.
The supercomputer and satellite agreements were both concluded within the last month. Under the supercomputer pact, which is expected to lead to increased sales of as much as $500 million a year, Japan would use practical benchmarks to select among machines, instead of the ''hypothetical'' standards used in the past to undercut American-made supercomputers.
 
Open Process Required
The agreement on satellites, which could increase exports by up to $200 million a year, requires the Government of Japan to buy all commercial and operational satellites in an open and competitive procurement process. It opens up the Japanese market to American commercial, communications and broadcast satellites and to non-research and development satellites.
The accords have come against a backdrop of improvement in the American bilateral trade balance with Japan. In the first two months of this year, the American trade deficit was running at an annual rate of $35.8 billion, a 27 percent improvement over the $49 billion trade deficit for all of 1989.
 
Reaction in Japan
TOKYO, Thursday, April 26 (Special to The New York Times) - Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today of the announcement by Mrs. Hills: ''It is good that we have settled the problems of our shared perceptions.'' He had no further comment.
Earlier, a Foreign Ministry spokesman offered guarded support, saying Japan had always ''firmly believed our country will not be cited once again'' under the United States trade law known as Super 301.

HEADLINE: Japan Offers Its Good Offices to U.S. and Iran

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 25

 BODY:
As Iran and the United States haltingly begin searching for ways to end a decade of hostility, the neutral ground for exchanging messages, providing explanations and coaxing both sides along has cropped up in an unlikely spot: the Japanese Foreign Ministry in downtown Tokyo.
For a decade, Japan has kept up regular, if not exactly warm, contacts with the Iranian Government. And over the last year, since President Hashemi Rafsanjani took office, Japanese officials have been gradually stepping up the pace of exchanges among the three countries, playing a go-between role that both Japanese and American officials are hestitant to discuss in detail.
The Japanese say they have not been involved in the specific negotiations over the fate of the American hostages, nor the logistics of the release of Robert Polhill on Sunday after 39 months in captivity. The main channel for those communication appears to have been the Swiss Embassy in Teheran, which represents American interests there. 
But officials say that the central figure for other, deeper exchanges has been a high-ranking Japanese diplomat, Makoto Watanabe, who directs the Mideast and African affairs division of the Japanese Foreign Ministry, and who formerly served as Ambassador to Jordan.
''It is not that I have been passing messages as much as conveying views,'' Mr. Watanabe said in an interview today. In visits to Iran in recent months, he and other Japanese diplomats ''described the American position and conveyed our own view that it is in Iran's interest to improve relations with the United States.''
''With the U.S., we are doing the same thing, trying to explain the Iranian positions,'' said Mr. Watanabe, who for most of his career has specialized in the United States. He added, ''It is almost clear that Rafsanjani does want the hostages released, and to begin to open the way'' for a lifting of American sanctions against his country.
Japanese and American diplomats say they cannot imagine Japan's playing a similar, third-party role in such talks three or four years ago. ''It's one of the strongest signs yet that they have emerged from their shell,'' a senior American official said, ''and they are ready to get in the middle of some very complicated issues that do not directly affect them or Asia.''
For Japan, it is a role that is not entirely free of self-interest. As talk of trade wars, military burden-sharing and the wisdom of buying American companies and property have dominated discussions with the United States, officials here are eager for any successful initiatives that demonstrate that a relationship with Japan can transcend economics.
American and Japanese diplomats say the strategy appears to be making an impression on the Bush Administration. ''I sense that there is a degree of appreciation in Washington of a general, deeper role of Japan in Middle Eastern issues,'' Mr. Watanabe said.
There is also the matter of Iran's need for Japanese money and technology.
This need is particularly acute now, with the American trade embargo against Iran still in place. But Japan has never had such an embargo, and, in small ways, there are signs that commercial relations are resuming for the first time since the end of the Iran-Iraq war.
The most tangible evidence can be found in Nagasaki, at the turbine factory of Mitsubshi Heavy Industries, one of Japan's biggest makers of ships, military equipment and energy devices. During a recent tour of Mitsubishi facilities, company executives pointed to four giant turbines nearing shipment to the Iranian power authority.
The 250,000 kilowatt turbines are intended to alleviate critical power shortages that have crippled Iranian industry. Already, four have been delivered, but the next four were delayed by the Iran-Iraq war. Mitsubishi officials declined to say how much the turbines cost, but equipment like that can easily run into the tens of millions of dollars.
Japan has also been a major market for Iranian oil, but Iran now ranks only sixth among Japan's petroleum suppliers.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Bush Defends Lithuania Policies, Saying Americans Support Them

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Responding to continuing criticism from Lithuania, President Bush declared bluntly today that he needed no defense for his refusal to penalize the Soviet Union for its tightening economic squeeze on the rebellious Baltic republic.
Answering President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, who has accused him of selling out the Lithuanian people by failing to move against Moscow, Mr. Bush said with unusual asperity, ''The policies and decisions I've taken have had strong support from the American people, and that's who I work for.''
Mr. Landsbergis said in a telephone conversation this morning with members of Congress that ''the Soviets are strangling our nation like a boa constrictor.'' Twenty-four hours earlier, he had called the American decision not to intervene ''another Munich'' - a reference, laden with political emotion, to the decision by Britain and France in 1938 to in effect abandon Czechoslovakia to Nazi Germany. The episode has since become synonymous with appeasement. 
Apparently trying to turn up the heat on Mr. Bush by appealing to American public opinion, Mr. Landsbergis said, ''Can the freedom of one group of people be sold for the freedom of another?'
 
Bush Policy 'Has Enough Support'
After promising ''appropriate action'' last week if the Soviets cut off oil and gas to Lithuania, Mr. Bush decided on Tuesday not to impose the limited economic sanctions that were under consideration. The tone and substance of the President's comments today, made during a picture-taking session at the White House, reflected the three principal White House conclusions about the potentially explosive situation in Lithuania.
Lithuania's parliamentary press office quoted the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, as saying today of Mr. Bush's decision, ''The logic in this is hard to understand, but blackmail does not require logic.''
The Administration is convinced, senior officials said, that the Lithuanians are more responsible than Moscow for provoking a crisis and have suffered less than they have contended; that furthering better relations between East and West is infinitely more important than responding immediately to the Lithuanians' pleas, and that the American people support Mr. Bush's policy of support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
''We're convinced that the President has enough support in the country to carry us without any sanctions through the summit, which starts in five weeks, unless the Soviets do something far more violent than we expect,'' a senior Presidential aide said.
Mr. Bush's reference to his popular support echoed remarks a year ago by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, to the effect that polls showed the President's foreign policy to be overwhelmingly popular among the American public, and thus to a considerable degree insulated from cricitism.
On Capitol Hill this morning, Mr. Baker suggested that if the negotiated settlement that Washington is counting on failed to materialize, Mr. Bush would be more likely to try to aid Lithuania, despite all the obvious difficulties that would be entailed in sending oil and gas or other supplies through closed ports, than to try to retaliate against the Soviets.
He said that Scandinavian countries had expressed interest in trying to get oil supplies to Lithuania and added that the subject was discussed by Mr. Bush and Congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday.
If it proved feasible, he said, such an idea might be preferable to sanctions against Moscow in which the United States would ''shoot ourselves in the foot'' by undermining progress in Eastern Europe and on arms negoitiations that are as important to the United States as they are to the Soviet Union.
Still, the realization was spreading in Washington today that when Mr. Bush stepped back on Tuesday from a confrontation with the Soviet Union, he tied his political fate more closely than ever to that of President Gorbachev.
 
'Response to Soviet Bullying'
Twice he had publicly promised action if the Soviet Union took certain steps, and twice he had decided to refrain from acting after the Soviet Union had crossed the line he had drawn in the sand. Mr. Bush said taking anti-Soviet measures might ''compel the Soviet Union to take action that would set back the whole case of freedom around the world.''
His decision won widespread approval on Capitol Hill and among the allies. Indeed, the allies had threatened to disown American policy if he took any other tack. But today there were signs of restiveness. Some analysts argued that the President is taking a considerable risk by gambling that the Lithuanian problem can be resolved relatively quickly, because if the matter is not resolved, currently quiescent American public opinion may shift against him.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority leader, said Mr. Bush should act to ''express disapproval and to deter further action'' against Lithuania. Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, a conservative Republican from New Hampshire, asserted that it was ''time for a principled response to Soviet bullying.''

HEADLINE: Republicans Name Donors of $7.1 Million to Party

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
The Republican Party today made public a list of wealthy givers who donated $7.1 million to the party last year. Democratic Party officials backed away from making a similar disclosure, saying it would interfere with critical negotiations in the Senate over campaign finance legislation.
Democratic officials said they feared that the disclosure of their largest donations would underscore the party's reliance on monied interests at a time when some leading Democrats are facing Senate investigations about their fund-raising practices and when members of Congress are calling for tightening the campaign finance laws.
Some of the individual contributions to the Republican Party were as much as $100,000.
 
Funds Are Unregulated
Donations to a political party that are not channeled directly to campaigns are not subject to Federal regulations. But they are often used by the party for voter drives and other efforts that help specific candidates. The parties are not required to disclose these funds, which are called ''soft money,'' as opposed to ''hard money'' that goes to the candidates. But advocates of new restrictions on political fund raising have pressed the parties to be more forthcoming about where their money comes from. 
The use of these funds is the subject of a simmering conflict between Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic Party chairman, and George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader. Mr. Brown and several Democratic state party chairmen have opposed many of the proposed new restrictions on how the parties use unregulated funds out of concern that they would hinder a major party effort this year to use this money to bolster Democratic slates in several states.
At the same time, Mr. Mitchell has made provisions regulating these funds a centerpiece of the campaign finance legislation he is sponsoring, which is pending in the Senate.
The Republicans are also more successful in collecting money that goes directly to the candidates and thus have not been as outspoken in opposing efforts to restrict these contributions. Republican officials said donations to the party that were not channeled directly to campaigns accounted for about 20 percent of their total receipts last year. That total was about $35 million. $2.7 Million for Democrats In February, Democratic officals said in interviews that they had collected $2.7 million in fund not channeled to campaigns in 1989, and they said they would release a list of the donors within days. But Mr. Brown has postponed the disclosure of the names indefinitely.
Ginny Terzano, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said: ''We believe in disclosure, and Brown has said time and again that we will release a list of non-Federal donors. But because of the reform legislation that is coming up, we waited on it and postponed it. We did not want to interfere with the process now going on on the Hill.''
Ms. Terzano added, ''We have nothing to hide.''
But another party official, speaking on the condition that he not be named, gave another reason.
''We didn't want to be used as an example, that this is the bad side of non-Federal money,'' the official said.
Mary Matalin, chief of staff for Lee Atwater, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said, ''On our side, soft money has had the effect of strengthening the state parties.'' The party has not actively lobbied to preserve its ability to raise such money, she said, because ''Senate Republicans understand how the system works'' and would not favor restrictions on donations to the party not channeled to campaigns, except for new disclosure requirements.
 
Voluntary Disclosures
From time to time, the Republican and Democratic Parties voluntarily make public some of these donations. The Republicans' last disclosure was before the 1988 election; the Democrats' disclosure was soon after that election. But officials in both parties concede that they never release the names of all these contributors and that there is no way of knowing exactly how much money they raise and from whom. Nor do the parties provide tallies of money that they help raise directly through state party committees.
The Republican Party's decision today to permit a reporter for The New York Times to review a list of 4,250 donors from 1989 was in response to a request. The list was headed, ''selected contributor report'' and included no information on how the money was spent.
But it was clear from the disclosure that even in the year after a successful Presidential campaign, when donors have often given all they thought they would, thousands of wealthy people and major corporations still found it in their interest to make sizable donations.
Many donors are longtime financial backers of the party. Individuals who gave $100,000 to the party last year include Joseph J. Bogdanovich, chairman of Star-Kist Foods; Roy M. Huffington, founder of a Houston oil company; Monty Hundley, a Manhattan-based hotel owner; Alexander P. Papamarkou, a Manhattan investment adviser, and Bertram R. Firestone, a Virginia horse breeder and race track owner.
Companies that contributed $100,000 included the Beatrice Corporation of Chicago; the Salem Leasing Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C.; Hibbard Brown & Company of New York, and Sonic Communications of Walnut Creek, Calif. RJR Nabisco of Wilkes Barre, Pa., gave $104,960.
Advocates of eliminating the loophole through which the parties raise and spend unregulated money argue that in accepting large contributions, the parties are becoming increasingly reliant on wealthy interests. They contend that these contributions render meaningless the spending limits in Presidential campaigns.
Ellen S. Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, which has lobbied for stricter laws to regulate these donations, said she believes the Democrats are embarrassed by their increasing reliance on major donors.
''It is perfectly conceivable that one of the reasons they don't want to show this money is that people will be alerted and reminded that there are many, many $100,000 contributors out there,'' she said. ''And these contributors have economic and legislative interests. The disclosure of these fat cat contributors might spur reform in such a way and to such a degree that the party will find untenable.''

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
'The German Question Remains Open'

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN

 BODY:
The message from the President of the United States was delivered to me on the Lufthansa plane even before the takeoff for Germany.
''George Bush: The Time Has Come to Forgive the German Holocaust,'' read the major headline in the German newspaper that the flight attendant offered me when I sat down.
I told the President and myself, as I buckled in, that there was no statute of limitations about forgiveness of a volcano that had spewed death and fire. What counted was to make sure that the volcano was cold and out, before settling down on its slopes again.
It seemed to me that ever since the collapse of Communism in East Germany brought down the Berlin wall, and started the rush toward unification, the world's leaders have been deliberately avoiding talking about the fear that the idea of a larger, stronger Germany fires in so many minds around the world. 
But by their moral casualness about a unification they never thought would take place, the Western nations have been saying there is nothing to worry about. But I did not believe them, nor did millions of others who belong to the blitzkrieged nations or the slaughtered peoples.
I believed unification could not be stopped. The passion of the East Germans surging through the wall was a song of testimony to freedom and wasn't that what we all wanted, for ourselves and for all people?
But, on the plane I thought again that without even giving the fears a chance to be heard, with hardly a pause to remember the scores of millions killed by the last unified Germany, the allies were giving their blessing to a new unified Germany. No attempt to remove the fears of the living, no prayers said for the dead.
Then I remembered a conversation that I had at a small party with a young German lawyer visiting the United States, just a day before I left.
She told me quietly that whenever she thought of all the Jews and so many others killed by Germans a half-century ago, just a minute in the memory, she felt personally guilty.
I said that she was too young to be personally guilty. I said it was even dangerous to think so, because unreal guilt can lead to real hatred.
She looked at me in some astonishment and said:
''But then what do you want us to do?''
I visited Bonn, the elegant port city of Hamburg, the Berlins, briefly Schwerin and Dresden in East Germany - all told, too much too fast. But for me it was more Germany than ever before.
Except for three short inescapable visits over the years, I had avoided Germany because I did not choose to try to keep a civil tongue or a civil face among those I felt would have stood by while my children and I were murdered. I did not choose to hear their reasons why they could not have helped and anyway could not have possibly known.
Still, I became sort of an expert in German efficiency. Living as a reporter for a couple of years in the Poland of the late 50's showed me how swiftly and completely Germans could turn almost a whole nation into rubble, blood and bones.
And I felt I knew all I cared to know then about German history and the German soul. On both, every Jew is a specialist.
So on this trip there was no epiphany for me in Germany, no sudden revelation and certainly no emotional reconciliation.
Sometimes I would feel real warmth flowing back and forth between me and Germans. That would happen when I talked with small, earnest groups of young Germans in Bonn and Berlin. They had studied the Holocaust. I knew we were trying to reach through to each other.
Then somebody in the group would complain about how hard it was on the Germans to be so feared. Why did everybody keep emphasizing the ''negative'' side of German history and not Beethoven or Goethe?
Or, riding around Berlin these past days, I would come across something like the squat waterside mansion where the final extermination of the Jews had been planned. The house of murder sits among trees and flowers.
Once I walked past a memorial list of concentration camps on a stanchion at a busy Berlin crossroads. I knew it was meant well - a reminder to the passers-by.
But I felt again the anger rise within me. I have no apology for the anger; it seems the least possible memorial to the dead.
But few trips turned out to be more important to me. The reason was that the visit removed from me a personal weight of hypocrisy. I always had said that I did not lump all middle-aged and older Germans together as tainted by the history of their nation. But I did. Now I do not.
I always believed the children of Germany were not responsible for the sins of their fathers. But I always thought of them as children of their parents - not as separate. Now I do not. I see them as separate, with their own fate to create.
Hypocrisy clouds the mind. Now I feel clearer - not gentler, just clearer.
There were a few surprises for me. One was that there was almost as little real discussion about the moral and political meaning of the creation of a stronger Germany as in the United States. I had been told by Americans at home and by Germans in letters that there was much more.
Unification talk dominates the country. But I found that Germans were interested in an aspect of unification that did not move me at all -money.
All they seem to be interested in talking about is how much it would cost West Germany to subsidize and change backward East Germany.
I wanted to talk about how to make sure a united Germany did not mean a greater threat. They wanted to talk about how to make sure a united Germany did not mean a weaker Deutsche mark.
The second surprise was how little patriotic enthusiasm I found in younger West Germans for unity.
For the most part they did not oppose it. But they told me that East Germans had such a different political and educational background that they were ''as different as Orientals.'' I was also surprised by the constant effort of West German officials to minimize the importance of unification. I was told jokes about how inefficient the East Germans were; worse than Poles, one chap in Bonn said, and then recovered himself.
German businessmen do not minimize it. They are making plans for new factories in East Germany. Real estate people hope to make millions buying up dilapidated estates of early German movie stars in Potsdam and turning them into luxury homes for West Berliners. They think that any economic loss Germany suffers as a result of unification will be handsomely made up in a couple of years.
German officials say that economic integration of Western Europe outdates any fears - no one country will be able to dominate the Continent.
Maybe they are right. But the cost of being wrong will fall not just on Germans but on the whole world.
''But what do you want us to do?'' I heard that question put to me not only in New York but in Bonn, Hamburg and Berlin.
The answer is for Germany to do itself what the Western allies have failed even to try.
First, recognize and acknowledge that the already dominant economic power of Germany in Europe plus Germany's own history create legitimate fears about a unified, more powerful Germany - not just fantasies or phobias. Military and economic agreements last only as long as the most powerful signatory wants them to last. Denial increases fear.
Germany can then seize the opportunity suddenly available to it to diminish the fears. That is, ask the nations and peoples that have suffered from Germany's history to meet with Germans in Germany to bring out their fears and whatever plans or hopes they have of making sure that the past does not await.
Before and after unification, Germans can establish in Germany a continuing conclave between Germans and people from the nations Germany invaded and the peoples it slaughtered. Yes, officials should take part, but also artists, scientists, students and workers.
No doubt they will waste time and bore each other frequently. But perhaps they will come up with ideas on how the world can live with a new Germany in something approaching trust and truth. Perhaps they can work out what freedom of action Germany must give up for that boon.
Over the decades of a divided Germany, West German diplomats always had the same sentence to emphasize that unification was the goal: ''Die Deutsche Frage bleibt offen.''
Unless Germany itself makes sure that all the victims of its history can express their fears and hopes, that sentence will echo generation after generation in a dozen languages:
''The German Question remains open.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Tax the Toxics Out of the Environment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With politicians from President Bush on down lecturing on the benefits of the market economy, we seem reluctant to take our own advice on environmental protection. We insist on periodic political combat to set a new round of rigid standards. We ignore that we can only guess at the relationship of these hard-fought standards to human health or even to environmental quality. When results fall short of expectations, we are compelled to repeat this ritual.
A more flexible and self-correcting approach relies on taxes to insure that health and environmental costs are reflected in the final cost of a product or service. Consumers and producers can then make intelligent choices without the bureaucratic overhead. It would let the political process define goals and use taxes to achieve them.
Think of it as an environmental value-added tax, a VAT, where the tax is not proportional to economic value but to health risk, environmental damage, public disposal costs. The most important feature is that the tax schedules remain flexible and be modified over time to adapt to market behavior and to scientific and technological developments.
Instead of a Congressionally mandated shock every 10 years or so, the tax schedules could be administratively fine-tuned to yield short-term benefits by influencing consumer choices and, when needed, phase in more substantive changes in coordination with product-process development cycles. An example would be a tax on gasoline to limit its adverse impact on the environment.
An environmental tax-based approach would allow more environmental protection with fewer job losses. There should also be no problem disposing of the additional revenue.
 
CHRISTIAN VAN SCHAYK
St. Petersburg, Fla., April 17, 1990
 The writer is an economist.

HEADLINE: Michael Milken's Guilt

 BODY:
Michael Milken is a crook. He admitted that much in U.S. District Court Tuesday when he pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to put up $600 million, $200 million of that in fines, to settle the biggest fraud case in the history of the securities industry.
Mr. Milken's public admission ends four years of obdurate denial of wrongdoing, virtually assures a prison term and opens the possibility of further fraud prosecutions. For those reasons, and also to avoid the uncertain outcome of a phenomenally complex jury trial, the Government's decision to accept the plea bargain is justified. But even if justified, the outcome is deeply unsatisfying. 
At one level, the likely punishment for these few admitted crimes will be light compared with that of criminals who steal money the old-fashioned way. At another level, the plea bargain is unsatisfying because it masks more than it uncovers. It masks the nature of Mr. Milken's personal crimes. And it masks the relationship between the market for the high-risk - junk - bonds he created and the crimes he committed.
The Government believes that Mr. Milken, in the process of becoming the ''king'' of junk bonds, engaged in a long pattern of lining his own pockets at the expense of his clients and his employer, Drexel Burnham Lambert.
But by comparison, the six felonies to which he pleaded guilty are serious yet technical securities violations and did not directly enrich him. His lawyer has even characterized them as an overzealous attempt to help friends.
The plea bargain allows theft to be cloaked as misguided loyalty. That's reason enough to hope the court will be able to release the extensive report the Government is expected to file before Mr. Milken is sentenced.
The plea bargain reinforces another misconception. In his statement to the court, Mr. Milken explained that his ''business was in no way dependent on these practices. Nor did they comprise a fundamental part of our business.'' That claim is, at best, a self-serving half-truth.
The junk bond markets that Mr. Milken orchestrated did feed credit to many promising new businesses - like MCI Communications - that had been turned away by commercial banks. Mr. Milken proudly, and correctly, claims credit for helping to create thousands of jobs in vibrant new industries.
But junk bonds also provided the borrowed money that financial buccaneers used in their frenzied corporate takeovers; such leveraged buyouts are an innovation of debatable economic value. In some cases, the new managers streamlined and improved their businesses' operations. In others, the corporate raiders buried themselves in debt and drove healthy companies into bankruptcy.
Whatever its long-term value, the world of junk bonds that Mr. Milken created did not work the way ordinary markets do. This was a highly personal world in which he intervened to match buyer and seller and depended on an intricate network of reciprocal obligation. He would sell the junk bonds of Corporation X only if it agreed, at least tacitly, to buy the junk bonds of Corporation Y at an advantageous time.
The stakes were immense and the identities of the players were often kept secret. The opportunities to cheat clients, the Internal Revenue Service and regulators were numerous and lucrative. Drexel, for example, would lend money to investors who were buying stocks based on the predicted outcome of deals that Drexel itself was arranging. There was obvious temptation to trade illegally on the basis of privileged information.
True, junk bonds can be sold without manipulation or deceit. But that requires extraordinary personal integrity. Tuesday showed that the King had no such moral compass.

HEADLINE: Roosevelt Island: A 'Wonderful' Experiment Still Building

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Twenty years after New York City and state officials decided to create a new community on Roosevelt Island, integrated by race and income, the social experiment has been hailed as a success while the housing development is still struggling toward completion.
''It is a piece of social engineering that worked,'' said Edward J. Logue, the former head of the State Urban Development Corporation who led development efforts for the island in the 1970's.
But Mr. Logue, along with many present and former public officials and some Roosevelt Island residents, remains frustrated at the slow pace of development on the cigar-shaped island in the East River. Though the first new housing there in more than a decade was completed last year, nearly 2,000 of the 5,000 apartments envisioned by the original planners have still not been built. 
An ambitious and complicated proposal announced last October by state housing officials for the final 1,956 apartments attracted little interest from private developers, apparently because of fears about New York's flat real-estate market.
 
Options Being Considered
The plan called for the creation of nearly 1,000 luxury apartments, to be sold at market rates. Some of the profits from the sales would be used to help subsidize almost 1,000 apartments for low-, moderate- and middle-income New Yorkers. The city and the state also would contribute subsidies to make the apartments affordable.
No developers bid for the key market-rate component of the plan, and state officials are now reconsidering it. Among the options are waiting until New York's housing market improves or reducing the number of subsidized apartments.
Many of those disappointed with the island's development say they are relieved that it was not completed quickly by foresaking the original vision of the community: racial and economic integration. ''In a very creative way, Roosevelt Island has muddled through,'' said Theodore Liebman, an architect who was the urban development agency's chief of architecture under Mr. Logue.
''One of the exciting things to me is that it didn't give in, in times of no subsidies, and did not just create a couple of thousand units of luxury housing,'' Mr. Liebman said. ''The most important thing is the creation of a mixed-income neighborhood.''
Several things give residents and planners confidence about the future. One is the affection that many residents have for the island.
''This is still a wonderful place,'' said Sandra Blake Neis, president of both the local P.T.A. and the Roosevelt Island Residents Association and a resident for 13 years. ''I wanted to be somewhere that seemed safe and was like the country. And yet it's also four or five minutes from Bloomingdale's. My children get to know all kinds of people, and I think that's really important.''
Many black residents said they were attracted to the island because they knew they could rent or buy housing without risking discrimination. Many black and white parents said they wanted the opportunity to send their children to a good integrated school.
Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, an industry group, moved to Roosevelt Island with her husband and two daughters in 1978. The children were in private school at the time, and the Becks wanted to send them to the island's public school. ''We wanted them to be with youngsters from a wide variety of backgrounds,'' she said.
Four original apartment buildings, with a total of 2,141 units, were constructed in the early and mid-1970's, built primarily for moderate- and middle-income families, using state subsidies. Low-income families with Federal rent subsidies also rented units.
 
A New Cluster
A new cluster of five buildings, called Manhattan Park, was completed last year. It has 1,100 apartments, with 20 percent set aside for low-income families, under one of the last Federal programs for new housing. The rest of the apartments are being rented at market rates, as high as $3,300 a month.
About 14 percent of the island's residents are black and about 9 percent are Hispanic, the 1980 census found. State officials estimate that the proportions remained stable over the last decade.
The state created an independent corporation in 1985 to manage the island and plan its future. Its president, Rosina K. Abramson, has presided over completion of Manhattan Park and a host of improvements, from a new indoor tennis center to a new park.
''I'm a fan of Rosina,'' said Mr. Logue, now a consultant and developer in Boston, who keeps a close watch on the island. ''She's the first person who clearly had the responsibility to run the place and do things with it.''
Ms. Abramson said her top priority was finishing the housing plan, both for its symbolic value and for the amenities that a larger population would attract and sustain. She likes to say Roosevelt Island may be the only place in Manhattan where the quality of life would improve with more people.
Before the building of Manhattan Park, Roosevelt Island had a population of 5,100. When the new development is completely rented - it is now about 70 percent full, officials say -the island is expected to have about 7,400 people. The population is still too small to qualify for a branch of the public library, nor have there been enough stores, restaurants or other basic services to make the community complete.
 
A Delayed Subway Line
One key to Roosevelt Island's future - a short subway line that connects it to Manhattan - finally opened last October, 14 years behind schedule. Construction of the last 2,000 apartments depended on the subway because the aerial tramway that connects the island to the rest of Manhattan could not have accommodated more passengers at peak hours. (The city government technically considers the island part of the borough of Manhattan.) Some racial tensions have also arisen. Most of the low-income residents who moved into Manhattan Park are black or Hispanic families. Ms. Neis, the P.T.A. president, said the demographics of the local elementary school had shifted slightly as a result. ''We've had some white flight,'' she said. ''And I have parents who count how many white kids are in the class.''
The actual number of students leaving the school has been small. Fifty-one percent of the school had been white, she said, and now 49 percent is white.
Ms. Neis, who is black, said she was hurt that some white parents removed their children from the school because it now had more minority students.
She said, though, that she was optimistic that most white residents continued to find integration one of the compelling attractions of Roosevelt Island. ''It's something we really want to hold on to,'' she said.
 
Tax-Exempt Bonds
With the subway in place, only one thing is missing to make possible the island's completion: money. Ms. Abramson, who heads the island's corporation, and Richard L. Higgins, State Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, said they hoped that after revision their plan for the last 2,000 apartments would succeed.
The state might float tax-exempt bonds to help finance the new buildings, Mr. Higgins said. The proportion of subsidized to unsubsidized units might also be changed, he said.
''We're ready to go,'' Ms. Abramson said. ''All we need is the money.''

HEADLINE: Officials Fear Albany Cuts Will Raise Local Taxes

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 25

 BODY:
While Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders continue their private negotiations on how to slash state spending, local officials fear that they may be the ones who get bloodied, both fiscally and politically.
Just as the Governor rails against Republicans in Washington for shifting the Federal tax burden to the states, New York's mayors and county executives complain that the state has been passing the buck along to them.
And the local leaders, many of whom are besieged by residents' rebellions against property tax increases, realize that they stand at the end of the line.
''On the local level, there's no place to hide,'' said Patrick G. Halpin, the Suffolk County Executive, a Democrat. ''You can't run to Albany or Washington to escape the attention.'' 
 
Frustratingly Little Information
Because the talks about filling the $1.8 billion gap in this year's state budget have been secretive, little is known about how local governments will ultimately be affected. Local leaders, who have budgets of their own to plan, are frustrated by the lack of information from Albany as negotiators finish work on a budget that is 25 days overdue.
They fear that they will be asked to absorb major cuts in social-service programs like Medicaid and welfare at a time when a weakening economy is stoking demand for those programs. But given that the only list of cuts in social services released by Mr. Cuomo includes vague entries like ''additional reductions - $49.3 million,'' many of their calculations are based on guesswork.
A plan announced today by Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders would save local governments $200 million by reducing their contributions to public employee pension systems. But local leaders believe the pension windfall may not completely offset expected cuts in social services, and they maintain it will not reverse the trend of local governments having to absorb state budget cuts by raising property taxes and cutting services.
''What the state is doing is forcing costs back on the local taxpayer and forcing local government to pay the state's bill,'' said Onondaga County Executive Nicholas J. Pirro, a Republican. ''And local government officials pay the price politically.''
That is a charge that Mr. Cuomo does not necessarily deny. But he argues that the responsibility for soaring property tax rates begins with the Republicans in Washington, who began the initiative that drastically reduced Federal aid to states as well as income-tax rates in the last 10 years.
Mr. Cuomo concedes that the shifting of the tax burden will be pushed along by his grudging compromise with the Senate's Republican leaders to preserve the last phase of a four-year cut in the state's personal-income tax.
''It's not the best thing to do,'' he said at a news conference on Tuesday. ''You cut the income tax when you're broke and you have to raise all the other taxes and the property tax goes up.''
 
Local Aid Increases
While conceding that the state's fiscal problems prevent it from doing all he would like for local governments, Mr. Cuomo points out that the share of the state's budget for local assistance has grown to 67 percent from 60 percent in his eight years as governor.
Almost half of that increase, however, has gone to education and another quarter has been absorbed by Medicaid, leaving local governments to rely more on their own revenues to provide other services. Excluding aid to education, the share of local government revenues provided by state and Federal sources dropped to 17 percent in 1988 from 21 percent in 1983, Mr. Cuomo's first year as governor.
Many local governments have relied on property taxes to make up the difference. A study by the New York Conference of Mayors showed that 87 percent of the state's cities and villages raised property taxes between 1986 and 1989, with the average three-year increase totaling 24 percent.
In the 24 counties that have responded to a survey being conducted by the New York State Association of Counties, property taxes increased last year by an average of 14 percent.
 
'It Must Be Your Fault'
In Broome County, for instance, property taxes were raised 42 percent last year, and County Executive Timothy Grippen attributes 10 percent of the increase to state budget cuts, including the elimination of revenue sharing for counties and restrictions on reimbursements for social-services programs.
''I'm glad I'm not up for re-election next year,'' said Mr. Grippen, a Democrat who is a year into his first four-year term. ''People don't want to hear about Federal cuts or the end of state revenue sharing. They just know it's you that's sitting there so it must be your fault.''
In Suffolk County, Mr. Halpin faces a different kind of problem. To quell a taxpayer revolt instigated by a 48 percent increase in property taxes last year, he took a two-year pledge not to raise them further. But with sales-tax revenues also stagnant, Mr. Halpin fears he will have to cut an already threadbare budget if Suffolk is pinched by the state.
He most fears cuts in Medicaid and welfare programs, which are financed jointly by Federal, state and county governments. Because the state mandates that those services be provided, cutbacks in the state budget often require counties to absorb the loss.
Among the projects that could be hurt is a Suffolk pilot program to save both the state and county money by certifying disabled people for Federal assistance, thereby removing them from county welfare rolls. Last year the program saved more than $3 million, and savings of $9 million are projected for this year.
Suffolk officials have lobbied to have such cost-saving programs exempted from state cuts. ''It just doesn't make any sense,'' said William W. Bartsch, Suffolk County's deputy director of social services. ''It's like firing the cashier in the supermarket and saying you reduced your payroll. Meanwhile, everyone's walking out of the market with bags of groceries.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2126 words

HEADLINE: The High Cost of Peace Jolts a Connecticut Factory Town

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTVILLE, Conn.

 BODY:
For most of the 1980's, this town 10 miles north of New London was awash in money from the nation's military build-up. Many of the 17,000 residents commuted to the Electric Boat submarine shipyard in nearby Groton. Others worked at the local UNC Naval Products plant, which builds nuclear reactors for submarines.
But as the cold war thaws and pressure grows to cut the defense budget, the price of peace is starting to become evident here in southeastern Connecticut, long among the nation's regions most dependent on military spending.
Electric Boat, maker of the Trident missile-launching submarine, has not lost any jobs. But this year UNC laid off 166 of its 1,060 employees. This month the company told the remaining workers that they would be dismissed within three years. The next round of layoffs, about 100, are to occur on June 10. 
 
'Tough Times Ahead'
Of the first layoffs, 117 have been prompted by a Navy decision to cut production of its fast-attack submarines.
All the rest are because of a cost-cutting decision by the Department of Energy to give all future marine reactor work to a single contractor, UNC's competitor.
''We are going to have some tough times ahead,'' said Montville's First Selectman, Wayne D. Scott.
In many areas where military contracts help fuel the economy, immediate layoffs remain more a distant fear than a reality. Just a few miles away in Groton, for example, Electric Boat officials are almost bullish about the future. Besides the Trident, the company is building the nation's first Seawolf submarine, a nuclear-powered attack vessel.
 
'We Have a Backlog'
''There are uncertainties,'' said Electric Boat's director of communications, Neil D. Ruenzel. ''Nevertheless we have a backlog and are looking ahead to continuing programs.''
In Montville, though, the military contracts are scheduled to stop, and the economic aftershocks are already rippling through the area's non-defense businesses, from realtors to pizzerias. Town officials also worry about large reductions in their tax bases.
UNC workers talk of winning the cold war only to lose their livelihood.
''The defense workers of America have paid the premiums of peace through their labor and efforts and dedication, but the peace dividend is going to be paid overseas,'' said James B. Rusiecki, a supervisor of electronic technologies. ''That dividend should be turned around and put back into the defense industry for retooling. It's only fair.''
 
Elimination of Competition
The main blow to UNC is a directive by the Department of Energy giving all future construction work on marine nuclear reactors to Babcock & Wilcox of Lynchburg, Va. In some areas of work, particularly those that produce a small volume of products, military officials consider using a single supplier more cost-effective than requiring competition between contractors.
The layoffs astonished UNC employees, many of whom are highly skilled technicians or engineers involved in classified work. As recently as December, they believed that they would be spared projected spending cuts because the Navy and its submarine program appeared the least vulnerable.
Indeed, when the layoffs were announced, UNC was two months shy of starting operations at a new $60 million reactor factory at the 32-year-old, 242-acre complex in the Uncasville section of Montville.
''It's now just sitting there, ready to be dismantled,'' Mr. Rusiecki said.
 
Petition Asks U.S. Aid
This month several hundred UNC employees and their families held a rally at the town's St. Bernard High School to express their concerns to a panel of visiting Congressmen. They also presented a 20,000-name petition asking the Government to supply either enough work to sustain the company or funds to attract non-defense industry to the area.
''We feel that some of the money that's being saved in defense should come back to us,'' said Charla McDermott, a UNC quality-control worker who lives in nearby Bozrah.
At the meeting were Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury, who sits on the sea power subcommittee of the Armed Forces Committee; Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut; Representative Sam Gejdenson of Bozrah and Representative Bruce A. Morrison of New Haven. Mr. Rowland, a Republican, and Mr. Morrison, a Democrat, are candidates for governor.
''This may be the first economic blow because of the peace dividend,'' Mr. Rowland said. Joining them was Dr. Robert M. Rauner, director of the Office of Economic Conversion. He noted that after World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War, the nation endured greater military reductions.
''It's a growing problem,'' he said. ''But it's just part of the defense industry dynamic.''
 
'Too Good for Too Long'
The lawmakers promised to a try a variety of remedies, including introducing legislation that would allow UNC to continue to compete with Babcock & Wilcox. They also promised to urge the Department of Energy to provide UNC with non-defense projects and to allow the company to do work for some foreign nations.
They cautioned, though, that diversification may arrive too late to save UNC. Asked why Montville had not aggressively sought non-military businesses, Mr. Scott said: ''Things have been too good for too long.''
Montville is home for 156 UNC employees and their families; the rest are scattered in neighboring towns like Norwich, Bozrah and Ledyard. The company is a subsidiary of UNC Inc. of Annapolis, Md., which has 12 divisions and 5,200 employees nationwide. A phase-out of a smaller UNC division in Montville, UNC Aerospace, is expected to be completed later this year.
 
Help to Displaced Offered
Robert F. Bonito, the vice president for human resources at UNC, said the company would offer job counseling and support services to laid-off workers for as long as necessary. He also said he believed that most employees would have little trouble finding work if they were willing to move.
''These are quality people,'' he said, adding that the average length of service at the company was 13 years.
Mr. Bonito said UNC would continue to assist in efforts to obtain new Federal work and attract non-defense industry. He was pessimistic about the prospects, though.
''If something doesn't happen in six months, we'll lose our resources,'' he said. ''Not equipment - people.'' Mr. Bonito said UNC would continue to assist in efforts to obtain new Federal work and attract non-defense industry. He was pessimistic about the prospects, though.
''If something doesn't happen in six months, we'll lose our resources,'' he said. ''Not equipment - people.''

HEADLINE: Police Say Drug-Program Profiles Are Not Biased

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
All but 2 of the 210 people arrested last year in a drug-interdiction program at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown were black or Hispanic, the bistate agency said yesterday.
But the agency insisted that the program, which use profiles of possible drug dealers and couriers, was free of racial discrimination.
A judge in Manhattan has thrown out crucial evidence in the drug arrest of a young black woman in the terminal on the ground that the profiles were almost exclusively aimed at black and Hispanic travelers. A police search found that the woman was carrying several ounces of cocaine, but the judge ruled that the search was illegal. 
The judge, Acting Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court, said she based her ruling on the fact that not one of the defendants arrested by the Port Authority police and taken before her for arraignment was white.
 
Problem With Stereotyping
The police profiles involve characteristics that might seem innocent by themselves but when taken together provide what the police say are strong clues to drug trafficking. They include factors like buying a one-way ticket, paying with cash or being obviously in a hurry.
Although Justice Berkman's ruling has focused new attention on police profiles, the Supreme Court of the United States has upheld their use. Critics contend, however, that since that decision last year, arrests of black and Hispanic suspects have significantly increased. To be black or Hispanic, the critics say, invites the police to draw a racial stereotype of criminal behavior.
The deputy director of the Port Authority public safety department, Salvatore Samperi, disputed such criticism and insisted that the Port Authority profiles were color blind.
He and other law-enforcement officials said profiles were necessary for transient populations, to sort out the criminals from the law-abiding citizens.
Virtually all the people arrested last year at the terminal were black and Hispanic, he said, because the program focuses on long-distance travelers, and nearly 90 percent of those passengers are members of minority groups. ''If you analyze the drug arrests made by the New York City police in areas such as Washington Heights and Harlem,'' Mr. Samperi said. ''you will find the same percentage of those arrested are black or Hispanic.''
 
Reflection of Other Factors
Several criminal-justice officials said the ratio of arrests reflected a ''reality of the streets'' rather than a policy of racial discrimination.
Even defense advocates like the Legal Aid Society said the preponderance of black and Hispanic arrests reflected the economic facts that most people who committed crimes were poor and that black and Hispanic people were the poorest in the city.
In her ruling, released on Tuesday, Justice Berkman harshly criticized the Port Authority for ''discriminatory law enforcement,'' which, she said, ''does incalculable damage to our civil liberties and which produces at best questionable results for the war on drugs.''
 
Ratio in Holding Cells
Justice Berkman's ruling dealt with a tiny percentage of the defendants taken to the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street. But it also reflected the reality of arraignment courts. On a given day, the defendants in holding cells awaiting arraignments are overwhelmingly black or Hispanic.
''Of course the criminal-justice system is racially biased,'' said Sterling Johnson Jr, the special narcotics prosecutor. Mr. Johnson, whose office prosecuted the case criticized by Justice Berkman, also said the profiles of criminal behavior used by narcotics police could ''absolutely be racially inspired.''
Mr. Johnson, who is black, said, ''The only thing we can do when that happens is weed it out.''
As for the impression that virtually everyone arrested on the street is a black or Hispanic suspect, Mr. Johnson added, ''It's a lot easier for the police to arrest a mugger and a drug seller than it is a forger, a wife beater or a discreet drug user in the suburbs.''
The city's new Criminal Justice Coordinator, former Justice Milton Mollen, said the disproportionate number of black and Hispanic defendants troubled him, too.
''How can you say if the ratio is a result of racism or reality?'' he asked yesterday. ''I'm not sure I'm capable of answering that question. I'm not sure there is any easy answer.
''But it all starts when the police arrest people, and I cannot accept the charge that the police only go out and arrest blacks and Hispanics and are reluctant to arrest whites. What I believe is that the arrest figures are a sad commentary on our society in that they relect the reality of the streets.''
The head of the Legal Aid Society, Archibald Murray, said: ''The police arrest the poorest people who have the least, and that happens to be the black and Hispanics of this city. Arrests are mostly made at the bottom of the economic ladder.
''But there is a need to make the criminal-justice system respond more apporopriately to that reality. Blacks and Hispanics are not inherently criminal, even though that is a common and mistaken impression. People become criminals because they are poor.''

HEADLINE: Milken's Sentence;
Leniency to Be Sought on Argument That 'Junk Bonds' Helped Business

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
Although the guilty pleas that Michael R. Milken entered on Tuesday were not to selling ''junk bonds,'' his legal team is planning to make the high-risk, high-yield securities a focal point of his attempt to avoid a long prison sentence.
Mr. Milken, the former head of the junk bond division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., faces a maximum prison term of 28 years when he is sentenced for securities laws violations. His counsel expect him to get no more than five years, but some legal scholars would not be surprised if he received eight years, and more is possible. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood who has scheduled sentencing for October, has been on the bench only since 1988, too short a time for lawyers to discern a pattern in sentencing. 
Nor can they predict with confidence how she will react to the arguments planned by Mr. Milken's lawyers and public relations team - that he is a statesman-like financier whose junk bond sales did significant good for the downtrodden among corporate America, which were unable to obtain money elsewhere.
 
Lack of Cooperation a Factor
Mr. Milken is precluded from using many of the standard pleas for leniency because of the breadth of the charges, his wealth and his lack of cooperation with Government investigators.
He and his lead lawyer, Arthur L. Liman, foreshadowed his argument on Tuesday in separate statements at the United States Courthouse.
''It is an enormous accomplishment for Michael to have been instrumental in finding the capital for hundreds of American corporations, which are generating jobs, providing a livelihood for hundreds of thousands of people,'' Mr. Liman said in a statement on the courthouse steps at Foley Square on Tuesday. ''It is Michael's hope that in the long run history will see his violations in context and judge him not just on the basis of his lapses but on the basis of the contributions that he made to the economy and to the American people.''
Some legal scholars are not impressed by that argument and suggest it could even cause the judge to impose a relatively steep sentence.
''The notion that junk bonds did a lot of good strikes me as a non sequitur,'' said Joel Seligman, a professor of securities regulation at the University of Michigan Law School. ''Whatever good they did, it doesn't justify violating the law.''
 
Other Arguments for Leniency
And that will not be the only basis for seeking leniency in sentencing. Lawyers and people involved in the case said that Mr. Milken would probably argue that the Government has already barred him from the American securities industry for life and that he has suffered close to four years of difficult publicity and scrutiny. He will also probably cite his enormous contributions over the years to a variety of charities through his private foundations.
But the thrust of his arguments is expected to be the contention that his work with junk bonds helped hundreds of small corporations expand and provided jobs for hundreds of thousands.
Some critics of debt financing, however, point to other aspects of the junk market. While many small and less creditworthy companies did expand by raising money through high-yield, high-risk instruments, estimates are that about half of the funds raised through junk bonds in the last decade have gone either for corporate takeovers or for reorganizations to avoid unsolicited takeover bids. According to the Securities Data Company of Newark, $71 billion of the $153.7 billion issued between 1980 and 1989 in junk bonds went to acquisition-related activities.
 
Heavy Cost to Taxpayers
And about 7 percent of the junk bonds were placed in the portfolios of savings and loans institutions, many of which have since collapsed, costing taxpayers billions of dollars.
But Mr. Milken's legal team cannot rely on the arguments that have won relatively lenient treatment for other Wall Street felons. They cannot argue, for example, that their client will be destitute. Indeed, although he agreed to pay a record-breaking fine of $600 million, he earned $1.1 billion in compensation alone.
Nor apparently will he be able to claim that he has provided any substantial assistance to the Government in tracking down other criminals. This defense worked particularly well in mitigating the sentences of Ivan F. Boesky, the speculator who served two years of a three-year sentence and settled insider trading charges, and Boyd L. Jefferies, the trader who received probation after pleading guilty to two felony counts.
The breadth of the six charges also prevent his lawyers from maintaining that the case involves a single aberrational instance of wrongdoing. This view was effectively argued by lawyers for Robert M. Freeman, a former partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, who earlier this month drew a four-month prison sentence for a single instance of illegal insider trading.
Judge Wood, a Reagan appointee and a relative newcomer to Foley Square, has earned high praise from a wide number of Government and private lawyers for her diligence and insightful rulings, but no one is predicting confidently what she will do in this case.
''She's an unknown on sentencing,'' a Milken adviser said.
 
Letters of Support Expected
Following a standard formula, the lawyers for Mr. Milken, in asking for mercy, will submit letters deeply supportive of Mr. Milken from business executives, clients, friends and others.
The Government will also file a memorandum that outlines the depths of the crimes Mr. Milken has committed and is expected to ask for a substantial sentence.
Under the terms of the plea agreement, prosecutors may not suggest what terms the judge ought to impose. In past practice, the prosecutors have noted to the judge what punishment would be under the Federal sentencing guidelines, which call for considerably harsher treatment in most white-collar crime and give less latitude to the judge than the previous rules. As a technical matter, the new rules are not applicable to the Milken case because they were adopted after his crimes were committed.
Judge Wood will also be guided by a report prepared by probation officers that presents a profile of Mr. Milken and suggests possible penalties.
