HEADLINE: Shorter Rations for Borrowers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Some companies are complaining that their banks have turned stingy with loans, creating a ''credit crunch'' that could needlessly strangle business activity and cause a recession. For their part, bankers talk about ''prudent'' lending as a reasoned response to a weaker economy and to the tightening of standards by Federal bank regulators.
Is corporate America feeling a genuine credit crunch, a squeeze in which loans are all but unavailable at any price, similar to the one that occurred in 1974?
Federal Reserve officials, economists and bankers say the answer is a qualified ''no.'' They agree that harsher treatment by Federal bank examiners has made bankers more cautious lenders, but they say that a lack of bank lending does not threaten to cause a recession. 
 
Tougher Requirements
Certainly, many small and medium-sized companies are finding loans tougher to get. With increasing frequency, their banks are withdrawing credit lines, demanding that more collateral be put up to back loans, trimming their estimates of the worth of collateral that is offered and taking a generally more suspicious view of borrowers' growth forecasts. There has even been a sharp slowing in some types of lending to individuals, like home-equity loans.
The problem of credit restraint varies considerably by region. Lending for real estate and to smaller companies has been most dramatically crimped in the Northeast, where the economy has slowed sharply after the booming 1980's. Politicians in New England are particularly concerned. The House Small Business Committee held hearings yesterday on the standards used by bank examiners and their effect on the availability of credit in New England.
Yet despite some tightening of lending standards, larger businesses -typically those with annual sales of $100 million and more - still find plenty of willing lenders, the Fed officials, economists and bankers say.
''This is not a credit crunch where suddenly the lenders have no money,'' said Albert Wojnilower, senior adviser to the First Boston Corporation. ''The process now is one of credit restraint where funds are readily available in the financial markets, but banks are tightening their standards.''
Instead of rationing loans by price - as when the Federal Reserve's tight-money policies pushed short-term interest rates above 20 percent in 1980 and 1981 - loans are now being allocated by credit standards set by each bank.
Mr. Wojnilower said both kinds of restraint tend to slow economic growth. But he said the current credit restraint was not severe enough to cause a recession.
With foreign banks accounting for more than a quarter of all business loans, and with the securities markets funneling money to more companies than ever before, analysts say that a credit crunch stemming only from American bankers' reticence is becoming less plausible every year.
Economists note that the gross national product, the output of goods and services, is expected to show a rise of more than 2 percent, at an annual rate after inflation, in the first quarter of 1990. That is up from 1.1 percent in the last quarter of 1989.
''A growth rate of over 2 percent does not describe an economy suffering from a credit crunch,'' said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. He noted that the seven-year-old economic expansion has survived other bouts of regional weakness, like the depression in the oil-producing states in the mid-1980's.
In New England, bankers' restraint is closely linked to the billions of dollars in losses banks have taken on bad real estate loans. With office vacancy rates above 25 percent in some cities in New England and elsewhere on the East Coast, banks began reducing lending last year, even before bank examiners forced them to report large losses early this year.
But recently, the cutback in real estate lending has been supplemented by a less severe but still noticeable reduction in lending to other businesses. In some cases, the cutback has come from banks that had much of their capital wiped out by real estate losses and are now forced to reduce their size to comply with regulators' rules on adequate capital.
In many cases, the cutbacks in bank lending go beyond just eliminating risky borrowers. Joseph Blair, executive director of the Massachusetts Industrial Finance Authority, said that a recent survey of companies showed ''significant problems with the availablity of credit'' even for companies that had previously been judged creditworthy by local banks. Effect on the G.N.P. ''There is no doubt that small and medium-sized companies are having problems getting credit,'' Richard F. Syron, president of the Boston Federal Reserve Bank, said in a telephone interview. ''It's not enough to expect a major impact on G.N.P., but that is scant comfort to someone who borrows $150,000 and is caught in a squeeze not of their own making.''
John P. LaWare, a former Boston banker who is now a governor of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, has spoken several times of anecdotal evidence that credit is now less available. But the most detailed comments by a Fed official on credit availability came last week from the chairman, Alan Greenspan, who said that bank lending to business has expanded this year, though more slowly than it did last year.
He conceded that tougher lending standards have ''potential effects on the level of local economic activity.'' But, he said, the restraint has not been severe or prolonged enough to hurt entire regions.
Bankers acknowledge that they have made some changes recently. But they also note that they have no desire to stop lending entirely, because making loans that are repaid is how banks generate profits.
''We are still trying to increase our market share, but when the regional economy worsens, it is only prudent for a lender to test new loan applications in light of the changed conditions,'' said Brendan J. Dugan, president of National Westminster Bank USA in New York.
 
Lowering Expectations
For example, instead of accepting a borrower's forecast of 15 percent sales growth, the bank might assume a 5 percent growth rate. And some companies that would be considered creditworthy with 15 percent sales growth are denied loans when the lower projection is used.
Chemical Bank is the largest and most active lender to middle-sized companies in the New York area, and its chairman, Walter V. Shipley, said lending standards were indeed a bit tougher. But the change has not been sudden or recent.
''We saw the economy in the Northeast softening about two years ago,'' Mr. Shipley said. Since then, Chemical has sharply cut real estate loans it deemed risky and ''consciously eliminated relationships with middle-market companies that accounted for about $1 billion of loans.''
Those cutbacks may send some customers to Chemical's competitors, but Mr. Shipley said any loss of business would be more than offset by the benefits of avoiding bad loans.
Fed data show that bank lending has grown this year, but at a slower rate than in 1989. Business loans at large banks have increased $3.1 billion since the beginning of the year, slower than the rate that produced a $17.9 billion rise for all of 1989.
But that is still a far cry from a credit crunch, in which loans actually decline. Real estate loans, excluding home-equity loans, also continue to increase, rising $6.7 billion since the beginning of the year, again at a slower rate than in 1989, when such loans rose $43 billion for the year.
In the six-state region tracked by the Boston Federal Reserve Bank, business loans at large banks have fallen 7.9 percent since the beginning of the year, or about $1.8 billion, to $20.8 billion as of April 11.
 
Borrowers Are More Cautious
Not all the slowdown in lending can be attributed to tougher credit standards at banks. When business turns down, experienced companies of all sizes try to ride out the bad times by reducing expenses and holding borrowing to a minimum.
''Rather than the banks turning off the spigot in the New York area, the demand for credit has subsided,'' said Mr. Dugan of National Westminster. ''We don't have to tell most customers to be cautious.''

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Behind the Sale Of Marshall Field

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
THE Dayton Hudson Corporation's $1.04 billion deal to buy Marshall Field & Company, announced last Thursday, shows that despite the recent troubles of several big department stores, a strong economic niche still exists for full-line, broad-based chains, merchants and analysts say.
They also say the aggressive bidding for Marshall Field by major department store companies and by a Field's management team reflected the value still held by huge stores that sell a wide range of wares aimed mostly at affluent customers. But more important, analysts say, is that they have healthy cash flows and good management.
The same could be said of the announced sale of Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday to an international investment group for about $1.5 billion. Saks and Marshall Field were put on the auction block last September by B.A.T. Industries as part of a restructuring plan to offset a hostile takeover bid by Sir James Goldsmith. 
The prices for Saks and Field's were both surprisingly high, but for different reasons, retail executives said. Saks sold at a premium because it is basically in a class by itself as a mass seller of high-fashion goods, they said. The Marshall Field deal centered on the fact that the Chicago retailer offers goods from housewares and furniture to toys and designer clothes - under exclusive labels and store brands - and does so more successfully than most other American department stores.
''Dayton Hudson knows what it is doing in department stores,'' said Robert Buchanan, an analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons of Baltimore. ''It obviously doesn't agree with the critics who say that the department store's day is over because of the big boom in specialty stores.''
With the recent demise, dismantling or fiscal problems of well-known retailers like B. Altman, Bonwit Teller and Bloomingdale's, many critics had pronounced department stores that sell everything from pots and pans to designer dresses as dinosaurs headed for extinction.
Specialty-store rivals, especially, deride what they call the anachronistic clutter of full-line department stores and point to their own relative success in handling only sportswear, high fashion or toys. Retailing consultants have said that stores with a wide array of merchandise had better strip down to their most desirable departments.
But Marshall Field, in Chicago, and Dayton Hudson, in Minneapolis and Detroit, have remained dominant in their home markets as full-price family department stores, making a good profit even as rivals have faltered.
It is not that the successful stores have not changed. Many of them, including Marshall Field, have added or eliminated entire departments.
But executives and analysts say the major distinctions of chains doing well are that they have made sure the customer has a clear perception of what the stores offer, kept up to date with trends and refurbished their stores. Marshall Field just spent more than $100 million to remodel its flagship store on State Street in downtown Chicago.
Analysts say there is little doubt that the purchase of Marshall Field was a good move by Dayton Hudson. ''It gives Dayton Hudson an excellent department store chain, with a strategic geographic fit,'' Mr. Buchanan said.
The move is also a strategic shift for Dayton Hudson. In 1984 it sold its department stores in Phoenix and Oklahoma City and consolidated some operations of its J. L. Hudson stores in Detroit with its Dayton stores in Minneapolis. Since then, Dayton Hudson appears to be retrenching its department store business and expanding its powerful discount chain, Target Stores, which rang up about $7.5 billion of the corporation's sales of more than $13 billion last year.
The latest transaction indicates that Dayton Hudson is not staking its future just on Target and on the moderate-priced Mervyn's clothing stores. By adding Marshall Field's $1.1 billion volume and some expected overall sales growth, Dayton Hudson's department store revenues should rise to about $3.1 billion this year from $1.8 billion last year, analysts say.
But more important for Dayton Hudson is that buying Marshall Field's 24 stores in four states makes Dayton the upper Midwest's biggest operator of middle-to-upper-priced department stores.
''While Dayton Hudson did sell its Southwest stores, the company apparently revised its opinion of department stores, probably because of their improved profitability,'' said Walter F. Loeb, a New York retailing consultant. ''The company's department stores had been growing at an estimated 11 percent annually compounded. The price paid for Field's is a good one, with most people thinking it would be about $800 million.''

HEADLINE: Real Estate Feels the Pain Of Tighter Credit Standards

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The real estate industry, more than any other, is feeling the pinch of the tighter lending standards being applied by banks across the country.
With real estate values falling in some regions, particularly the Northeast, after the generous lending and building boom of the 1980's, some tightening of credit is natural and even welcomed by some developers.
But many real estate professionals say that even some established developers without problem loans now find themselves unable to finance their projects. The problem, they contend, has been made worse by overzealous Federal bank examiners. 
 
Regulators Called 'Intimidating'
''We are in the middle of a real estate credit crunch right now,'' said Kenneth Rosen, chairman of the department of real estate and urban economics at the University of California at Berkeley and a consultant at Salomon Brothers. ''The regulators are being overly aggressive and far too cautious in their assessment of the value of real estate. The regulators are intimidating the lenders.''
In the light of the savings and loan debacle and the troubled real estate portfolios of banks in New England and the Southwest, Robert Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, and his examiners have become more strict in supervising commercial bank lending, especially real estate loans.
Mr. Clarke defends the tougher approach, saying regulators are often unfairly deemed responsible for tighter lending policies that were adopted by the banks themselves.
''It's really the responsibility of the banks to oversee their own credit quality,'' Mr. Clarke said. ''To suggest that it's our fault is to abdicate the banks' responsibility to maintain their own credit quality.''
Yet Mr. Clarke also notes that his examiners try to assess the likelihood that a loan might be paid, rather than ''wait until it goes sour.''
''You can be anticipatory without being unreasonable,'' he said.
Lending for real estate nationwide has not been stagnant, but the standards for loans have been raised. According to Federal Reserve figures, real estate loans nationally continued to increase in the first three months of 1990, rising $6.7 billion, though the rate of increase is far slower than the pace last year. But a different picture emerges from regional data. For example, construction loans in New England dropped 9.1 percent last year, after annual increases ranging from 25 percent to 52 percent in the previous four years.
''What we have is American banks taking a much more conservative view toward real estate lending and raising the credit requirements,'' said Arthur Sonnenblick, vice chairman of Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, one of the country's largest commercial brokers.
 
Other Sources of Finance
He said, however, that top-quality, pre-leased buildings were still being financed. ''On attractive transactions there's still plenty of money,'' Mr. Sonnenblick said. ''There are the Canadian banks, the Japanese banks, and some American banks that are out there and still feel comfortable doing deals.''
The banks have cut back on their lending largely by raising the standards used to judge loan requests, a change that many say was sorely needed to correct excesses in real estate lending. For example, banks that a few years ago were willing to provide all the financing for an office building or shopping center are now willing to supply only a portion of the financing and they require that more money be put up by the borrower.
''I think you will find that all the banks now have more stringent underwriting criteria,'' said Edward Pabich, the former senior vice president in charge of real estate lending at Connecticut Bank and Trust.
 
Advance Commitments Sought
Mr. Pabich said the banks had also raised their standards by, for instance, demanding that developers have more advance commitments to lease the office space or buy the apartments being built.
One of the most frequent complaints the banks have about the regulators is that they are excessively and arbitrarily marking down the value of real estate loan portfolios. In many instances the bankers say the examiners are reviewing loans that they reviewed only a year ago and marking down the value or forcing the banks to increase loan-loss reserves, even when there have been no late payments or other problems on those loans.
''This is causing banks to increase their loan-loss reserves and add more loans to their nonperforming lists than they would have had to last year with the same exact loans still being paid,'' said Joseph Brannen, executive vice president of the Georgia Bankers Association.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Stable To Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of the taxable money market funds monitored by the IBC/ Donoghue's Money Fund Report were unchanged for the week that ended yesterday, while those of tax-exempt funds were slightly higher.
Mixed economic news and constant signs of inflation are keeping the Federal Reserve Bank from taking any action on lowering short-term interest rates, Donoghue's analysts said. The yields on money market funds have remained relatively flat for months, and fund managers say they do not expect any noticeable change in the near future. 
For the third straight week, the average number of days to maturity of securities held in money managers' portfolios was 44.
The analysts note that the yields on bank certificates of deposit are becoming attractive. Some money that found its way into money market funds as C.D. yields fell may be headed back, they say.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund was unchanged at 7.99 percent, while the 30-day average yield rose by a basis point, to 7.99 percent.
The assets of taxable funds declined by $400 million for the week, to a total of $381.7 billion, with institutional assets down by $661 million, to $78.4 billion. The assets of consumer funds, those for small investors, rose by about $260 million, to $303.1 billion.
 
Dreyfus Riding High
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I., showed the best return, with a yield of 8.91 percent, up from 8.88 percent. The fund has shown the best return for more than two months.
The yields of tax-exempt funds were up slightly for the week that ended yesterday, and assets declined by $916 million, to a total of $76.6 billion. The average on a seven-day compounded yield increased to 5.74 percent, from 5.63 percent last week. For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, an equivalent taxable yield would be 7.97 percent. For those in a 33 percent bracket, the equivalent would be 8.56 percent.
For the third consecutive week, the best-yielding tax-exempt fund was the Spartan Pennsylvania Municipal Money Market Portfolio, distributed by the Fidelity Distributors Corporation in Boston. Its yield was 6.56 percent, up from 6.52 percent last week and about 82 basis points points higher than the seven-day average.
By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed that bank money market accounts were unchanged at 6.24 percent. C.D.'s, on the other hand, were up.

HEADLINE: Goodyear Net Tumbled 77.9% in First Quarter

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 77.9 percent because of severe price competition, the slowdown in automobile production and higher costs.
Goodyear's net income fell to $20.9 million, or 36 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with $94.5 million, or $1.64 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales were up slightly, to $2.69 billion, from $2.64 billion in the first quarter of last year. 
Goodyear's position as the world's largest tire producer will soon be overtaken with the acquisition of the Uniroyal-Goodrich Tire Company by Groupe Michelin of France. In the last few years, competition has intensified as the merger of tire companies has produced a few international giants, eager to gain market share. And price competition has been particularly fierce in recent years.
Tom H. Barrett, Goodyear's chairman, said that the company had expected earnings to be depressed in the first half of the year and that conditions were likely to improve in the second half.
''We're not happy with the results, but they are basically what we saw coming with the economic conditions in Detroit being what they are,'' Mr. Barrett said.
 
Results Affected by Ad Costs
Goodyear, which has been looking to increase its share in the replacement tire market, said that its results were affected by the costs of an advertising campaign to promote its new All-American and Concorde lines. Indeed, the first-quarter results indicated that worldwide tire sales, on a unit basis, increased 1.1 percent, with a 3.3 percent increase in unit sales domestically.
''That increase was the surprise in the first-quarter earnings, since it was coming in the face of a 27 percent decline in original equipment sales,'' said Harry W. Millis, a tire industry analyst with McDonald & Company in Cleveland, referring to the drop in sales to automobile manufacturers. ''That indicates a sharp gain in market penetration in the replacement tire market,'' Mr. Millis said.
He and other analysts said, however, that the company's earnings were being hurt by lower prices for tires. ''It appears that tire profits for Goodyear were down close to 40 percent for the quarter,'' he said.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Goodyear's stock was up 50 cents yesterday, closing at $35.50.
The company said that operating income in its domestic geographic segment fell 40.3 percent, to $82.8 million. The foreign geographic segment had a 25.4 percent drop in operating income, to $90.8 million.
In Europe, sales increased strongly but operating income declined because of lower prices and marketing costs, the company said. First-quarter sales in Latin America increased significantly, Goodyear said, but operating income was negatively affected because of major economic reforms currently being undertaken in Brazil, Mr. Barrett said.
The company said sales and operating income in the Asia and Africa segment declined, primarily because of the sale last year of Goodyear's subsidiary in South Africa. And sales declined in Canada, where Goodyear recorded a loss because of start-up costs at a plant in Napanee, Ontario.

HEADLINE: New U.S. Aid Sought For High Technology

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Proponents of increased financial support for the development of advanced technologies, concerned that the Bush Administration is reducing its commitment to research sponsored by a Pentagon agency, are scrambling to find new sources of money outside the military budget.
The efforts have been intensified because of the removal last week of Craig I. Fields, the director of the Pentagon agency, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, in a dispute over what the agency's role should be. The agency has played a vital role in the development of technologies that proved to have important commercial as well as military applications, including advanced computers and aerospace materials.
Several executives of the agency said Dr. Fields had been transferred to a new post because he had advocated high-technology initiatives that some high Administration officials opposed as smacking of advocating the development of certain industries - a de facto industrial policy. 
 
A Variety of Proposals
Acknowledging that they have little hope of either restoring Dr. Fields to his old position or forcing the Administration to direct the Pentagon agency toward nonmilitary research, proponents of increased financial support have shifted their attention to a variety of proposals. But they concede that the prospects for such proposals are dimmed by the Administration's ideological opposition to such concepts.
Here are some of the proposals:
* A new plan by the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors, a Government-industry advisory group, to set up a private $5 billion to $10 billion fund, backed by Federal loan guarantees, to create an Electronics Capital Corporation. It would provide money for important technology projects.
* A bill introduced by Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, that would provide $1.75 billion for the development of advanced computers, software and computer networks.
* A bill to be introduced soon by Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, to establish a corporation, known as the Technology Corporation of America, that would support joint ventures with $50 million a year.
* A bill by Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, that would allocate $100 million annually for applied research financed by a new organization, the Advanced Civilian Technology Agency, a civilian counterpart to Darpa within the Commerce Department.
* The expansion of Federal financing for the Advanced Technology Program, created this year at the National Institute for Standards and Technology and currently receiving $10 million annually.
But the Bush Administration's position has left supporters pessimistic that significant Federal programs will emerge soon to underwrite important research in areas including high-definition television, advanced semiconductors and computers.
''Even many of the initiatives that were started under the Reagan Administration are on the chopping block,'' said Robert Reich, a Harvard economist who favors the development of Government programs that foster advanced technologies.
 
'An Industrial Outcry'
But proponents of increased support for such research argue that the Administration's opposition to new spending initiatives is breeding intense criticism even from Republican strongholds.
''There's an industrial outcry building up,'' said Robert Cohen, a New York economic consultant. ''Normally conservative corporate executives are extremely upset about the way the country is moving away from promoting industrial innovation.''
One difficulty facing those concerned about a growing gap between the United States and Japan in terms of capital investment is how to match the historically effective style of the Pentagon agency in supporting leading-edge research.
The agency spends about $1 billion annually in areas including advanced computing, exotic materials and future manufacturing techniques. By spending in a freewheeling fashion, often backing academic and corporate research ventures before they are ready for commercial financing, the agency has had an enormous influence over the course of the computer industry, many executives say.
Some industry executives and Government officials point out that it will not be easy to duplicate the Pentagon agency's style. ''The big issue is who are you going to trust to make the investment?'' said Robert Kahn, a former official of the agency who left it to found the Corporation for National Research Initiatives. ''Setting up a brand new organization and bringing in new people entails its own risks.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
2-Year Notes Get Tepid Reception

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved lower again yesterday, as a morning rally was cut short by selling after an auction of $10.5 billion of new two-year Treasury notes received a lukewarm reception.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 8.90 percent, the highest yield on a two-year note since the two-year note sale a year ago, and well above the 8.59 percent average yield at the last two-year note auction on March 27.
Attracted by high yields, demand from individual investors was strong, as more than $1.9 billion worth of noncompetitive bids were placed. The amount was the highest for a two-year note auction since January 1989. 
Noncompetitive bids, where investors agree to pay the average of all bids, are considered a good gauge of demand by individual investors and small banks.
 
'Market Just Isn't in Good Shape'
''The auction wasn't good, but it wasn't terrible,'' one government bond trader said. ''The market just isn't in good shape, and there is nothing else to say about it.''
There were strong signs that the new securities were having difficulties. Late yesterday, the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.94 percent, up four basis points from the average yield at the auction. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
William V. Sullivan, a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said that ''there is no retail sponsorship for higher prices, and a sense that the upcoming supply of new Treasury issues can only be underwritten at higher yields.''
Traders said some of yesterday's selling was prompted by fears that the Federal Reserve Board would tighten its monetary policy in advance of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions early next month.
 
Stable Federal Funds Rate
Despite continued worries about inflation, most analysts remain convinced that weakness in certain key sectors of the economy, as well as a strong dollar, will prevent the Fed from moving soon to push up the overnight Federal funds rate, the short-term money-market interest rate it most directly controls.
The Federal funds rate has remained around its current level of about 8 1/4 percent since mid-December.
''There is a fairly sharp division at the Fed'' about the need to tighten policy, said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that examines the credit and foreign-exchange markets.
''If I thought they were going to move tomorrow, it would be to tighten rather than ease,'' Mr. Stone said. ''But I think they will wait. The economy is not as strong as many people seem to think it is.''
 
Eighth Drop in Nine Sessions
Yesterday's dip in cash market prices was the eighth in the last nine sessions.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent Treasury bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 95 1/8, down 5/32, to yield 8.97 percent. Late Tuesday, the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.95 percent.
The 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 27/32, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 8.98 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 1/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.97 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved higher. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.76 percent, up two basis points. And six-month bills were offered at a rate of 7.94 percent, up six basis points.
 
New Brunswick Debentures
Elsewhere, a number of new issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including a $200 million offering of 30-year debentures for the Province of New Brunswick in Canada.
The 9 3/4 percent debentures, which mature on May 15, 2020, were priced at $99.85 to yield 9.87 percent, 90 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds at the time of pricing. The securities are noncallable for life.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead underwriter for the transaction, which is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Morgan Stanley Group Inc. offered $200 million of five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company, its principal subsidiary.
The 9 7/8 percent notes were priced at $99.875, to yield 9.907 percent, 95 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
 
Rothschild's Re-evaluation
In other developments, poor conditions in the tax-exempt municipal bond market have forced L. F. Rothschild & Company to re-evaluate whether it will remain in the market.
The financially troubled firm re-entered the municipal bond market in November after an absence of nearly two years.
''When we got back in, we decided to give it six months,'' said Robert McNamara, a managing director in charge of capital market operations. ''But the market has been choppy and new-issue volume has been low. At this pont we don't know whether or not next month we will have a municipal bond department.''
Actively traded issues in the secondary municipal bond market, which have mostly avoided the sharp drop in Treasury prices, were hit hard yesterday. Dealers said that prices of most issues fell by about 1/2 a point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of intermediate-term issues dipped by about 1/8 point, while long-term bond prices fell by about 1/4 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Prices Plunge; Gold and Silver Fall Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices plunged yesterday as a supply-connected collapse of platinum prices prompted selling in the gold and silver markets, which had already been weakened by a lack of investor demand.
Gold for spot delivery traded as low as $370 an ounce for the first time since April 2, and silver plummeted to its lowest level in nearly four years.
On other commodity markets, copper futures surged to an eight-month high; oil futures were sharply lower; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
Gold futures settled $5.20 to $5.70 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in April at $370.70 an ounce; silver was 7.5 to 9.1 cents lower, with April at $4.919, the lowest settlement price for a near-month silver contract on the exchange since May 19, 1986.
 
Platinum Off $15.60 an Ounce
Platinum futures finished $15.60 lower across the board on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with July at $472.20 an ounce, the lowest near-month platinum settlement since April 2.
The tumble extended Tuesday's steep losses in gold and silver, which analysts had attributed mainly to weak investor demand in the face of rising interest rates.
Some analysts also cited sluggish spring car sales, inferring a corresponding drop in platinum demand for use in automobile catalytic converters.
Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., discounted that notion, saying that car makers buy platinum on an annual contract basis.
''I really think it was a technical selloff and all these things were excuses,'' she said.
 
Copper Prices Surge
The exchange reported supplies of deliverable copper at about 6,000 tons yesterday, one day before the April contract is due to expire. Another exchange report indicated that more than 10,000 tons of copper would have been needed to satisfy all outstanding April contracts as of Tuesday, the last day for which statistics were available.
The apparent shortfall in deliverable supplies was the main factor behind yesterday's striking surge in copper futures prices, analysts said.
Copper settled 1.1 to 10 cents higher, with the April contract up 10 cents at $1.34 a pound, the highest settlement of a near-month copper contract since Aug. 25.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading; Swiss Franc and Mark Gain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most primary foreign currencies yesterday in light trading as the Swiss franc and the West German mark rose sharply, traders said.
The traders said the Swiss currency was bolstered by the Swiss central bank's decision on Tuesday to raise interest rates. That caused the dollar to lose strength against the franc, said Lorenzo Troni, the vice president of foreign exchange at Paine Webber International Inc. 
The mark strengthened against the dollar on the belief that the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, would raise its official interest rate soon to stem inflation, Mr. Troni said. Higher West German interest rates make returns on the mark relatively more attractive as an investment.
Linda McLaughlin, a currency trader with Chemical Bank, said the dollar lost its value because of technical factors, with little economic news to affect the currency. Trading was light, she added.
In late trading in London, the dollar fetched 1.4665 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865 late on Tuesday. Later, in New York, the American currency traded at 1.4575 Swiss francs, down from 1.4875 late on Tuesday.
In late London trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6820 marks, down from 1.6930 marks late on Tuesday. It stood at 1.6780 marks late yesterday in New York, lower than Tuesday's late rate of 1.6980 marks.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose by 1.10 yen to close at 159.25 yen. In London, it was quoted late yesterday at 158.59 yen. In New York, the dollar finished at 158.73 yen, down from 158.95 yen late on Tuesday.
The pound sank in London after the British announcement that the country's merchandise trade deficit widened in March to 2.18 billion, from February's 1.39 billion. The currency, however, later finished stronger on buying by the Bank of England.
Sterling finished the day in London at $1.6370, compared with $1.6345 on Tuesday. Later in New York, the pound rose to $1.6405, from $1.6347 on Tuesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 5.6345 French francs, down from 5.6980; 1,231.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.75, and 1.1608 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15955.

HEADLINE: CHENEY PROPOSES SHARP REDUCTIONS IN NEW WARPLANES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Facing intense pressure from Congress to cut more deeply into the Pentagon budget, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today proposed large reductions in the development and production of new warplanes, including the Stealth bomber.
Citing changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, Mr. Cheney told Congress that the Pentagon now wants to buy 75 of the Stealth, or B-2, bombers instead of the 132 that the Air Force had initially sought. The cut would reduce the cost of the Stealth program from $75.4 billion to $61.1 billion, but raise the cost of each plane to $815 million from $530 million.
The cost tradeoff drew support from some members of Congress, but appeared to leave the program vulnerable to further reductions from lawmakers who consider the advanced radar-evading aircraft a prime target for budget savings.
 
Seeking Political Viability
Mr. Cheney also indicated that he had made a preliminary decision to cut the Navy's fleet of aircraft carriers from 14 to 12. 
The overall plan represents the Bush Administration's most forceful effort to shape a politically viable plan for military spending when tensions with the Soviet Union are receding and the Warsaw Pact has collapsed as a threat to Europe. It brings the Administration's military spending proposals closer to the lower ones outlined by leading members of Congress, but still leaves a substantial gap.
Mr. Cheney's proposals would produce a reduction of $2.4 billion in the $295 billion Pentagon budget that the Administration has proposed for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. That proposal is already 2.6 percent lower than the amount that would be needed to keep pace with inflation.
 
Cheney's Promise
Through 1997, Mr. Cheney's proposals would produce savings of $34.8 billion, which would amount to a first step toward fulfilling the promise he made earlier this year to continue cutting the budget at a rate of about 2 percent a year.
Shortly after the Bush Administration submitted its budget proposal to Congress in January, Mr. Cheney said he had begun a review of plans to buy new warplanes and might return later in the year with revised plans and additional savings. He did so today in appearances before the Senate and House Armed Services Committees. Mr. Cheney had been chided by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and others in Congress for failing to outline a long-term vision for reshaping the military. His testimony today, which was an important step in that process, was in general welcomed by Congressional arms experts, although some said the plans still did not go far enough.
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services committee, said further budget reductions would be needed, and he complained that Mr. Cheney's proposals were ''still based on an unrealistically pessimistic view of the Soviet threat.''
In addition to the Stealth reductions, Mr. Cheney proposed cutting by half the Pentagon's planned purchase of new C-17 transport planes, buying fewer of the Navy's A-12 attack plane and deferring production of two new Air Force planes, an air-to-air fighter and an air-to-ground attack plane.
The immediate military implications of the plan are limited, since some of the new warplanes were not scheduled for production until the mid-1990's.
 
A Program That Can Be Sold
Nevertheless, Mr. Cheney's proposals are an important scaling back for weapons systems that are to serve the military well into the next century.
Mr. Cheney is clearly hoping the reduction in the total cost of the Stealth program will improve the prospects for Congressional approval, and some supporters agreed.
Representative Robert W. Davis, Republican of Michigan, said Mr. Cheney had given Republicans ''a very defensible position, something we can sell to the House and the American people.''
But the proposal to scale back the Stealth program is a double-edged sword. Almost $30 billion has already been spent on development. Because this investment would be spread over a smaller number of planes, it means a less efficient rate of production by the Northrop Corporation.
''They are cutting out 40 percent of the aircraft and only saving 20 percent of the cost of the program,'' said Michael C. Brower, an analyst with the Union of Concerned Scientists, which has urged the Stealth program be canceled.
 
Inefficiencies Enhanced
Mr. Cheney has previously stressed his opposition to stretching out weapons programs, which creates inefficies. His new proposal, which would provide the Air Force with two wings of Stealth bombers, represents something of a reversal.
Adding to his predicament is that deeper cuts in the Stealth program Congress might dictate would drive up the cost of each plane even more. The Congressional Budget Office warned in a report earlier this month that ''slow rates of production are particularly inefficient for the B-2 bomber because of the program's complexity and because the bomber is reportedly being assembled at a factory that only produces one product - the B-2 bomber.''
In another important development, Mr. Cheney disclosed today that strategists had begun reviewing the number and types of targets that would be struck in a nuclear war. He suggested that altered targeting requirements justified a scaling back of the Stealth program.
''To the extent that you used to be concerned about targeting military targets in the Warsaw Pact, and the old Warsaw Pact goes away, you've got new requirements,'' Mr. Cheney said.
Discussing the C-17 transport plane, being built by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Mr. Cheney said the Pentagon wants to buy 120 of the aircraft instead of the 210 originally planned. That would cut the cost of the program from $41.8 billion to $29.9 billion.
 
Transport Needs Change
Mr. Cheney said that the political changes in Eastern Europe as well as the withdrawals of Soviet forces would mean the Western nations would have much greater warning of a possible Soviet attack.
''We can anticipate that warning time now will be a matter of months, not a matter of days or a couple of weeks,'' Mr. Cheney said. ''And that gives us more time to marshal our resources and to acquire what we need and get it to Europe given that amount of time.''
Scaling back the C-17 program would raise the cost of each of the planes to about $240 million, providing ammuntion to critics who argue that the improved warning time suggests the C-17 should be canceled altogether and instead, fast ships should be built.
The Navy has been relatively unscathed in the military budget cuts so far, but Mr. Cheney's testimony today was seen by Navy officials as a message that the service would have to accept some reductions. The Secretary noted that the figure of 12 aircraft carrier battle groups was tentative. Last week Senator Nunn, in outlining his ideas for military cuts, suggested that the Navy's 14 carrier groups could be reduced to the range of 10 to 12.
Mr. Cheney said his decision to defer Air Force fighter and attack planes was based in part on new intelligence data suggesting a lag in the production of similar Soviet planes.
Mr. Cheney added that as a result of the changes in Europe, the Western allies would face ''fewer enemy aircraft, a reduced ground threat, and a less robust air defense threat over Eastern Europe itself.''

HEADLINE: California Pushing the Limits With Environmental Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 26

 BODY:
The stage was set today for one of the toughest national political battles of 1990, drawing the environmental movement directly into hardball politics over a measure that would impose on California the most sweeping controls in the country.
A coalition of environmental groups turned in 800,000 signatures, more than enough to place a voter-initiated referendum on the November ballot.
The initiative would, among other things, ban 19 cancer-causing pesticides still in wide use, drastically reduce emission of artificial gases that trap and retain heat from the sun, curtail clearing of forests, ban offshore oil drilling except in national emergencies and create an elected state environmental advocate to enforce the law.
The measure has stirred nationwide unease among agricultural, chemical, logging and other interests, who are mounting a multimillion-dollar campaign to defeat it and to pass competing initiatives to override it lest the other states follow California's lead. But given the mounting public concern about the environment, the Big Green initiative, as its backers have named it, is considered likely to pass. 
 
Votes Are Involved
''There's no way we can lose,'' the initiative's campaign manager, Bob Mulholland, said today. ''This is a done deal. We can't lose unless there's an earthquake that stops California.''
Much more than the environment is at stake. The measure has been deeply enmeshed in the race for Governor as candidates have jockeyed for the powerful environmental vote.
The measure was endorsed early on by State Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp, who faces the former Mayor of San Francisco, Dianne Feinstein, in the Democratic primary on June 5. After months of hesitation, Mrs. Feinstein, who had feared losing support in the agricultural Central Valley, endorsed the measure on Sunday, Earth Day.
That leaves the certain Republican nominee, Senator Pete Wilson, a moderate with a pro-environment record, in the position of seeming to be against something widely perceived as akin to motherhood. He says he opposes the measure because it takes environmental authority away from the Governor.
Critics of the measure say it would grievously injure the state's billion-dollar agriculture, aerospace and electronics industries, cause food prices to rise nationally and bring substantial increases in gasoline taxes, electricity rates and unemployment. They have tried to tarnish it by tagging it the ''Hayden initiative'' after Assemblyman Tom Hayden, the Democrat from Santa Monica who largely wrote the measure and who has a long association with radical and liberal causes.
 
Interest in New Post
Mr. Hayden is thought to be interested in running for the post of environmental advocate.
The measure, the California Environmental Protection Act of 1990, touches on food safety, global warming from pollution, oceans, beaches and forests. Environmentalists say it is necessary to go directly to the voters because the California Legislature is so beholden to special interests that legislative remedies are impossible.
The measure includes these major elements:
* All pesticides judged by the state to cause cancer or reproductive damage are phased out in foods by 1996. Food produced out-of-state is banned from sale if even the slightest residue of such chemicals is detected.
* Allowable residues of other pesticides are reduced to levels considered safe for children. Exposure of farmworkers to pesticides would be reduced to the lowest achievable levels.
* Emissions of carbon dioxide, believed to add to global warming, are reduced by 20 percent by the year 2000 and 40 percent by 2010.
* Steps to cut the emission of chlorofluorocarbons and other industrial chemicals believed to damage the earth's protective ozone layer. By 1995, the sale of cars using these chemicals in air conditioners is banned.
* Oil drilling within three miles of the coast is forbidden unless the President declares a national emergency.
* Creation of an oil-spill prevention plan, including a $500 million prevention and cleanup fund established with a fee of 25 cents a barrel paid by companies moving oil through California waters.
* New controls on public sewage discharges and stricter health standards for beach waters and seafood.
Although the measures do not address all of California's environmental problems, Albert H. Meyerhoff of the Natural Resources Defense Council said they represented the most comprehensive environmental law ever proposed.
''It will not by itself save the planet,'' Mr. Meyerhoff said. ''It will save this corner of it.''
Proponents say they expect to spend as much as $3 million to pass it.
To fight the measure, the California Chamber of Commerce and the pesticide industry are mounting a campaign that opponents assert will cost $16 million. They have employed the political consulting firm Woodward & McDowell of Burlingame, Calif. Jack S. McDowell, a partner in the firm, said the initiative was scientifically flawed in that it ignores the possibility that chemical residues at extremely low levels may not be hazardous to health.
According to a preliminary study for industry by Spectrum Economics Inc. of San Francisco, the initiative would have devastating economic consequences for the state. The study said it would increase gasoline prices by 25 to 50 cents a gallon, raise electricity rates by more than 20 percent, force food processors, supermarkets, restaurants and shippers to spend millions of dollars to replace refrigeration units, cost one million jobs by the year 2000 and put California businesses at a competitive disadvantage.
 
Competing Measure on the Way
Food growers and processors have also joined to fight the initiative by forming Californians for Responsible Food Laws. They are gathering signatures for a competing measure, which they call the Consumer Pesticide Enforcement Act for Food, Water, and Worker Safety. That measure would double the amount of testing of fresh fruits and vegetables and establish a fund to find means of reducing pesticide use, but that sets less stringent standards.
Lee Stitzenberger, campaign director of the growers' measure, said the approach was ''driven by science'' to establish safe risk levels for pesticide use. If the growers' measure gets more votes than the environmental initiative, it will override the pesticide provisions addressed in ''Big Green.''
A spokesman for the Wilson campaign said that while Mr. Wilson approved of many parts of the environmentalists' measure, he thought environmental responsibility should remain with the Governor. But critics maintain that Mr. Wilson is beholden to the state's agricultural and chemical interests.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
LITHUANIA IS ASKED BY PARIS AND BONN TO HALT DECISIONS

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 26

 BODY:
France and West Germany jointly urged Lithuania today to suspend its Parliament's moves toward independence and to seek negotiations with Moscow with a view to finding ''a solution acceptable to all parties.''
The move came in a letter addressed to Lithuania's President, Vytautas Landsbergis, by President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany at the conclusion of two days of talks here.
In their letter, the two leaders said a solution to the complex situation in Lithuania ''requires time and patience and should be sought through the classic channels of dialogue.''
 
Self-Determination Backed
''Without doubt, to facilitate the opening of these talks, it would be helpful if the effects of the decisions taken by your Parliament were suspended for a while,'' they said. ''They would lose none of their validity because they are based on the universally recognized principle of the self-determination of peoples.'' 
While Western countries have generally advocated a dialogue between Moscow and Lithuania, this was the first time any of them have specifically called on Lithuania to suspend any of the pro-independence actions taken by its Parliament.
As their meeting concluded, the French and West German leaders signaled that they had surmounted threats to their special relationship posed by recent events in Eastern Europe and that having patched up differences, they were again working in tandem on speeding European integration.
In a joint news conference Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl fell short of hailing a reconciliation, but both stressed the special role that France and West Germany should now play in Europe.
''We never thought that alone we could make things advance,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''But, without arrogance, it can be said that the process of European unity could not occur unless France and Germany pushed for it.''
Mr. Mitterrand, who last week joined Mr. Kohl in calling on the 12-nation European Community to start planning political union, said his talks with the German leader had resulted in ''a feeling of deep understanding.'' And he added, ''French-German friendship is more alive than ever.''
In their letter to the Lithuanian leader, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl said they shared ''the same worries'' about the situation in Lithuania and had decided to convey them to Mr. Landsbergis. But they added, ''The Lithuanian people have demonstrated unequivocally their desire to exercise their right to sovereignty.''
Their initiative came just days after President Bush and Mr. Mitterrand agreed at a meeting in Florida that the United States Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, and the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, whould work through diplomatic channels to promote talks between Vilnius and Moscow.
Earlier today, in a news conference, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl were asked whether Lithuania was a victim of ''the spirit of Munich,'' a reference to the 1938 agreement between Britain and Nazi Germany that in effect legitimized Germany's occupation of Czechoslovakia.
 
Munich Analogy Disputed
Mr. Mitterrand said no comparison could be made between the policies of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and Hitler. ''We are not on the eve of a war; there is no conquering imperialism,'' he said.
He said it was now up to Mr. Gorbachev to take the initiative to establish a dialogue with Lithuania, and he added that the contents of the French-German letter would be conveyed to him.
Responding to the same question, Mr. Kohl said the comparison to Munich was totally inappropriate. He added, ''I do not think it is advisable to create any pressure that could block the start of a true discussion.''
In referring to the two days of talks, French and German officials said one immediate result of the new mood of cooperation between their Governments was likely to be the further isolation of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain when Community leaders hold a special summit meeting in Dublin on Saturday.
Mrs. Thatcher has made no secret of her opposition to both existing Community plans for economic and monetary union and the new call for political union, but in recent weeks her Government has been seeking closer ties with France as a way of counterbalancing the power of a future united Germany.
With Paris and Bonn agreed on the need for a parallel process of German and European unification, foreign diplomats said, recent uncertainty over how the European Community should respond to both the uniting of the two Germanys and the revolution in Eastern Europe should now evaporate.
But the nervousness created by tensions between Paris and Bonn in recent months also reflected the way that France and West Germany had come to view their postwar rapprochement as perhaps the single most important pillar of European stability.
After the crumbling of the Berlin wall in November, France was alarmed by the pace of German unification and worried openly that West Germany was losing interest in European integration. Mr. Mitterrand also criticized Mr. Kohl for not assuring Poland that its postwar borders would not be challenged.
But Bonn showed irritation with Mr. Mitterrand's apparent effort to move closer to Moscow in response to German unification as well as with his proposal that a special inter-government conference on economic and monetary union be held before West Germany's elections this December.
Their joint statement last week calling for a simultaneous inter-governmental conference on political union in December was therefore seen as a boost for European integration and a symbol of what one Bonn official called ''the rediscovery of our friendship.''
Today the two leaders went out of their way to emphasize the harmony of their views, with Mr. Kohl reassuring France that German monetary union would not only provide French businesses with new opportunities but would also benefit all of Europe.
Endorsing Mr. Mitterrand's call for a NATO summit meeting later this year, the Chancellor brushed aside concerns expressed in the German Parliament over France's plans to install the new Hades short-range nuclear missile, which could strike targets in Germany but not in the Soviet Union. ''Hades doesn't worry me at all,'' Mr. Kohl said.
Mr. Mitterrand said he expected a summit conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to review all aspects of Western defense and that he did not regard the Hades missile as a priority issue. ''There is not yet a new European balance,'' he said. ''France will not budge while circumstances have not changed.''
 
Lithuanian to Study Message
MOSCOW, April 26 (Reuters) -President Landsbergis of Lithuania promised today to ''carefully study'' a French-German proposal to suspend the effects of recent laws linked with his independence declaration.
''The leadership of Lithuania also desires that a dialogue between the two countries begin as soon as possible,'' Mr. Landsbergis said. He added that talks would be helped by an end to the Soviet blockade.

COUNTRY: FRANCE (96%); LITHUANIA (96%); GERMANY (95%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (94%); EUROPE (94%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (54%);

HEADLINE: In Battle Over Sign, All Roads Lead to Albany

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FULTONVILLE, N.Y., April 26

 BODY:
Vinnie Gramuglia is very fond of his giant road sign - a retired 18-wheeler perched 65 feet up in the sky over the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. The sign, the local truck-stop owner says, ''is to trucks what a lighthouse is to ships.''
Thruway officials think it is nothing but an illegal blemish on the Mohawk Valley landscape of this village just off Exit 28. The sign, they say, must go. 
Now a potent mixture of local enthusiasm and Albany politics has turned what began as a local dispute into a statewide issue. The two lawmakers who represent the village, feeling the heat from residents who are passionately in favor of preserving the truck, introduced a bill that would do much more than that. Their legislation would remove the New York State Thruway Authority's jurisdiction over signs, billboards or other advertising devices within two miles of any exit on the 559-mile highway.
 
'Invitation to Visual Pollution'
The State Senate passed the bill 57 to 1, and it is about to go to the floor of the Assembly, whose transportation committee approved it earlier this week on a 17-to-3 vote. Final approval is expected as early as next week.
While the measure could be a boon for merchants along the Thruway and a bonanza for the billboard industry, Thruway officials say lawmakers have either ignored its damaging consequences or do not understand them.
''It's a sneak attack on the environment,'' said Peter F. Tufo, the Thruway Authority's chairman. ''This legislation is an open invitation to visual pollution.''
Environmentalists are dismayed as well. Instead of insuring sweeping views of the Catskills mountains or the rolling hills of the Mohawk Valley, ''this bill will turn a trip on the Thruway into a drive through the yellow pages,'' said Edward T. McMahon, executive director of Scenic America, a Washington-based group concerned with the country's natural vistas.
If it receives final approval from the Legislature, the measure will go to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. A spokeswoman for the Governor, Anne Crowley, said Mr. Cuomo would have no comment on the bill until it reached his desk.
 
Truck Called Hazardous
The Thruway Authority calls the truck - which sits atop an abandoned oil tank - ''the most hazardous, gaudiest, most novel and most distracting advertising device on the Thruway.'' Although it concedes no accidents have occurred, the authority says the truck is illegal and could cause accidents involving gawking motorists who might wonder whether the rig is about to cross over the roadway.
''That is absolutely nuts,'' replied Mr. Gramuglia, who has tied up state efforts to get rid of his truck in the courts, partly by contending that the truck is duly registered and legally parked. ''Anybody who thinks this truck is moving shouldn't be out on the road to begin with.''
Mr. Gramuglia, a New Jersey native who opened his Countryside Fuel Stop 28 a few years ago, described his rig as a ''thing of beauty.'' And he said, ''All I'm asking here is that the state keep its hands off my truck.''
Mr. Gramuglia installed the truck on its perch last November. First he poured 300,000 pounds of cement into the abandoned oil tank, then welded the trailer to two 60-foot I-beams. He then hoisted the truck to the top of the tank with a crane.
 
'Save the Truck' T-Shirts
The bill gained momentum partly because Mr. Gramuglia, who has become a folk hero here in Montgomery County, seems to have captured the imagination of many lawmakers in Albany. He has made several lobbying trips to the capital from Fultonville, 40 miles away, and hands out ''Save the Truck'' T-shirts to just about anybody. Most lawmakers in Albany seem to have deferred judgment on the bill to the legislators who represent Mr. Gramuglia - State Senator Hugh T. Farley, a Schenectady County Republican, and Paul D. Tonko, an Amsterdam Democrat. But many critics of the bill say the plight of the colorful Mr. Gramuglia and his truck has obscured the much broader effects of the bill.
''This is a textbook case of how a bill should not become law,'' said Lee Wasserman, executive director of the Environmental Planning Lobby, a nonprofit advocacy group. ''A truck gets put on a pole, the case becomes a cause celebre, and now the Legislature stands poised to roll back a 40-year policy of protecting richly scenic landscapes statewide.''
The state Thruway Authority currently has some of the most stringent rules on billboards of any highway authority in the country. Almost all billboards are set back at least 660 feet from the highway, and the Authority has tight control over the exceptions.
Here in Fultonville, support for Mr. Gramuglia runs all the deeper because residents say they have many reasons to resent the Thruway Authority. The highway bisected the village when it was built in the 1950's, and it is just a few miles from where a bridge over the highway collapsed in the spring of 1987, sending 10 motorists to their deaths in the Schoharie Creek.
Still, the village economy has become largely dependent on Thruway motorists. ''It's been terrific for business,'' said the mayor, George Wadsworth. ''If it weren't for that truck, a lot of people might not even know we were here.''

GRAPHIC: photos: Vinnie Gramuglia and his truck stop sign in Fultonville, N.Y., are on the verge of a legislative victory against the state Thruway Authority. (The New York Times/David Jennings) (pg. HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
U.S. Reaches Trade Deal With Moscow

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 26

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it had reached broad agreement with the Soviet Union on a trade pact that should be ready for President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to sign when they hold their next summit meeting in Washington in late May.
Once it is approved by Congress, the trade agreement could pave the way for the Soviet Union to be granted most-favored-nation treatment by the United States. This status, already enjoyed by some Eastern European countries, would provide the Soviet Union with additional trade privileges.
United States tariffs average about 5 percent for countries with most-favored-nation status, but for countries like the Soviet Union that do not have the privilege, they can be 10 times as high - that is, 45 or 50 percent. The United States does not permit the export of some strategic goods to the Soviet Union, but that is a different matter that is not affected by most-favor-nation status. 
 
Disagreement Over Small Points
After three days of talks here, the Deputy United States Trade Representative, Julius L. Katz, noted that the two governments were still in disagreement over three or four small points. He declined to identify them, but he said they should be resolved through diplomatic exchanges in the coming weeks.
There had been some speculation that the talks could be suspended because of Washington's disapproval of Moscow's policies toward Lithuania. Mr. Katz said the Lithuanian crisis was not discussed during the meeting.
''Fundamentally, we have reached agreement on the text,'' he said. ''It is still the intention that the agreement be signed at the Washington summit between May 30 and June 3.''
The agreement would initially be for three years. Then it could automatically be renewed for a further three years if neither side objects. It is expected to bring a moderate increase in bilateral trade, as well as provide the Soviet Union with easier access to American goods needed for its modernization program.
 
Toward a Market Economy
''The agreement looks toward development of a market economy in the Soviet Union but reflects the fact that they are not quite there at this point,'' Mr. Katz said. Before the trade agreement can be signed, President Bush has insisted, the Soviet Union must adopt a new emigration law, a demand that prevented a trade pact signed between the two countries in 1972 from coming into force.
Mr. Katz said he did not know when Moscow's new legislation would be approved, but he noted that the link between the trade agreement and a more flexible Soviet emigration policy was clear and understood. ''I am not sure if it will be ready in time,'' he said.
Describing the contents of the provisional agreement, Mr. Katz said that in addition to the exchange of Most Favored Nation treatment, it called for the establishment of trade offices by both governments and travel facilities for Soviet and American businessmen.
 
Making It Easier for U.S. Business
Before the talks began, United States officials said Washington was particularly eager to make it easier for American companies to operate in the Soviet Union, not only as traders but also as investors who can repatriate their profits without difficulty.
Mr. Katz noted that the two governments planned to sign separate letters dealing with trade facilities, financial relations, tourism and protection of all aspects of intellectual property, such as patents, copyrights and sound recordings. The draft agreement also includes provisions dealing with national security questions.
He said that Soviet access to official American loans, such as trade financing from the Export-Import Bank, was not covered in the planned trade agreement. He added that the Bush Administration would be required to seek Congressional approval if such a privilege was granted to Moscow.

HEADLINE: Panel Rejects a Social Security Tax Cut

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
In the first test of Congressional sentiment on Senator Daniel P. Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, the Senate Budget Committee today overwhelmingly rejected the measure.
The 17-to-6 vote came on a motion by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who said his purpose was to force the panel to adopt ''truth in budgeting.'' Cutting the Social Security payroll taxes, he said, would eliminate the surplus in the Social Security trust fund, which is being used to mask the real size of the Federal deficit.
But only four Democrats and two Republicans voted for the proposal. 
Today's vote is by no means the last word on the subject. Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat who is not a member of the Budget Committee, said today that the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, had assurred him that the measure would come to a vote on the floor.
A test of sentiment for the measure on the Senate floor could come in the next few days, when Mr. Moynihan, Mr. Hollings and other senators plan to offer the tax cut proposal as an amendment to an unrelated emergency spending measure.
 
Moynihan Predicts Victory
''There will be a floor vote, the majority leader has made very clear that he wants to facilitate that,'' he said. Mr. Moynihan predicted that he would win a majority for his proposal on the Senate floor.
Mr. Moynihan caused a political firestorm last December when he suggested cutting the Social Security payroll tax. Mr. Moynihan said that it was unfair to collect workers' Social Security taxes meant to finance their retirement, and then use the money to cover part of the budget deficit.
The Moynihan proposal divided the Democrats and stirred strong opposition from the White House. Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said the Moynihan plan risked ''fiscal policy havoc'' by substantially increasing the budget deficit.
But political strategists at the Democratic National Committee and the more conservative Democratic Leadership Council eagerly seized on the plan as a potent weapon to counter President Bush's tax policies.
 
Worries About Deficit
Mr. Moynihan's supporters said the proposal was a politically savvy move that would help the Democrats re-establish themselves as the party of the working people while the Republicans pushed a capital gains tax cut that would benefit the wealthy.
But Democrats in Congress, including Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committtee, have been cool to the payroll tax cut. Critics argued today that the proposal would increase the Federal deficit.
''I'd be prepared to support Mr. Hollings if he offered any offset either on the revenue or the spending side,'' said Senator Charles S. Robb, a Virginia Democrat and a member of the Democratic Leadership Council. His views were echoed, though more cautiously, by other Democrats who voted against the proposal today but said they might change their minds if it reached the Senate floor.
But Sen. Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, a supporter of the Moynihan proposal, said he was endorsing the plan in part because using Social Security surpluses to hide the true size of the deficit was ''embezzlement.''
The House Budget Committee, which has already adopted its 1991 spending plan, has recommended immediately removing the trust fund from the calculation of the deficit, a plan the Administration is willing to accept. The Senate Budget Committee is moving in the same direction but has not decided when and how it will be accomplished.
After an increase in the payroll tax on Jan. 1, workers and their employers each pay 7.65 percent on wages up to $51,300. Of that tax, 6.2 percent finances retirement benefits, with the rest going to Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. Mr. Hollings' measure would have reduced the retirement benefits portion to 5.1 percent.
Today's vote in the Senate Budget Committee would not necessarily preclude lawmakers on the Senate Finance Committee from adopting Mr. Moynihan's proposal if they found other tax increases to offset it.
While the Congressional tax committees will make the ultimate decisions on which taxes to cut or raise later this year, it is the Congressional budget committes that determine the overall revenue level within which the tax panels must work.
Earlier today, the Senate Budget panel rejected on a tie vote a proposal by Senator Tim Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, to impose a $5-a-barrel fee on oil imports.
 
Hollings Chides Colleagues
Mr. Hollings chided his Democratic colleagues for not rallying around the Social Security tax cut, noting that he had called for revenue increases, including an oil import fee and a 5 percent ''value added tax'' to make up for the revenue the Treasury would lose from cutting the payroll tax. The value added tax, a system used by the European Economic Community, taxes goods and services at each stage of production and at final sale to the consumer.
''You know what the offset is,'' he said, referring to the value added tax. ''I could have married the two plans, but everybody wanted a clean vote on this.''
The committee later defeated Mr. Hollings' overall budget plan including those tax increases, by a vote of 15 to 7.
In addition to Mr. Hollings and Mr. Exon, the committee Democrats who voted for the Moynihan proposal were Senators Terry Sanford of North Carolina and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey. The two committee Republicans who voted for it were Senators Steve Symms of Idaho and Robert Kasten of Wisconsin.
While the budget panel struggled to reach agreement on a fiscal 1991 spending plan, the full Senate spent the day struggling to tie up loose ends for spending in the current 1990 fiscal year. The Senate is working on a $2.3 billion emergency spending measure that includes $720 million in aid for Panama and Nicaragua as well as additional financing for a variety of domestic programs, including food stamps, disaster relief and the census. It also includes $400 million in housing loan guarantees to Israel to help pay for resettlement of Soviet Jews.
More than 60 amendments, including those dealing with the Social Security tax cut and abortion, are pending.
