LENGTH: 762 words

HEADLINE: Grim Contractors Ready For Cutbacks on Arms

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 26

 BODY:
The Pentagon's plan to scale back and stretch out its purchases of aircraft in the coming decade confirms what many arms makers have come to expect: a period of painful consolidation.
Industry executives to some extent took heart from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision not to cancel any of the expensive and complex military aircraft programs planned for the next few years, but instead to buy fewer of the planes and to buy them at a lower annual rate. This would reduce the potential profits for the weapons makers but not eliminate them.
''This removes the anticipation of bad news and turns it into reality,'' said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst who studies military contractors for the Wall Street investment concern C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. ''The question is how well you can manage the consolidation.'' 
The programs involved are the Stealth bomber, built for the Air Force by the Northrop Corporation; the C-17 transport plane built for the Air Force by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation; the A-12 attack plane, built for the Navy by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation, and the advanced tactical fighter being developed for the Air Force by two competing teams of contractors, one headed by Northrop and one by the Lockheed Corporation. Mr. Cheney also delayed production of a variant of the A-12 planned for the Air Force and a variant of the advanced fighter being developed for the Navy.
 
Defining the Debate
The cuts proposed by Mr. Cheney are a major step in defining the debate over military spending and will shape the business strategies of almost all the major aerospace companies and their subcontractors. But the final numbers and the fate of some of the programs will not be determined until after what is certain to be a lengthy process of horse-trading in Congress. Pressure there for deeper budget cuts is partly offset by the desire of some lawmakers to protect prgrams that benefit their consitutents.
Some members of Congress are already concerned that delays and reductions in big programs will force up prices per plane because the production lines will become less efficient. The Stealth bomber, for example, would be cut to 75 planes from 132, with peak production of 12 a year, as against the 24 a year originally envisioned.
Mr. Cheney said the cut would save more than $14 billion over the life of the program by reducing the total price to about $61 billion. But the cost of a one of the radar-evading bombers would jump from about $530 million to $815 million.
If there are any winners from Mr. Cheney's decision, they could be the companies making the planes scheduled to be replaced by the programs being delayed. The Grumman Corporation, for example, might find it easier to persuade Congress to upgrade its F-14 fighter if the Navy has to wait longer than it planned for a new generation of fighters.
''To the extent that new programs get stretched out, the unit costs go up, and if you look at it rationally the new programs start to look less cost-effective versus existing programs,'' said Robert Paulson of McKinsey & Company, a management consulting firm. ''If there are any winners, they are the old programs.''
 
The Appeal: Few Jobs Lost
Mr. Cheney's plan has the political appeal of dealing primarily with programs that are not yet in full-scale production and that therefore do not put many jobs in jeopardy. As a result, the economic impact in southern California and around St. Louis, where most of the aerospace companies are situated, will be largely limited to the loss of new jobs in coming years.
''Congress will take as much money as it can out of the new programs to keep the old programs in production, because they want to keep people in their districts employed,'' said Paul H. Nisbet, an analyst at Prudential Bache Securities.
But in a sign of the industry's precarious financial condition, McDonnell Douglas said today that it would eliminate 3,000 jobs at its Douglas Aircraft plant in Long Beach, Calif., where the new C-17 transport plane is built. The cut was not directly related to Mr. Cheney's decision on the C-17, which has had design problems and cost overruns. The Douglas plant, which also builds two commercial aircraft, the MD-80 and MD-11, has had a poor financial performance.
Investors have long assumed that cuts of this magnitude would be imposed, if not by Pentagon decisions, then by Congressional actions. As a result, the stock prices of most military contractors were not hard hit by today's announcement.

HEADLINE: Temporary Census Army Begins Door-to-Door Count Nationwide

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
A temporary army of students and homemakers, laid-off coal miners and between-jobs executives swept down on their neighbors yesterday as the Government began its most complex effort ever to count people door-to-door.
But while the hastily trained enumerators took to the streets of major cities, many district offices were still scrambling to hire recruits.
Census Bureau officials, noting that they had more than half again as many approved job applicants nationwide as were hired in 1980, said they remained confident that the count would be finished on time.
But other experts said that with about 37 million households still to be counted, 75 percent more than at this stage a decade ago, census officials might nonetheless be short-handed. 
 
'Much Tougher'
''It's going to be much tougher than the bureau thought it would be,'' said William M. Hunt, who manages national studies on the census for the General Accounting Office.
''Certainly the recruitment has fallen short of their goal,'' he said. ''We'll have to wait and see whether the recruitment is enough to sustain them through the process. They tend to lose a lot of people.''
Only 63 percent of households mailed back completed census forms, seven percent fewer than the bureau projected and 12 percent fewer than in 1980. Because of that, census officials and their critics agree that the second phase of the 1990 count will be more difficult and more critical.
Across the country, experts say, the process will be hindered by many of the same demographic changes that the census seeks to document.
With more women in the work place, fewer will be available for temporary jobs as census takers and fewer will be at home to answer the door. An older population will mean fewer students, a group usually sought out for recruitment. And growing numbers of immigrants will demand counters who speak more languages, understand more cultures and who can penetrate more mistrustful households.
 
Some Daunting Changes
Lower-level census officials and enumerators also described changes that were less tangible, but perhaps equally daunting to the uninvited: rising fears of crime, increasing concerns about privacy, and pervasive feelings, especially in large cities, that days have grown shorter and time more precious.
Then there are the worries that have grown frustratingly familiar to those who train the arithmetic legions.
''I didn't want this job,'' said Virginia Pei, who was pressed into door-knocking service in New York's Chinatown by friends in a community group anxious to make use of her skills in Cantonese, Mandarin and a couple of dialects. ''I am scared. What if they open the door and shoot you?''
In classrooms, meeting halls and community centers, supervisors have steeled their counters for the task with advice of common sense and special local tactics.
For some neighborhoods, instructors say, passwords must be spoken in foreign languages and in obscure accents. The doormen of fancy apartment buildings or the wary eyes at tenement windows might yield only to certain colors of skin or styles of dress.
 
'Like Little Spies'
''You're going to have to be like little spies,'' Charles W. Mitchell, a former Army captain on his way to law school, warned a small audience dominated by middle-aged women in sensible shoes. ''This isn't selling brownie cookies.'' From his district office for Manhattan's Upper East Side, Mr. Mitchell surveys one of the toughest spots on a generally bleak landscape. The households he is to count are mostly affluent, busy and deluged with junk mail. And the residents appear even less anxious to count others than they have been to count themselves.
A general rule of census-taking holds that the harder a community's economic times, the more fertile the terrain for bureau recruiters.
So, around Kentucky coal mines, as in East Harlem, applicants are more than sufficient. Along New York's Park Avenue and California's Silicon Valley, recruiters are struggling.
Of a recent recruiting visit to a community meeting in New York, Mr. Mitchell said: ''The guy before me talked about the problems of limos being double-parked. And then I got up to offer these people $8 an hour to go door-to-door.''
 
Scale is Top in New York
That wage is the top of the Census Bureau's scale, paid only in New York City. Elsewhere, the pay runs between $5 an hour and $7.50.
Richard L. Bitzer, the Census Bureau's assistant chief for the field division, said the pay scale was one source of optimism in the bureau. In 1980, he said, enumerators were paid primarily by the number of households they visited. This year, along with an hourly wage, they will receive bonuses of $75 to $325 for completing their work and then for taking on more.
A survey of district offices around the country suggested that in some areas, many of them suburban, low rates of return for census forms were matched by indifference to recruiters. But in others, impoverished people who paid little attention to forms quickly answered offers of a job.
Around Boston, where the mail response rate ranged from 45 percent to 49 percent, the region's assistant census director, Harold K. Wood, said recruiters had qualified between three and four applicants for every job slot. But experts on the census say such accomplishments can be deceptive.
To compensate for no-shows, high attrition and inadequate work habits, many New York officials said they hoped to approve - by written test, interview, and a background check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation -10 times the number of workers they would need on a full-time basis. Because they were instructed to wait until the last minute to call applicants back, district officers said they found that many had already taken other jobs.
By contrast, in the San Francisco Bay area, where about 62 percent of the forms mailed out were returned, the Census Bureau yesterday had trained only 2,500 enumerators. The bureau estimated that it needed about 10,000, a spokeswoman, Elaine Dempsey, said.
For all the difficulties faced by Census Bureau officials, the challenges for some employees loomed larger.
B. Edward Garrison, a 56-year-old former truck driver, applied too late to be an enumerator in 1980, but he was approved this year. In the interim, he lost his left leg in a driving accident, and will search for his uncounted fellow residents of the South Bronx in his wheel chair.
''I could use the money,'' said Mr. Garrison, who lives on welfare. ''And I figure it has to be done, and it seems nobody wants to do it.''

HEADLINE: Ex-Official Is Contrite in Obscenity Furor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Dr. Richard Berendzen, who has been in seclusion since he was forced to resign as president of American University two weeks ago amid complaints that he had made obscene telephone calls, broke his silence today and said he was tormented and embarrassed by the events surrounding him.
In a statement issued through his lawyer, Dr. Berendzen confirmed reports that he was undergoing treatment and counseling at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore. His lawyer, Gerard Treanor, said, ''He is in a general psychiatric unit.'' But Mr. Treanor declined to discuss details.
Dr. Berendzen's statement seemed to acknowledge that he had made a series of obscene telephone calls to women in nearby Fairfax County, Va., many from the ornate office of the president on the American University campus in northwest Washington. ''I cannot begin to convey my embarrassment or torment,'' he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. PANEL WARNS ON CHILD POVERTY

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Poverty and despair facing many American children are not only personal tragedies but also ''a staggering national tragedy'' that threatens America's future, a Federal commission reported today.
The panel, the National Commission on Children, said in an interim report that children had become the poorest age group in the nation, with one child in five living below the poverty line.
It said childhood poverty, more than any other factor, placed young Americans at risk for long-term problems, including poor health, failure in school, teen-age pregnancy, crime and drugs. 
As a result, it said, many of today's children will reach adulthood unhealthy, illiterate and unemployable.
 
Broad Peril is Discerned
''The health and vitality of our economy and our democracy are increasingly in danger,'' Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the chairman of the panel and a West Virginia Democrat, said in releasing the report. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ''We have very deep concerns about the children of this country and the poverty level that they may be facing.''
The panel was established by Congress in December 1987 and began its work early last year. It made no recommendations in its interim report, but its findings thus far are expected to form the basis for suggestions for new spending when it issues its final report, due no later than next March 31.
The report cited an array of jarring statistics, all of them previously reported:
* Malnutrition affects nearly half a million children, and 100,000 children are homeless.
* Among black and Hispanic children, poverty is even worse. The poverty rate in 1987, the year the report cited, was 15 percent for white children but 45 percent for black children and 39 percent for Hispanic children.
* One of every four rural children is poor, and rural families are less likely than urban ones to receive public assistance.
American children on average are economically better off now than they were in the 1960's. But those figures do not reflect the growing disparity among families, it said.

LENGTH: 495 words

HEADLINE: Don't Punish the Wrong China

 BODY:
President Bush, justly criticized for failing to distance himself from Beijing's bloodstained leaders, can now best serve freedom by asking Congress to maintain China's status as a most favored nation. Congress, which has honorably resisted other Bush accommodations to the Chinese leadership, can go along in good conscience.
Insuring preferred treatment in U.S. markets would constitute a wise bet on those sectors of Chinese society most likely to build a progressive state once time and popular scorn sweep away today's aging rulers. 
Most-favored-nation status entitles a country to whatever preferences the U.S. grants its best trading partners. Most capitalist countries enjoy this status. Most Communist countries, including the Soviet Union, do not.
Under the Jackson-Vanik Amendment of 1974, a country with a non-market economy that restricts the right to emigrate is ineligible unless the President grants a waiver. Such waivers must be renewed annually, with the consent of Congress. President Bush's recommendation on China is due by June 3.
Washington first granted China a waiver in 1979, amid predictions that Deng Xiaoping's reforms would eventually produce a market economy with unrestricted emigration. For a decade, events supported those predictions. Exports to the U.S. soared. Areas like Guangdong Province and the Shenzen Special Economic Zone became engines of modernization and growth, showcases of reform. Stimulated by this new commerce, economic reform created a new China - capitalistic, urbanized and more engaged with the outside world. The older, more insular, less politicized, peasant China persists, more populous but losing ground.
These two Chinas clashed violently last June in Tiananmen Square. As in the 1930's, the armed peasantry wore People's Liberation Army uniforms. As in the 1930's, Communist propaganda portrayed urbanites as corrupted by foreign influence. Over the decades, however, peasant Maoism has lost its capacity to inspire and lead. The demise of today's aged leaders could spark a succession crisis, as the new China of Guangdong, Shenzen and, soon, Hong Kong try to renew China's frustrated advance.
Granted, extension of most-favored-nation privileges would permit the current leaders to gloat. Continued economic development coupled with political repression is their aim. But suspending trade preferences has little chance of deflecting them. If forced to choose, they've shown that they put repression first.
For the workers and entrepreneurs of China's new export industries, losing low tariff access to the U.S. would be disastrous. It would bring huge financial losses - and halt, even reverse, the modernizing trends that gave the pro-democracy movement its extraordinary resonance. Continuing favored-nation status would nourish China's progressive forces for the coming succession battles. Deng Xiaoping and his associates deserve to be pariahs. The Chinese deserve to be a favored nation.

HEADLINE: Another Kind of Peace Dividend?

 BODY:
Peace is breaking out in Central America -and maybe north of the border, too.
Four years ago, President Reagan warned that the Sandinistas in Nicaragua were consolidating ''a privileged sanctuary for terrorists and subversives just two days' driving time from Harlingen, Texas.'' Mr. Reagan's histrionic threat of invasion never materialized. Now, as Nicaragua's democratically elected President, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is taking office in Managua, Border Patrol stations near Harlingen and San Diego are reporting something like the opposite: fewer undocumented immigrants from Central America.
O.T.M.'s, they're called, ''other than Mexicans.'' In Texas and California, the vast majority of them come from Central America. Arrests of O.T.M.'s dropped by 50 percent in Harlingen and 43 percent in San Diego, comparing the first three months of 1990 and 1989. This reverses a three-year pattern in which O.T.M. arrests increased steeply. By contrast, apprehensions of Mexicans in the San Diego area increased by more than 60 percent in the first three months of 1990.
What accounts for the drop in non-Mexican arrests? The obvious speculative interpretation is that the border is a barometer of political violence and economic stress to the South. It may well be that Nicaraguans otherwise inclined to flee are now staying home to test the fruits of peace.
Political violence robs ''the slim waist of the Americas,'' as the Nicaraguan-born poet Ruben Dario lovingly called his home, of its greatest resource, its people. Refugees from El Salvador and Guatemala, where war and death squad violence drag on, also dream of the day they can return to their villages. If the O.T.M. pattern continues, diminished illegal immigration from Central America will be another, welcome kind of peace dividend.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Intelligence Fiasco

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
The central mission of U.S. intelligence is to gather and evaluate data on the economic and military strength of the Soviet Union in comparison with the U.S. We are now discovering how the C.I.A. has botched that assignment.
Throughout the 80's, our analysts clung to the notion that the Soviet economy was more than half as large as our own, and that 15 percent of its budget was devoted to arms. That was the bedrock estimate on which most other projections - and our own defense planning - was based. 
A handful of outside experts began to dissent from the official view in 1985. Led by Henry Rowen of Stanford (now with Defense), Charles Wolf of the Rand Corporation, the Russian emigre Igor Birmin and the Swedish economist Anders Aklund, the dissenters drew on startling Gorbachev admissions to arrive at a wholly different conclusion:
Growth had stopped in the Soviet Union as the 80's began; this meant that its economy had shrunk to less than a third the size of ours, and the percentage of Soviet national product spent on armaments had become an unsustainable 22 to 25 percent. (Each dissenter came up with a different percentage, but all differed from the C.I.A. on the essential points - that the Soviet economy was disaster-bound unless drastic arms cutbacks began right away.) When this disagreement was bared in this space two years ago, Director of Central Intelligence William Webster - not an uptight fellow - invited a couple of us to an on-the-record lunch at Langley. I outlined the views of the new thinkers and called for appointment of a ''team B''; the C.I.A. economists politely held their ground. As we left, I stole a C.I.A. ashtray and left behind a New York Times mug; Director Webster called it ''a fair exchange in more ways than one.''
The discussion was duly recorded in a column; the C.I.A. economists' contrary views were expressed in a letter to the editor from the staff of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, which has become a C.I.A. publications outlet.
Here we are in 1990. One side operated on shoestrings, the other on billions; which proved right?
The answer is evident in the C.I.A.'s catch-up analysis. ''The Soviet Economy Stumbles Badly in 1989'' is the title of Director Webster's recent report to his Joint Economic Receptacle; it is as if the decadelong decline - long ago divined by the unappointed ''team B'' - had mostly taken place in the past 12 months.
The agency belatedly discovers that the Soviet Union is in ''near crisis'' and might soon be pushed ''over the edge into sharp deterioration.'' Its assessment of the pressure on Mr. Gorbachev reads like a rehash of Judy Shelton's 1989 ''The Coming Soviet Crash'' with an update from Wellesley Prof. Marshall Goldman's excoriation of Gorbanomics in the latest Foreign Affairs magazine.
A few days after this C.I.A. epiphany, a trio of reformist Soviet economists came over to tell an American Enterprise Institute conference -headed by non-team B's Nicholas Eberstadt - how it really is. Oleg Bogomolov, who serves in the Congress of People's Deputies, said that Soviet military expenditure was 20 to 25 percent of G.N.P., contrary to the C.I.A.'s lowball 16 percent; Viktor Belkin, also a Gorbachevite, said that Soviet output was about one-fourth that of the U.S., not nearly the half that the C.I.A. still estimates.
These Soviet economists disagree with the official figures put out by their establishment, just as our outsiders dispute C.I.A. estimates. However, the C.I.A. is hustling over to the conclusion reached by the outsiders about the economic crisis forcing the Soviets to reduce arms spending. To avoid admitting egregious error, the C.I.A. will gradually revise its underlying estimates in future years to jibe with present conclusions.
Doesn't this huge miscalculation cry out for oversight? Economic intelligence has none.
The Senate Intelligence Committee defers to a Joint Economic subcommittee on these matters, and its dovish chairman, Jeff Bingaman, is putty in the hands of the C.I.A. In the National Security Council, the posterior coverage of the misguided evaluation is handled by former spook Robert Gates. And the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board is being limited to technological kibitzing.
As the Bay of Pigs was to intelligence operations, the extended misreading of the Soviet economic debacle is to intelligence evaluation. Yet this fiasco is ignored and concealed -even as the future C.I.A. mission must be redirected toward realistic assessments of economic and scientific strength.

HEADLINE: CUNY Says Budget Cut Affects Open Admission

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
Officials of the City University of New York have told the Dinkins administration that a major reduction in financing from New York City would threaten the university's 20-year-old open admissions policy.
The open admissions policy, which was begun in 1970, guarantees a place within the university system - generally at one of seven two-year community colleges - to any high school graduate. The policy has fueled the tremendous enrollment growth that has made CUNY the third-largest universty system in the nation. It has also provided the opportunity for many of the educationally disadvantaged, particularly minority students, to attend college. 
CUNY has faced serious financial crises before, including one that led to its closing for two weeks in 1976.
But university officials said yesterday that the warning to the city earlier this month, which came in an April 11 letter to the Budget Director, Phillip R. Michael, from Joseph F. Vivona, who was the university's vice chancellor for budget and finance, was the first time since open admissions began that CUNY officials had suggested that budget reductions might jeopardize its ability to absorb all applicants.
 
A 4 Percent Cutback
The university's assessment comes at a time when city agencies have been asked by Mayor David N. Dinkins to report to him on the effect of a possible 4 percent budget reduction in the 1990-91 fiscal year, which begins on July 1. A 4 percent cutback in the $279.5 million budget for the community colleges would be $9.1 million. Mr. Dinkins is expected to present his executive budget for the next fiscal year on May 17.
While the greater share of the university's overall $1.2 billion budget is financed by the state, the city currently contributes $122 million of the financing for the community colleges. Students are accepted into the community colleges if they have a high school diploma or a general equivalency diploma. Students applying to the university's 10 four-year undergraduate colleges must generally have a minimum high school average of 80 or be in the top one-third of their graduating class.
The community colleges currently enroll 60,000 of the university's 193,000 students.
In his letter, Mr. Vivona noted that the community colleges had absorbed several financing cuts by the city in the last decade and that this year the colleges had already eliminated hundreds of classes, stopped buying virtually all library materials and deferred many building repairs. ''Hundreds of class sections have been eliminated, thus increasing class sizes to levels which, in some cases, threaten effective learning,'' Mr. Vivona said.
He said a $9.1 million reduction could mean the elimination of nearly 10 percent of the current classes. ''Ultimately, implementation of the latest proposed budget reduction would jeopardize open admissions and render continuation of current enrollment levels impossible,'' Mr. Vivona said in his letter.
A spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, Albert Scardino, said yesterday that the Mayor's position was that there was no way to close the city's nearly $2 billion budget gap without imposing cuts on ''the order of magnitude of 4 percent.''
But Mr. Scardino said that how each agency absorbed the cuts was between the agency and the city's Office of Management and Budget. The budget office, he said, had prepared a list of suggestions on how CUNY could deal with the cutbacks, including an increase in class size.
Although Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature have not agreed on a budget for the fiscal year that began on April 1, they have already announced they will make major cuts in the budgets of both the City University and the State University of New York.

HEADLINE: A Week After Closing, 7 Days Wins a Magazine Award

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
The two-year-old weekly magazine 7 Days, which closed down last week, yesterday won a National Magazine Award for general excellence in magazines with circulations of less than 100,000.
To the wild applause of the 1,200 magazine editors and publishers who attended the annual presentation luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Adam Moss, the editor of 7 Days, thanked the judges for ''the first clean posthumous win.''
''We will wear that asterisk with particular pride,'' he said. 
Leonard Stern, publisher of 7 Days, announced on April 16 that the magazine would fold. Mr. Stern blamed, among other things, the severe competition for advertisers' dollars and the sluggish New York economy.
 
The New Yorker Wins Again
The National Magazine Awards, established in 1966 by the American Society of Magazine Editors, are administered by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America. The 14 winners were selected from 74 finalists. In all, 292 magazines submitted 1,239 entries. The awards carry no money, but each winner received a bronze plaque and a reproduction of an Alexander Calder stabile, ''Elephant.''
The New Yorker won the same two awards it won last year. It received its sixth citation for reporting for its three-part series ''Beyond the Mountains,'' by Mark Danner about civil warfare in Haiti. The magazine received its fourth award for fiction for three stories: ''Goodness and Mercy,'' by Alice Munro; ''The Trick of It,'' by Michael Frayn, and ''Letter to the Lady of the House,'' by Richard Bausch.
Texas Monthly also won two awards, one for general excellence in the 100,000-to-400,000 circulation category, and one for photography for a series of photo essays, including ''The Soul of East Texas''; ''Side by Side,'' about Mennonite farmers and Tarahumara Indians living in Northern Mexico, and ''Get Along, Little Doggies,'' a spoof of Texans' love for their boots and their dogs.
Sports Illustrated won the award for general excellence in the 1,000,000-and-over category. Metropolitan Home won the general excellence award for the 400,000-to-1,000,00 slot.
 
Styron Essay Wins for Vanity Fair
Vanity Fair received the award for essays and criticism for ''Darkness Visible,'' an essay by the novelist William Styron, who at the age of 60 fell into a clinical depression and found himself on the verge of suicide.
Consumer Reports won the award for personal service for ''Beyond Medicare,'' by Trudy Lieberman, a comprehensive examination of the Medicare system.
Arts & Antiques won in the special-interests category for ''What's Not Hot.''
The Washingtonian won the feature-writing award for its profile by Katie McCabe of Vivien Thomas, a laboratory assistant who, without formal scientific training, became a pioneer in cardiovascular medicine.
The public-interest award went to Southern Exposure for three articles on the chicken industry that resulted in fines and legislative action intended to make the industry safer for workers and customers.
The design award went to Esquire for its issues of April, June and November, 1989.
National Geographic won the single-topic award for an issue in which 50 percent or more of the editorial content is devoted to one subject, in this case the celebration of France's bicentennial in the July 1989 issue.

HEADLINE: India Is Expected to Remain On U.S. Trade 'Hit List'

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
As President Bush's Cabinet-level Economic Policy Council met today to consider which countries to target for reprisal under 1988 trade legislation, Administration officials said that India was likely to remain on their ''hit list'' but that Brazil, like Japan, had worked its way off.
The two largest third world democracies were cited last year, along with Japan, as having the most onerous barriers to American trade. Unlike the other two, India has made no concessions. It has taken the position that it cannot submit to another nation's law. 
''How do you not name India this year and maintain credibility of our law?'' asked a senior Administration official, who requested anonymity.
The President did not meet with the Cabinet group today and has not yet made a decision, according to White House officials. The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told the Senate Finance Committee yesterday that India ''is truly out of step with the historic changes taking place around the globe,'' a reference to market liberalization and deregulation spreading in Eastern Europe and the third world.
The 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act imposes a Monday deadline for setting trade policy priorities. The law generated a similar procedure last year, creating the initial list of countries to be subject to reprisals.
 
'A Fantastic Change'
Mrs. Hills contrasted the Indian experience with the ''very happy story'' of Brazil, which has undertaken ''a fantastic change in policy'' under its newly elected President, Fernando Collor de Mello.
Brazil is not only cutting protectionist barriers but has also agreed to submit for international settlement the licensing restrictions for imports cited by the United States in last year's complaint.
Mrs. Hills said yesterday that because of three important agreements to open Japanese markets for wood products, satellites and supercomputers, Japan should not be cited again. It is expected to be dropped from the list with a warning that trade reprisal weapons remain, should difficulties persist.
Much of the political debate has centered on Japan. ''If we have learned anything over the years that we have fought to reduce our monumental trade deficit with Japan, it is that the only thing that works is clear, constant, consistent pressure for needed change,'' said House majority leader Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who made an America First trade policy the linchpin of his unsuccessful bid for his party's 1988 Presidential nomination. .
But the Indian situation has also raised some basic issues. The trade law's Super 301 provision, which increases the likelihood of retaliation against countries that do not lower barriers on United States products, was aimed chiefly at Japan.
The United States is Japan's largest export market, and Japan is this country's second-largest export market after Canada. Over the last decade, the United States has run deficits with Japan approaching a total of $400 billion. Last year's deficit was $49 billion, and total trade between the two countries was $138.2 billion. In contrast, total trade with India last year was $5.8 billion. India was the United States' 27th-largest export market. Why India? ''Surely we must be inconsequential to the American economy,'' an Indian businessman said at the United States-India Bilateral Business Conference in Washington. ''Why then will we remain under 301?'' he asked Mrs. Hills.
She replied that India, with its population of 850 million, represented a potentially huge market. ''We select our trade liberalization priorities on the basis of those which have maximum potential for U.S. exporters and for the world at large,'' she stressed.
India was cited last year for a ban on operations of foreign private insurance companies and for controls on foreign investment that distort world trade. Both issues are important in the context of global market-opening that the United States is seeking in the so-called Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks.
Now being negotiated by 105 Governments in Geneva, the round aims at lowering barriers in services like insurance that account for ever growing portions of world trade. Other goals include ending trade distortions from foreign investment regulations, improving protection for copyrights, trademarks, patents and other intellectual property and wiping out farm export subsidies.
 
A Hard Line
India, which maintains one of the most protected economies in the world, has taken a hard line against not only the bilateral American trade demands but also the objectives of the Uruguay Round. The new Government of Prime Minister Vishwanath Pratap Singh has been cool to foreign investment and unwilling to promise anything more than what it terms a ''gradual'' tariff cutting.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Rise Above 9%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates moved above 9 percent yesterday for the first time in nearly a year, continuing a rise that will crimp certain sectors of the economy.
Since mid-December, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds, the benchmark most often used in setting rates on a wide variety of debts, including home mortgages, have risen by more than a full percentage point, and prices have fallen for 9 of the last 10 days.
If the trend continues, economists said, the rate increase will hurt the housing and construction industries, but have relatively little impact elsewhere.
 
Housing Demand 'Is Pretty Weak'
''The rate rise comes at a time when demand in the housing market is pretty weak, and it will hit that sector pretty hard,'' said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. ''But a rise of a little over one percentage point in long-term interest rates is not going to kill the economy.'' 
The increase over the last four and a half months has been caused by a number of factors, some international, many domestic. For the last month or so, developments in the United States have caused the greatest worries. There are signs of more rapid economic growth and rising inflation than were anticipated at the start of the year, and traders fear the Federal Reserve might tighten credit, which would further raise rates and depress bond prices.
Those concerns were paramount in the credit markets yesterday, as dealers in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds sold securities in advance of the Commerce Department's preliminary estimate of first-quarter economic growth, which is to be released today.
Most economists expect the report to show that the economy grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 2.5 percent or better in the first quarter, up from the 1.1 percent rise in the previous quarter, in large part because of unseasonably warm weather.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 94 14/32, down 3/4 point, to yield 9.04 percent. This is the first time that the bellwether issue has closed at a yield of more than 9 percent since May 11, 1989.
The rise in money-market interest rates, however, has not yet prompted the Federal Reserve Board to tighten its grip on monetary policy by raising the rate on overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market, and some economists do not believe it will do so. That rate has stayed around 8 1/4 percent since mid-December.
''My guess is the Fed won't tighten policy,'' said Mr. Gramley, a former Fed governor. ''There is not enough evidence of economic resurgence or rising inflation to warrant that sort of action.''
 
Chrysler's $1 Billion Issue
But economic worries were not the only reason for yesterday's selloff. Traders and analysts said the sale of $1 billion of long-term bonds backed by the Chrysler Corporation also played a role, as some dealers adjusted their portfolios to accommodate the new issue, which bankers said sold out quickly.
The offering, for Auburn Hills Trust, a technical center under construction in Auburn Hills, Mich., is unconditionally guranteed by Chrysler. The 12 3/8 percent issue, which matures on May 1, 2020, was priced at $100. Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which was increased in size from $800 million. It is rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A number of other analysts agree with Mr. Gramley that economic worries are overblown, and that some of the recent run-up in rates will subsequently be retraced.
''I don't see where the supposed strength in the economy is, and I don't think inflation pressures are anywhere near as bad as the market does,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior adviser to the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
 
Rising Volume of Financings
Mr. Chimerine expects the second quarter's economic reports will calm some of the market's fears. But, he said, the rising volume of Treasury debt financings will help to keep interest rates higher than they might otherwise be.
William Melton, a vice president and chief economist at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis, agreed that the increasing financings were a problem. ''There is a concern that the supply problem is going to get worse and worse,'' he said.
Increasingly higher cost estimates for bailing out the nation's savings and loan industry have created ''a kind of dread that there will be a tidal wave of Treasury bonds in drag,'' Mr. Melton said.
The Resolution Funding Corporation, the financing arm charged with raising the money for the bailout, issues its securities through the Treasury Department, and the quarterly Treasury refunding auctions will take place in early May. Such large-scale borrowing ''will prevent rates from falling back toward 8 percent,'' he said.
 
Notes Fall Sharply
Yesterday's deterioration in Treasury prices was not confined to bonds.
In the secondary note market, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 14/32, down 17/32, to yield 9.05 percent.
And the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes auctioned Wednesday at an average yield of 8.90 percent were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 9.04 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.81 percent late yesterday, up 5 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by a like amount, to a late offered rate of 7.99 percent.
The fall in Treasury prices once again took a toll on the secondary market for investment-grade corporate securities. Dealers said prices of most issues fell by as much as 3/4 point.
 
Lower Citicorp Ratings
The announcement that Standard & Poor's had lowered its ratings on $30 billion of Citicorp's outstanding debt was made after most trading had ended.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, dealers said prices of most actively traded issues fell by 5/8 point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended April 16. The report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Global Program For Environment

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WITH the ebbing of the cold war, the environmental issue is moving up on the international agenda. And it is also moving up on the corporate agenda, as demonstrated by this week's Exxon stockholders' meeting in Houston at which a series of environmental initiatives were defeated even as top management insisted upon its commitment to environmental protection.
Is the environment a ''motherhood issue''? Indeed, one problem in dealing with the topic is that everybody insists he or she is devoted to preserving the environment, but there is intense conflict over how to do it and at what cost to taxpayers, business or national economic interests.
Last week at Harriman, N.Y., the American Assembly, a forum founded by Dwight D. Eisenhower when he was president of Columbia University, brought together 76 leading scientists, economists, business executives, political scientists and politicians, international officials and environmentalists from 19 countries to tackle the environmental problem. 
After four days of debate, the participants concluded that the danger of global warming was so severe that the United States should take immediate action to lessen it. That conclusion came, as the assembly statement noted, ''just days after a White House conference on the same subject at which the President and other Administration officials refused to acknowledge that the risks of global warming are sufficiently clear to merit immediate action.''
In sharp contradiction to the Administration's position, the assembly declared: ''There is a scientific consensus that rising concentrations of greenhouse gases will cause global climate change. Therefore, the earth is set to experience substantial climate change of unknown scale and rate. The consequences are likely to include sea level rise, greater frequency of extreme weather events, disruptions of ecosystems and potentially vast impacts on the global economy.''
It made specific recommendations on how to reduce those dangers. Warning of the ''irreversibility'' of some threats to the environment unless prompt action was taken, it called for a 20 percent reduction by the year 2005 in global carbon dioxide emissions from burning gasoline, coal, oil and other fossil fuels. And it recommended that the United States enact a ''large, phased-in increase in the Federal tax on gasoline and the adoption of a carbon dioxide emissions fee applicable to the uses of fossil fuels.''
While a large majority of the participants wanted all countries to impose such taxes on carbons, they insisted that the United States, which has lower gasoline taxes than other industrial countries, should act at once on fuel taxes. But there was no consensus on whether to restrict the use of funds raised from taxes on gasoline and other carbon fuels only for developing safer technologies and other environmental purposes, rather than for other purposes.
Even a heavy fuel tax would be only the beginning of an effective global program. The assembly observed that the environmental threat stemmed from three ''indivisibly linked'' global trends: human population growth, with world population, now at 5.2 billion, headed for 14 billion by the middle of the next century at present rates of growth; tropical deforestation and the rapid loss of biological diversity, and global atmospheric change, including stratospheric ozone loss and greenhouse warming.
On population policy, it again criticized the Administration in urging that family planning be supported and made available ''to those who want it'' throughout the world, which it estimated would cost $10 billion a year by 2000. ''Ultimately,'' the assembly stated, ''no Administration can be regarded as serious about the environment unless it is serious about global population growth.''
The threat to the global environment stems both from poverty and from affluence: poverty in the developing countries, which drives poor people to cut down forests and to have more children for the sake of family security, and affluence in the industrial countries, where rising income leads to an increase of polluting fuels and technologies.
As wealth and poverty can both lead to environmental destruction, so can both Communism and capitalism - and the worst of these is almost certainly Communism, with its restrictions of public pressure on bureaucrats, and with the lack of private property giving scant incentive to individuals to protect their land and other resources.
Delegates from Eastern Europe attending the assembly, which was also sponsored by the World Resources Institute, felt that their physical environments were among the worst in the world. They sought collaboration between their countries and the United States, including private business, on the environment. ''Such collaboration,'' the assembly agreed, ''is a commercial opportunity, and should be one of the more economically efficient ways of reducing environmental degradation.''
Business people from the West insisted that they should not be regarded as ''the enemy,'' but rather as potential solvers of environmental problems. Some called for creation of a ''business forum'' to work with governments and environmental groups. And the assembly reached consensus in urging governments to encourage ''environmental enterpreneurship'' through the use of taxes, subsidies and other signals.
But the environment is no more a ''motherhood problem'' than, say, motherhood itself, as the abortion debate proves.

HEADLINE: Some Savings Fraud Cases Will Slide By, Official Says

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The Federal Government is unlikely to prosecute all the major savings and loan fraud cases that are pending or to recover most of the assets of failed institutions, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today.
''Can we reach every major case? Probably not,'' Mr. Thornburgh said. ''Most of these assets have been frittered away.''
In his appearance before the Senate Appropriations Committee he responded to questions on whether the department would be able to handle the backlog of 1,300 major fraud cases against savings associations and their officials.
The cases are criminal referrals to the Justice Department. In some of them an investigation has begun; in others, one is about to begin, financed by the $50 million set aside for such investigations in the savings-bailout bill enacted last summer.
The Justice Department said it intended to assign the cases priority based first on their size and significance, and then on whether the case might face difficulties with the deadline posed by the statute of limitations. The statute of limitations under the bailout bill is 10 years.
''These are extremely difficult cases; we are trying to concentrate on major cases,'' Mr. Thornburgh said.
While weak regional economies, particularly in the Southwest, were initially blamed for much of the savings industry's troubles, regulators now say that fraud played a much larger role than originally thought.
Some Government experts have said the bailout of the savings industry could cost as much as $500 billion over the next 30 years.
Mr. Thornburgh said he was trying to focus the Justice Department's resources on several areas, all of which are competing for attention. They include drug prosecutions and white-collar crime, in addition to savings industry fraud, he said.

HEADLINE: J.&J.'s Profit Plunges 23.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. April 26

 BODY:
Johnson & Johnson, the health-care products giant, said today that its profit declined 23.2 percent in the first quarter because of repayment of a loan in Argentina. The company said sales increased 16.1 percent in the quarter. 
Earnings for the period were $244 million, or 73 cents a share, on sales of $2.84 billion, compared with $317 million, or 95 cents a share, on sales of $2.45 billion for the corresponding period last year.
The 1990 results were reduced by a nonrecurring charge of $125 million for paying off an Argentine subsidiary's loan that was growing rapidly because of inflation in that country. Without the repayment, the company said, earnings would have increased 16.4 percent.
''We are very pleased with the 16 percent increase in sales, especially in the light of the extreme competitive environment in the domestic consumer environment,'' Johnson & Johnson's chairman, Ralph S. Larsen, said. ''The increase reflects substantial sales gains from worldwide and professional operations, as well as strong international revenues from our consumer businesses.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Up as Traders Await Information on G.N.P.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
After falling in Europe, the dollar finished mostly higher yesterday in dull trading in the United States. The trading was limited, analysts said, as those in the market waited for today's release of first-quarter data on the gross national product.
''It was a corrective uptick,'' said James Chorek, an analyst at Money Market Services in Chicago. ''There wasn't much happening on fundamental ground to move the dollar one way or another.'' 
Analysts said the dollar got some support late in the day when bond prices dropped, pushing the interest rate on the Treasury's key 30-year bond to more than 9 percent for the first time since May. Rising American rates usually bolster the dollar.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a close of 158.77 Japanese yen, from 159.25 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar fell to 158.75 yen. By the end of the day in New York, however, the dollar had risen to 159.23 yen, from 158.73 yen late Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6340, from $1.6370 late Wednesday. Later, in New York, a pound fetched $1.6342, down from $1.6405 the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Wednesday, included: 1.6797 West German marks, up from 1.6780 marks; 1.4575 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6355 French francs, up from 5.6345; 1,231.75 Italian lire, up from 1,231.00, and 1.1603 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1608.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's, included: 1.6810 West German marks, down from 1.6820; 1.4605 Swiss francs, down from 1.4665; 5.6395 French francs, down from 5.6455; 1.8915 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8970; 1,231.00 Italian lire, down from 1,234.00, and 1.1602 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1603.
Gold prices fell in New York after rising in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $370.50 an ounce, down from $370.70 late Wednesday. Also in New York, the Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $370.60 an ounce as of 4 P.M., down from $371.25 late Wednesday.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $372.65 an ounce, from $371.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $372.75, from $371.00 late Wednesday.
Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.92 to close at a bid of $373.03.
Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.96 an ounce, from $4.97 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspaper Executives See Falling Profits

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 26

 BODY:
Executives at some of the nation's largest communications companies said here today that a broad and deep slump in newspaper advertising would hurt profits this year.
''It will not be one of our better years,'' said Warren H. Phillips, the chairman of Dow Jones & Company, adding that the company's long-term prospects remained bright.
Representatives of The New York Times Company, Multimedia Inc. and the Tribune Company expressed similar judgments to analysts gathered here to assess the financial health of the industry at the John Morton Forum, which continues on Friday.
The forum is organized by Mr. Morton, a newspaper analyst for Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a Washington brokerage, and has become an annual tradition in which many of the nation's newspaper-oriented communications companies describe their situations before analysts and reporters. 17% Profit Margins Mr. Morton said the forum's fundamental message seemed to be that newspaper profit margins, which have averaged about 20 percent over the last decade, have slipped now to about 17 percent and might decline further, to an average of about 15 percent in the 1990's. 
''It is clear that newspapers are going to be twice as profitable as most other businesses, but maybe not three or four times,'' he said.
Most newspaper-oriented companies have now diversified into other segments of the communications business, like broadcasting, newsprint manufacturing, cable televison, entertainment and electronic data delivery.
And while newspaper profits are being squeezed everywhere, each company's overall situation depends on its particular mix of businesses.
Walter E. Bartlett, the chairman of Multimedia, which publishes The Greenville (S.C.) News and produces the ''Donahue'' talk show, said his company had benefited from having about equal holdings in four communications businesses - newspapers, broadcasting, cable and entertainment.
 
Cable Profit at 55%
While the advertising slump has hurt newspapers and broadcasting, Multimedia's cable and entertainment divisions remain highly profitable. For instance, he said, cash flow operating profit margins at its cable systems were 55 percent or better.
Walter E. Mattson, the president of The New York Times Company, said the company's primary holding, The New York Times, had been badly hurt by the poor economy in New York City and the Northeast.
Mr. Mattson said that The Times was likely to have continued losses in advertising volume in the coming year, but added that he thought that the overall economy would improve, and advertising along with it.
''No one predicts a return to the boom of the 80's,'' Mr. Mattson said, adding that he thought the current slump would bottom out next year and that The Times would show advertising growth in 1992, barring a national recession.
 
Controlling Costs
A recurring theme at the forum was a determination to keep costs under careful control.
Peter R. Kann, the president of Dow Jones, said advertising volume was down by about 4 percent in the company's business publications division, whose principal publication is The Wall Street Journal.
But he said that the division's costs were up by only 1.3 percent in 1989 and that they were holding at that level in the first quarter of this year, while advertising revenues rose because of a rate increase after circulation improved.
The overall result was a 20 percent increase in operating income for the first quarter, compared with the corresponding period in 1989. But Mr. Kann said the division's operating income was off by 50 percent since the stock market crash of Oct. 19, 1987, which had a severe impact on financial advertising.
Mr. Phillips, the company's chairman, said Dow Jones's profits this year would be hurt by start-up costs associated with the company's new electronic foreign-exchange service for currency investors and because of expenses related to the acquisition of the portion of Telerate Inc., the electronic data service, that Dow Jones did not own.
 
Tribune's Outlook
Charles T. Brumback, the chairman of the Chicago-based Tribune Company, said the company's profits for the year would probably be hurt by continuing losses at The Daily News in New York and by costs associated with labor negotiations now under way with the paper's 10 unions. He declined to say what those labor costs would be.
He said, however, that the company's entertainment division was expected to be highly profitable this year. The company also owns the Chicago Cubs baseball team.
The Tribune Company and The New York Times Company also have newsprint manufacturing operations and have been hurt by depressed newsprint prices caused by oversupply and heavy discounting.
Mr. Mattson and Mr. Brumback said they thought an announced increase in newsprint prices by $35 a metric ton would not be undercut by further discounting.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
When an Ad Takes Off but Product Stalls

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
IT is one of the best-known advertising campaigns in the country and yet the product it sells has experienced a slide in market share since the effort began four years ago.
The television commercials of Lintas Campbell-Ewald's ''Heartbeat of America'' campaign for Chevrolet are famed for slow-motion shots of parents frolicking with their children and the insistent thump of the ''Listen to the Heartbeat of America'' song.
Although print ads are often less memorable than television, both ''Heartbeat'' executions have scored consistently high in consumer recall. The ''Heartbeat'' campaign scored No. 3 in Adweek's ''America's Favorite Print Campaigns,'' behind Ford and Pepsi-Cola. 
Yet Chevrolet is losing ground. According to Ward's Communications Inc., a leading trade publisher, Chevrolet's share of the American car market in 1986, when ''Heartbeat'' began, totaled about 15 percent. By 1989, it declined to 13.6 percent.
Bob Garfield, a columnist for Advertising Age, took notice of the gap between the campaign's visibilty and Chevrolet's sales. ''I may be the only person in the hemisphere to think so,'' he wrote recently, ''but my view is that 'Heartbeat' is simply a glitzy, stylish, somewhat sexy, extremely catchy, painstakingly cultivated archetype of puffery - because Chevrolet is not the heartbeat of America.''
He added, ''It's a declining entry-level car brand, and it desperately needs to communicate quality and value, not some fading vestige of ubiquity.''
In its April 14 cover article on the American automobile industry, The Economist, the British weekly, also criticized the ''Heartbeat'' campaign. ''Appeals to national pride, never very effective with America's discriminating shoppers, have backfired,'' the magazine said.
Sean K. Fitzpatrick, who led the Lintas team that developed the campaign, takes both views to task. ''To say the least, they are dead wrong,'' said Mr. Fitzpatrick, now vice chairman of McCann-Erickson Inc.
The Economist critique ignores a fundamental change in the automotive market, Mr. Fitzpatrick said: Many Chevrolet customers have turned to light trucks.
Indeed, it is true that Chevrolet is selling more light trucks, and these vehicles are also a part of the ''Heartbeat'' campaign, he said.
When light trucks are added in, Chevrolet's market share fell less steeply, to 18.1 percent last year from 18.3 percent in 1986, according to Ward's.
Moreover, ''every manufacturer has taken declines because there are more competitors,'' said Dannielle K. Colliver, Chevrolet's advertising manager for passenger cars.
Besides, Mr. Fitzpatrick said, ''advertising does not sell cars, dealers sell cars.''
William J. Ludwig, the current chief of the ''Heartbeat'' campaign at Lintas, makes a similar point. ''Our job is to cause customer consideration - to get Chevrolet on the shopping list,'' he said.
Dealers are happy with the campaign, according to the Lintas and other surveys, Mr. Ludwig said. One out of three car shoppers visits a Chevrolet dealer, he said.
''I think Heartbeat's a great concept that really gets people in the door,'' said Michael A. Inzirillo, the sales manager for B. K. Chevrolet Inc. in Brooklyn, which sells more than 1,000 cars annually.
Before the ''Heartbeat'' campaign, Chevrolet was having difficulty luring customers into the showrooms, Mr. Fitzpatrick and Mr. Ludwig say.
In the 10 years before ''Heartbeat,'' Mr. Ludwig said, Chevrolet had more than 20 campaigns, most of them short-term drives to increase sales rather than efforts to build brand recognition. ''We are USA-1 and USA-1 is taking charge,'' was one such effort.
Chevrolet also suffered from an unusually poor image among young car buyers, Mr. Fitzpatrick said. In 1984 and 1985, ''We asked people what they thought of Chevy,'' he recalled. ''And young girls would tell us that if they looked out the window and saw their date drive up in a Honda, they'd think, 'Must be a cool guy.' But if their date drove up in a Chevy, they wouldn't even come out the door.''
If part of the public was hostile, Chevrolet itself had difficulty knowing its own mind, Mr. Fitzpatrick said. In late 1985 and 1986, Lintas surveyed the company's top 100 executives, asking them what Chevrolet meant to them, and got back 5,000 pages of notes. Lintas boiled the responses down to a 100-word mission statement that became ''Heartbeat.''
The statement said that ''Chevrolet markets a variety of vehicles that are better than you expect, given the cost, and that are excellent cars but without the Tiffany accouterments,'' Mr. Fitzpatrick said.
Recent stylish changes in product line have also helped, he said, because Chevrolet cars used to seem relatively anonymous. ''We used to joke that Cavaliers and Celebrities were the favorite cars of bank robbers,'' he said. ''Get in one and you just fade into the background.''
Will General Motors stick with the ''Heartbeat'' campaign? ''We'll eventually change it, but not for the next few years,'' Ms. Colliver of Chevrolet said. ''Because nothing lives forever.''

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Temporarily Banning Gene-Engineered Drug for Cows

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

 BODY:
In a decision that could spell enormous trouble for the fledgling agricultural biotechnology industry, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin yesterday approved legislation that temporarily bars the sale or use of a genetically engineered drug for use in dairy cows.
The action is the first prohibition of a product of genetic engineering anywhere in the country, and it sets off another temporary ban of the drug in neighboring Minnesota. On Thursday, Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota signed into law a measure barring the drug there for a year; the measure was to become effective only if Wisconsin enacted its ban.
Mr. Thompson, a first-term Republican running for re-election in November, said the temporary ban, until June 1, 1991, would be ''sufficient to allow for additional farmer and consumer education'' on the drug's use and would not ''compromise Wisconsin's ability to compete in the national and international markets.'' The temporary ban was a political compromise between forces favoring a permanent ban and those opposing any ban. 
 
Development of Drug
The genetically engineered drug, bovine somatotropin (soh-mat-uh-TROPE-in), is a nearly identical copy of a naturally occurring protein produced by cows that helps to control milk production. In the early 1980's scientists isolated the gene that produces the protein, duplicated it and inserted it into common bacteria that are capable of producing unlimited quantities of the drug.
The Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve the drug next year, but any state bans still in effect would remain in force in those states. Because it is not yet on the market, the immediate economic effects of the bans in the nation's largest and fourth-largest milk-producing states are not likely to be significant, agricultural biotechnology industry executives said.
But the political and symbolic significance to the agricultural biotechnology industry could be profound, said industry analysts. Since the development of genetic engineering in the early 1970's, companies using the technology to invent new microbes, plants and drugs for use in agriculture have been convulsed by waves of dissent from environmental groups, farmers and other opponents.
At issue is whether the products will do more to harm farmers, consumers and rural communities than to help them. Developers of the drug - Monsanto, American Cyanamid, Eli Lilly and Upjohn - say bovine somatotropin is a triumph of technology that will cause cows to produce 10 to 25 percent more milk on less feed, thus raising productivity and profits. Opponents of the drug say it will drive farmers out of business by encouraging overproduction, and they say questions about its effect on human health have not been adequately answered.
The supporters of the temporary ban said Mr. Thompson's action was a turning point for farmers and consumers in a long struggle against technology that they say encourages the extinction of small farms and harms the quality of food.
 
Intense Activity in Wisconsin
Nowhere has the political activity been more intense than in Wisconsin, which has more dairy farms than any other state, and where small dairy farmers are going out of business at a surprisingly swift rate. More than 10,000 dairy farms disappeared from the state's countryside in the 1980's, about a quarter of the total.
''This is going to send shock waves in the investment community,'' said Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington, a group opposing biotechnology development that is leading the campaign to ban the drug.
''We have clearly demonstrated that we can mount a political campaign to defeat biotechnology,'' he added. ''Some of these products have no redeeming value. This one is bad for the farms. It's bad for the cows. It's bad for taxpayers who will have to pay for all that extra milk. The only winners would be the four companies trying to bring it to market.''
Executives in farm biotechnology reacted to the action with a mix of relief and dismay. They noted that when the campaign to bar the drug began in the Midwest four years ago, the aim was a ban that was permanent.
''It's very positive clear signal that we're not going to be stormed over by emotionalism,'' said Robert E. Walton, president of Grace Animal Services, a division of W. R. Grace & Company, in DeForrest, Wis.
 
Race to Market Hormone
The four corporations racing each other to bring the hormone to the market have spent at least $500 million on its development and had counted on its success as the foundation to their programs in agricultural biotechnology. The worldwide market for bovine somatotropin has been estimated at $500 million to $1 billion a year.
Yet ever since Monsanto announced in 1985 that field trials at Cornell University in New York had produced spectacular gains in milk production, the drug's future has been clouded by political campaigns, protests, boycotts and other actions by opponents. Last summer, for instance, some of the nation's largest supermarket chains said they would not accept for use in their dairy products any milk from herds treated with the drug.
Mr. Thompson said his decision was a compromise intended to satisfy opponents and supporters of the drug. But the drug's opponents saw the decision as a clear victory.
''Although the Governor has tried to dodge the issue, he did in fact finally agree with our point that Wisconsin is not ready for bovine growth hormone,'' said State Senator Russell Feingold, a Democrat, who has led the battle in the Legislature for four years. ''It's a milestone. We've served notice on Monsanto and the others that money alone does not control Wisconsin.''
In St. Louis, Laurence J. O'Neill, a spokesman for the Monsanto Company, which has spent $300 million on developing the drug, said: ''We're disappointed by this temporary setback but don't regard it as significant for the long term future of BST or biotechnology. The real losers are the state's dairy farmers who will not have the same freedom as farmers in other parts of the country to immeidately begin using BST to improve their profitability. The product's merits will carry the day over the long term.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Legislation approved yesterday by Gov. Tommy Thompson bans a genetically engineered drug for use in dairy cows in Wisconsin. (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
LITHUANIA REPORTS PROMISING CONTACT WITH SOVIET AIDES

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, April 27

 BODY:
The political impasse over Lithuania's independence appears to be moving closer to a resolution after the intervention of the French and German leaders and backstage contacts between Moscow and the rebellious republic, officials here said today.
The Lithuanian Government expressed interest today in a letter from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France proposing that the republic temporarily suspend enforcement of its declaration of independence as a gesture to get substantive negotiations with Moscow under way.
''Perhaps this could be considered as a compromise,'' said Lithuania's Prime Minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene. ''How far Lithuania can get toward this should be the object of discussion in the Lithuanian Parliament. I do not think that these two countries have taken a position hostile to the interests of Lithuania.'' 
 
Consultations in the West
Mrs. Prunskiene said the idea was ''close to something that has already been discussed'' by Lithuanian leaders. [Despite suggestions that a compromise might be nearer, the Kremlin tightened its economic blockade of Lithuania early Saturday by announcing a cutoff in coal supplies, Reuters reported, quoting a dispatch from the official news Soviet agency Tass. Vladimir Kostyunin, Deputy Chairman of the State Committee for Material and Technical Supplies, said the supplies were halted because the republic had not paid for coal it had already received, according to the Tass report, which was monitored in London by the British Broadcasting Corporation.] The Kohl-Mitterrand letter came after intensive consultations in Washington and other Western capitals on how best to ease negotiations between Moscow and Vilnius. As a result of the discussions, President Bush, who was inclined to avoid putting the Kremlin in a corner by invoking sanctions, said earlier this week that he had decided not to penalize Moscow for the time being in the hope that this would lead to talks with the Lithuanians.
Lithuanian officials said that after several days of being ignored in Moscow, they were received by high-ranking aides to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. One Lithuanian said that the talks seemed to represent a thaw.
President Vytautas Landsbergis, who has staunchly refused to make any concessions until Moscow and Lithuania begin official negotiations, called the letter ''a step forward toward realization of Lithuanian independence.'' But he stopped short of saying he would agree to the proposal, and called on Moscow to make a good-will gesture of its own by lifting its nine-day-old embargo on oil, gas and industrial raw materials.
Romas Gudaitis, a member of an official Lithuanian delegation that returned today from Moscow, said the leaders of the republic's Parliament planned to meet this weekend to work out a package of measures that could be construed as a gesture of compromise toward Moscow.
He said the measures under discussion included conceding to Moscow the right to maintain military bases in Lithuania and spelling out in law the republic's economic ties to the Soviet Union, but he declined to discuss other steps that might be considered.
''A search is under way,'' Mr. Gudaitis said, adding that ''we need a clever formulation'' to insure that Lithuania goes to the bargaining table as an equal partner with Moscow, and not as a political subject.
 
Reaching a Middle Ground
The carefully worded letter from Mr. Kohl and Mr. Mitterrand represents a middle ground between Mr. Gorbachev's demand that the republic return to the Soviet fold and seek independence under Soviet law and the Lithuanian insistence that the republic's declaration of sovereignty is irrevocable.
The two leaders proposed that Lithuania ''suspend for a certain time the effects of the decisions taken by your Parliament,'' without disavowing the declaration of independence.
Lithuania's decrees on independence, the two Europeans added, ''would not in any way lose their value since they are based upon a universally accepted principle: the principle of peoples' right to self-determination.''
Lithuanians said the letter was important because it was highly unlikely that the European leaders would have risked diplomatic embarrassment by offering such a proposal without consulting Moscow.
Moreover, they said, by sending the letter Mr. Kohl and Mr. Mitterrand have invested their own political credibility in the dispute. If Lithuania accepts their advice and Mr. Gorbachev spurns it, or if Mr. Gorbachev fails to bargain in good faith in the ensuing negotiations, France and Germany would also have some basis to feel betrayed.
At a news conference today, Prime Minister Prunskiene said that after an earlier snub by the State Department she had been given a visa to enter the United States next week on an unofficial visit to plead with bankers, business leaders and senators for aid during the economic embargo. The United States scuttled an earlier request for a visit out of fear that it would disrupt the climate for Mr. Gorbachev's summit meeting with President Bush in Washington, which begins on May 30.
Even before the Kohl-Mitterrand letter arrived on Thursday, Moscow had begun sending diplomatic feelers probing the Lithuanians' openness to a face-saving settlement.
After several days of being studiously ignored in Moscow, Mr. Gudaitis and his fellow Lithuanian officials spent an hour on Thursday with Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov, and chatted with Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, who advises Mr. Gorbachev on military affairs.
 
Earlier Talks Broken Off
Mr. Gudaitis said the talks produced ''nothing new'' but they seemed to represent a thaw. He said that the Lithuanians had earlier begun talks with Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a Politburo member regarded as Mr. Gorbachev's closest ally, but that these discussions broke off after word of them was leaked to the Lithuanian press.
Another member of Mr. Gorbachev's inner circle, the economist Stanislav S. Shatalin, talked on Thursday with Eduardas Vilkas, a prominent member of a bloc in the Lithuanian Parliament that favors a more pragmatic approach to Moscow.
''From his words, it was clear that Gorbachev very much wants to solve this,'' said Mr. Vilkas, the director of the Lithuanian Institute of Economics. Mr. Vilkas said that Moscow itself was paying a high price for its economic sanctions against Lithuania, including industrial disruptions.

GRAPHIC: Lithuania expressed interest yesterday in a compromise plan proposed by France and Germany to ease its negotiations with Moscow. Despite the Kremlin's economic blockade of the Baltic republic, the supply of goods appeared plentiful as shoppers in Vilnius bought teacups. (Associated Press)(pg4)
