HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
9 G.O.P. Senators Attack Bush on Lithuania

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
President Bush's policy of seeking not to damage relations with the Soviet Union during the Lithuanian crisis came under sharp attack today by nine Republican senators, marking the first serious break in Congressional support for the Administration's handling of the Baltic situation.
The senators called on the Administration to renounce the trade agreement that American and Soviet negotiators reached in principle on Thursday, saying it was ill-timed because of the Soviet crackdown on Lithuania.
Until today, Mr. Bush's decision not to impose sanctions against Moscow for its economic embargo of Lithuania had been greeted mostly with bipartisan approval. But the trade agreement has apparently galvanized conservative lawmakers who privately questioned Mr. Bush's decisions. 
The senators, many of whom have strongly backed President Bush's foreign policy stands, were unusually critical today, though they were careful not to attack the President personally.
 
'Callous,' Humphrey Says
''I am appalled at the lack of sensitivity by the White House towards the Lithuanian people as they desperately struggle to reassert independence,'' said Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hamphshire. ''To announce an agreement liberalizing trade with the Soviets, two days after the President revealed he would assess no penalty against the Soviets for their bullying of Lithuania, is callous and unfeeling in the extreme.''
Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, was not one of the nine senators who criticized the President. But in separate comments today, he suggested that he would ''slow walk'' the trade pact through Congress. ''We shouldn't be doing the Kremlin any favors right now,'' he said. George J. Mitchell, the Senate Majority leader, has also indicated he would consider a slowdown in the negotiations.
The United States announced in Paris on Thursday that it had reached broad agreement with the Soviets on a pact that once approved by Congress could make it possible for the Soviet Union to win most-favored-nation tariff treatment by the United States, giving that country new trade privileges. The agreement is likely to be signed when Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union hold their summit meeting here late next month.
While most of the senators were not ready to suggest that Mr. Bush call off the summit meeting, they did assert at a Capitol Hill news conference that the trade agreement should be shelved from the agenda.
 
'Sellout of Freedom'
''This is a sellout of freedom, and, to be quite frank, it is sickening,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who organized the news conference. ''It is unacceptable for the U.S. to enter into a favorable trade agreement with the Soviet Union while it crushes Lithuanian freedom under a jackboot.''
Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, said that while he usually backed Mr. Bush, he decided to ''respectfully disagree'' in this case. ''If my choice is between Mr. Gorbachev and his policies and the people of Lithuania and their freedoms,'' he said, ''I'll choose freedom every time.''
The other Republican senators who criticized the Administration's expected pact with the Soviet Union were Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, Steve Symms of Idaho, James A. McClure of Idaho, Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, Don Nickles of Oklahoma and William L. Armstrong of Colorado.
Several Democrats also criticized the Administration's policy on Lithuania today. Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, joined his Republican colleagues at the news conference, and Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, also issued a statement opposing the agreement.
 
Avoid 'Anything Precipitous'
Roman Popadiuk, a White House spokesman, said that while ''we are aware of the senators' concerns,'' Mr. Bush ''does not want to do anything precipitous that will affect the process of change'' in the Soviet Union.
Another White House official, speaking on the condition that he not be named, said of the senators' remarks: ''It is damaging. But does it undercut the necessity about being prudent about what you say and what you do? The answer is no.''

HEADLINE: Peruvian Bars Drug Accord Unless U.S. Helps on Crops

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 27

 BODY:
President Alan Garcia has declared that he will not sign an agreement with the United States to combat the cocaine trade if the accord does not include economic compensation for losses from growing coca leaf.
''The war on drugs cannot sustain itself with military aid alone,'' Mr. Garcia said on Thursday. ''I am not going to sign any agreement if it does not include economic aid for crop substitution and to give relief to the balance of payments.''
On Monday, the United States announced details of a plan to provide $35 million in military aid and training to combat drug trafficking in Peru's Amazon basin, which produces half of the world's coca leaf crop.
The military accord was to have been signed on Thursday by Defense Minister Julio Velazquez Giaccarini and the United States Ambassador to Peru, Anthony C. E. Quainton. No signing took place. It is not clear whether Mr. Garcia's comments indicated that he had directed the Minister not to sign.

HEADLINE: 10,000 Are Expected to Lose Jobs to Spotted Owl

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ANGELES, Wash.

 BODY:
The loggers who have been chewing at this peninsula of ancient forest for the last century have weathered hard times from automation, overcutting and recessions. But never have they taken the kind of economic blow expected this summer on behalf of an owl whose life is endangered by the way they earn their living.
With at least 10,000 jobs in the Pacific Northwest expected to be lost so as to save some of nation's oldest trees and the owls that live among them, loggers and sawmill workers here are demanding economic compensation from the Federal Government.
''We don't want to move,'' said Kirk Dahlstrom, whose small lumber company in the timber town of Hoquiam depends on 300-year-old trees from the nearby Olympic National Forest. ''We want to live the way we've always lived. But now we're going to shut down. Is the Government going to take care of us?'' 
 
'A Real Sinking Feeling'
Direct Federal relief seems unlikely. This month, the Senate narrowly voted down a $500 million proposal to aid miners expected to lose their jobs as utilities burn cleaner coal from other areas to meet the requirements being developed for a new Clean Air Act.
''We felt a real sinking feeling,'' Representative Sid Morrison said of the proposal's defeat. Mr. Morrison, a Republican from Washington, is coordinating efforts by the Northwest Congressional delegation to aid the loggers here.
Economists have been predicting the demise of the logging of ancient trees, as both trees and jobs continued to disappear. Then, this month, a Federal study group recommended that 2.5 million acres of virgin forest be set aside this summer to protect the endangered spotted owl.
Few people expected the end to be so sudden, As a result, leaders on both sides of the issue are grasping to find specific solutions.
 
'We'll Have to Get Along'
''There is never a good time to do these things,'' Mr. Morrison said. ''But if it's the will of the public, we'll have to get along. What this proves is that you can't have both a protected old-growth forest and timber supply at historical levels.''
The question now becomes: Can loggers, truck drivers, sawmill workers and coal miners learn to be computer technicians, tour operators or assemblers at small manufacturing shops? Timber jobs pay $8 to $13 an hour; tourism, touted as the best economic alternative for the Olympic Peninsula, would bring salaries half that amount, according to projections by Washington State officials.
The proposal to save the owls' habitat, almost certain to be adopted by the Forest Service this summer, would place most virgin forest and some replanted areas off limits to loggers on Federal land in Northern California, Oregon and Washington. It would reduce the Federal timber harvest in the Northwest by 25 percent.
''Good environmentalism is, for the most part, good economics,'' said Jeff Olson, an economist with the Wilderness Society in Portland, Ore. ''We've seen the end of an era coming for 10 years. The problem is how to ease the transition.''
 
'Proposal Will Outlaw Jobs'
Senator Slade Gorton, Republican from Washington, said in a recent speech to a timber group in this town on the Olympic Peninsula, ''This owl proposal will essentially outlaw your jobs.'' The Senator has proposed setting aside parts of national forests for exclusive use by loggers for generations.
Environmentalists say the present system, under which large sections of national forests are sold to timber companies, already resembles Senator Gorton's plan and has contributed to the loss of large sections of forests.
Less than 500 yards away from the site of Mr. Gorton's speech, old-growth logs were being prepared for shipment to Japan, where they bring nearly twice the price that American timber mills are willing to pay. Thousands of sawmill jobs could be saved if exports were restricted, according to Forest Service estimates.
With 40 percent of Washington's logs exported last year as unprocessed raw material, a ban on exports is gaining acceptance as one solution to the timber crisis. Nearly four billion board feet of logs were exported from the West Coast last year, about four times the amount of wood that would be off-limits to logging because of the spotted owl.
 
Congressional Action Possible
This week, the United States Senate passed an amendment to a trade bill offered by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, that would allow states to ban the export of logs. It would have an immediate effect in Oregon, which has already passed such a law, but would not apply in Washington State until the Legislature enacted a ban. A similar bill is before the House, and prospects appear good for Congessional passage.
Also this week, Japan agreed to drop some trade barriers to finished wood products. American officials have complained that the Japanese accept mainly logs instead of wood products from the United States.
The legislation and Japan's move should help the economically distressed timber towns, Mr. Packwood said.
Some political leaders are urging even stronger export controls.
While some business leaders foresee ghost towns, the mill towns can stay alive if they move quickly to diversify their economies, an Oregon state study says. The best hope for these towns, notched in river valleys among forest lands that have been cut, is to attract retirees, to promote tourism and to move into secondary manufacturing.
But Oregon officials say they do not have money in their budget to help these towns make the transition.
Making furniture, cabinets and stereo equipment out of wood that is usually sent abroad or is sliced into boards is being promoted as a way to squeeze more jobs and money out of the available trees.
 
No Money, Just Trees
The Wilderness Society has recommended that a stiff tariff be placed on log exports and that the money from those taxes be used to help start small businesses making such products or to retrain workers.
But Mr. Dahlstrom, whose Dahlstrom Lumber Company is already making finished products like door frames and windows with his old-growth logs, says he does not need any more money, just wood.
His company, he said, is a victim of historic change. He could move to Seattle, two hours away, where 60,000 jobs were created last year. But he wants to stay where he is, making doors from tight-grain vertical fir from trees that have been on the Olympic Peninsula longer than America has been an independent nation.

HEADLINE: BUSH PRODS NATION ON CENSUS RETURNS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Eager to speed a lagging population count that Republicans hope will help them gain seats in Congress, President Bush today called on Americans ''to stand up and be counted'' by returning their census forms.
Mr. Bush said the large number of people who did not return their forms, or who did not even receive them because of problems in the mailing system, had created ''mammoth'' difficulties for census takers, who began going door to door around the country on Thursday to collect the missing information.
''We really need to get moving on this,'' Mr. Bush said in an appearance before a White House gathering of state legislators. 
''I simply want to take this opportunity,'' he said, ''to urge every American who has not returned the census form to do so, to stand up and be counted.''
 
Second Plea by President
This was the second time that the President, who filled out his own census form during a recent White House photo-taking session, had made such an appeal. Earlier this month he taped a television commercial that was broadcast around the country.
But it was not clear how much Mr. Bush's comments today would help ease the task that has been left for the door-to-door census takers. That task is enormous, because nearly 40 percent of the 95 million questionnaires mailed by the Census Bureau in March have not been returned.
The lists that the census takers are using to make their treks were drawn up according to households that had not returned census forms as of April 20. Addresses could be removed from the list if a form were returned now, but only a huge response to Mr. Bush's plea would have a significant impact.
Mr. Bush framed his appeal in terms of the effect of the census on the financial relationship between Washington and the state and local governments. The Federal Government distributes more than $50 billion to states and localities through 142 programs that are based in whole or in part on population, income and ethnic data.
''Our partnership must begin with an accurate account of the depth and scope of our needs that can only begin with the U.S. Census,'' Mr. Bush said.
 
Important Political Theme
But although the President did not touch on it today, there was also an important political theme behind his remarks.
The 1990 census will be used to apportion Congressional seats to each of the 50 states and, within each state, to draw Congressional districts. Republicans hope the census will favor them by reflecting a substantial population shift from the industrial North to the more Republican Southwest, thus improving their chances of whittling away at the Democratic majority in the House of Representatives.
But within each state, it is the state legislature that determines the boundaries of Congressional districts. Republicans, including Mr. Bush, have accused the Democrats, who control a majority of state legislatures, of drawing those boundaries to favor their own candidates.
Mr. Bush has made Republican attacks on the gerrymandering one of his top political priorities, touching on it in many of the speeches he has made around the country in recent months.
Another political issue related to the census is that an incomplete count would increase pressure on the Government to adjust the results by using mathematical techniques intended to reflect a truer count of the population and its ethnic and economic makeup.
Democrats believe this would help them, because the adjustment would be intended to compensate for an undercount of the inner-city poor and minority members, who are traditionally Democratic voters.

HEADLINE: Unrelated Amendments Snag Bill on Emergency Spending

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Senate efforts to complete action on an emergency spending bill that includes money for domestic programs and aid for Panama and Nicaragua slowed to a crawl today as lawmakers battled over scores of unrelated amendments on everything from abortion to the death penalty.
The $3.4 billion spending measure would provide $420 million to help rebuild Panama's economy and $300 million to assist the administration of Nicaragua's new President, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who was sworn in on Wednesday.
''Mrs. Chamorro's term may expire before we get the aid down there,'' said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, as he surveyed the list of proposed amendments. 
 
A Variety of Issues
Domestic programs covered in the bill include food stamps, disaster assistance, veterans' medical care and the 1990 census.
The House approved its version of the legislation earlier this month. But under the Senate's more lax rules, which permit unlimited amendments and debate, the spending measure has become a magnet for pet initiatives that lawmakers might not otherwise have an opportunity to raise. Senators are essentially hoping to attach their proposals to a bill that will ultimately pass in one form or another.
One of the most volatile issues is abortion, and conservative Republicans, led by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, took their first shot by trying to scuttle language adopted by the Senate Appropriations Committee that would permit the District of Columbia to use its own funds to finance abortions.
 
Outlook for a Veto
President Bush vetoed a similar measure last year, and he has made it clear that he would do so again if the language is included in the spending bill.
While the abortion measure survived two procedural votes, the Senate suspended further debate on the language and lawmakers appeared headed for a protracted fight.
''As usual, the Senate doesn't know where it's going, or how long it's going to take us to get there,'' said Senator Trent Lott, a Mississippi Republican.

HEADLINE: Expansion at the Brooklyn Museum

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Construction will begin Monday on the first phase of a master plan that would more than double the size of the Brooklyn Museum. The museum, one of the largest in the United States, has already raised most of the $31 million for the first stage, confounding skeptics who doubted the project would ever get off the ground.
The plan calls for one of the largest museum expansions since the Metropolitan Museum of Art embarked on a 25-year, $250 million program in 1969. If the Brooklyn plan is completed as envisioned, probably some time in the third decade of the 21st century, the museum will grow to 900,000 square feet at a cost estimated at nearly $250 million.
In the first phase, some 64,000 square feet of space will be rebuilt, producing three new floors of galleries in the west wing. They are to open in 1992 with an exhibition of Spanish Colonial art to mark the Columbus quincentenary. These galleries will be larger than the entire current exhibition space of the Whitney Museum of American Art and will increase the museum's gallery space by 25 percent. This will allow it to expand special-exhibition areas, display more paintings from its permanent collection and reinstall its prized Egyptian collection. 
 
An Auditorium Next Spring
The first phase will also create a 460-seat auditorium and additional art-storage areas. The auditorium is to open next spring and will be the museum's first formal venue for films and lectures since the original auditorium was closed 56 years ago.
''So many people thought the master plan was just pie-in-the-sky drawings and publicity,'' said James Stewart Polshek, the architect who developed the plan with the Japanese architect Arata Isozaki. ''No one believed we'd get this going in anything like its current form.''
The scope of the new plan recalls the original one by McKim, Mead & White in 1893. That plan envisioned a monumental 1.5-million-square-foot palace of arts and sciences to establish Brooklyn, then an independent city, as the cultural equal of Paris, London or its rival across the East River. Only one-sixth of that plan was realized by 1927, when construction stopped. Since then, the museum has been largely overshadowed by its richer, flashier counterparts in Manhattan and has been unable to complete the original plan on Eastern Parkway near Grand Army Plaza.
 
Only 5 Percent on View
Nonetheless, the Brooklyn has an encyclopedic collection of some two million objects, ranging from ancient Egyptian and Mayan sculptures to early American decorative arts and European and American works from the 14th century to the present. Only about 5 percent of its holdings can be displayed now.
''It was irresponsible to condemn such a lodestone of treasure to decay,'' said Robert T. Buck, who was named director in 1983. ''But de facto, that's what happened.''
''There were several awful attempts to deal with this unfinished monument over the years,'' he continued. Many designs were commissioned but never realized, and a boxlike new wing was added in the early 1980's. Mr. Buck said, ''Small actions on a building like this look like bandages.''
The new building plan evolved when the museum's art school in the west wing closed in 1985. Mr. Buck asked the school's director, Joan Darragh, for ideas on how to use the space, which has remained empty. After evaluating their priorities, museum officials decided to organize an architectural competition for a master plan.
 
A Unanimous Decision
In October 1986, after receiving submissions from some of the leading architects in the world, they unanimously selected a bold abstract and neo-classical scheme developed by Arata Isozaki & Associates and James Stewart Polshek & Partners. The design, which Mr. Isozaki said ''establishes continuity with the original plan,'' also incorporates decidedly modern elements, like a 150-foot tapered tower with a skylight. Mr. Isozaki designed the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, and Mr. Polshek's firm designed the restoration of Carnegie Hall.
While many people in the museum world doubted that the plan would ever be anything more than impressive renderings and models, the Beaux-Arts museum gathered support from government and private sources. It won a $1 million challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, then received pledges from the city's Department of Cultural Affairs and the Brooklyn Borough President's office for $14 million.
Although the museum is privately administered, its building is owned by the city, which provides 40 percent of its $15 million annual operating budget.
 
Large Private Gifts
''Their project request was a standout,'' said Mary Schmidt Campbell, New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner. Because of the plan's architectural qualities as well as what she called Brooklyn's ''new artistic vitality'' and the museum's ''leadership position in presenting culturally diverse programs,'' Dr. Campbell said that she had made city support for its renovation ''my highest priority during my first year as commissioner.''
Large private contributions followed, including $3.5 million from Iris and B. Gerald Cantor, $2.5 million from Marty and Robert S. Rubin, $1 million from Alastair B. Martin and $750,000 from Mary P. Oenslager. A 1983 grant from the Vincent Astor Foundation for $1 million was also applied to the effort.
Mr. Buck said he expected to have the remaining money for the first phase within a year. He also said the museum would remain open during the reconstruction.
''I'm rather surprised they raised money so well and so fast,'' said Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum. ''It's a testament to Bob Buck and the trustees and reflects the quality of the museum.''
 
No Deals, No Opposition
The Brooklyn Museum plan does not follow the expansion course set by other New York cultural institutions. The Museum of Modern Art, Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, for example, all made real-estate deals to help pay for their building plans and operating budgets.
Nor has the Brooklyn encountered the sort of community opposition that has hampered efforts at other museums. Additions to the Guggenheim and the Jewish Museums, to be completed within the next few years, were both scaled down after architects, preservationists and neighborhood organizations charged that the proposed structures would threaten the original buildings' integrity and the architectural character of their neighborhoods. The worst problems have been at the Whitney Museum, which for five years has unsuccessfully tried to gain approval of its expansion plans from the local Community Board and the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.
''Happily, we didn't have the land-encroachment problems that the Whitney and Guggenheim had, because the original 1893 plan gave us our turf,'' Mr. Buck said. ''The site, where the parking lot is, was already designated for the museum.''
 
Next Step Is Undecided
Museum officials have not decided what to tackle next in the master plan. ''Once we finish this, we have to reassess the building and New York's economy, since we're linked to local economic tides,'' Mr. Buck said.
But Ms. Darragh, who has become the museum's vice director for planning and architecture, said further renovations of the current building and new construction are expected to begin in this decade.
Given the task of raising up to $200 million when the city has a severe budget deficit and New York's economy is sluggish, the museum will probably have separate fund-raising campaigns for each phase of construction, said Mr. Rubin, the museum's chairman and a senior executive vice president with Smith Barney, Harris Upham.
''The museum and the city are partners in this project, and I think we'll be able to make a convincing case to them for the next phases,'' he said. ''We're also expanding our sources of private interest and funding, and we want to bolster our endowment, now $25 million, because as exhibition space increases, our operating expenses will move upward.''
Mr. Polshek offered a generally optimistic assessment: ''I think there will be another piece completed within 15 years, but resources have changed. Maybe another architect will come along and change the plan, but the museum will eventually be completed.''
Reflecting on the museum's long, tangled construction history and its role as a symbol for Brooklyn, Mr. Buck said: ''To Manhattan's hare, we're the tortoise. We move along step by step.''

HEADLINE: REGENTS APPROVE PANEL ON NEW ETHNIC STUDIES

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 27

 BODY:
The Regents today authorized creating a panel to draft changes in school curriculums to add weight to the influence of non-white cultures on American society.
The makeup of the panel will be largely up to Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol, who in February called publicily for the revisions as a racially sensitive way to teach. 
The names for the 21-member panel will be offered to the Regents in June. Under the plan, the committee is to have two elementary school teachers, two middle school teachers, two high school teachers, two curriculum administrators, two school administrators, one technology expert, two to four university-level scholars in history, geography, anthropology, sociology, political science or economics.
The panel will be formed in the next two months. Mr.Sobol said it would be ''at least a couple of years'' before significant changes might actually appear int he courses taught to the 2.5 million schoolchildren in the state.

HEADLINE: Charlotte Boschan, Developer of Banks Of Data, Dies at 70

 BODY:
Charlotte Boschan, an economist who established the first electronic data bank in the field when she was associated with the National Bureau of Economic Research a quarter-century ago, died of complications of surgery on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.
Dr. Boschan, who was born in Frankfurt-am-Main, Germany, received a bachelor's degree from New York University and a master's and a doctorate from Columbia University. After working at the Econometric Institute she joined the National Bureau in 1951 and was an early developer of data banks.
At the bureau she helped revise the cyclical economic indicators used by the United States Department of Commerce and the procedure for combining the indicators into indexes of economic activity. She was also largely responsible for constructing the Growth Cycle Program, a method of determining turning points in the economy.
From 1977 to 1986 Dr. Boschan was a vice president of Citibank, which took over the economic data bank, now known as Citibase, from the National Bureau.
Her husband, Paul Boschan, a statistician, died in 1986.
She is survived by a brother, Beretz Ronen of Kibbutz Hazorea, Israel.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate Up by 2.1% For Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The economy grew at a moderate 2.1 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year while inflation took its biggest quarterly jump since 1981, the Commerce Department reported today.
Exceptional weather - a record cold December followed by the second-warmest January-March period in this century - affected both sets of figures, however, and economists were not prompted to make a major reappraisal of economic and financial prospects. The expectation continues to be for solid, though perhaps slightly decelerating, growth for the balance of 1990 with prices rising less rapidly than in the first quarter but at a still-unsettling pace.
The growth in the G.N.P. came in at less than many analysts had expected and might have encouraged some in the financial markets to think that this would reduce upward pressure on interest rates. But the dominant view was that the price data would support the Federal Reserve in its resolve to keep inflation under control. 
 
6.5 Percent Inflation Rate
 The price of a fixed list of goods climbed at a 6.5 percent annual rate, compared with 3.6 percent in the final 1989 quarter and 4.5 percent for all of last year, today's report showed. The jump for January to March is the highest since a 7.7 percent increase in the fourth quarter of 1981.
J. Antonio Villamil, the Commerce Department's chief economist, called the news on inflation ''disappointing'' and implied that the Bush Administration would not complain if the Federal Reserve found it necessary to tighten monetary policy to prevent price pressures from intensifying.
''There is no room for complacency on inflation,'' Mr. Villamil said at a briefing for reporters. ''The Administration shares the Fed's goal of maximum growth consistent with price stability.''
At the same time, however, he added that he expected inflation to moderate in coming months, saying that a ''likely unwinding of energy and food prices'' already appears under way.
Private economists generally agreed, noting that the extremes of the weather caused huge gyrations in the price of heating oil and other fuels and in fresh fruits and vegetables. Clothing prices were subjected to unusually big price increases in February and March.
But while today's inflation data may have added to uneasiness over prices, there was little surprise because the Labor Department had reported last week that the Consumer Price Index jumped at an 8.5 percent rate in the January-March period.
Many economists, including Kenneth T. Mayland of the Society National Bank in Cleveland, say that today's inflation figures overstate the severity of the situation and the persistence of inflation. Mr. Mayland said that ''the inflation pressures are easily identifiable and reversible.''
The economic data caused a flurry of activity early in the bond market as traders seesawed in interpreting the data, but bond prices managed to close the day with a slight price rise after declining in 9 of the previous 10 trading days. On Thursday, prices slumped and the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond closed above 9 percent for the first time in nearly a year.
As for the gross national product, the 2.1 percent increase, while lower than recent expectations, was still well above what most economists were predicting at the turn of the year. The result was also nearly twice the depressed 1.1 percent growth rate of the fourth quarter, when the economy slowed substantially, partly because of a strike at the Boeing Company.
 
Gain in Real Final Sales
 Real final sales - a broad measure of the G.N.P. that excludes changes in inventories - advanced at a hefty 4 percent rate in the first quarter, up from 1.1 percent in the preceding three months. When averaged to smooth the various distortions, this gauge has thus risen at about a 2.5 percent rate over the last six months, said Gary E. Schlossberg, a senior economist for the Wells Fargo Bank.
He added that he thought the economy was now ''neither slowing down nor speeding up,'' although the odds favored some ''softening'' in the months ahead as the Federal Reserve keeps upward pressure on interest rates.
Business inventories rose at a rate of only $2.6 billion in the first quarter following two straight quarters of advances of more than $20 billion, today's report showed.
 
Inventory Levels Down
 Reduced inventory levels were a drag on growth in the quarter. In computing the G.N.P. it only matters if goods were produced, not whether they were actually sold. The lean stocks, however, now mean that additional demand would quickly translate to new production.
''Overall inventories are in fairly good shape, adding a positive element for continued economic growth,'' Mr. Villamil of the Commerce Department said.
Cutbacks in automobile output lopped some seven-tenths of a percentage point off the first-quarter G.N.P., but some of the reduction in auto inventories was offset by a rebuilding of oil and coal stocks drawn down during December's extremely cold weather. The cold also raised fuel and food prices in the early part of the first quarter, accounting for about half the increase in the fixed-weight inflation gauge.
 
Big Lift to Construction
 On the other hand, warm weather early this year gave a big lift to construction, with the result that this sector is unlikely to contribute much to growth in the current quarter.
The import-export sector added to growth at a $6 billion rate in the first quarter, down from $9.9 billion in the preceding three months, today's report also showed. Real personal consumption rose $16.4 billion, well above the $3.6 billion fourth-quarter rate.
Measured in current dollars rather than in constant 1982 dollars, the G.N.P. rose at a 7.8 percent rate in the first quarter, compared with a 4.6 percent rate of increase in the October-December period.
An alternate price gauge in the report, the so-called deflator, jumped to a 5.7 percent rate in the latest quarter, from 3.2 percent in the fourth quarter. While this is not a pure measure of inflation because it takes into account shifts in the composition of demand, it is widely watched by analysts. Unlike the fixed-weight index, the deflator captures the fact that when tomatoes, say, soar to $1 each - as they did this winter - people stop buying them.
The savings rate - which is personal savings as a percentage of disposable personal income - eased to 5.4 percent in the first quarter from 5.6 percent, today's report also showed.
The Commerce Department revised its estimate of fourth-quarter corporate profits from current production to a rate $200 million higher than it first estimated last month. Instead of being down $9.5 billion at an annual rate, profits dropped by $9.3 billion.

HEADLINE: Anti-Takeover Law Signed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LANCASTER, Pa., April 27

 BODY:
Gov. Robert P. Casey signed the nation's toughest anti-takeover law today in hopes of cooling the threat of corporate raiders aiming at Pennsylvania companies. The law, which took effect immediately, has been the center of a national debate that pitted leading members of the investment community against state labor and business groups. 
For the first time in any state, raiders will be forced to surrender short-term profits from takeover attempts. The law also clamps down on raider voting rights and establishes protections for labor contracts when corporations change hands.
Mr. Casey said the law put the interests of Pennsylvania companies and families above those of corporate deal makers, whose motives are rooted in a zeal for profits. Mr. Casey signed the bill at the Lancaster City Council chambers, only blocks from the corporate headquarters of Armstrong World Industries, the floor covering manufacturer that the legislation was first drafted to protect.
The central provision in the law requires raiders, after a failed buyout or proxy fight, to forfeit any profit made from the sale of the target company's stock for 18 months.
The law would also allow management to give first consideration to employees, customers, suppliers or the community, rather than to shareholders, in weighing takeover bids.

HEADLINE: Trump Says He Might Sell Shuttle

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he might sell the shuttle he bought from Eastern Airlines as part of a drive to build up his cash so that he could take advantage of new deals.
The New York developer confirmed that he had retained Merrill Lynch & Company to negotiate a possible shuttle sale. But he seemed reluctant to give up the shuttle, whose market share has rebounded in the last few months.
''It's highly unlikely that I will sell the shuttle but I never rule out anything,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''I believe that over the next couple of years cash is going to be king. That's why I've built up a large amount of cash and will continue to build up a large amount of cash.'' 
''Interest rates are too high right now to justify a lot of deals if you have to borrow the money,'' he said.
 
Some Potential Buyers
 Mr. Trump said that some airlines had expressed interest in buying the shuttle, which has valuable flight slots and gates at La Guardia Airport in New York, National Airport in Washington and Logan International Airport in Boston.
Most large carriers like American, United, USAir and Delta would have difficulty buying the shuttle because they have extensive operations on the East Coast, posing possible antitrust problems. A sale would be subject to the approval of the Transportation Department.
The most likely bidders would be smaller carriers like America West Airlines, which tried to buy the shuttle last spring but lost out to Mr. Trump, and Midway Airlines.
 
Premium Fares
 Pan American World Airways operates a rival shuttle service. The East Coast shuttles have long had a following among business travelers who are willing to pay premium fares because of the convenience of hourly flights on which they do not need a reservation.
Mr. Trump denied reports in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that he was considering asset sales and new deals because he needs to raise cash to pay off his current interest costs and to reduce his debt.
The reports said Mr. Trump was planning to sell some of his prime assets like the shuttle and doing various deals that would involve the Trump Tower in Manhattan, the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan and his three casinos in Atlantic City.
Forbes magazine in an article about Mr. Trump said it had sharply reduced its estimate of his net worth, putting it at $500 million, or $1 billion less than last year's estimate. In the cover story of the May 14 issue, which Forbes made available yesterday, the magazine said it revised the estimate after examining nonpublic documents submitted by Mr. Trump last year to a government body. The magazine did not elaborate.
Using the list of properties in Mr. Trump's 1989 documents, and updating their values, Forbes said it came up with a total market value of slightly less than $3.7 billion. With nearly $3.2 billion in debt, however, Mr. Trump's cash shortfall may be nearly $40 million a year, Forbes estimated.
The Trump Organization released a statement yesterday saying that Forbes made a ''mathematical mistake or purposeful omission'' because its calculations did not include $160 million a year in anticipated operating profit from the Taj Mahal casino, but did include the casino's debt service costs. A Forbes spokesman said the magazine stood by its story.
When Mr. Trump assumed control of the shuttle from the Texas Air Corporation for $365 million in June, the operation had been devastated by a strike that the machinists' union had begun on March 4 against Eastern Airlines. Its market share, which had been 57 percent before the strike, dropped as low as about 20 percent.

HEADLINE: Japanese Still Fear Trade Tensions With U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 27

 BODY:
A flurry of recent trade accords between the United States and Japan appears to have arrested a deterioration in the two countries' relationship. But the sense of relief in Tokyo is diminished by deep worries about the future.
The reason is that none of the agreements are expected to make a large dent in America's $50 billion trade deficit with Japan, according to both Japanese and American officials and trade experts.
Japanese officials said they were pleased with President Bush's decision not to cite Japan this year for unfair trading practices under ''Super 301'' of the tough 1988 trade law, which calls for sanctions against those cited. 
But they remain anxious about what may lie ahead. One reason is that the yen's steep decline in relation to the dollar in recent months is widely expected to jeopardize the gains made in the negotiations by lowering the price of Japanese products overseas and increasing the price of American exports to Japan. Indeed, the deficit worsened last month, after some improvement in the last year.
 
New Troubles Feared
 The concern in Japan, therefore, is that the trade frictions may have lifted only temporarily, and that deeper tensions are bound to return.
''We have not entered any kind of new era because of these agreements,'' said a senior Japanese negotiator. ''Just as we have been pestered by the American trade people day after day and week after week, so we will be pestered again. Our endurance is down to the barest of threads.''
When the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, cited Japan last year under Congressional pressure, it caused enormous strains with Tokyo. Japan at first refused to negotiate on the issues cited by Mrs. Hills, but eventually it did so, reaching an accord this week on the last of three major items on the American agenda, wood products. Japan agreed to streamline certification procedures and building codes.
The wood products accord built on two earlier, but smaller, agreements providing increased access for American satellites and supercomputers. Altogether, the accords are far below $2 billion in trade volume, a tiny fraction of the trade deficit.
 
A Spurt in Imports
 Indeed, although American exports to Japan have risen in recent years, American imports - particularly automobiles, consumer electronics and machinery - have risen twice as fast.
Japanese officials say they feel lingering bitterness at the way they had to negotiate with the United States under the threat of sanctions, a principal tool of the Super 301 clause.
Japan viewed the Super 301 action as coercive, unilateral and illegal. Mrs. Hills was understood to have been advised by many American negotiators not to use it again this year. The United States Ambassador, Michael H. Armacost, said this week that he thought more progress could be made now in a quieter atmosphere, free of recriminations over unilateral threats by Washington.
But he also acknowledged that foreign pressure, known as ''gai-atsu'' in Japanese, does seem to produce results. ''It is undeniably apparent that much of the movement has come near these deadlines,'' Mr. Armacost said.
Japanese politicians and bureacrats contend, however, that American pressure cannot work again. In the future Japan will contest the legality of Super 301 in international trade forums and refuse to negotiate.
 
'Increasing Irritation'
 ''Within Japan there is increasing irritation among the Japanese people vis-a-vis the United States as a result of the latest talks,'' said Takujiro Hamada, a member of Parliament. ''My constituents are asking, 'Why should Japan do that much?' It is a matter of concern.''
How much Japan has done may be subject to debate. In one breakthrough, Japan agreed recently to revise its copyright law to protect foreign recordings made before 1978. But American negotiators say that the biggest lobbyist for this change was a Japanese businessman - Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation, which now owns CBS Records.
In another recent accord seeking to reduce so-called structural impediments to trade, Tokyo pledged to spend more on public works projects, ease regulations that protect Japan's small stores, lower Japanese land prices, crack down on collusive business practices and undertake other ''structural'' changes to improve access for imports. But trade officials say that the accord will be difficult to put into effect and that it may not lead to more sales of American products.
The trade problems lying ahead arise from new demands for American access to Japanese markets in semiconductors, construction contracts, telecommunications equipment and for a new product called amorphous metal.
 
Now for the Details
 ''The immediate problems seem now to have been sorted out,'' Mr. Armacost told a news conference on Thursday. ''But we've got to fill in a lot of very important details. As everyone knows in Government work, the devil is usually in the details.''
Japanese economists say, for instance, that the basic monopolistic behavior of business cartels, considered by Americans to be unfair, is considered by Japan to be both fair and legal.
''It's going to be very difficult to change, in a major way, our bilateral balance of trade,'' said Kazuo Nukuzawa, managing director of Keidanren, Japan's most powerful industrial trade association. ''The danger is if there is little or almost no reduction in the trade figures, and the United States links this result with Japanese sincerity or insincerity in implementing the structural changes.''

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Issues Rise a Bit

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities finished with slight gains yesterday after a brief advance early in the session gave way to profit taking.
Dealers attributed the early strength to a smaller-than-expected rise in the first-quarter gross national product that was reported before trading began in New York.
The Government said that the G.N.P. rose at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the first quarter of 1990, up from an increase of 1.1 percent in the last three months of 1989. But dealers said the market had expected a rise of closer to 2.5 percent for the first quarter. Any negative economic news is considered bullish for the fixed-income market because it lessens the fear of inflation and resultant higher yields on new debt offerings. 
 
Depressed by Inflation Gauge
 But the price gain partly eroded when attention apparently turned to the fixed-weight deflator, a major barometer of inflation, which was reported by the Commerce Department to have risen to 6.5 percent, from 5.5 percent in the last quarter of 1989.
In late trading, the Treasury's bellwether long-term bonds were offered at 94 21/32, up by 5/32, after rising as much as 22/32 early in the day. At 94 21/32, the long bond's yield was 9.02 percent, compared with 9.04 percent the day before and 8.93 percent a week ago.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new 8 7/8 percent notes of 1992 rose 5/32, to 99 29/32, to yield 8.93 percent; the 8 1/2's of 1994 rose by 5/32, at 98 8/32, for a yield of 9.04 percent, and the long notes, the 8 1/2's of the year 2000, rose 5/32, to 96 16/32, to yield 9.03 percent.
''Given the fact that the fixed-income market is now predisposed to negative news, the size of the rise in the G.N.P. was quickly overshadowed by the deflator number,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at the Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Corporation. ''By midday, dealers and traders who hadn't left for the weekend were focusing on what the market considers will be a week of negative news.'' $31 Billion Expected On Wednesday, Mr. Ricchiuto added, the debt market expects the Treasury to announce an increase in the package of refunding issues that it plans to auction the next week. The market expects the Treasury to sell a total of at least $31 billion of notes and bonds, compared with $30 billion in the previous refunding.
The Treasury's recent practice has been to increase the amount of debt it auctions, partly as an indirect means of providing funds to bail out beleaguered savings and loan institutions. For example, the Treasury said yesterday that it planned to auction $10 billion of new one-year bills next Thursday. At the Treasury's last monthly auction of one-year bills, the sale amounted to $9.75 billion.
''Traders are also concerned about next week's series of Japanese holidays known as 'Golden Week,' which closes down much of Japan's financial market,'' Mr. Ricchiuto said. ''What trading does take place there during Golden Week often produces volatile price moves.''
 
Bracing for Job Figures
 The debt market is also bracing for next Friday's employment figures, which are expected to be swelled by the hiring of an estimated 400,000 full-time and part-time census takers. And because the national minimum wage was raised by 13.4 percent on April 1 for three million workers, Mr. Ricchiuto said, this might produce a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in hourly earnings.
Dealers said that continuing weakness in the stock market, with the Dow Jones industrial average down by 31.53 points yesterday and 50.90 points for the week, caused a shift of some funds to Treasury bills. The discount rate on the 90-day bills fell 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.77 percent; six-month bills lost 8 basis points, at 7.93 percent, and the one-year bills dropped by 10 basis points, to 7.93 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 31.53 as Bonds Offer Competition

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks sank yesterday in the wake of further uneasiness in the bond market, signs of rising inflation, heavy computerized selling and a move by many investors to higher-paying investments.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.53 points, to 2,645.05, its lowest level in nearly two months. For the week, the Dow dropped 50.90 points. 
Volume slumped to 130.63 million shares, from a weak 141.3 million the day before. Declines far outweighed advances, by 1,070 to 403.
 
Weighing the Yield
 In the credit markets, the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond actually fell slightly yesterday, to 9.02 percent, from 9.04 percent the day before. Still, the yield was ample enough to lure some investors from equities. And higher interest rates in general pose a threat to corporate performance, further discouraging investing in stocks.
The big news yesterday was the report that gross national product rose at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the first quarter, which was less than had been expected, and that an inflation indicator for the quarter showed an annualized gain of 6.5 percent.
The bond market briefly rallied early yesterday but then gave up most of the day's gains.
Hugh Johnson, the head strategist for the First Albany Corporation, contended that bond prices might slide further before stabilizing because economic data were pointing to a fairly strong economy, which would keep upward pressure on interest rates.
Even so, one group of money managers, known as asset allocators, was said to be selling stocks and putting the money into bonds.
Birinyi Associates said that program traders instituted eight ''sell'' programs that cumulatively lopped 40.80 points off the Dow yesterday. Two programs totaling 20 minutes alone clipped nearly 16 points.
Illinois Power topped the Big Board active list, falling 1, to 15, on volume of 3.2 million shares, after an examiner for the Illinois Commerce Commission offered a much smaller rate rise than had been requested.
Harley-Davidson, the motorcycle company, rose 1 5/8, to 46 1/8, after Investors Daily published a favorable article.
Black & Decker fell 2 3/8, to 13 3/4, on 1.5 million shares. The power-tool company said Daniel Carasso of Goldman, Sachs & Company had cut his rating and urged investors to sell.
McDonnell Douglas, the aircraft company, fell to a new low of 47 1/2 before ending at 47 5/8, down 3 1/2. Last week it reported a sharp drop in first-quarter profits.
Paramount Communications rose 5/8, to 47 7/8, in heavy trading after an article in Business Week magazine said Chris-Craft Industries might have a stake and might propose a friendly takeover. Paramount declined to comment.
In other moves, Graco, a pump company that earlier reported a rise in first-quarter profits, rose 1 5/8, to 22 1/2. Motel 6, rose 1 3/8, to 16, on new takeover rumors.
Teradata, a computer company, fell 4, to 24 1/2, on 2.2 million shares in the over-the-counter market. Kenneth J. Burke, an analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons of Baltimore, said that the company had reported a rise in profits but that its remarks on foreign business ''suggested trimming fourth-quarter estimates.''
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.81, to 329.11; the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter trading fell 3.08, to 417.98, and the Amex market-value index dropped 2.11, to 342.64.

HEADLINE: New England Bank Has Loss

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corporation yesterday announced a loss of $46.6 million for the quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $42.3 million, or 60 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.
The company, which lost $1.1 billion in 1989, continues to be troubled by bad real estate loans in a weakening New England economy. 
Earnings were hurt by the need to add $151 million to its reserves for loan losses in the first quarter, up from a $108 million increase a year ago.
Earnings were also hurt by the need to pay higher interest rates on deposits to attract funds in the midst of its financial trouble.
Losses were partly offset by gains of $173 million from the sale of various assets, including its credit card business.
 
Following guidelines set by
Federal regulators, Bank of New Engalnd is in the midst of a reorganization and trying to raise more capital. As part of that plan, the company has contracted to about $24.9 billion of assets from $32.6 billion a year ago.
The company's stock slipped 12.5 cents a share yesterday, to $3.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Down As Mark and Yen Dominate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most major currencies yesterday in trading dominated by the West German mark and Japanese yen. News that inflation picked up this year initially caused heavy dollar buying but it tapered off by late morning.
Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar traded within a narrow range as most of the buying and selling was directed toward the mark and yen. 
''The day was dominated by cross trading, particularly the mark-yen,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston.
Traders snapped up dollars in the morning after the Government reported that inflation jumped 6.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, the steepest increase since a 7.7 percent advance in the fourth quarter of 1981.
Analysts said the report might prompt the Federal Reserve to pursue a tighter credit policy, which would lead to higher interest rates. Higher rates would increase returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to increase demand for dollars. But the buying enthusiasm soon waned. Traders apparently concluded that the central bank would not adjust its policy in the immediate future.
 
G.N.P. Figure Largely Ignored
 The inflation reading came in a report showing that the gross national product grew at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the first three months of 1990. That was in line with expectations and therefore had little impact on the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 159.08 Japanese yen, from 158.77 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it fell to 158.80 yen. In New York, the dollar climbed to 159.30 yen, from 159.23 late Thursday.
The British pound rose to $1.6360, from $1.6340 late Thursday. Sterling also strengthened in New York, rising to $1.6350, from $1.6342 the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's quotes, were: 1.6775 West German marks, down from 1.6797; 1.4530 Swiss francs, down from 1.4575; 5.6290 French francs, down from 5.6355; 1,230.00 Italian lire, down from 1,231.75, and 1.16375 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1603.
Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, were: 1.6755 West German marks, down from 1.6810; 1.4560 Swiss francs, down from 1.4605; 5.6240 French francs, down from 5.6395; 1.8845 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8915; 1,228.00 Italian lire, down from 1,231.00, and 1.1632 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1602.
Gold prices fell modestly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for June delivery was down 30 cents, to $373 an ounce, in an abbreviated session because of a communications problem.

HEADLINE: Druce's Overtime Goal Finishes the Rangers

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
James Patrick had referred to it as a buzz in the air. The not-entirely-unrealistic current of excitement concerned a run by the Rangers at the Stanley Cup, and it both lighted up people's imaginations and crackled inside Madison Square Garden.
There was, after all, no prohibitive favorite, no defending champion, no reason the Rangers couldn't dream like the other remaining National Hockey League teams.
The buzz went dead last night, and the Rangers, although they didn't go quietly, went into yet one more tenure of springtime unemployment when John Druce, the no-name who had become a nemesis, deflected in a goal 6 minutes 48 seconds into overtime to give the Washington Capitals a 2-1 victory and the right to represent the Patrick Division in the Wales Conference final. 
 
Capitals Make History
Druce, who has 12 goals in the playoffs, 9 of them in the five-game series against the Rangers, stuck his stick in front of John Vanbiesbrouck to redirect Geoff Courtnall's centering pass into the net.
The Capitals, who demonstrated the gifts of grit and passion throughout the series, accomplished with successive triumphs in overtime what had eluded them for their entire history as an organization and moved out of the Patrick Division.
In the Stanley Cup semifinals, the Capitals will play the Boston Bruins, who eliminated the Montreal Canadiens last night.
 
Sad Final Thought
For the Rangers, the defeat meant they would celebrate the 50th anniversary of their last Stanley Cup in the sorry but familiar solitude of the golf course, or in front of a television set.
''The only thought that went through my head when the puck went in was that it was over, everything was over,'' said Vanbiesbrouck, who may have played his finest game in four years in holding the Capitals to a single goal for more than 66 minutes. ''I don't think there was a guy in this room who didn't think we had a legitimate shot at the Stanley Cup.
''You finish first in the Patrick Division for the first time ever, and you think: Maybe, just maybe. And why can't you go to bed at night dreaming? I know I did.''
 
Relentless Opponent
Speaking of Druce, Vanbiesbrouck added: ''The guy had as good a series as a player can have in the National Hockey League, bar none. To come to terms with that is pretty tough.''
The Capitals made everything tough for the Rangers in the series. They outhit them in all three zones and in every game. They rocked them in the second and third games of the series, outscoring them by 13-4, knocking them off their feet and off their game plan. And then they devastated them with consecutive triumphs in overtime.
''I can't say enough about how well so many of them played,'' James Patrick said of the Capitals. ''Are they the better team? Right now, they are. Maybe a month ago they weren't, or a month from now they wouldn't be. But they are now. It was closer than a 4-1 series, but you certainly can't argue with the result.''
 
Short Ray of Hope
The result looked like it might be different when John Ogrodnick, a minute into the extra session, blasted a shot from the left wing.
Mike Liut, the Washington goaltender, blocked the puck with his right shoulder, but then had it crawl over his back and dribble down toward the goal line.
''I started getting excited again when I saw that,'' Ogrodnick said. ''I thought maybe I had a hope again.''
''We lost the series in Games 2 and 3,'' said Roger Neilson, the coach of the Rangers, who evened the close, bruising game with a goal by Normand Rochefort early in the third period. ''And in Games 3 and 4, we didn't get a break.''
 
Still More Injuries
Had they, though, other factors would still have made prevailing against the Capitals a long shot.
Darren Turcotte, the often deadly scoring center, broke a bone in his left foot in the second period and would have been lost for weeks.
And Mark Hardy, whose return to the defense had restored some strength to a beleaguered unit, re-injured his right ankle and probably would not have been of any use until next season.
''Funny things happen in the playoffs,'' Neilson said.

HEADLINE: Employers Balk at High Cost Of High-Tech Medical Care

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
In a dramatic illustration of the way rapid advances in medical care in the United States sometimes collide with the will to pay for them, an employer is objecting to a $1.25 million bill for a worker's spouse who became the first person to receive a new heart, liver and kidney in the same operation.
The 26-year-old patient, Cindy Martin, was an ebullient former high school cheerleader and executive secretary from Archbald, Pa. She died March 26 after almost four months in intensive care at Presbyterian University Hospital here.
''They did everything they could,'' said her husband, John. ''They tried to make her life better. But she suffered for four months in the hospital and nothing was really accomplished.'' 
Mrs. Martin was covered under the health insurance of her husband, a 31-year-old engineer at the Loral Corporation, a military contractor. Loral repeatedly declined to comment on the case, and the insurance company that administers Loral's health plan will say only that payment is being withheld because it is not satisfied with the billing information provided by the hospital.
 
Growing Number of Challenges
But physicians, benefits consultants and ethicists say a growing number of challenges to medical bills are part of a revolt by employers against soaring health care expenses that erode their profitability, competitiveness and ability to raise wages.
They say employers are increasingly asking whether they are overpaying for medical care, and even questioning whether in some cases the enormous cost of an operation might outweigh the benefits when the chances of prolonging a life seem small.
Most experts agree that taking heroic measures with little thought of costs is the American way of delivering health care, at least for those with comprehensive insurance. Economists estimate that advances in high-technology medicine contributed at least one-fifth of the 10.1 percent growth last year in spending on health care, costs that the Commerce Department says will exceed $660 billion in 1990. In 1980 such spending came to $248 billion.
The issue is only expanding, what with expensive advances that include transplants of not only organs but also bone marrow, whose supply is virtually unlimited, in contrast to organs. Other costly advances include heart bypass operations, computerized diagnostic scans and genetically engineered drugs.
While heroic medical efforts are well intended, some experts wonder whether, in cases where the chances of success are small, the money might better be used in ways that might benefit more people. Among them: preventive health measures like vaccinations and prenatal care, and cleaning up the environment.
Indeed, some countries like Britain and Canada and states like Oregon are trying to give priority to primary care. But where such policies are practiced, expensive high-technology medicine is rationed by budget constraints on hospitals and doctors.
Elsewhere, the ability of patients or their insurance companies to pay for costly medical care has rationed such care.
 
'Rationing by Price, Excluding the Poor'
 ''We have always been rationing by price, excluding the poor,'' said Dr. William B. Schwartz, a professor of medicine at Tufts University. ''The new phenomenon is non-price rationing, where you have Blue Cross but you can't get it anyway,'' he said, referring to certain types of health care.
In this country, a few experts would like to see guidelines that would determine when an operation's cost is not warranted, given its chance of success.
''We need an accountable body that could issue some sort of rules,'' said Arthur L. Caplan, who heads the University of Minnesota's Center for Biomedical Ethics. He suggests a ''government commission, which can come up with policies and guidelines that would govern experimental and innovative medical interventions.''
But Gail Wilensky, an economist who heads the Federal Medicare and Medicaid programs, said it would be ''very difficult, if not impossible, for this country to try to set up rules about who should not be able to have the use of medically beneficial technologies.''
The case of Cindy Martin encapsulates the difficulty of deciding not to go ahead with an attempt to save a life, even an extremely costly effort.
Mrs. Martin, who came from a family plagued by early deaths associated with heart disease, had already undergone a heart transplant in October 1985 at the hospital, a unit of the University of Pittsburgh's medical center. That procedure, which generally costs about $150,000 with follow-up care, was covered by her employer, the McKinney Products Company, a Scranton hardware maker.
John Martin said that after the first transplant, his wife returned to work for a time but that starting in 1987 she was ''constantly in and out of the hospital.''
Her doctors said that her heart was weakening and that a drug that transplant patients must take was destroying her liver and kidneys. ''She was a patient dying, with three organs failing,'' said Dr. Thomas Starzl, a prominent transplant surgeon.
He said the hospital had a commitment to Mrs. Martin in part because it provided her first transplant. ''The options were wash your hands or not abandon her,'' Dr. Starzl said.
The hospital said after the operation in December that Mrs. Martin might live five to 10 years. But surgeons acknowledge that even in a single-organ transplant, there is a 15 to 25 percent chance of death within months. If the operation fails and is repeated, the odds against the patient rise.
 
7 More Operations, And More Problems
 The Pittsburgh transplant doctors said they do not concern themselves with who will pay or how much, pulling back only in hopeless cases like advanced stages of cancer.
''If the patient understands the situation and wants to go ahead, my job is to deliver health care,'' said Dr. David H. Van Thiel, medical director of the University of Pittsburgh transplant group.
After the 21-hour three-organ transplant in early December, Mrs. Martin underwent surgery seven more times, her husband said. ''She encountered other problems, including pancreatitis; that almost killed her in December,'' he said.
Eventually she contracted hepatitis. Dr. Starzl said the doctors then considered providing yet another liver, which would have been her fifth transplant. He rejected the idea, and Mrs. Martin herself agreed, as did her family.
Her death was attributed to infections that often follow transplants.
Although the hospital declined to make the disputed bill available, it provided details of payments it receives from Blue Cross and Blue Shield, on average, for a $120,000 liver transplant when there are no complications.
The main items include $28,000 for hospital and intensive-care rooms; $20,000 to acquire a donor organ; $20,000 for surgeons, anesthesiologists, a radiologist, internist and neurologist; $15,000 for various tests, including radiology, ultrasound and CAT scans; $8,000 to administer blood; $7,000 each for use of the operating room and the pharmacy charges, and $4,000 each for anesthesia and pulmonary services.
In Mrs. Martin's case, many of the charges would have been multiplied. At least 36 people worked on her three successive transplants: 11 surgeons, 6 anesthesiologists, 15 nurses, a physician's assistant, 2 blood technicians and a liver technician.
 
113 Days Spent In Intensive Care
 There were also charges for the seven surgical procedures and 113 days in the intensive-care unit as the doctors struggled to save her.
John W. Paul, a vice president with the medical center, said the hospital had received approval from Loral's insurance administrator, the Cigna Corporation, before proceeding with the treatment. He added: ''They had people come in and do ongoing reviews. What is unusual is that on the basis of those two things, they didn't make payments.''
The Pittsburgh medical center, which is the nation's busiest transplant center, says enormous expenses are involved in such cases, including training and paying surgeons, nurses and other sophisticated support people.
''We can more easily justify our terribly expensive care because we are providing the most intensive and, in some cases, unique care for very ill patients,'' said Jeffrey Romoff, an executive vice president with the medical center.
Indeed, the medical center receives $110 million a year in Federal research money, half of its research budget.
But Cigna, like all health-insurance administrators, has been under pressure from employers to find ways to hold down medical costs. So it has insisted on inspecting the records in the Martin case to insure that the charges are valid before paying.
But the hospital refuses to permit an audit of its bills until payment is made.
 
$1 Million Question: Who Pays the Bill?
 ''The hospital has refused our repeated requests to have access to medical records and to do a hospital-bill audit,'' said Amy De Marco, a Cigna spokeswoman. ''We're talking about a customer's dollars'' and possibly the family's dollars.
Employers have sometimes refused to pay for high-cost procedures that they say are experimental and unproved. But Cigna said Mrs. Martin's coverage did not exclude experimental treatments and so this was not an issue in her case.
While Loral would not comment on its costs, the million-dollar bill could by itself raise the annual health-care bill by 3 to 5 percent for a company of its size, 12,000 employees. (A smaller company's costs would rise by an even higher percentage.) Meanwhile, Mr. Martin, who spent three years caring for the woman he began dating when she was 15, is in theory responsible for the portion of the hospital bill that exceeded the $1 million limit in Loral's employee health plan. But the hospital said it would ''take a very realistic look'' at his ability to pay.
''Sometimes we don't collect 100 percent,'' said Jane Duffield, a hospital spokeswoman.
What Loral and Mr. Martin do not pay, someone else might. The hospital could compensate by raising its rates for other customers, including patients covered by private and Government insurance, and by seeking more Government research money.
''The bottom line is: We all pay either through insurance premiums, out of pocket or in higher taxes,'' said Roger Evans, a senior researcher at Battelle Seattle Research Institute.
