HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Lithuania Pays the Price And Acquires a Stoicism

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, April 28

 BODY:
By squeezing Lithuania's economic lifeline, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may have brought his conflict with the errant republic closer to compromise, but many Lithuanians say his embargo has had another, unintended effect: the quick maturing of an independent Lithuania.
From factory managers to taxi drivers, from the grocery stores to the President's office, Lithuanians say Mr. Gorbachev has unwittingly forced them to think more seriously about how they will live outside the paternalistic Soviet system.
In the short run, although the selective economic blockade now in its second week has not yet caused serious hardship here, it has concentrated the politicians' attention on the quest for a compromise.
Lithuanian political leaders realize that it is only a matter of weeks before their citizens begin to suffer. Mr. Gorbachev no doubt recognizes that Lithuania in misery would distract attention from his meeting next month in Washington with President Bush.
 
Way to Save Face
The appeal by France and Germany on Thursday for the republic to temporarily suspend enforcement of its March 11 independence declaration seems to have given both sides a face-saving way to the bargaining table. The Lithuanians can portray any concessions as a gesture to the European leaders rather than capitulation to the Kremlin's economic pressure. 
But the deeper effect of the sanctions, Lithuanians interviewed here say, appears to be quite the opposite from what Moscow intended. The blockade of fuel, industrial materials and other goods has unified Lithuanians more than ever in their feeling of alienation from Moscow and hardened their resolve to be free.
The layoffs and black market gasoline prices, Lithuanians say, have introduced market economics faster than the republic's leaders might have dared on their own. The workers raised with the security of the Soviet safety net are now getting a small lesson in unemployment and inflation and seeing that it is unpleasant but bearable.
An estimated 10,000 workers have been sent home from factories idled by the fuel embargo, and officials predict the number will triple in a week. But it will be several weeks before they exhaust unemployment benefits and begin to feel the pinch.
 
Encouraging Independence
The embargo has also spurred the independence Government on a search for direct economic ties with the West and with insurgent city councils and factories inside the Soviet Union.
Nothing much has come of it yet. A few factories have reportedly managed small freelance deals with neighboring Soviet republics, bartering bricks for a truckload of fuel oil or meat for machinery.
Nonetheless, Prime Minister Kazimieras Prunskiene said, people are beginning to calculate the real value of what they produce.
''Up to now our entire economic structure, everything we buy and everything we sell was based on Moscow,'' she said today. ''Now those connections are being demolished, not by us but by Moscow, and we are trying to manage on our own.''
Officials say the embargoes of oil, natural gas and now coal have has forced industrial managers to begin contemplating conservation, which never mattered when oil and everything else came from Moscow according to a plan.
Most striking, the showdown with Moscow has introduced a sobering note of pragmatism into the sometimes romantic politics of independence.
 
Kicking the Giant's Shins
From a distance, the Government of Lithuania sometimes resembles a comic opera, in which the amateur leaders of a pipsqueak republic kick the shins of the lethal giant next door.
In fact, judging from talks here with dozens of Lithuanians, their political leaders are playing out deep national feelings of pride and suspicions of the Soviet Union - feelings that are almost always locked behind a stoic Northern demeanor. But then there are such moments as the one when a woman suddenly bursts into tears in a crowded grocery store recalling her childhood in a Stalinist camp for Lithuanian deportees.
''Moscow does not understand why France is afraid of them, Germany is afraid of them, and little Lithuania is not afraid,'' said Virgilius Cepaitis, a member of Parliament and a fervent nationalist. Mr. Gorbachev, he adds, ''seems to forget that from 1944 to 1953 we fought against the Soviets. Longer than Vietnam.''
The Lithuanians' intense national pride and deep mistrust of the Soviet Union are embodied in the republic's president, Vytautis Landsbergis, a musicologist whose public pronouncements sometimes seemed to flow from a kind of mystic nationalism.
 
A Visceral Distaste
Mr. Cepaitis, who works closely with the Lithuanian President and shares his visceral distaste for the notion of placating Moscow, talks of the conflict with Mr. Gorbachev as a climactic battle, one which will speed the demise of a doomed Soviet system.
''Moscow only understands one language, the language of strength,'' Mr. Cepaitis said.
''We understand that this is a big inconvenience for the whole world,'' said Mr. Cepaitis, wearily acknowledging the Western views that Mr. Gorbachev's stability outweighs Lithuania's liberty, but suggesting that the collapse of the Soviet Union would be a blessing. ''It is our duty to the world to destroy this empire.''
In the new world of Lithuanian politics, this strain of messianic nationalism struggles with a more conventional political pragmatism.
While few deny that Mr. Landsbergis represents the aspirations of many Lithuanians, many questioned his political tactics, his seemingly boundless moral stubborness that could not be more remote from the cut-a-deal politics of Mr. Gorbachev.
By most estimates about one-third of the Lithuanian Parliament shares Mr. Landsbergis's reluctance to compromise. Another third is loyal to Mr. Landsbergis, but ambivalent about his tactics. The remaining third, while no less committed to independence, supports the idea of dealing more flexibly with Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Gain for Compromise
Arvydas Juozaitis, a young politician who dropped out of the leadership of the Lithuanian independence movement because ''I personally don't trust feelings in politics,'' said this week that he believed the conflict with Moscow may embolden the pro-compromise faction.
''The absolute majority of Lithuanians are not satisfied with the Landsbergis position, but at the same time the absolute majority does not see how to overcome what they have already done,'' said Mr. Juozaitis, who caused a stir last month with an article calling the election of Mr. Landsbergis ''a historic mistake.''
''The support for Landsbergis is still strong because there is no clear alternative program,'' he said.
Eduardas Vilkas, one of the most influential members of the group favoring compromise, said he senses that Mr. Landsbergis is moving slowly toward a more conciliatory stand.
Mr. Vilkas favors a six-month moratorium on the independence declaration, accompanied by a guarantee from Mr. Gorbachev to honor Lithuania's sovereignty afterward.
''Inflexibility is also a kind of strategy, but I do not think it is the right one,'' he said. ''We can hold out against economic sanctions for quite a long time. A lot of people are prepared to ride it out to the end. But there is no purely economic solution to the blockade, unless we learn to live without oil.''
 
Caring About Neighbors
Mr. Vilkas said Lithuania will never be safely free until people in the Soviet Union themselves have absorbed enough democracy to care about their neighbors.
''I used to think the democratization of Russia would take three to five years, but it is happening much more quickly,'' propelled by the example of Eastern Europe.
''It is dangerous to live with angry neighbors,'' said Mr. Vilkas, explaining why Lithuania has an interest in Mr. Gorbachev's fate.
''The position of the West is understandable, because the risk to the world is great,'' he said. ''If there is serious instability in the U.S.S.R., this will not be simply the civil war of 1917. Now it is a question of nuclear weapons, atomic power stations, chemical factories. All of this represents a global danger.''

HEADLINE: Concern Rises Over the Cost Of Statehood for Puerto Rico

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Although supporters say legislation authorizing Puerto Ricans to decide the status of their commonwealth is likely to pass the Senate this year, there is growing concern in Congress over the potential costs of statehood.
Approval of a bill authorizing a Puerto Rican plebiscite is predicted by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee. That panel held a hearing on Thursday to discuss the economic impact of any change in Puerto Rico's status. President Bush, who has expressed a preference for Puerto Rican statehood, has urged Congress to pass the bill. 
But some lawmakers are alarmed by the projected cost of statehood to United States taxpayers, $2 billion, and by the prospect of phasing out tax inducements now provided to those who invest in businesses on the island.
 
Warnings on 2 Fronts
The cost of bringing Puerto Rico's social welfare programs up to the level of other states' would be borne by the Federal Government. Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said at the hearing that the Administration must say where the money would come from.
In a report prepared for Mr. Bentsen, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that if Puerto Rico became a state its growth would be slowed by subjecting United States companies to Federal taxation on profits earned on the island.
Supporters of statehood say any economic losses would be more than offset by the stability of joining the union. Pointing out that Hawaii grew rapidly after it was admitted as a state, they argue that statehood would provide the basis for economic advances.
Many opponents of statehood say Puerto Rico's future would be better served by an ''enhanced'' and more flexible commonwealth.
In recent opinion polls, Puerto Ricans favoring statehood lead those who want it to keep commonwealth status. Adherents of independence, while influential among Puerto Rican intellectuals, have fared poorly in elections and polls.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, called for passage of the bill before the Senate panel and chided the House for not acting on a version of it. Ron de Lugo, the Delegate from the Virgin Islands who heads the House subcommittee responsible for island affairs, said a draft bill before his panel was awaiting an agreement from the three factions in Puerto Rico - those favoring statehood, continued commonwealth status and independence.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mistrial Declared in Case of Congressman

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, April 28

 BODY:
A mistrial was declared Friday in the bank fraud trial of Representative Harold E. Ford after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked.
''I'm hopeful now that I can put this episode behind me,'' said Mr. Ford, a 44-year-old Democrat from Memphis. 
But United States Attorney John Gill said in an interview from Knoxville that the case would be retried.
Mr. Ford was accused of taking $1 million in loans that prosecutors said he was never expected to repay. The loans came from Jake Butcher and C .H. Butcher Jr., brothers whose banking chain went out of business in 1983 in one of the nation's worst bank collapses.
The foreman of the jury, H. O. Robinson, reported the deadlock after Federal District Judge Odell Horton dismissed one juror for failing to disclose a past felony conviction. That development did not figure in the mistrial, lawyers said, because the jury could have continued deliberating with 11 members.
Mr. Ford was charged with 19 counts of conspiracy, bank fraud and mail fraud. The only black member of Congress from Tennessee, he complained after his indictment that he was the victim of racism, an allegation the Government has denied.

HEADLINE: Man Says He Put Dead Friend Outside His E. 68th St. House

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
The police were awaiting autopsy results yesterday after a man said he had left the body of a friend outside his brownstone on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
The friend , Lourie Sue Rosenthal, 29 years old, of Jamaica, Queens, apparently died late Wednesday or early Thursday in the apartment of a former Buildings Department official, a senior police investigator said.
The cause of death has not yet been determined, said a spokeswoman for the Chief Medical Examiner's office, Ellen Borakove. 
The former official, Peter Franconeri, who resigned this month effective on Friday as an assistant commissioner, told the police that the woman visited him on Wednesday night, the authorities said. The investigator said Mr. Franconeri had told the police that when he went to sleep, Miss Rosenthal was still in the apartment at 36 East 68th Street and that when he woke up several hours later she was dead. He said that, in a panic, he dragged her downstairs and left her.
 
From Office to Station House
The body was found after 8:55 A.M., when the police received an anonymous call to the 911 emergency telephone number. The police said they believed Mr. Franconeri was the caller.
When the police arrived, Miss Rosenthal, who had lived with her parents in Queens, was lying near the trash cans in front of the brownstone, dressed in jeans and a cotton blouse. Her handbag with identification was nearby.
Detectives notified Miss Rosenthal's parents, who gave them Mr. Franconeri's beeper number, which was written in the woman's address book. Investigators called Mr. Franconeri, who was at his job as an $83,459-a-year official in charge of centralized inspections, largely elevators and boilers. He went voluntarily to the 19th Precinct station house for questioning about 4 P.M. and met with detectives until midnight, when he was released.
A spokesman for the Buildings Department, Vahe Tiryakian, said Mr. Franconeri had been with the department about 10 months and that his resignation had nothing to do with the events of Thursday morning.
 
'Our Only Daughter'
''This other matter is nothing work- related,'' Mr. Tiryakian said. ''It's a matter of his private life, and it took us by surprise.''
Mr. Tiryakian said the department was restructured several weeks ago, and Mr. Franconeri's duties were distributed among other officials. ''His resignation was expected for some time,'' Mr. Tiryakian said.
Miss Rosenthal's mother, Seil, said her daughter had known Mr. Franconeri for about a year. Mrs. Rosenthal said her daughter, who was unemployed, called her on Wednesday night, apparently from Mr. Franconeri's apartment, and complained that she felt ill. She told her mother that she wanted to take a nap and would return home shortly.
''She's our only daughter,'' Mrs. Rosenthal said. ''I don't know how I will ever get over this.''

HEADLINE: Weicker's Senate Successor Wins Rapid Prominence

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut narrowly won election in 1988, it was widely considered a fluke, a victory that reflected a rejection of the three-term Republican incumbent, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., more than widespread support for the state's lesser-known Democratic Attorney General.
But in the last 16 months, Mr. Lieberman has become one of the more prominent and visible new members of the Senate, winning praise from Democrats for his grasp of environmental issues and from Republicans for his support of an aggressive foreign policy and a cut in the capital gains tax.
Perhaps more than any political issue, though, Mr. Lieberman has been applauded by members of both parties for his engaging personal skills, particularly since he succeeds Mr. Weicker, who was regarded by many as a brash and enigmatic loner in a legislative body as courtly and cliquish as a country club.
''The Senate is a great forum, great issues are debated, but it is ultimately 100 people,'' Mr. Lieberman said. ''Your ability to get things done is dependent on the quality of your goals, the quality of your argument and also the ability to develop mutually respectful working relationships with your colleagues.'' 
 
Environment Is Cornerstone
Thus far, Mr. Lieberman has made his greatest mark on environmental legislation. Aside from attacks on Mr. Weicker's effectiveness, environmental issues were the cornerstone of Mr. Lieberman's 1988 campaign.
The Senator has urged the Environmental Protection Agency to create a Long Island Sound office and obtained $2.4 million for two studies of the Sound by the E.P.A. and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Protecting the Sound is perhaps the largest environmental issue in Connecticut.
''He has done an excellent job in terms of Long Island Sound,'' said Christopher Percy, president of the Sounds Conservancy, a private nonprofit agency.
In the recent Clean Air Act compromise, Mr. Lieberman helped create a regional organization to monitor air pollution and enforce regulations in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states.
 
'Mastering the Fine Print'
''Joe demonstrated a real dedication toward mastering the fine print of Clean Air amendments, the kind of work that doesn't get much attention but commands respect from his colleagues,'' said Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat from Montana and chairman of the Environmental Protection subcommittee.
Senator Lieberman also introduced strong oil spill liability legislation, parts of which were included in the Senate bill approved last year. And he played a large role in legislation that led to a voluntary agreement by Uniroyal Chemical Company of Middlebury, Conn., to withdraw the ripening agent Alar from any use on food, after it was linked to cancer in laboratory animals.
''I have found Joe Lieberman to be a valuable ally,'' said Senator Harry M. Reid, a Democrat of Nevada and chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Toxic Substances, Environmental Oversight, Research and Development. ''He's tough, fair and doesn't settle for easy answers. When my committee was leading the fight to ban Alar, Joe was right there.''
Much of Mr. Lieberman's environmental work was accomplished because of his seat on the Environment and Public Works Committee, an appointment he sought and won largely because of his support in helping to elect Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine the Democratic majority leader. He also sits on the Governmental Affairs Committee and the Small Business Committee.
 
Broke With Party Leaders
Mr. Lieberman, however, broke with Mr. Mitchell and the party leadership in seeking to attach several stricter amendments to the Clean Air Act, including one that mandated tougher automobile emission standards.
Mr. Lieberman stepped out of line with his party on other occasions. Two months before the United States invasion of Panama in December, he was one of only three Senate Democrats to support a failed amendment by Republican Senator Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina that authorized President Bush to use force to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. He also is one of nine Democrats in the Senate who have called for diplomatic recognition of Lithuania. ''To me this is a moral crisis, a critical moment in history,'' he said. ''We've made this promise to the Lithuanian people, and it's not a time to mumble - it's a time to act.''
His independent streak was noticeable in the annual ratings of Senators made by various organizations, particularly in comparison with ratings for Mr. Weicker, a liberal who was often at odds with his own party.
The American Conservative Union gave Mr. Lieberman a rating of 32 out of 100; the average rating for Democratic senators from the East was an 11. ''Lowell Weicker got a zero sometimes,'' said Robert Billings, the legislative director for the organization.
The liberal Americans for Democratic Action, however, gave Mr. Lieberman a 75 out of 100. The National Journal, an influential political magazine, labeled him as the most conservative of all Eastern Democratic senators and less liberal than five Democrats from the South.
''We think we are going to get a vote from him now and again,'' said Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Republican of Minnesota. ''Not as often as it should be, but what can you do?''
 
Favored Capital-Gains Tax Cut
The Senator was also one of only six Democrats who supported a cut in the capital-gains tax rate, which was adamantly opposed by party leaders and defeated by the Senate last year.
Mr. Lieberman, however, does not always take a conservative, free-market approach to business and economic matters. For example, he introduced legislation last year that would allow state and local governments to re-regulate cable television prices.
He also helped draft a bill that would create housing for 135,000 low-income and homeless families by rehabilitating existing buildings. That legislation, which is pending, would allow homeless families and individuals to move into rental apartments without first posting a security deposit.
 
National Park in Connecticut
Of particular interest to Connecticut, Mr. Lieberman has proposed legislation to create Connecticut's first National Park at Weir Farm in Ridgefield and Wilton. He also obtained $630,000 for the McKinney Wildlife Refuge, in the Norwalk Islands in the Sound, and $7 million for Lyme disease research.
Mr. Lieberman's constituent service program includes a Senate office in a van that travels around the state to help residents tell staff members their concerns.
Since taking office, Senator Lieberman has not spoken to Mr. Weicker, who is now running for governor as an independent third-party candidate.
Keeping a 1988 campaign promise, Mr. Lieberman has not accepted honoraria or speaking fees. He also has not missed a roll call vote on the Senate floor, an issue on which he frequently criticized Mr. Weicker.
''It's been a very exciting and satisfying year for me,'' Mr. Lieberman said. ''Look, I'm just plain thrilled to be here. In some senses, I consider it a miracle that I'm here, and I'm grateful for the miracle, and I want to make the most of it.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Clark;
A Teacher's Edict Breaks Tradition On Class-Cutting

DATELINE: WORCESTER, Mass.

 BODY:
William Koelsch, a professor of history and geography at Clark University, last week became the first faculty member to break with an 87-year-old tradition, approved by the administration, that let students skip classes on one day of the term.
Taking his cue from Winston Churchill, Professor Keolsch said, ''Up with this I will not put,'' as he informed his classes in a memorandum that any absences on Spree Day would be tantamount to missing a one-hour examination and would lower the absent student's final grade a letter.
His stand put him at loggerheads with the administration. 
The date of Spree Day, which celebrates the arrival of spring, is kept secret until students awake to find the campus transformed into a playground. Last Tuesday's Spree Day featured a hot-air balloon, giant slides, popcorn machines and a carnival.
Historically no classes are held on Spree Day. But this year many administrators and teachers were disgruntled to learn that the administration had approved a date that fell near the semester's end, leaving them little time to reschedule review sessions for final exams.
''The issue here is not Spree Day,'' said Professor Koelsch, himself a Clark alumnus. ''It's Spree Day held on the last week of classes.'' The timing, he said, suggested that the administration placed Spree Day above academic priorities.
Mona Olds, the dean of students, said in an interview that ''the administration respects Spree Day as a tradition,'' and that students who believed they had received an unfair grade because they were absent from class could appeal - first to the teacher involved, then to the head of the teacher's department and finally to the dean of the college.
Daniel DiSano, a senior in economics from Melrose, Mass., and co-chairman of the 10-student Spree Day committee, said that the April 24 date had been approved last month by the offices of the dean of students and the provost, with the understanding that teachers would be notified through department heads so they could prepare.
The scheduling became an issue in the wake of Professor Koelsch's class memo. At a meeting on April 20, teachers adopted without dissent a motion to ''accommodate the traditional sense of collegiality between students and faculty and wherever possible to make accommodations for Spree Day.'' But the motion left it to individual professors to act as they saw fit.
Edward Dzialo, a junior in history and theater from Fall River, Mass., who is in Professor Koelsch's class, said the decision to require attendance had suprised him, since he considered the professor a ''Clark enthusiast.'' Mr. Dzialo said it was not fair that Professor Koelsch should hold students accountable for an administration decision.
Other class members agreed. A sophomore, Joseph Rodio from Webster, Mass., who is majoring in history, said, ''It's not right to punish us for other people's mistakes.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clark University students enjoying Spree Day last week. Historically no classes are held then. One professor decided to break with tradition and told his classes that absences on the day would be tantamount to missing an examination and would lower the student's final grade. (The New York Times/Rick Friedman)

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Chicago;
A Major Imperiled By Popularity And Understaffing

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
A shortage of professors and a growing number of students is leading the University of Chicago to suspend a program started after Watergate called Politics, Economics, Rhetoric and Law.
The program combines the four areas with junior and senior research papers. Recent topics have included a study of integration at universities near here, the rhetoric of the Little Rock, Ark., desegregation crisis and the social structure of the southeast side of Chicago. 
Students and faculty members met last week on the possibility of reviving the major. The program, with 28 students, had 40 applications for seven spots last year, said its chairman, Dennis Hutchinson, a professor of legal history.
''It's a question of manpower,'' he said, noting that three professors ''present at the creation of PERL'' would retire next year.
Although Professor Hutchinson and many students agree that the papers, which require two professors as readers, are ''the heart and soul of PERL,'' finding the professors became a challenge.
 
Called Too 'Time Consuming'
''More and more people have too many other things that they're doing to take on something this time consuming,'' said Charles Gray, a history professor and the master of the new collegiate division, which oversees the program.
Four classes a year were required. Mr. Gray said in-class teaching was just the beginning. In addition to preparing lectures and grading papers from the five or six courses he usually teaches, he said he supervised senior papers and tutorials and advised graduate students.
Professor Hutchinson, who is teaching four classes this year, noted that one has almost 100 students. Neither he nor Mr. Gray uses teaching assistants to grade papers. ''I'm lucky if I get five hours a week for research during the school year,'' Mr. Hutchinson said.
The college has grown from 2,981 students in 1984 to more than 3,300. ''Why is the political science department overburdened with its own papers?'' Professor Hutchinson asked. ''Because we have more students than we did five or six years ago.''
 
'Don't Have Enough Professors'
He added that the problems confronted other interdisciplinary majors, because many professors have work in their disciplines. A member of the program faculty, Wayne Booth, a professor of English, said some extradepartmental projects required professors to spend time on background research.
Jennifer Nessmith, a senior from Freeport, said: ''We simply don't have enough professors for all the students. We need to hire more.'' Ms. Nesmith said the program was one of the only majors here that allowed students to combine theory with practical concerns.
Eliminating the junior or senior paper would be a mistake, said Mary Johnston, a third-year student from Washington, adding, ''They're the best part of the program.''
Although projects ''do not always fit in comfortably with my schedule,'' said Barry Karl, a history professor who is frequently a reader, they are ''intellectually exciting and built on ideas.''
The suspension of the program ''will leave a noticeable hole in the sense of myself as a teacher here,'' he said.
Mr. Gray foresees a one-year hiatus and hopes to have a new program ''like PERL, only better'' by next spring. A new major would have to be ''less labor intensive,'' he said.
''I don't think it's going to be revamped,'' Mr. Hutchinson said. ''In two years it will be history.''

HEADLINE: THEATER;
WILLIAMS SHOCKED AMERICAN THEATER INTO MATURITY

BYLINE: By RICHARD GILMAN; Richard Gilman, the author of ''The Making of Modern Drama'' (Da Capo), is a critic and professor at the Yale School of Drama.

 BODY:
The story is told that when Andre Gide was asked who was France's greatest writer he replied, ''Victor Hugo . . . helas.'' In the same way, the answer to a question about America's best playwright might be, ''Eugene O'Neill (or, to some minds, Tennessee Williams) . . . alas.'' Though both responses express sorrow, the cases are different. Gide's point was that Hugo, a forceful but not especially profound or original writer, was so wrapped in the apparel of literary fame that he dwarfed all other reputations, whereas the point about O'Neill and Williams is that our history of writing for the stage, writing seriously, is so thin and insubstantial compared to Europe as to make them our masters by default.
The two suffer from the invidious effects of such comparison, particularly among those we might call the theater intelligentsia. In both cases, their gifts existed in the midst of grave deficiencies, embarrassments of an intellectual and esthetic order. In the oeuvre of both, very few plays measure up to, indeed most fall drastically short of, the standards established by the dramas of Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekhov, Shaw, Pirandello, Brecht and Beckett. 
Yet why play the rating game? In the matter of Williams, about whom we've all been reminded by the presence on Broadway of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' with Kathleen Turner (and earlier this season by Peter Hall's production of ''Orpheus Descending'' with Vanessa Redgrave), he should not be allowed to drift off, a fringe figure, a dubious case, to some third or fourth tier of theatrical renown. For it's not too much to say that Williams brought American drama to maturity in a way that not even O'Neill had done. Williams once said he wanted to air out all those ''closets, attics and basements of human behavior,'' which is just what he succeeded in doing. He brought a darker, more violent side to our stage imaginings, brought the unconscious into prominence; after him there was no clear artistically obnoxious line between normal and abnormal, no excuse for evasion. One specific triumph was that he changed the way women are portrayed on our stage, offering us articulate and powerfully erotic beings where the ordinary range had been between charmers and bitches.
It's hard to keep in mind that Williams was once our most scandalous dramatist, ''the one,'' as he wryly said of himself, ''who writes all those dirty plays.'' I suppose there are still a few moralists around who make faces at the mention of his name, but otherwise his ''disturbing'' subjects have long since been assimilated into theatrical and public consciousness, though the cannibalism of ''Suddenly Last Summer,'' spoken of in the play and absurdly made partly visible in the film version, has hardly become a common theme.
But the rest of it, the hunger for erotic contact (but seldom simply for the erotic), the secrets of lust, the range of sexual phenomena from adultery to sadomasochism, the castrations and abortions, above all the homosexual dispositions and implications, sometimes disguised as a concession to the times as heterosexual arrangements (well, Proust did that magnificently, too) - all this no longer has any power to shock. That is why it's so important to remember, or understand for the first time, the dismally cautious, safely ''liberal'' bloodless atmosphere of the American theater at the time - the late 40's, early 50's - Williams made his dangerous, irreverent appearance. Drama has been called the ''impure'' art and if Williams's is notably impure, the best of it retains, or more accurately seems to have regained, a legitimate place in our affections and esteem, whatever the skepticism of the absolutists. After a long period of decline, the result primarily of the series of inferior and sometimes catastrophically bad plays he kept desperately turning out for the last 20 years of his life, his reputation, insecure as it continues to be, appears to be on the rise.
Over the last six or seven years since his death in 1983 three or four dozen productions of his plays have been put on by theaters around the country, a new biography by Virginia Carr, the biographer of Carson McCullers, will be published by Scribner's in the next couple of years and an exhaustive two-volume literary biography by Lyle Leverich is in the works. There have been several large-scale television productions (the most recent an unfortunate ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' last fall with Elizabeth Taylor) and he has returned to Broadway in considerable triumph, or at least with much fanfare, with ''Cat,'' a production that though overlong and unevenly acted, allows the text to survive its playing.
The way that a text can be said to ''hold up'' is that it resists being confined to its period, something Williams's less harsh detractors like to do with nearly all his plays; the harshest deny him any virtues at all except perhaps for a wan exoticism. What may date in Williams are details, local references, the catch phrases and iconography of an era, but not, in his best or better work, his deep motifs, his obsessions, the singularities of his vision, his having written for actors roles with real weight and intensity. Even less likely to date are the pleasures his dramatic language can now and then give - unsurpassed by an American dramatist.
The consensus is nearly absolute as to what his best works are: ''The Glass Menagerie'' (1945) and ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' (1947). After that, opinion tends to splinter. In my own case I see a little below those two plays another quite admirable pair: ''Suddenly Last Summer'' (1958) and ''The Eccentricities of a Nightingale'' (1964), Williams's rewriting of and improvement on ''Summer and Smoke.'' And below them, managing to hang on to some minor territory of theatrical permanence, or semi-permanence, ''Orpheus Descending,'' ''The Rose Tattoo'' and ''Cat,'' with ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' and ''Night of the Iguana'' asking us to look as kindly as we can on their severe frailties, and ''Camino Real'' remaining visible as a noble if almost totally failed experiment.
Not surprisingly the best of Williams's plays are the best constructed - their dramatic progression marked by economy, coherence and the absence of wayward issues competing ruinously for the playwright's attention. They are also the ones most free from intellectual fog, into which Williams, like O'Neill, was so prone to disappear.
And they're freest, too, from false lyricism, a vocabulary of pseudo-poetic longing and pained amorousness and from flaccid melancholy, sorrowfulness so free-floating it can attach itself to nothing instructive. (Williams, who had rather more self-awareness than he's usually credited with, once told an interviewer that his chief debility ''has been a tendency to what people call . . . to poeticize, you know.'') The last hapless plays, with their angels, ghosts, apparitions and avatars of Williams himself as suffering poet and doomed lover, are full of these qualities of maimed dramatic speech, though they can crop up in his work at any time.
But when he's using his ear well (the ''ear'' in a good playwright, or novelist for that matter, is never for the details of speech but its rhythms) and his emotions are under artistic control, the language in his plays is as inventive and evocative as any we've had. Blanche Dubois's painful, self-serving memories, Tom's speech in ''The Glass Menagerie'' about going to the moon, or Val's in ''Orpheus Descending'' about the bird that sleeps on the wing are characterized by a splendid fusion of imaginative verve and exact diction.
These examples, however, are dramatic high points, arias that anyone familiar with Williams will know. It's in the humbler speeches, dialogue that neither soars nor celebrates, that Williams's forever beleaguered mastery of language can best be heard. Out of a wealth of possibilities two little speeches from ''The Eccentricities of a Nightingale'' make the point.
One is by Alma after her father has told her of her mother's ''cold spite'' and that such women shouldn't get married. Alma: ''I know, but they do, they do. They are the ones that marry! The ones that could bring to marriage the sort of almost - transcendental tenderness that it calls for - what do they do? Teach school! Teach singing! Make a life out of little accomplishments.''
The other is by the father to Alma: ''Little things like that, an accumulation of them, Alma, little habits, little mannerisms, little - peculiarities of behavior - they are what get people known, eventually, as - eccentrics. And eccentric people are not happy, they are not happy people, Alma.''
The rhythms, the strategic repetitions, the exactly chosen emphases and beautifully functioning hesitations - all this quietly demonstrates Williams at his craftsmanlike best. But often in the last plays, Williams fell into dialogue of an almost hysterical incoherence, as in this outburst from ''The Red Devil Battery Sign'' (1975), perhaps his worst play: ''Yes! Human! To enter my life something human is special, this day, this night, this place, suddenly - you - human! Here! What?'' The speech is by a character called the Woman Downtown, whose abstract name suggests the Expressionistic influences (more broadly the dated avant-gardism) to which Williams came to succumb in his fever to get past the naturalistic limitations - as he, reluctantly, and others, cruelly, saw them - of the plays of his heyday. A late two-character short play, ''I Can't Imagine Tomorrow,'' has, for example, a woman called One and a man called Two, indicative of the ''experimental'' tics that more and more afflicted his writing.
The itch to do something technically ''new'' was likely the result of the scorn in which his later realistic plays were increasingly held by sophisticated critics. During the 50's, when Williams was flourishing, the European avant-garde - Beckett, Genet, Ionesco, Pinter - was seizing the imaginations of Americans concerned with the laggard condition of our dramatic art. And even those writers' (distant) American cousins, Edward Albee in his earliest work, Jack Gelber in ''The Connection,'' had begun to shift attention from Williams's ''old-fashioned'' dramas. But this old-fashionedness, the quality of bold sequential narrative and mimetic fidelity, is just what makes for Williams at his best.
If Williams maintains his place in our theater it's because his frequently elegant imagination is its own justification. To see ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' now is to become aware again of how that imagination worked. Proof that in Williams the erotic is seldom present for its own sake is abundant in ''Cat.'' Brick's anguish over his possible homosexuality, his and Maggie's marital Armageddon, are subsumed under a much larger and more complex rubric: that of ''mendacity,'' lying about oneself and to the self.
In Williams, sexual passions always conceal and at the same time give body to themes of besieged spirit, loss, anguish and the demands of moral integrity. The erotic is the scene of defeat and despair but also at times of affirmation, generosity. The ''heroes'' in his plays, I once wrote, are those who, however faulty or maimed in other realms remain fully human in this one; his ''villains'' are the envious, the vindictive, the converters of love into use.
Sometime in the 70's, the years of Williams's decline and despair, several students of mine made a pilgrimage to his house in Key West, Fla. They deeply admired his earlier work and had the crazy idea that they could convince him that he didn't have to keep trying to prove himself. ''You've done enough,'' they said. ''What we feel for you isn't going to evaporate.'' He was flattered, moved and defensive. He fed them and sent them on their way. Yes, their mission was naive, even foolish, but they were right: he did do enough.

LENGTH: 1560 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: April 22-27

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
 
 
The Milken Guilty Pleas
 
It began as a noble enterprise: Open up the credit markets to the daring and the imaginative, the untested companies snubbed by the ossified old firms that rule Wall Street. Rattle the complacent managers of the bloated corporations those older investment banks count as their clients. At times, the strivings of Michael R. Milken had all the romance of a revolution. But his financial career, if not his financial revolution, apparently ended in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday with his guilty pleas to six felonies carrying penalties and fines of $600 million. He admitted to cheating customers, rigging the market for some stocks and bonds and helping a friend illegally avoid taxes. A prison term is all but certain. How long might depend on whether a judge agrees with Mr. Milken's lawyers that the nation is better off for his efforts, or with regulators who say that criminality became the essence of his work. 
 
 
Arabs, Yen, Oil, Saks . . .
 
It is no fluke that Arab investors outbid the Japanese for Saks Fifth Avenue. Investcorp, whose shareholders have included several oil ministers, agreed last week to pay B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of London $1.5 billion for the chain. Investment bankers were heard to say it was a ''full price'' - Wall Street talk for ''too much.'' A group including the Tobu Department Store Company of Japan and Saks's management bid only $1.25 billion. For the Japanese, the yen's depreciation has made American investments more expensive. If the yen were still 125 to the dollar, instead of 159, the Japanese could have as easily afforded $1.6 billion. With oil prices stabilizing and America's oil imports increasing, the Arabs are likely to ship more of their earnings to the United States. As David T. Mizrahi, editor of the Mideast Report, said, ''In the 70's, we had the Arab era. In the 80's, we had the Japanese era. Within two years, we're going to see the Arab era again.''
 
 
. . . And a Rebuff to Sir James
 
B.A.T. went through with the Saks auction even though it has been freed from a takeover threat. Sir James Goldsmith dropped his $21 billion bid for the conglomerate last Monday. To defend against his assault, B.A.T. had bought back stock, raised its dividend and agreed to sell several divisions. ''The bird would have been nearly carved,'' said an official of Sir James's investment group. But his withdrawal lessens the chances that American-style corporate carving and takeovers will spread across Europe.
 
 
Profits Up, Outlook Mixed
 
Corporate profits are getting a reprieve from a stronger economy. Economists say that first-quarter earnings, while not booming, are producing at least as many pleasant surprises as disappointments. Several computer and technology companies, like International Business Machines, which depend heavily on business investment, have come through well. Many traders were braced for a round of results as poor as the fourth quarter's. Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, says he didn't expect profits to rebound until later this year. Now, he says, rising interest rates and inflation might stall corporate performance in the second half.
 
*
 
Earnings reported last week were shaky, but special factors accounted for much of the news:
* Exxon profits down 29.3 percent to $1.28 billion after a one-time gain from an accounting change last year.
* RJR Nabisco, a $222 million loss from interest expenses, but strong operating profits.
* Sears, Roebuck profits down 58.8 percent to $106.3 million as the stores posted a loss.
* USX profits of $176 million, 40.5 percent lower with the steel division hardest hit.
* Time Warner, a $187 million loss due to interest expenses and the acquisition of Warner.
 
 
The St. Louis Sun Blues
 
Was it debt or was it the newspaper slump that killed the St. Louis Sun? Those gathered at the American Newspaper Publishers Association last week doubted Ralph Ingersoll 2d's newspaper would survive, but they were surprised it failed so soon. On Wednesday, he published his 213th and last issue. It is easy enough to point to his own particular problems - staggering debts, a slack local economy, slow circulation gains and a more secure competitor in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. But some analysts say Mr. Ingersoll's tabloid was also swept away by the ills of the industry. ''The newspaper business is going through a very, very severe downturn, and there doesn't seem to be any upturn in sight,'' said Kenneth T. Berents, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons.
 
 
In Brief
 
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, told Congress that Japan's new openness to American products argues against citing it for unfair trading practices.
 
*
 
The Norton Company agreed on Wednesday to be acquired by Compagnie de Saint-Gobain of France for $1.9 billion.
 
*
 
Henry Recamier, who put handbags and luggage with the LV on fashionable arms around the world, resigned as Louis Vuitton chairman on Thursday. His departure ended a long board-room battle at LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, France's leading maker of luxury goods.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Tokyo Ups the Holiday Ante
 
The Japanese Government has finally found a way to get obsessively dedicated workers out of their offices: pack the calendar with more holidays. Tomorrow will be Japan's first Greenery Day. The holiday is meant to encourage the planting and cultivation of natural vistas celebrated in Japan's art but rare in its cities. It was marked as Emperor Hirohito's birthday until he died last year. Now, the birthday of his son, Emperor Akihito, is being celebrated as well, on Dec. 23. A spokesman for the Japanese consulate in New York had difficulty listing all the official holidays. He came up with 13, three more than the Government and several more than most businesses observe in the United States. Many of the days have high-minded themes - Culture Day and Exercise Day, Children's Day and Respect the Elders Day - that encourage workers to think of the observances as virtual obligations.
 
 
Deciphering the Soviet Economy
 
Talk about shifting international alliances. When it comes to estimating Soviet economic strength, some Soviet economists said at a conference in Washington last week, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Kremlin are, in effect, on the same, overly optimistic team. The intelligence agency says the Soviet gross national product is half that of the United States; try 28 percent, said a Soviet economist. And to the Soviet Government's claim that its agricultural output is 85 percent of America's, another Soviet economist estimated 55 percent. Soviet officials have been so successful at hiding their true economic statistics, its seems, that now neither they nor the C.I.A. can find them.
 
 
Those Generous Germans
 
What's a few billion marks between old friends? To smooth the process of reunification, West Germany has offered to buy East German marks at a generous, one-to-one rate - at least for wages, pensions and some household savings. The black market rate is five to one. Many West German economists fear the plan's inflationary expense.
 
 
 
ECONOMY
 
 
Interest Rates: Inevitably Up?
 
A sharp rise in an inflation index could force the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates. An inflation measure used to adjust the gross national product rose at a 6.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter, the steepest increase since 1982. The Commerce Department also reported on Friday that the G.N.P. itself rose 2.1 percent - healthy, but not as large a gain as economists had recently predicted. Signs of renewed inflation and growth pushed rates on long-term Treasury bonds past 9 percent last week for the first time in a year. With both inflation and the G.N.P. growing faster than targeted, the Fed is likely to raise the Federal funds rate one quarter of 1 percent in the next couple of months, said Roseanne Cahn, an economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''They are on record as pursuing an anti-inflationary policy, and if they don't do something, they lose credibility.''
 
 
Playing the Derby Nags
 
Battered by the bond market? Sick of stocks? For some less-risky investments, and maybe some equine arbitrage, check out next Saturday's card at Churchill Downs. Value investors at the Kentucky Derby might favor the poor boy from the tropics, Mister Frisky. A $15,000 horse bred in Florida and raced in Puerto Rico, he swept all 16 of his starts - including the Santa Anita Derby, whose winners have gone on to victory in the Kentucky Derby two years in a row. Bettors who prize Kentucky heritage and breeding instead will lay their investments on Summer Squall. By Storm Bird out of the Secretariat mare Weekend Surprise, he was sold at the Keeneland auctions in Kentucky two years ago for $300,000. He returned there to win the Blue Grass Stakes on a track as muddy as a Marine training course. As the local favorite, Summer Squall is bound to be overbet at the track. The arbitrage-minded might take Mister Frisky there, then hedge by having friends wager for them on Summer Squall in New York, where Off-Track Betting has its own pool and its own odds.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Time to Test the Country Funds?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Single-country funds, the glamour stocks of the closed-end mutual fund group, have taken investors on a dizzying downhill ride since they peaked in mid-January. But some analysts say the overheated market has finally cooled, leaving good buys for speculators and people who want to fill the high-risk end of portfolios.
''The group is beginning to look quite reasonably valued and, in some cases, even cheap,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser, who said many funds in the group are trading at prices lower than the value of the stock in their portfolios.
Single-country funds, which invest in foreign equities, lost 27.1 percent between mid-January and mid-April, said Mr. Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end fund investment and analysis. Closed-end funds trade on major exchanges like common stock, at a premium or discount to the value of the stock in their portfolios. 
Although country funds have always been the most volatile component of the closed-end fund industry, many investors were caught by surprise when the bottom fell out of the market this year. Disenchanted with wide price swings, many investors have bailed out. Others are having second thoughts, especially as they watch Europe's wobbly efforts to redefine itself.
Clearly, only investors with a strong appetite for risk should consider country funds, analysts warn. But there may be some big gains to be had. Last year, for example, four such funds - the Asia Pacific Fund, the Thai Fund, the Spain Fund and the Germany Fund - were among the top 10 performing shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The crash of the Tokyo market earlier this year has not affected single-country funds that invest in the Pacific rim, according to Steven M. Cress, senior analyst for closed-end funds at Prudential-Bache Securities. He noted that the Japan O.T.C. Equity Fund has been a spectacular performer this year and he expects the Pacific to be a solid performer at least through the end of the year.
He also recommends the R.O.C./Taiwan Fund, which is trading at a 28 percent discount while its counterpart, the Taiwan Fund, trades at a 15 percent discount. He says the discrepancy occurred because the established Taiwan Fund has paid out large capital gains distributions. He predicted that after the R.O.C./Taiwan Fund builds a track record, it will probably do the same, shrinking the size of its discount.
Mr. Herzfeld considers Southeast Asian countries to have some of the best growth rates in the world. One of his favorite funds is Asia Pacific, now trading at a 20 percent discount, compared with a 43 percent premium in January. He also likes the First Philippine Fund, which traded at a 34 percent premium in Janaury and is now at an 18 percent discount. He believes the Philippine economy will grow strongly this year.
The Turkish Investment Fund, which traded at a 2 percent premium in January but now is at a 32 percent discount, is another of Mr. Herzfeld's picks. The fund's portfolio manager is predicting that the Turkish stock market will rise sharply this year and Mr. Herzfeld thinks that would almost double the fund's price.
Much of the turbulence in the single-country fund market has centered on Europe. Market prices began their runup in mid-1989. Perestroika, the progress toward unifying Western Europe's trade and monetary policies, and the crumbling of the Berlin wall and the Communist bloc - all heightened investor interest in country funds.
At the turn of the year, only 24 funds were up and running and, overloaded with new money, they began trading at huge premiums. Underwriters soon fell over each other to set up new funds. Since the beginning of 1990, 11 new ones, most of them in Europe, have come to market, pulling the total to 35 - a 46 percent jump in only four months.
Four funds created to invest in companies in East and West Germany are doing business now and four more are in the works. The Germany Fund, created to back West German investment, traded at a 100 percent premium to its net asset value early this year, but now trades at a 3 percent premium.
Mr. Herzfeld especially likes the Future Germany Fund. Its price has dropped to about $14 a share from about $19 when it came to market in February at a 15 percent premium. The proliferation of Germany funds has put pressure on prices, but Mr. Herzfeld expects that to keep underwriters from launching similar issues. Once supply stabilizes - later this year, he thinks - prices of Germany funds should recover.
But Germany is not the only European country to warrant investor interest. Mr. Cress of Pru-Bache favors the Growth Fund of Spain, which is trading at a 9 percent discount while the the Iberian Fund and the Spain Fund trade at premiums. Mr. Cress says that the Spanish Government now is keeping to a tight monetary policy to control inflation. As inflation cools, interest rates should drop and that will let the Spanish market reflect its strong earnings growth, he said.
 
 
 
THE SWITCH IN FUNDS
In the early 1980's, investors flocked into money market funds as yields rose as high as 16 percent. In 1981, almost 80 percent of the people who invested in mutual funds owned money market funds - a level that has not been seen since.
But as rates fell - and the long bull market began - stock and bond funds outpaced money market funds. And despite the 1987 market crash, they continued to attract many more investors than money funds. Indeed, if rates stay stable and the stock market doesn't take a nosedive, investors will stay in stock and bond funds this decade, said Louis S. Harvey, president of Dalbar Financial Services, a Boston-based mutual fund research group. ''I think that we'll see a continuing movement into stock and bond funds because the returns are better,'' he said.
Stock fund investors have earned annual rates of return of just over 18.7 percent since 1980, Dalbar said, while bond funds averaged returns of 9.4 percent and money funds yielded 8.5 percent.

LENGTH: 1787 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Stubborn Overseas Bank

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
As Japan's longtime financial ambassador to the world, the Bank of Tokyo became used to seeing its fortunes mirror the international successes of corporate Japan. But in a striking example of how deregulation and competition are transforming the financial system here, this proud institution is now in the fight of its life.
The bank's century-old role as the engine for much of Japan's international growth has been eroded by the expanding foreign presence of much bigger and more aggressive Japanese rivals, like the Sumitomo Bank, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and the Industrial Bank of Japan. The bank has also been hurt by the loosening of the country's rigid financial regulations. The liberalization, for example, has ended its monopoly on the foreign-exchange business of Japanese corporations.
But most of all it is suffering for simply doing what it was designed to do: focus on overseas business and not worry about the home market. Its heavy international involvement made it vulnerable during the last two decades to the same financial turbulence that nearly ruined a number of American banks, leaving it with the same third-world debt problems, while it largely missed out on the economic boom in Japan. 
But despite the weight of its troubles, the bank - 19th largest in the world and 14th largest in Japan - has no plans to change direction, top executives say.
''We're an international specialist bank,'' insisted Kaoru Hayama, the bank's key strategist and managing director of its planning department. ''That is what makes us unique. We are operating in a more competitive world, and customers tend to shop around rather than assign their business to just one bank. That's why our specialty in international business matters is a strength.''
It is a strategy that leaves analysts skeptical. ''Their position as a specialty foreign-exchange bank made them very important to Japanese corporations at one time,'' said James E. Russell at Merrill Lynch Japan. ''But everywhere you turn today, they have some disadvantage. In some ways they are being pushed back into fringe markets.''
The bank has spent heavily, for instance, to build its presence in California, where it owns the Union Bank. And the Bank of Tokyo's chairman, Yusuke Kashiwagi, has said repeatedly that he sees Asia as the most promising market for expansion. But analysts say it is just purchasing market share in the United States. And in Asia, they add, the bank is finding it harder to compete.
In Asia, ''they no longer have any real advantages,'' said Brian Waterhouse, a banking analyst with James Capel Pacific. ''They're steeped in history, but there's not much they can do that Mitsubishi Bank or I.B.J. or Fuji Bank cannot do.''
Meanwhile, there is little room to grow at home, where the bank has just 32 offices, compared with 295 abroad. Its chances of expanding that domestic base to match any of its bigger rivals - Dai-Ichi Kangyo, the country's largest bank, has 377 offices in Japan - are slim. Since the Government tightly regulates the number of new offices, the only effective way to expand is by acquisition, and prices are prohibitive.
''We can manage,'' said the 55-year-old Mr. Hayama. But the trouble signs remain. Although the Bank of Tokyo has reduced its exposure in recent years, it still has by far the largest portfolio of problem third-world loans of any Japanese lender, equal to 92 percent of its equity.
And sharply rising interest rates over the last six months have depressed the bank's basic profit spread, the difference between its return on all its assets and the rate it pays for its capital. According to Merrill Lynch, that spread has tumbled from a relatively healthy 0.74 percentage points three years ago to an estimated -0.20 now. Certainly, all Japanese banks have suffered, but those whose deposits come largely from companies rather than individuals, like the Bank of Tokyo, have been hit hardest. This is because the rates paid to companies tend to rise faster than those paid to consumers.
That trend will contribute to the expected decline in the Bank of Tokyo's consolidated net income to an estimated 50 billion yen, or about $320 million, for the year that ended March 31, down from 60.7 billion yen the previous fiscal year.
Several analysts are now asking whether the bank would be better off combining with another institution. Some say it would make an ideal merger candidate with a regional Japanese bank that has a strong domestic branch system.
''They need a partner,'' said Stuart Matthews, an analyst here for Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''They're getting killed in so many ways, precisely because they're just an international bank.''
Added James Capel Pacific's Mr. Waterhouse, ''They have excellent management, their products are excellent and they are in all the important markets. But for every international advantage there's a domestic disadvantage. At some point I imagine they'd want to overcome their domestic weaknesses, and they can't do it on their own.''
Adding more pressure for a merger is deregulation of Japanese bank deposits. In the compartmentalized system established after World War II, the regular commercial banks, known as city banks, were permitted to take deposits for terms only up to two years. A group of special institutions, the long-term credit banks, were allowed to take deposits, in the form of debentures, for up to five years, but they could only make long-term loans. The Bank of Tokyo was in a category by itself: it could sell three-year debentures, which gave it a big advantage over the city banks in attracting deposits.
In recent years, however, the Finance Ministry has been tearing down those barriers, and the city banks are expected to be able to sell certificates of deposit for up to three years, and possibly longer, in the near future. That will give banks with wide domestic branch networks far greater access to Japan's huge pool of private savings.
Ironically, the troubles now being faced by this quintessential Japanese institution are not much different from what many American banks are encountering as they try to match financial muscle with the Japanese banking behemoths.
Coddled in the protected domestic market for years, Dai-Ichi Kangyo and the others have grown far larger, more powerful and much more aggressive than the Bank of Tokyo - and the Americans.
Notwithstanding the recent turmoil in the Japanese financial markets, the domestic bases of most major Japanese banks are still the envy of the industry, and the absence of such a base at the Bank of Tokyo is its most glaring weakness. Indeed, analysts say, the bank's situation is underscoring a lesson that Americans need to learn as well: it is very hard for any major global bank to compete internationally if its base at home is weak.
Weakness is a relatively new word to use in connection with the Bank of Tokyo. The bank and its prewar predecessor, the Yokohama Specie Bank, had been Japan's premier international financial institution since the mid-19th century, when the country began its headlong rush toward industrial development. (See box.) The true measure of how much things had changed came during the domestic boom of the 1980's: When the other major Japanese banks were raking in billions of yen by lending to wealthy individuals, real estate developers and corporate borrowers at home, the Bank of Tokyo was busy making risky loans to third-world nations.
Because it was putting most of its capital abroad, the bank did not benefit as much as its competitors did from the skyrocketing prices on the Tokyo stock and real estate markets. Japanese banks are permitted to own up to 5 percent of the shares of corporations, and all the big banks have huge stock portfolios. (Those portfolios have been buffeted by the recent Tokyo stock declines, but the values of shares are only back to where they were about six months ago.) Besides providing a major source of profits in the past few years, the huge portfolios helped the banks bolster their capital bases. Under international banking rules adopted by the major industrialized nations, big banks must increase their capital as a proportion of their assets to a ratio of better than 8 percent by 1993. Banks can raise those sums by retaining some of their profits, issuing new shares - or selling off some of their portfolios.
The Bank of Tokyo also had to contend in the early 80's with the end of its monopoly in the foreign-exchange business. By the first half of fiscal 1989, the bank had only the fourth-highest pretax income among Japanese banks from foreign-exchange trading.
Given all these changes, it is unclear just how long the bank can afford to remain committed to its international strategy, particularly in light of the looming increase in capital requirements.
''The capital issue makes it harder for them to get over their problems,'' said Mr. Matthews of Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''They have less flexibility. They have some decisions to make.''
 
 
 
 THE CHRYSANTHEMUM AND THE BANK
The Bank of Tokyo has played a unique role in Japanese history, serving as the main conduit through which this once-isolated country dealt with the world.
The bank was founded in 1880 as the Yokohama Specie Bank and was partly owned by the Imperial family. The country's rulers had decided to transform Japan into the biggest industrial power in Asia, so the bank was stocked with the best and brightest graduates from the country's top Imperial universities, a source of prestige to this day.
The bank was indispensable to the Government in the 1930's, when Japan forcibly transformed Manchuria, the northeastern portion of China, into the puppet state of Manchukuo. Japan poured capital and technology into the region to create an industrial colony to feed its military machine and the Yokohama Specie Bank played a key role in financing and organizing the strategy.
Because of its wartime role, the bank was ordered to reorganize by the American occupation forces. What emerged was the Bank of Tokyo. It became privately owned, but was granted exclusive status as the foreign-exchange bank and helped finance Japan's burgeoning foreign trade. The bank became an innovator. It led a number of important large syndicated loans and put together the first Euroyen bond offering.
Despite all the regulatory changes and increased competition from larger Japanese rivals, the bank retains a special relationship with the Government. Its modern new headquarters in central Tokyo sits prominently beside the Bank of Japan. And the bank still acts as the Government's agent and financial adviser in distributing foreign aid to developing countries.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Who's to Settle Cross-Border Spats?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Congress and the securities industry may not yet be prepared to do much about the arbitration process that Wall Street administers to settle disputes between investors and their brokers. But they certainly seem willing to study it.
On Jan. 31, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, and Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of that committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance, asked the General Accounting Office to initiate a broad study of the investor arbitration process.
Late last month, five members of the Senate Commitee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, including the chairman, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, chimed in with a list of their own questions for the G.A.O about the process. 
Last week, Representatives Dingell and Markey sent a letter to Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, saying that the Senators' request could undermine the ''objective nature'' of the G.A.O. study. To buttress their argument, they noted that the Securities Industry Association, the brokerage industry's trade organization, was trying to raise funds to commission a Rand Corporation study of the arbitration process.
But while applauding all this studiousness, a few important figures on the arbitration scene suggest that a critical issue is being neglected in all these surveys: As the securities markets become increasingly international, where will cross-border disputes between investors and brokers be settled? By whom? And at what cost?
The securities association's own research shows that there has been a remarkable rise in the volume of cross-border investments in recent years. The pace of foreign equity purchases in the United States has increased at a fairly steady clip since the early 80's. In 1989, net purchases of foreign equities by American investors exploded to $13.7 billion, from just $1.5 billion in 1988.
No doubt a substantial percentage of those investments has been made through brokers in the investors' home countries. But it would be naive to assume that this dramatic increase in cross-border business will not generate any of the rancorous disputes that crop up between investors and their brokers in the domestic market.
Robert Coulson, the executive director of the American Arbitration Association in New York, which competes with the securities industry's arbitration process, endorses the various plans to study his rival but wishes the focus would be expanded to include cross-border disputes. ''Americans are really still very parochial,'' he said. ''The securities markets are becoming increasingly global, and this could be one of the most creative things these studies could come up with.''
Mr. Coulson points out that the legal framework for international arbitration is already quite sound. It rests on a cumbersome-sounding international pact known as the New York Convention on the Enforceability of Arbitral Awards, adopted in 1958 by almost every country with commercial relations with the United States.
For example, the 1958 pact provides that the parties to the dispute should have the right to select their own forum.
''It is obviously totally unfair to make foreign investors come to the United States to arbitrate,'' Mr. Coulson said. ''We wouldn't stand for it if we were required to go abroad.'' In fact, Mr. Coulson's association has already handled several cases involving foreign investors and American firms.
Deciding where these cases will be heard is not as simple as just flipping a coin. For starters, the arbitration association must consider which country's laws apply, where the witnesses live, what language the dispute will be conducted in and where the case was originally filed. The nationality of the chosen arbitrators is another ticklish issue. ''Very often,'' Mr. Coulson said, ''the people involved want arbitrators of a different nationality than either of the parties, out of some fear of partisanship, I guess.''
Such subtleties have not yet invaded the arbitration policy at the National Association of Securities Dealers, the self-regulatory organization (S.R.O.) that handles the largest share of domestic arbitration cases.
Eno Hobbing, a spokesman for the N.A.S.D., said that he knew of ''maybe a dozen cases where foreigners proceeded against a United States firm'' by seeking a hearing before an N.A.S.D. panel. ''Those hearings were held here, but the investors were fairly substantial people and had no problem getting on a plane and coming here,'' Mr. Hobbing said. ''If these cases started coming in spades, it would raise some issues of how to cope. But we're a long way from that.''
Maybe not. With the sharp increase in cross-border investment, that day may come sooner than S.R.O.'s like the N.A.S.D. and the exchanges think.
Constantine N. Katsoris, a professor at the Fordham University law school and a specialist in securities arbitration, warned in a recent article in the Fordham Urban Law Journal that providing for foreign arbitration sites will simply exacerbate the already intense financial pressures on the current arbitration system.
''Indeed, the aggregate arbitration expenses at competing S.R.O. forums are escalating, with no apparent end in sight,'' noted Professor Katsoris, who calls for a single, independent arbitration forum for securities disputes. ''The demands for securities arbitration will escalate beyond the abilities of various S.R.O. forums to fund them adequately.''
And an inadequately funded arbitration process, the professor warned, has little chance of offering ''a level playing field'' to either investors or brokers.

HEADLINE: Currency;
The Swiss Franc Moves Up

 BODY:
This was the week of the Swiss franc as it moved higher against the dollar, the West German mark and the yen. A week ago, it took 1.4900 francs to buy a dollar. By last Friday, it took only 1.4530. The franc has been helped by the country's relatively high interest rates and by comments at week's end by the head of Switzerland's central bank supporting a strong currency and a sustained fight against inflation. In the foreign exchange market, that means interest rates will be pushed higher if necessary. Meanwhile, the pound ran into some trouble in the middle of the week as the British trade deficit jumped in March to 2.18 billion, from 1.39 billion in February. The yen stayed below 160 to the dollar for another week, a success of sorts for the beleaguered Japanese currency.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Latin America Develops a Longing For Aid and Investment From Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
TO impress Japanese investors, Brazil's President-elect performed karate kicks before photographers while in Tokyo in January. To master the Japanese language, the children of Mexico's President attend a bilingual school in Mexico City. And to win votes, the front-runner in Peru's presidential campaign has declared that his Japanese ancestry will help his nation attract $3 billion in aid and investment from Japan.
Japan fever is running high in Latin America, a region traditionally under the sway of the United States. If present economic trends continue, Japan will emerge in the 1990's as the region's second-largest foreign investor, creditor and trading partner. 
Newspapers speculate excitedly about fantastic Japanese-financed deals: building a road to link Colombia's Pacific and Atlantic coasts; building a road from Peru to open Brazil's western Amazon for logging operations, and trading gold-mining rights in the Amazon to erase Brazil's $110 billion foreign debt, the largest in the third world.
''It seems like the Japanese are dominating the world - all radios and watches come from there now,'' Ruben Ricapa Guerreros, a Lima slum dweller, said when asked why he voted this month for Alberto Fujimori, the Peruvian candidate.
But for Latin America, the courtship of Japan could prove to be a case of unrequited love.
Using the calculus of low political risk and high economic benefit, Japanese businesses have targeted only two nations in the region, Mexico and Chile, for more investment in manufacturing and mining, the kinds of industries that create significant wealth for the host country and thereby help repay foreign debt.
''The uncertain political climate, both regionally and in individual countries, deters investments,'' Gretchen Green, an international consultant, wrote this month in a report prepared for the Japan Economic Institute, a Japanese Government organization.
On paper, Latin America compares favorably with Asia and Europe in attracting Japanese investment. From 1984 through March 1989, Japan invested $32 billion in Asia, $30 billion in Europe and $32 billion in Latin America, the Caribbean and Bermuda. (By comparison, the Japanese invested $72 billion in the United States.) But Latin America attracts mainly ''paper investments'' - ship registries in Panama and investments in tax havens like the Bahamas, Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and the Netherlands Antilles. Only 17 percent of Japanese investment in Latin America is in manufacturing.
Chile, with a free-market economy and political stability, was the only Latin American economy to join the Pacific boom in the late 1980's. In the last half of the decade, Chile quadrupled its trade with Japan, to $1.8 billion in 1989. Japanese investment in 1988 was $123 million - 10 times the total for the previous 10 years combined.
Japanese interest is also high in Mexico. Japanese investment is expected to nearly double this year, with $1.5 billion worth of new projects planned. Most of the investment is in border assembly plants that import components free of duty, assemble them with cheap Mexican labor and export the finished products to the United States, which charges low duties. Beyond sending his children to the Liceo Mexicano-Japones, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has a political incentive to court the Japanese -Mexico's eternal search for a counterbalance to the overwhelming influence of the United States.
Recognizing Mr. Salinas's efforts to open his economy to foreign investment, Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, visited Mexico last September. In recent months, the Japanese have allocated to Mexico 20 percent of a $10 billion third world debt-relief fund. They have extended a $1 billion low-interest loan to reduce pollution in Mexico City, and a $500 million line of credit to help Mexico develop its Pacific Coast oil resources.
 
Brazil's new President, Fernando
Collor de Mello, seeks to match Mexico's bid for Japanese investment.
Since taking office last month, he has introduced a radical anti-inflationary program that has led to a recession.
Japanese business executives apparently believe it is prudent to wait and see what happens, given Brazil's long history of failed wars on inflation.
''Japanese investment in Brazil was practically stagnant during the 1980's,'' said Toshiro Kobayashi, chairman of the Brazilian subsidiary of the Bank of Tokyo. ''This tendency is not going to change quickly.''
In the 1970's, a big draw for Japanese companies was the 1.2 million Brazilians of Japanese descent, the largest such community in Latin America. With high education levels, the Japanese-Brazilians have formed a support pool of executives, secretaries and translators for 360 Japanese companies.
But hard times are taking a toll on this community, centered in Sao Paulo. Many Japanese-Brazilians are leaving for Japan to seek high-paying menial jobs now spurned by the Japanese. The descendants of Japanese immigrants are also leaving Argentina and Peru for Japan.
Peru, with Latin America's second-largest Japanese immigrant community, illustrates the rule that Japanese capital follows opportunities, not sentiment.
For many Japanese business executives, the prospect of a Fujimori presidency and the presence of a Japanese enclave in Lima are outweighed by Peru's failure to pay for an $800 million oil pipeline built by Japan in the 1970's and by the terrorist slaying of the Bank of Tokyo's representative in Peru this year.
To dampen expectations that a Fujimori victory in the coming election would unleash an avalanche of aid and investment, Masaki Seo, Japan's Ambassador to Peru, said this month, ''Japanese aid is to countries, not individuals.''
