HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
High-Tech Business Loses A Friend at the Pentagon

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
AS reports circulated late last year that the Bush Administration was planning to cut back support for high-technology programs, Andrew S. Grove, president of the Intel Corporation, the Silicon Valley computer chip maker, sent a violin to Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director. ''If what I hear is true,'' Dr. Grove wrote in a terse note, ''you'll need this to fiddle with as the high-tech industry burns.''
The gesture points to a rising frustration among many electronics industry executives with the Administration's opposition to programs the executives say are needed to help American industry compete with Japan. That frustration turned to outrage a week and a half ago when Craig I. Fields was abruptly removed as director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, a division of the Pentagon that is charged with sponsoring university and corporate research that could be of importance to the military. Dr. Fields has been an advocate of programs to help industry with high-definition television, high-speed semiconductors and other research - a position out of line with the free-market philosophy of some powerful White House officials. 
Some executives say that the Administration is becoming so out of touch with the needs of American industry that the Republican Party is at risk of losing the support of business leaders. ''Electronics is heavily Republican,'' said J. Richard Iverson, president of the American Electronics Association, an industry trade group. ''Now we're confused. I think the Democrats have a great chance of picking up some followers.''
Several Democrats, including the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee and Representative Mel Levine of California, have condemned the removal of Dr. Fields and have proposed bills in which Government would support high-technology industry. A group of Democratic legislators is trying to tie the separate bills into a competitiveness package. Not everyone thinks the Republicans are in danger. Representative Tom Campbell, a Republican whose district covers much of Silicon Valley, said he does not see a loss of support for his party. The Democrats, he said, ''burned many, many bridges'' with industry by fighting a reduction in the capital gains tax last year. Still, Mr. Campbell said he has been urging the Administration to come up with its own high-technology policy to try to blunt the criticism.
Ten years ago, leaders of the electronics industry generally viewed themselves as can-do entrepreneurs who wanted nothing more from Government than to be left alone. While some still feel that way, a decade of battering by competition from Japan has caused many to question the idea that the industry should go it alone. ''I think that is an idealistic view that the late 20th century can't afford,'' said Charles E. Sporck, president of the National Semiconductor Corporation.
Mr. Sporck and many other executives have come to believe that they cannot compete effectively without Government help in such areas as opening up Japan to American exports and, in some cases, providing subsidies to overcome the inability of American companies to raise capital as easily as Japanese companies can.
The Reagan Administration seemed to go along with some of these ideas, such as Sematech, a semiconductor industry consortium that is financed half by industry and half by Government. But the Bush Administration, led by Mr. Darman, John Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Michael A. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has been much more ideologically opposed to such programs. While it supports programs to help industry in general, the White House has fought any plan that smacked of favoritism to a particular industry, arguing that it is not the Government's role to make decisions that should be made by the marketplace.
 
A Civilian Alternative?
The Administration has come close to killing Government efforts to help the United States develop high-definition television systems. It turned a deaf ear to recommendations from the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors to set up a corporation to provide low-cost capital to American electronics companies. With Dr. Fields's departure from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, there is a fear that many programs financed by the agency might also be slashed, such as research in high-speed computer chips, advanced computers and possibly even Sematech. Dr. Fields generally supported and even championed such programs, arguing that if the Pentagon was to get the technology it required at an affordable cost, it would need a healthy American electronics industry that could make high-volume consumer products as well as specialized military ones.
Some officials in Congress and industry say it was never ideal that the Pentagon be involved in helping industry. The transfer of Dr. Fields is likely to renew efforts in Congress to create a civilian version of his agency to handle such tasks. But for now, many say, it appears that ideology has triumphed over technology.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
New York Subways Run Into Another Round of Trouble

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
FRUSTRATED by rising crime, long lines at token booths, vandalized turnstiles and the presence of homeless people and beggars on trains, many New Yorkers are abandoning the subway.
In a recent report by the New York City Transit Authority, weekday subway ridership in February declined, by 2.8 percent to 3.6 million passengers, from 3.7 million in the same month last year. After several years of steady increases in ridership during the late 1980's, it was the third consecutive and significant monthly decline from year-earlier levels.
''I think most people feel that no one is in control of the subways anymore, and they avoid going down there except when they have to,'' said Beverly Dolinsky, executive director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee, a consumer group that advises the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency. 
''The system is filled with smelly homeless people, hustlers and fare beaters,'' Ms. Dolinsky said. ''It's gotten so bad that nice middle-class people are just walking through the gate without paying.''
Transit officials attribute the drop in paid fares to a weakening of the economy in the metropolitan area, layoffs in the financial-services industry and a sudden rise in the number of people who are riding without paying.
In February, about 5.2 percent of the riders did not pay, compared with 4.2 percent in the same month of 1989, according to Transit Authority estimates. ''The simple truth is that if people don't have jobs, they are not going to ride,'' said Jared Lebow, a spokesman for the authority. ''A lot of people are still taking the system. It's just that they aren't paying, and that shows up as a drop in ridership.''
The agency bases its ridership tallies on the number of tokens deposited in turnstiles as well that of students, elderly or handicapped riders, who may use passes or coupons. Its count misses those riders who pass through the turnstiles or gates without paying, and it does not take into account people who transfer to other trains within the 27-line system.
Transit officials acknowledged that the increase in subway and bus fares from $1 to $1.15 on Jan. 1 has caused long lines at token booths. Although some of the wait is a result of riders whose hoards of the cheaper token have dwindled, most of it can be laid to clerks who need extra time to make change. Some riders have waited as long as 10 minutes to buy tokens during rush hour, and many become so exasperated they walk or take a taxi - or walk through the gates.
The increased level of subway crime is also prompting people to stay above ground. In February, the number of felonies like assaults, grand larcenies and necklace snatchings rose to 1,362 from 1,088. Last year a record 16,906 felonious crimes were committed in the subways, an 18 percent increase from 1989.
''The reasons for the drop in ridership go far deeper than an economic downturn and a fare increase,'' said Joseph Rappaport, a spokesman for the Straphangers Campaign, a consumer-advocacy group. ''Our riders want reliable service that gets them to their destination on time, and they want to feel safe using it. Right now they are not getting that.''
Alan F. Kiepper, who took over as president of the Transit Authority in February, has said that improving the general quality of life on the subways is a top priority. Last month, Mr. Kiepper hired a new transit police chief from Boston, William Bratton, who promises a crackdown on crime. Mr. Kiepper is also formulating plans to overhaul stations and to deal with the homeless problem.
One solution to fare beaters, transit officials say, is automated fare collection, an electronic system that allows passengers to pass through turnstiles using a prepaid fare card; such a system is in use in the Washington subway. But the electronic turnstiles, which cost $675 million, are not expected to go into operation until late in the decade.
Robert R. Kiley, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's chairman, once said that ridership is the measure of the agency's success or failure. Consumer advocates say that one way for the authority to increase ridership is to convince the public that it is in control of the subway system and that the service is worth $1.15.
Mr. Kiepper's predecessor, David L. Gunn, won praise for overhauling the mechanics of the city's subway system - the tracks, switches and signals - and for ridding cars of graffiti. As a result, ridership increased. Passengers responded positively to boarding cars that were clean, air-conditioned and on time.
Today, riders want the Transit Authority to go a step further, consumer advocates say. They want clean, well-lit stations, shorter lines at token booths, greater security, better information on service delays and incentives like discounts and weekend passes. But continuing the overhaul of the subway system and enhancing service will cost money at a time when the state and city, struggling with budget difficulties, are looking for ways to cut programs, not expand them.
''A lot will depend on the city's economy, but I don't think ridership will improve very much in the short term,'' Mr. Lebow said. ''We will try a number of programs to make the system more pleasant and attractive. Hopefully some of them will work.''

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Despite the Deficit, at Least One Tax Looks Untouchable

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
OVER the last two decades, New Yorkers have seen their taxes rise on just about everything. But not on gasoline. When this year's state budget is finally adopted, taxes on dozens of goods and services will likely rise once again. But not on gasoline. In politics, it seems, some things are indeed sacred.
The constancy of New York's gasoline excise tax, which has remained at eight cents a gallon since 1972, stands in stark contrast to the upward trend in other states. Overall, New York State has one of the highest personal and corporate income tax rates in the nation. Yet its gasoline tax is now the third lowest in the country. Only Georgia and Florida have a lower excise tax on gasoline, although those two states and New York, unlike most others, also impose a sales tax on gasoline. As a proportion of personal income, New York's gasoline tax burden ranks absolute last. And over the last decade, New York, according to the Highway Users Federation in Washington, is one of only three states that has not raised its gasoline tax. In some states the tax has doubled or even tripled since 1980. 
In many ways, the steadiness of New York's gasoline tax defies logic. Profoundly indebted, the state could certainly use the income that higher gasoline taxes would provide. Each penny's increase in the tax is worth about $60 million. New York's smoggy air, many environmentalists argue, would also profit from higher fuel prices, which could discourage needless driving. And since in real terms the cost of motor fuel has actually fallen by almost 50 percent over the last decade, it would seem to make sense to raise the tax at a time when the state is desperately looking for new revenues.
''New York certainly should raise its gas tax,'' said Philip Verleger Jr., a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group. ''But there is nothing more visible than gas taxes.''
Last month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo made a passing attempt to raise the gasoline tax to help the state fill its budget gap. But the effort seemed tentative at best. Mr. Cuomo floated the idea one day at a late afternoon news conference, refusing even to say how much he thought the tax should be raised. Within hours of the Governor's news conference, legislative leaders had dismissed the proposal as politically impossible. It has not been mentioned since.
With negotiations on a new state budget still continuing four weeks beyond the legal deadline, officials here in Albany say that the taboo on increasing the gasoline tax is a product of the regional split that dominates politics in New York State. Roughly half of the state's residents - and their elected representatives - live in New York City and depend mainly on mass transit to get around. The other half live in suburban and rural areas and rely mainly on automobiles. To this second group, trying to raise the gasoline tax is tantamount to declaring civil war.
''The central impact of the gasoline tax is on upstate, middle-income people,'' said State Senator Dale Volker, an upstate Republican. ''The issue is very politically charged.''
 
Bearing the Brunt
State consumption figures confirm that it is upstate and suburban residents who bear the brunt of the gasoline tax. New York City motorists consume only 20 percent of the gasoline in the state. Another 20 percent is used in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Westchester and Rockland Counties consume 10 percent, and the remaining 50 percent is consumed upstate.
Opposition to the gasoline tax has long been centered in the State Senate, where the Republican Party owes its majority to its strong showing in rural and suburban areas. But even in the Democratic-controlled Assembly, where most of the majority party members come from New York City, there is only lukewarm support for increasing the tax. In part this is because many of the most politically vulnerable Assembly Democrats come from areas like Rochester and Long Island, where higher gasoline taxes are unpopular. In addition, Assembly members say, gasoline taxes, like all sales taxes, are regressive because they are not based on the ability to pay and affect the poor proportionally more than the rich.
Many state legislators say that the only way to make higher gasoline taxes politically palatable in New York would be to earmark the proceeds for highway projects instead of putting the revenues into the state's general treasury.
''There's a simple consensus that if you're going to do gas taxes, you've got to dedicate them to a highway fund,'' said the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat. This is something that more than half the states in the country already do and something New York State appears likely to do in a year or two, legislators say, when money from the state's most recent transportation bond issue runs out.
Environmentalists are disturbed by such a plan. They contend that gasoline tax revenues should not be used to expand highways and encourage more driving, but to discourage the use of automobiles and subsidize mass transit. To many environmentalists, the nearly two decades that have passed since New York last raised its gasoline tax have been a wasted opportunity.
''The gasoline tax offers a chance not only to potentially reduce pollution, but to provide a permanent source of funding for mass transit,'' said Eric A. Goldstein, an attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Manhattan. ''New York has been too slow in raising it.''
The relationship between gasoline prices and gasoline consumption and, by extension, pollution is one that has been studied extensively, with mixed results. The short-term effects of higher prices, according to Mr. Verleger of the Institute for International Economics, are small. But longer term, as people switch to more fuel-efficient automobiles, the effects in reducing consumption are more dramatic.
''From a conservation point of view, it makes sense,'' Mr. Verleger said. ''But the public does not like gas taxes, and politicians are not very courageous.''

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Monet's 90's, and Ours

 BODY:
For a century now, those who love beauty have reveled in the lucid landscapes of Claude Monet. But an exhibition of 95 of his works at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston makes the surprising case that Monet was a political artist as well. ''Monet in the 90's,'' which closes today, reopens May 19 at the Art Institute of Chicago. It sends a timely message to America's heartland.
Monet's 90's - the 1890's - were as dizzying as our own. In the decades following a painful loss in the Franco-Prussian war, France was beset by fierce economic competition, an alarming rise in consumption of drugs and alcohol, poisonous bigotry and a banking crisis. Yet each day brought technological advances that transformed society. ''Is it decadence or progress?'' asked one bewildered Frenchman. Monet's response was to show his countrymen the true nature of their home.
According to Paul Hayes Tucker, the exhibit's curator, the artist's serial paintings of stacks of grain, poplar trees, water lilies and the solemn face of Rouen Cathedral celebrate the enduring glory of France. The fertile farmlands and Gothic wonders, chased by light and shadow, survive time and weather. Rows upon rows of poplars stand for a proud and liberty-loving populace. Each ''Morning on the Seine'' reflects the depth of France's natural strength, endlessly renewed.
Perhaps only the French fully grasp Monet's meaning; perhaps not. For the basic message of ''Monet in the 90's'' is plain. The artist proved that truth is not the secret knowledge of the rich, the learned or the powerful.
It is there, in living color, for all who open their eyes.

HEADLINE: More, Not Less Aid to Afghan Rebels

BYLINE: By Henry J. Hyde and Charles Wilson; Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, and Charles Wilson, Democrat of Texas, are members of the House Intelligence Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Just a year ago, following the Soviet troop departure, we were counting the days until the mujahedeen took over in Afghanistan. But so far President Najibullah's staying power has proved far stronger than anyone imagined, bolstered by more than $300 million a month in Soviet economic and military assistance.
To salvage our interests, we've got to sustain the pressure on Mr. Najibullah and the Soviets, squeezing them until they realize that U.S. resolve has not slackened one iota. To get this job done, we need to be prepared to continue providing substantial aid to the mujahedeen - though this will be far less than what the Soviets give Kabul. 
Conventional wisdom says Americans are not good at playing a long end game; we prefer ''quickie'' actions like Grenada and Panama. There may be truth to that thesis, but we've also demonstrated staying power. Look at our long-term commitment to NATO and the billions it has cost us. Look at the results in Eastern Europe.
We must do the same in Afghanistan. We've been helping the mujahedeen for 11 years. That's only a fraction of the time (and involves only a fraction of the money) we've spent assisting our friends in Western Europe, Israel and South Korea.
Victory will not be easy, but we offer a recipe. First, stop the bickering in Washington. The jubilation of last year has turned to finger-pointing. Rather than looking inward to find out why we didn't win last year, let's look to the future and rejuvenate the forces that ousted the Soviet Army.
Second, allow the Afghans to choose their own form of government -don't impose one. Tribalism has been the rule in Afghanistan for centuries. We are not going to change that overnight. At our urging, the mujahedeen are laudably trying to form a more representative government. But we are placing more hope in this process than is reasonable.
Third, exploit opportunities exposed by the recent coup attempt against Mr. Najibullah. For instance, the mujahedeen should return to what worked in the past: step-by-step strangulation of Government strongholds. As the resistance draws the noose tighter, key cities will fall and so eventually will the regime. But this takes time.
Finally, up the ante with more support, more political pressure and, yes, more sophisticated weaponry to demonstrate to Mr. Najibullah and the Soviets the futility of hoping that we are short of breath.
Pravda reported on March 20: ''The main paymaster behind the bloody deadlock in Afghanistan - the Congress - has increasingly . . . begun to show signs of dissatisfaction and criticize the White House for its lack of flexibility toward the efforts to achieve settlement.'' Comments by our colleague Stephen Solarz, Democrat of New York, were cited to authenticate this analysis.
Some argue that both sides should stop delivering arms to their clients. This plays into the hands of the Soviets. Despite all predictions, it is unclear who will be the main beneficiary from a cutoff in arms. Moreover, there would be immediate repercussions for the U.S.
Pakistan, a loyal ally through the war, would be left isolated with more than three million Afghan refugees within its borders. Influential moderate states in the Arab world, generally sympathetic to U.S. interests, would see us as an untrustworthy partner that will not stay the course. Our departure would open the door to the Iranians, angering our moderate Arab allies and leading to unknowable consequences.
The Soviets cannot be expected to hand us another victory. They, too, have lost many lives and have squandered more than $70 billion. We must give them a chance to extract themselves from their own mess.
Equally important, the Soviets will be reminded that we do not desert our friends when the going gets tough. That's a reminder that will significantly strengthen our hand in future Soviet-American efforts to resolve other third world conflicts.
In the euphoria over the Soviets' departure, we lost sight of the ultimate goal: ouster of the regime of Mr. Najibullah and his associates.

HEADLINE: Sorry to Get Personal, but. . .

BYLINE: By J. William Fulbright; J. William Fulbright was chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for 15 years.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is a matter of concern that after many ups and downs over the years, educational exchange is once again coming on hard times. Despite rising costs, it appears that the Administration and Congress intend to let stand a flat budget for Fulbright scholarships for the fifth straight year. In doing so, they will ratify a 23 percent decline in the number of participants over this five-year period.
It is a small item in the Federal budget, but a highly significant element of our foreign policy and national interest. 
The year 1945 and the destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki marked a profound break in the thread of human history. Only in the last few years have the dimensions of that break become apparent to the leaders of the military superpowers. Hesitantly and haltingly, they seem to be beginning to recognize how profoundly, criminally and stupidly wasteful it has been to squander the greater part of humanity's creative energies on war and the preparation for war.
Even before the failure of Marxist economics led Mikhail Gorbachev toward a new approach at home and abroad, there began to dawn an awareness of the obsoleteness of war. In Europe and East Asia, people have discovered that wealth is power in the new international system. While the superpowers expended vast sums on vast military establishments, the European Community, Japan and some smaller Asian countries captured world markets, enabling their people to live in growing freedom, prosperity and dignity.
How has this come to pass? For the most part from experience - but experience can be vicarious, too. Sometimes we profit from historic as well as proximate example. That is what education is all about.
The Fulbright exchange program, initiated in 1946, has been a long-term, low-cost investment and it is beginning to yield high dividends. Nearly 50,000 living American alumni, among 60,000 grantees over all, have gained knowledge and perspective on other nations by participating in the Fulbright program.
Some are now contributing to the education of another generation; some are strengthening American competitiveness; and a considerable number are serving with distinction in the executive and legislative branches of our Government.
The rewards are perhaps even greater from the contributions of foreigners who study here, numbering to date about 116,000. Fulbright alumni hold influential positions in countries all over the world, over 30 of which now contribute substantially to the costs of the exchange. The West German Government, for example, now pays almost 80 percent of the costs of its exchange.
Three members of Poland's Solidarity-led Government are Fulbright alumni; so are the majority of the South Korean Cabinet. Many of the Chinese students who demonstrated last year in Tiananmen Square were returnees from study in the U.S. It is a fair guess that among the many thousands of Chinese who have been and are still studying in America are some who will govern China when the frightened old men who now rule have passed from the scene.
It doesn't take many to make a difference. A single leader or a few legislators or writers who know something about what other countries are like can contribute to making a wise decision or to forestalling a disastrous one. If Khrushchev had had more than a rudimentary sense of what the United States was like, there might have been no Cuban missile crisis. If President Johnson or his senior advisers had had a deeper understanding of the Chinese and Vietnamese, we might have been spared the Vietnam War.
Conversely, I think it quite likely that President Gorbachev has a more realistic perspective on the United States because of the advice he receives from his friend and senior adviser Aleksandr Yakovlev, who studied American history and wrote on the New Deal as a Fulbright scholar at Columbia University in 1958.
There is power here - immediate and potential, the kind of power that counts in the new post-cold-war world. I hope that President Bush and the Congress will give close and careful consideration to restoring and strengthening the Fulbright exchange. I may be prejudiced, but I think it's a terrific investment.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3735 words

HEADLINE: BETWEEN TWO WORLDS

BYLINE: By BILL BRYSON; Bill Bryson, an American writer living in England, is the author of ''The Lost Continent.''

 BODY:
SYDENHAM IS A DISTRICT of London famous for, well, nothing. It is one of those gray, anonymous, slightly tattered neighborhoods where the hairdressing salons have names like World of Hair and most businesses seem to deal in video films, plumbing supplies or fish and chips. About a third of the shops on the street are vacant, their windows soaped and covered with faded posters for pop concerts and wrestling matches. It's the kind of neighborhood where you turn up your collar and pass on.
Around the corner from a gas station lives Kazuo Ishiguro, in a modest semidetached house distinguished from its neighbors by little more than the number plate on its door. It is a somewhat surprising choice of residence for one of Britain's hottest, and lately wealthiest, young novelists.
Even more surprising perhaps is that Ishiguro, who was born in Japan 35 years ago but has lived in England since he was 6 years old, has achieved this blend of fame and wealth with just three books, none of which offers the reader much in the way of violence, sex, greed, jokes or even plot. ''I try to put in as little plot as possible,'' he says with an engaging grin. 
What the reader gets instead is a quiet, spare narrative, often full of melancholy and irony, disarmingly unflashy in its presentation and yet clearly constructed with immense care. Ishiguro is happy to devote six years to a novel, and he anguished for weeks over just one line in his latest book, ''The Remains of the Day,'' which was published to general acclaim in America last fall.
''Brilliant and quietly devastating,'' Newsweek called it. Lawrence Graver, writing in The New York Times Book Review, used words like ''dazzling,'' ''masterly'' and ''strikingly original.'' At least two reviewers likened Ishiguro to Henry James.
In Britain the book has hovered around the summit of the best-seller lists more or less continuously since its publication last May. In the United States, where Ishiguro was largely unknown, it has already clocked up sales of about 50,000. In October, it won the Booker Prize, Britain's top literary award; he had already won, for earlier books, the Whitbread Book of the Year and Winifred Holtby prizes. Film rights to ''The Remains of the Day'' have been bought by Harold Pinter, and there is talk of a movie to be directed by Mike Nichols.
''He has clearly become one of the best young writers in Britain today,'' says the critic and novelist Malcolm Bradbury, who taught Ishiguro when he was a creative writing student at the University of East Anglia. ''Thanks to him and six or seven other very good young writers - Salman Rushdie, Timothy Mo, Julian Barnes, Martin Amis and Jeanette Winterson, for instance - the novel has become exciting again in Britain in the 1980's, rather in the way it was in the 50's when writers like Iris Murdoch were rising to prominence.''
Ishiguro is naturally pleased to be a well-paid part of this literary resurgence, but scarcely overwhelmed by it. He and his wife, Lorna, a social worker, would like to move closer to the fashionable West End of London, not out of any particular desire to be in the thick of things but rather to be nearer to her job. His unostentatious life style - a Roland piano, bought with some of the Whitbread prize money, and three acoustic guitars are the only outward signs of self-indulgence in his living room - reflects the suddenness of his success, but it's largely a matter of choice. ''I've never had any ambition to have a Porsche or anything,'' he says. ''Frankly, I don't understand the idea of having a car that costs 12 times more than another car. If you feel you have to spend that kind of money, why not buy 12 cars?'' Instead he is content to spend the money on more modest ambitions, ''like phasing British Rail out of my life,'' and on buying himself time to do a proper job on the next book.
In conversation, Ishiguro is relaxed, genial, composed. He speaks in measured tones, his outsized glasses and custom of dressing entirely in black lending him a solemn air, which is frequently and rather startlingly dispersed by a flash of boyish grin. Though it is never explicit in his novels, humor of an ironic and self-deprecating kind is seldom far away from anything he says. It appears to be impossible to find anyone who knows him who does not like him a lot.
''He's just a very, very nice guy,'' a close friend, Robin Robertson of the British publisher Secker & Warburg, told me. ''On the day of the Booker Prize, just to give you an example, he arranged to meet John Banville'' - the Irish novelist who was considered with Ishiguro to be the joint favorite to win the award - ''for tea at the Ritz beforehand, because they had never met before and he thought it would be more pleasant for both of them if they arrived at the award ceremony as friends. That sort of thoughtfulness is very typical of him.''
Ishiguro's novels - ''A Pale View of Hills,'' ''An Artist of the Floating World'' and ''The Remains of the Day'' - are preoccupied with certain recurring themes: self-deception, devalued ideals, unuttered sentiments, the high cost of misplaced loyalty. Each takes place largely in the past - the first two in Japan just after the war, the third in England in 1956 at the time of the Suez crisis - yet each moves freely and often skillfully across time.
In all three, fragments of crucial information are exposed gradually, piece by piece, often seemingly in passing, so that the reader collects clues and arrives at the truth rather as in a murder mystery. Often the most basic information is only vaguely alluded to or withheld altogether. ''A Pale View of Hills'' is set in Nagasaki just after the war, yet not once is the atomic bomb mentioned. In ''An Artist of the Floating World,'' the setting appears to be Tokyo, but we are never told. In ''The Remains of the Day'' we never learn the narrator's first name. In each of the books, the truth is revealed to us through the words of narrators who themselves largely fail to see it.
A striking characteristic of Ishiguro's books is how remote they are from his own experiences of time, place and even - in the case of ''A Pale View of Hills,'' which is narrated by a woman - sex. Two of his novels were set in a Japan that Ishiguro had not seen for almost 30 years - he made his first trip back to the country last fall - while ''The Remains of the Day'' is narrated by a butler, about whose profession Ishiguro happily professes large-scale ignorance.
''I've always found it easier to be intimate and revealing with central characters who are not like me,'' he says. ''Partly it's to do with not being of an exhibitionist kind of nature, but also I think it serves me as a form of artistic discipline.''
''When you're dealing with someone not like yourself, you have to think much harder about why that person behaves in certain ways, why certain things have happened to him or her. I think one of the dangers of having a kind of alter ego in fiction is that you drag in all kinds of things that are irrelevant in an artistic sense simply because they are things that you are concerned with as a person yourself.''
Having lived most of his life in England, Ishiguro claims that his ''Japaneseness'' is not something that he is particularly conscious of. ''It's a thing I think about only when people ask me. I never asked myself about it when I was growing up. I'm reluctant even now to try to quantify how much of me is Japanese and how much British.'' Ishiguro was born in Nagasaki in 1954, but came to England in 1960 with his parents and two sisters. His father was an oceanographer working in an area that was of peripheral interest in Japan but of some moment to the British Government, which was then on the brink of developing oil fields in the North Sea. The family settled outside London in Guildford, the county town of Surrey and quintessence of the Home Counties - ''the sort of place,'' as Ishiguro puts it, ''where an Agatha Christie mystery could have been set.''
''I didn't think of myself as particularly different from my friends,'' he recalls. ''I can't remember any instances of racism. Basically I had a happy and very typical middle-class southern English upbringing.''
For most of his childhood it was assumed that the family would eventually return to Japan. ''It was always going to be next year or, at the most, in two years' time. It wasn't until I was 15 that my parents finally said, 'Well, we're not going to go back,' '' Ishiguro remembers. ''They just liked it here, I think. There's a surprising amount of similarity between Japanese culture and the sort of culture you find in places like Guildford. But there was also a measure of freedom that I think they - and particularly my father - found appealing. When Japanese people move to another country, one of two things will usually happen. Some of them just flounder and find they can't cope at all where there isn't a clearly defined rigid code of behavior. But others find it liberating, and my father is clearly of the latter sort. I think he realized that the idea of having to go back to all those social obligations, having to drink with your pals every night, just wasn't his scene.''
In the meantime, Ishiguro's parents had continued the Japanese side of his education. Every month for years a parcel of books would arrive from Japan and he would have to plow through them. As a result he grew up intimately acquainted with a Japan that existed almost entirely in his head, a compound of childhood memories, text(Continued on Page 44) book facts and imagination. This is the Japan that appeared in his first two novels.
''I recognize that I have a Japanese dimension to me and that derives from my having been brought up by Japanese parents in a Japanese-speaking home,'' Ishiguro says. ''I think I've always learned to use that in my favor. I'm certainly aware that at least part of the reason for my success has to do with the unusual nature of my profile. When I published my first novel, in 1982, that was exactly the time when people in the literary world were looking for a different kind of young writer. Salman Rushdie had just broken through as the Booker Prize winner. People had started to read writers like Kundera and Marquez. Everyone was hungry for young writers who had an international flavor about their writing - and, if possible, about their person.
''There's no doubt I got far more coverage and a more favorable reception than if I had been just a white English guy. So while I've not consciously exploited my background, I think it's always been an instinct.'' On the other hand, it has sometimes been an encumbrance. It disturbs Ishiguro that people regard him as an expert on a country that he barely knows. The tendency to regard his first two books as literal representations of life in Japan is particularly exasperating. ''I sometimes feel that if I had written a book like Kafka's 'Trial,' people would say to me, 'What a strange judicial system the Japanese have.'
''I get a lot of very strange requests. One of the British television networks rang me up during rumors of a U.S.-Japanese trade war and asked me if I would go on a program to discuss things from the Japanese side. Quite apart from the consideration that I'm not an economist, you're talking about a country that I hadn't been to at that point for 29 years, since I was a 6-year-old child. It's crazy.''
A rueful grin gives way to a sudden burst of earnestness. ''I'm very aware that I know very little about Japan, particularly modern-day Japan, and I found it disturbing that many of the reviews of my first two books were saying things like, 'Read this book if you want to understand how Japanese people think.' That was worrying to me because I didn't have that kind of authority.''
Although his parents returned on periodic visits, Ishiguro himself did not go back until last fall when the Japan Foundation paid for him and his wife to make a visit. It was nothing like the Japan he remembered from his childhood. ''Apart from the fact that both places are called Japan I might as well have been to different countries.'' Even the language was different from the familiar form he had used at home. ''It was odd because I found that I could sometimes carry on fairly elaborate conversations with an academic or somebody but would be completely flummoxed trying to order a snack in a restaurant.''
Why did it take him so long to go back? ''When I was 19 or 20 and got a chance to travel, I wanted to go to places like California and Amsterdam - the sort of places my friends were all going. It didn't seem an unnatural thing not to go to Japan since no one I knew was going there then.''
Instead, Ishiguro devoted himself to odd jobs, peripatetic traveling and a brief but resoundingly unsuccessful attempt to become a singer-songwriter. Before and after studying philosophy and literature at the University of Kent he hitchhiked around the United States and Canada and worked at a variety of jobs - as a grouse beater on the Queen Mother's estate, as a community worker helping homeless people in Glasgow and London. It wasn't until 1979 that he decided, suddenly and at the somewhat advanced age of 25, to try writing. He applied for and was accepted at the now-celebrated but then little-known creative writing course at the University of East Anglia run by Malcolm Bradbury.
''I suddenly panicked,'' Ishiguro recalls, ''because I'd never really written anything before and was afraid I would be exposed as a fraud.'' He spent the summer before the first term locked away in a farmhouse in Cornwall and wrote four short stories. Bill Buford, editor of the literary magazine Granta, remembers receiving one of them: ''It was remarkably accomplished. You could tell right away that he was a writer of considerable potential.''
Faber & Faber, the London publisher, bought three of the stories while Ishiguro was still a student and published them in a volume of stories by promising young writers called ''Introductions N7.'' It also offered him a small advance for his first novel, ''A Pale View of Hills,'' which he began writing at East Anglia in 1980. Published in 1982, it is the story of a widowed, middle-aged Japanese woman living in England whose daughter from a previous marriage in Japan has committed suicide. As with his two later books, the action drifts across time - from an unhappy visit by the woman's surviving, English-born daughter in the present to a more lengthy recollection of a summer just after the war when the narrator, Etsuko, was a young housewife in Nagasaki.
The book was widely praised in Britain and translated into 13 languages, but it sank without a trace in America. So, too, did Ishiguro's second book, ''An Artist of the Floating World,'' which sold fewer than 2,000 copies. It is the story of Masuji Ono, a retired artist who unwittingly reveals in his rambling, self-absorbed ruminations that he is neither so accomplished in his work nor so admirable in his character as he himself clearly believes.
Though ''An Artist of the Floating World'' failed to attract much notice in this country, it enjoyed outstanding success elsewhere. Foreign rights were sold in 14 countries and it was a paperback best seller in Britain, achieving for Ishiguro a measure of financial independence that allowed him to give up his job working at a hostel for London's homeless and write full time.
Writing does not come easily to him. ''Every time I've got another novel to write I just can't believe that I ever managed to write one before,'' he says. ''I do desperate things. I make notes. I spend a lot of time thinking. I'd do almost anything to get it going.'' Typically, he spends a year writing the words but two years planning what he's going to say. ''I'm not the kind of writer who can put a sheet of paper into the typewriter and improvise. I have to know more or less the whole structure of the book beforehand.''
Though he has been widely praised for the assuredness of his prose style, Ishiguro is curiously dismissive of his handling of language, insisting that he has little natural talent for expressing himself and that any felicities of rhythm and tone surface at a late stage in the writing process. ''I don't actually pay a great deal of attention to the prose in my books,'' he says. ''That's something I do right at the end when I go through it all and tidy everything up - actually, I don't just tidy it up because my prose is really terrible until I go through this fairly thorough editing process. By any standards it's terrible.''
Ishiguro's restrained approach may seldom dazzle, but he has a true gift for making the mundane compelling. It is difficult indeed to pick up one of his books and not find oneself being buoyed along, gently but helplessly, by the words. Consider the opening lines from ''An Artist of the Floating World'': ''If on a sunny day you climb the steep path leading up from the little wooden bridge still referred to around here as 'the Bridge of Hesitation,' you will not have to walk far before the roof of my house becomes visible between the tops of two gingko trees. Even if it did not occupy such a commanding position on the hill, the house would still stand out from all others nearby, so that as you come up the path, you may find yourself wondering what sort of wealthy man owns it.''
Or take the first sentence from ''The Remains of the Day'': ''It seems increasingly likely that I really will undertake the expedition that has been preoccupying my imagination now for some days.'' Who could fail to venture on from that deceptively beguiling introduction?
The narrator here is Stevens, a dull, self-important butler who has devoted his life - quite literally, since in his view a good butler is never seen to be off-duty - to the smooth running of Darlington Hall and to the comfort of its eponymous master, the shadowy Lord Darlington. He is an almost comically pathetic character, blindly subservient to his employer, so dedicated to duty that he leaves his father's deathbed to serve cocktails, so out of touch with his own feelings that he cannot recognize love when it flutters into his life, so blinkered that his one recollection of a visit by George Bernard Shaw is of Shaw's being impressed by the shine on a well-polished spoon.
It is a thoroughly convincing portrait, larded with long, oddly absorbing disquisitions on the art of managing a large house, yet Ishiguro has never met a butler and most of Stevens's emphatic opinions on such matters as where to acquire the best silver polish or deal with guests who show up three days early spring entirely from Ishiguro's fertile mind.
Ishiguro chose an English setting as a deliberate reaction to the labeling of him as a Japanese writer living in England. ''Before I knew anything about the book, I knew that it wasn't going to have anything to do with Japan or Japanese people,'' he says. Yet the book reprises many of the earlier themes and underscores the closeness in temperament between the British and Japanese - the suppressed emotions, the unwillingness to be explicit, the almost ritualistic politeness, and, at least where servants are concerned, the high personal and emotional cost of unstinting loyalty to one's employer. It is an immensely accomplished book. As Malcolm Bradbury puts it: ''To get so convincingly into the mind, the language, the habits and feelings of someone from a different period and completely different background is an enormous achievement.''
Ishiguro isn't at all certain that Britain is the most desirable locale for modern fiction. ''The younger generation of writers in this country is much more conscious now of addressing an international audience. They don't make the assumption that perhaps some older writers did that Britain is somehow culturally very central to the world, that you can just write about English issues and about English life and it will be automatically of international interest.
''I go to these big international conferences and here are all these writers, a lot of whom have been in prison and really have been in the front line of recent developments. I was in Budapest at a conference and I was very (Continued on Page 80) conscious that the British contingent and to a certain extent the French and Italian and even possibly the Americans looked very much like provincial little communities of writers discussing rather trivial things. For me it's difficult to find a stance that is appropriate given that I live in this quiet, little, safe, democratic, prosperous country at the edge of Europe.''
Although many of Ishiguro's closest friends are writers or work in publishing, he has little to do with the literary life of London. ''You could almost make a career out of just going to publishers' parties here,'' he says. ''And in fact some people more or less do that. But to me it's basically a distraction.'' For much the same reason, he has always declined to write book reviews or undertake journalistic assignments. What he's really interested in is making progress as a novelist.
''What impresses me most about Ishiguro,'' says Granta's Bill Buford, ''is not so much what he has done - though that is impressive enough - as what he is likely to do. Each of his books has been a clear progression from the previous one. I think he's going to just keep getting better and better.''
Ishiguro himself is certainly determined to try. ''I don't know how long it's going to take me to do the next book. It may take three years, it may take six. But I think it's important to produce something that is in some sense a step forward. One of the problems with success is that it becomes harder and harder to do new things, partly because you are under some pressure to come up with another book to capitalize on the commercial success of the previous one, and partly because there's a lot of psychological pressure of your own making. If you've been praised in your books for doing A, B and C well, you are naturally a little scared to write a book without A, B and C in it.'' He pauses and smiles. ''That's the position I'm in now.''
So has he started his next book? ''Uh . . . not really. Well, maybe. I'm not quite sure.'' He smiles again and pushes back a shock of hair. ''Ask me that in a couple of years.''

SECTION: Section 6; Page 75, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2090 words

HEADLINE: FOOD;
POTATO POTENTIAL

BYLINE: BY LINDA WELLS

 BODY:
A SIMPLE BAKED POTATO IS FINE. AND A NICELY TURNED, boiled potato with parsley is perfectly pleasant. But they are to food what sensible shoes are to fashion. More and more, the potato is a medium of culinary inspiration and flights of fancy. Potato slices are masquerading as ravioli and stuffed with pigs' cheeks. They are spread to form sheets of lasagna, curled into cannelloni, shaved and sealed around scallops and slid into terrines of salmon or monkfish. They are pureed and stacked between foie gras and duck confit. Even mashed potatoes are treated with more respect - and more flair - than they get with the standard butter and cream.
''It's supposed to be the honest era, right?'' says Christopher Idone, the owner of Ten Twenty-Two, a restaurant in New York. ''We're all going to be eating this stuff.''
The potato's rise to prominence can be explained by a sagging economy, a reaction against conspicuous consumption and a desire for the familiar. ''People aren't intimidated by potato dishes,'' says Joachim Splichal, the chef and co-owner of Patina in Los Angeles. But maybe it's more basic than all that: quite simply, people like them. And on restaurant menus, potatoes sell. At Aureole in Manhattan, Charles Palmer, the chef and co-owner, has lamb with couscous on the menu. ''People order potatoes on the side,'' he says. ''They want to eat the couscous, but they also want the potatoes just in case.'' 
Splichal turned to potatoes as a reaction against pasta. ''There isn't a restaurant in town that doesn't serve pasta, even if it's a French place,'' he says. ''I didn't want to fall into that trap. So I took pasta dishes and did them with potatoes.'' Sheets of potato are wrapped around salmon and basil, then called cannelloni. Ravioli holds potatoes and oysters; lasagna is made of potatoes layered with wild mushrooms and chives drenched with truffle sauce. On his vegetarian menu, one course, called Idaho Three Ways, consists entirely of potatoes - the lasagna, ravioli stuffed with potatoes and yams, and a flamboyant potato pancake wedged with truffles.
''Some of the potato dishes may seem gimmicky,'' Palmer says. ''But the potato is so versatile; almost anything you put with it will work.'' He stuffs duck confit into small yellow Finnish potatoes. Thin slices, filled with pork, sealed and fried become ravioli. Salmon with potato and pesto form a bright, summery terrine.
Not all potato dishes are new and flashy. At Park Bistro, in Manhattan, ''We create the dishes of our grandmothers,'' says Max Bernard, a part owner. ''Everyone in the Lyon region knows how to make these potatoes. They're not a new thing.'' Some dishes, though, are slightly altered. The meltingly rich potato tart with goat cheese, basil and mesclun salad was conceived by Jean-Michel Diot, the chef. ''In France, there is a dish of potato salad with goat cheese, a gratin,'' he says. ''That's too heavy for a first course, so I added salad and vinaigrette to it.''
Ten Twenty-Two is the kingdom of mashed potatoes. They are whipped with butter, milk and a handful of herbs. They are showered with Roquefort or sheep cheese and served with steak. ''We're painting the lily,'' Idone says. He has been known to tuck a ball of fresh mozzarella inside a mound of mashed potatoes, coat the whole thing with bechamel and bake it. ''You stick a spoon inside and pull out mashed potatoes, bechamel and a long string of this wonderful, fluffy cheese,'' he says. ''It's a little twisted. But if you're going to eat mashed potatoes, you might as well go whole hog.''
All of this may seem to be heavy going for spring and summer. Most chefs will replace the creamed and fried potatoes of winter with boiled potatoes tossed with vinaigrette. Idone indulges in a lusty potato salad made with homemade mayonnaise and dill pickles - but only in the privacy of home. At the restaurant, the potato salad will be tossed with steamed mussels and a Champagne vinaigrette. Mashed potatoes will also disappear from Idone's menu, but not from his personal repertory. ''In the country, there is nothing like spreading mashed potatoes on grilled steak and letting the juices blend into the potato,'' he says.
Potatoes are emotional, basic, elemental. They are, more than any other food, an object to be transformed and elevated, re-created and redesigned. As Charles Palmer says, ''This wouldn't happen with the turnip.''
 
SPRING SALMON, POTATO AND PESTO TERRINE
(From Charles Palmer, Aureole)
4 starchy Maine potatoes, each about fist size
1 1/2 pounds salmon - use center cut fillet - boneless, skinless
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
2 shallots, peeled
2 cups chicken stock
1 tablespoon, plus 1 1/2 cups, olive oil
 3/4 cups pesto
1/3 cup red-wine vinegar
Zest of 1 lemon
Juice of 1 lemon
1 bunch basil, leaves shredded
1 cup mixed greens, such as arugula, mache, purslane, etc.
 1/2 cup walnuts, toasted (see note).
1. Peel the potatoes and place in a large pot. Cover with cold salted water. Cook until the potatoes are tender, or when a knife inserted in the center of the potato slides out easily. Drain and allow to cool only long enough to handle. Slice the potatoes into 1/4-inch-thick slices.
2. Cut the salmon into 3 pieces and season both sides with salt and pepper. Slice 1 shallot and place on the bottom of a shallow pan. Put the salmon on top of the shallot and pour in the chicken stock and 1 tablespoon of the olive oil. There should be enough liquid to cover the fish. Brush a piece of wax paper with oil and place over the fish. Cook over medium heat. When the liquid has come to a boil reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook 8 minutes, or until the fish is slightly pink in the center. Remove the salmon from the liquid and cool. Then break the meat with your fingers into small - about 1 1/2 inches - pieces.
3. Line a terrine mold or bread loaf pan approximately 3 1/2 by 7 by 3 inches with wax paper, cutting the paper to fit the mold precisely.
4. Place an even layer, about 1/4-inch deep, of salmon on the bottom of the mold. Press the salmon evenly into the mold. Using a pastry brush, brush the salmon with pesto.
5. Place a layer of potatoes on top of the salmon-pesto layer. Trim the potatoes to fit the mold precisely. Brush the layer of potatoes with pesto.
6. Repeat the process until there are 3 layers each of salmon and potatoes.
7. Cover the top of the terrine with plastic wrap and weight down with heavy cans that fit within the terrine. Refrigerate overnight.
8. Prepare the vinaigrette by mixing the 1 1/2 cups of olive oil, red-wine vinegar, lemon juice and zest, and salt and pepper to taste. Mince the remaining shallot and mix into the vinaigrette. Just before serving, add the shredded basil and pieces of broken walnuts.
9. Dress the greens, reserving some vinaigrette for saucing the terrine. Divide the greens among eight plates, placing the greens in the center.
10. Cut the terrine into eight slices. Place a piece on the greens and drizzle on the remaining vinaigrette.
Yield: Eight servings.
Note: To toast walnuts, spread the pieces on a cookie sheet. Cook in a preheated, 350-degree oven. About every 5 minutes, toss the pieces to assure even cooking. Cook until slightly darkened and crisp, about 15 minutes.
 
PETATOU DE CHEVRE FRAIS
(Potato tart with goat cheese, from Jean-Michel Diot, Park Bistro)
1 1/2 pounds new potatoes (preferably Yukon Gold)
1 cup heavy cream
1 egg yolk, beaten
1/3 cup balsamic vinegar
1 bunch fresh basil, chopped
1 bunch fresh thyme, chopped
1 bunch fresh tarragon, chopped
1 bunch Italian parsley, chopped
3 shallots, chopped
1 cup extra-virgin olive oil
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
1 10-ounce log goat cheese, cut in 6 even slices, preferably Coach Farm
 1/2 pound mesclun salad greens.
1. Place the potatoes in a pot and cover with cold, salted water. Cook until the potatoes are tender. Drain, peel and slice into 1/2-inch rounds.
2. Whip the cream until it forms soft peaks, then gently fold in the egg yolk. Set aside.
3. In a bowl, whisk together the vinegar with half the herbs and shallots. Slowly whisk in the oil. Set aside.
4. Season the potatoes with salt and pepper to taste. Toss with the remaining herbs, the shallots and all but 2 tablespoons of the vinaigrette. Place the potatoes in the bottom of 6 small metal pastry rings set on a cookie sheet. Place a slice of cheese on top of each, pressing the cheese with a spoon to the edge of the ring. Refrigerate for half an hour.
5. Preheat the oven to 300 degrees.
6. Remove the rings from the potatoes. Place the potato-cheese rounds in the oven for 7 minutes. Spread 1 tablespoon of cream on top of each and glaze briefly under the broiler. With a spatula, carefully transfer to 6 small plates. Garnish with mesclun and drizzle the remaining vinaigrette over all.
Yield: Six appetizer servings.
 
HERBED MASHED POTATOES WITH ROQUEFORT
(From Christopher Idone, Ten Twenty-Two)
4 pounds baking potatoes, peeled and halved
1 cup milk
 1/2 cup heavy cream
7 ounces unsalted butter (2 sticks less 1 tablespoon)
2 to 3 gratings fresh nutmeg
 1/4 cup mixed fresh herbs (use any combination of parsley, chives, thyme, rosemary or tarragon)
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/4 pound Roquefort, crumbled into small pieces (see note).
1. Place the potatoes in lightly salted cold water to cover. Boil until their centers can be pierced easily with a knife, about 12 to 15 minutes. Drain the potatoes.
2. In a medium-sized saucepan, scald the milk and cream. Add the butter and continue cooking until the butter melts.
3. Place a ricer over a large saute pan and push the potatoes through the ricer.
4. Place the pan with the potatoes over medium heat and, stirring with a wooden spoon, gradually pour in the scalded milk. Mix until the potatoes are smooth and creamy.
5. Fold in the herbs and seasonings.
6. Serve on warm places and sprinkle with Roquefort cheese.
Yield: Four to six servings.
Note: Goat or sheep cheese can be substituted for Roquefort. To do so, cut the goat or sheep cheese into 1/4-inch disks. Place two disks over each portion of mashed potatoes.
 
POTATO LASAGNA WITH WILD MUSHROOMS AND HERB SAUCE
From Joachim Splichal, Patina restaurant)
4 large Idaho potatoes of equal size
8 ounces unsalted butter
3 ounces shiitake mushrooms (see note)
3 ounces oyster mushrooms (see note)
3 ounces white mushrooms
3 ounces chanterelles (optional)
1 large shallot,
 1/2 bunch parsley
Half a bunch, or 8 ounces, celery, diced
2 ounces leek, diced
1 ounce shallots, diced
1 ounce onions, diced
1 ounce butter
1 cup dry white wine
1 clove garlic
1 branch fresh thyme
Juice of 1/2 lemon
8 ounces butter
1 ounce diced tomatoes.
1. Preheat the oven to 300 degrees.
2. Peel and cut the potatoes into rectangular shapes, about 3 by 1 1/2 inches.
3. Using a mandoline, a vegetable slicer or a sharp kitchen knife, slice each potato rectangle into 5 slices.
4. Line a cookie sheet with parchment paper and brush the parchment with the melted butter. Spread out the potato slices on a cookie sheet. Butter another piece of parchment paper and place, buttered side down, on the potatoes. Cook in the oven until the potatoes are soft, about 10 to 15 minutes.
5. Chop all the mushrooms. Heat 1 tablespoon of the butter in a saute pan and add the mushrooms. Cook over medium-low heat until they are soft. Add the finely chopped shallots and cook for 2 minutes more, or until the shallots are translucent.
6. In a medium-sized saucepan, melt 2 tablespoons of butter. Add the diced celery, leeks, shallots and onion. Saute for about 5 minutes. Add the wine and, over high heat, reduce the liquid until it almost totally evaporates. Add 1 cup of water, the garlic, thyme and lemon juice and reduce it by a fourth. There should be 6 ounces of liquid. Strain through a sieve, pressing on the vegetables to release the juices. While the liquid is hot, pour it into a blender. Whir the liquid, adding 8 ounces of butter tablespoon by tablespoon. Season the sauce with salt and pepper to taste. Pour the broth back into the pan and stir in the chopped parsley and diced tomatoes.
7. To serve, alternate slices of potato with mushrooms. Spoon the celery sauce over the potatoes and serve.
Yield: Four servings.
Note: If these mushrooms are unavailable, any variety can be substituted.
