PUB-DATE: April 29, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 22, Column 1; The Good Health Magazine

LENGTH: 3224 words

HEADLINE: Is America Abandoning Sick Patients?

BYLINE: By Susan Gilbert; Susan Gilbert is a freelance journalist and an editor of The Good Health Magazine.

 BODY:
WHEN 79-YEAR-OLD Ernesta Springer entered Doctors Hospital in New York for surgery on her right leg, she was in excruciating pain but she was able to walk. A month later, she was still in great pain. And now she could not get out of bed on her own. But because the treatment was completed for the particular ailments for which she had been admitted - a blocked artery as well as gangrene, both associated with diabetes - the hospital sent her home.
A week later she was back for more surgery on the gangrenous wound. Again she was discharged, still in pain and unable to walk. This time the hospital arranged for a nurse to visit her daily to change the dressing on the wound and monitor her condition. The nurse, Madalyn Benjamin, felt that Ernesta Springer should not have been at home: ''The wound was huge. The pain was huge. She was given no medication except Tylenol. The wound wasn't going to heal.'' Benjamin telephoned the patient's doctors, and she was admitted to the hospital yet a third time for surgery. 
Cases like this one, in which a patient is released from a hospital in unstable condition only to return days or weeks later for further treatment, are becoming more and more common, according to many medical professionals. And there is evidence that such cases are directly related to a cost-cutting measure instituted by the Federal Government known as diagnostic-related groups, or DRG's.
Virtually everyone involved in health care - physicians, hospital administrators, Government officials and insurers - agrees that DRG's have brought about profound change in the practice of medicine in the United States. Instead of allowing hospitals to set their own fees for in-patient care for Medicare recipients, the DRG system sets them. In doing so, it has given hospitals a powerful incentive to look for ways to save money, whether this means ordering fewer diagnostic tests or denying patients certain treatments. But the crucial question is this: has the incentive to save money led to more efficient medical care, or has it caused a general decline in the quality of medicine?
Today this question primarily involves care for the elderly, but it is becoming increasingly relevant to the medical treatment everyone receives. DRG's initially applied only to Medicare patients, most of whom are over the age of 65. But several states have adopted DRG's for administering Medicaid, the joint Federal and state health care program for poor people. And such private health insurance companies as The Travelers and Aetna Life & Casualty have recently begun using a reimbursement system similar to DRG's.
Some health professionals express strong convictions that the system is diminishing the quality of medical attention elderly patients receive. Doctors, nurses and social workers recount stories of patients being denied admission to hospitals, being told they cannot get certain kinds of treatment when they are admitted and being released while they are still sick. ''The fallout is that patients don't get as good care,'' says Dr. Thomas H. Dailey, a surgeon who is also president of the medical board at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York.
Many doctors, whether speaking on the record or not, say that DRG's have caused hospitals to cut back on costly services, such as intensive care and the use of state-of-the-art technology. Therefore, these services may go only to the sickest patients or to those who have private insurance or are wealthy enough to pay for treatment out of their own pockets. ''Most people don't realize there's rationing taking place,'' says Dr. Roger C. Bone, chief of pulmonary and critical-care medicine at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. ''I see a trend developing in which some patients receive less and less medical care.''
MEDICARE WAS INSTITUTED IN 1965 AFTER Congress passed a law mandating that the Federal Government provide health insurance to all Americans age 65 and over, as well as younger people who are disabled. Approximately 33 million people are now enrolled in Medicare, all but three million of whom are elderly. (This figure includes people who are still employed and covered by private health insurance.) By the early 1980's, when medical costs were rising faster than the rate of inflation, the Reagan Administration had come to look upon Medicare as a gravy train for hospitals, because they could bill for an unlimited number of tests, surgical procedures and days a patient occupied a bed. The Congressional Budget Office projected that Medicare would run out of money by 1988, leaving millions of the sickest Americans without any medical insurance. In response, Congress passed legislation in 1982 requiring the Department of Health and Human Services to find a way to curb reimbursements.
The department turned to a novel system designed by two Yale professors that placed thousands of illnesses in about 500 categories called diagnostic-related groups. Each category was then assigned a fixed fee. There were regional variations in the fees for each DRG, and hospitals in large cities were paid more than rural hospitals, because their costs were presumably higher. In 1983 the department began implementing the system for all in-hospital services provided to Medicare recipients. Outpatient care and doctor visits, which cost less than hospitalization, are still paid for on the conventional fee-for-service basis. But the department is considering extending DRG's to them, too.
The DRG system has achieved its goal. The rate of increase of Medicare reimbursements for in-patient care declined dramatically, from nearly 19 percent from 1981 to 1982 to just 4 percent from 1987 to 1988. The incentive to cut costs has in some instances forced hospitals to operate more efficiently. Before DRG's, for example, it was not uncommon for patients to sit around the hospital for a day or so before receiving any treatment. Now, hospitals do not admit patients until the day medical procedures begin. There is also less superfluous testing. ''In the old days,'' Dr. Bone says, ''expensive tests were repeated, like putting catheters into the heart to test for heart failure.'' Not only is there less repetition of such tests today, but hospitals think twice before doing them at all.
THE DRG SYSTEM HAS ALSO had some troubling side effects, in addition to encouraging the premature discharge of patients like Ernesta Springer. For one thing, it's hard for patients to get admitted to a hospital unless their symptoms fit squarely into a DRG. ''If you have an old woman with swelling in her legs and shortness of breath who's too sick to get out of bed, you used to be able to bring her into the hospital for a cardiogram,'' says Dr. Dailey. ''Now, she has to sit at home until she has pulmonary edema and then be admitted through the emergency room.'' The first sign of pulmonary edema, or fluid in the lungs, is sometimes swelling of the legs, and early detection can help prevent respiratory failure - and save lives.
Some Medicare patients are denied services for which the Government reimbursement is so low that hospitals lose money. For example, a report in The New England Journal of Medicine last fall found that many hospitals won't give Medicare recipients a relatively new operation for deafness - the cochlear implant, widely regarded as the only treatment for severe deafness - because of the financial loss involved. The average cost for such an implant is $14,000, whereas the average Medicare payment for ear surgery is $10,000.
The reason hospitals are discharging patients earlier than they did before DRG's went into effect is that they can no longer bill Medicare for each day a patient stays. Under the old system, even after patients no longer needed daily care, they could spend a few extra days in the hospital just to rest. No more. Now, they are sometimes released even if they are still weak and in considerable pain from surgery.
''There might be someone who has just had a heart attack and is still paralyzed, and I'd have to talk to the family about discharge,'' says Elizabeth B. Dakin, a social worker who until recently helped coordinate discharge planning for St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. ''I'd get pleas from families that weren't ready to take an invalid home. I'd explain to them that hospitals operate differently today.''
According to a report to be published this year by the Rand Corporation - the largest to date on the effects of DRG's - greater numbers of elderly people are being released from hospitals in unstable condition, with such medical problems as chest pain, rapid heartbeat and confusion. The researchers studied the records of 16,762 Medicare patients age 65 and over who had been admitted to 297 hospitals across the country. They found that the death rate for patients discharged in unstable condition was significantly higher than for those who had remained in the hospital until they had recovered. For example, 17 percent of the patients admitted with congestive heart failure who were discharged with three or more instabilities died within a month of the day they had entered the hospital, compared with just 5 percent of those released with no medical complications.
There is also evidence that recovery takes longer when patients are released from the hospital too early. A 1988 study in The New England Journal of Medicine looked at the records of 586 elderly patients treated for hip fractures at an unnamed Midwestern hospital before and after DRG's went into effect. Under the DRG system, patients were released about nine days earlier than before, and the percentage of those still recuperating in nursing homes a year after leaving the hospital had nearly quadrupled, from 9 to 33 percent.
IN THEIR DEFENSE, HOSPITALS contend that they have been forced to change their policies because they are losing money under the DRG system. Hospitals across the country are losing, on average, 8 cents on every dollar they spend caring for Medicare patients, according to the American Hospital Association. This adds up, because Medicare patients typically make up about 40 percent of a hospital's admissions. The financial burden is so great that since DRG's went into effect, record numbers of hospitals have shut their doors. Many have managed to stay in business only by eliminating or cutting back on certain costly services. These cutbacks are felt not only by the elderly, but by everyone.
In no area of medicine have cutbacks been more drastic than in intensive care. Although there are few figures available, doctors and hospital administrators say that some hospitals have either eliminated their intensive-care units or reduced their intensive-care services, because the financial loss can run into tens of thousands of dollars for each Medicare patient. In Chicago, for example, there is now just one respirator for every 50 chronically ill patients who need it, according to Dr. Bone. ''The patient who can benefit the most from it -and who can pay for it - gets it, and the rest have to wait,'' he says. ''They're sitting and waiting in emergency rooms, sometimes for days.'' Not everyone in the health care field agrees that the overall quality of medical treatment in America has suffered - yet. ''Appropriate high-quality health care is still in place,'' says Larry D. Krupala, chief executive officer of Cuero Community Hospital in rural Texas. ''But we're all fighting against a system that is dislodging that quality.'' Unless Medicare makes more money available to hospitals, he warns, ''quality will slip or access to medical care will slip. There will be a two-tiered system in which Medicare patients are denied intensive care and patients with money will get it.''
The Government maintains that health care has not deteriorated as a result of DRG's, and discounts the fear that this will happen in the future. ''Our responsibility is to assure access to quality medical care and to pay our fair share, and we're doing a perfectly adequate job,'' says Louis B. Hays, an administrator for the Health Care Financing Administration, the office within the Department of Health and Human Services that oversees Medicare. Hays also believes that hospitals overstate the financial strain that DRG's have placed on them. ''Medicare is not designed to assure the financial viability of hospitals,'' he says coolly. ''It is supposed to pay for the cost of treating patients and, on average, it does that. That doesn't mean that every case admitted does well under the system and that all hospitals do well.''
CRITICS OF DRG'S ARGUE that they have not really saved any money at all, but merely redistributed costs from the Government to individuals - closer to the way things were before Medicare. Elderly people who can afford it can buy extra hospital time or treatment either by paying for it themselves or by taking out supplemental insurance. The premiums for these so-called Medigap policies, like all private insurance, have risen dramatically in recent years, in part because increasing numbers of elderly people are filing claims to cover what Medicare doesn't. Those who can't afford to pay for hospital services beyond what Medicare provides may end up paying in other ways. If they leave the hospital in unstable condition, they will certainly need further care, either in a nursing home or from a visiting nurse or home-health aide in their own home. Indeed, many will require 24-hour monitoring. But Medicare pays for only 100 days in a nursing home and eight hours a day of home-nursing care for three weeks, and it does not cover the cost of a visiting home-health aide.
Whether or not patients who need 24-hour monitoring actually get it depends, again, on how much money they have. Those with enough money can pay for extra care, either through a Medigap policy or on their own. In some parts of the country, round-the-clock home-health care for a year can easily run $40,000. Patients with low incomes, and the figure varies from state to state - $459 per month for a single person in New York, for example, and $600 in California - can rely on Medicaid to pay for home-health care. But the vast numbers of elderly people in the middle class get stuck.
They have two options, neither of them appealing. One is to do without professional health care and rely on relatives and friends. ''Sometimes we must teach a significant other what to do,'' says Judith H. Levy, director of patient services at Home Health Services of Westchester Jewish Community Services, in White Plains. Even such complex procedures as using a suctioning device to draw excess fluid from the lungs may fall to a relative or friend. The patient's other option is to spend so much of his income and savings on home care that he becomes poor enough to qualify for Medicaid. This is what people in the home-care industry refer to as ''spending down.'' To avoid having to spend down, and to be eligible for Medicaid from the start of their illness, some elderly people have become adept at seeming poorer than they really are - for example, by transferring their assets to their children or other relatives.
The Government's savings under DRG's have also forced younger, privately insured patients to pay more. Hospitals acknowledge that they count on insurance companies to pay more for treatment than the Government. ''That's a fact of life,'' says Larry Krupala, of Cuero Community Hospital. By way of example, he says, if Medicare pays $3,500 for a particular operation, a hospital might charge a privately insured person $5,000 for the same procedure in an effort to recoup its loss.
''There always was a differential between Medicare reimbursement and private reimbursement,'' says Elliot Wicks, an associate director at the Health Insurance Association of America, in Washington. ''But our tentative research shows that private insurance companies have been paying even higher prices as a result of DRG's.'' This is one reason why premiums for some individual and group health insurance policies have jumped by 100 percent or more in the last year. It is also one reason why some private health insurers are attempting to trim their reimbursements by turning to systems modeled on DRG's. As more insurance companies follow suit, hospitals will have a more difficult time shifting their costs, and many more will probably have to close their doors.
IT WOULD SEEM THAT THE solution is largely a matter of money. But the United States already spends a greater portion of its gross national product on health care than any other country in the world - and 20 percent flows to administrative costs alone. So, rather than spend even more, the solution is likely to be to spend money more intelligently.
Many doctors and policy makers have come to the opinion that the only way to insure quality care at an affordable price is to revamp the entire system of health care delivery. Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, has identified reform of the health care system as a major national issue, and proposals for several alternatives are being hammered out in the Government as well as by private researchers. A group of doctors based in Cambridge, Mass., have formally proposed the unthinkable: national health insurance. Under this proposal all hospital and medical care for every citizen would be paid for by the Federal Government; there would be no private insurance, no insurance premiums and no deductibles. The doctors allow that some sort of tax increase would be needed to finance their plan, but they estimate that the increased taxes would be no greater than what individuals now pay in premiums, deductibles and out-of-pocket medical expenses.
There's no guarantee that a new health insurance system would be any more successful than the present one at delivering high-quality medical care to all unless health experts come to an agreement on just what high-quality care is. Few people would argue that when a person dies because he or she has been discharged from a hospital too soon, the quality of care is less than it should be. But beyond that there is considerable debate. The Rand Corporation and other research institutions are studying a wide range of medical procedures in an effort to determine which ones work for particular patients and which ones do not. Only when this is clearly understood will insurers be able to make their cuts with surgical precision and will patients no longer have to settle for second best.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1130 words

HEADLINE: A LOOK ON THE BRIGHT SIDE

BYLINE: By GODFREY HODGSON; Godfrey Hodgson, the foreign editor of The Independent of London, has published several books on United States politics, including ''America in Our Time.''

 BODY:

OUR COUNTRY
The Shaping of America From Roosevelt to Reagan.
By Michael Barone.
805 pp. New York: The Free Press. $29.95.
Around 1980, Michael Barone remarks in a somewhat lofty vein at one point in ''Our Country,'' his new history of modern American politics, ''the standard paradigms which members of the American elite used to understand and explain events'' began to cloud rather than clarify their understanding. Those ''paradigms,'' he explains, were ''analyses of the leaders of big American units,'' as well as ''a focus on domestic markets and domestic elections.'' 
The remark may or may not be pertinent: it is in any case a little surprising, since the method of this serious and thoughtful attempt at both telling and interpreting the last 60 years of American history is to examine those very three dimensions, in particular the first and last of them.
The method is easy to parody, even to mock. Mr. Barone is a senior writer for U.S. News and World Report and one of the authors of ''The Almanac of American Politics,'' a reference book that is indispensable to politicians and their handlers, political scientists, reporters and others involved in the business of politics, not to mention amateur enthusiasts like the present reviewer.
Sometimes the spirit of the ''Almanac'' steps out from the curb and gives Mr. Barone the historian a speeding ticket. As the narrative of ''Our Country'' moves toward Watergate's finale, for example, the author, in search of illustrations, returns - as he does quite often -to his native Michigan, and dumps the reader in ''the heavily Republican sugar beet and bean fields of the so-called Thumb of Michigan's mitten-shaped Lower Peninsula - the descendant of the district which in another special election in November 1931 had first signaled that the bottom had fallen out politically for Herbert Hoover.'' Sandbagged by electoral and agrarian expertise, this reader sank to his knees in those Republican bean fields. It took a perceptible effort of will to rise and leave that unmemorable contest and follow Richard Nixon to the end of his political night.
Yet if the writing is occasionally pedestrian, and the reader sometimes overwhelmed with political ephemera, Mr. Barone has a story to tell whose sweep is irresistible: nothing less than the fortunes of the United States from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Ronald Reagan, or from Herbert Hoover to George Bush (it doesn't sound quite such a long way, somehow, if you put it like that).
Mr. Barone starts in the 1920's with contrasting portraits of William Howard Taft, former President and incumbent Chief Justice, and Charles F. Murphy, sachem of Tammany Hall, as emblematic representatives of ''two contending approaches to American politics and two different cultures,'' which Mr. Barone calls the ''Yankees'' and the ''Ellis Islanders.'' He rounds off his story, by way of cadence and symmetry, with a picture of Ronald Reagan, Ellis Islander and ''son of a WPA worker,'' standing side by side with George Bush, ''the son of an investment banker,'' to receive the ''surrender'' of Mikhail Gorbachev.
As that image suggests, Mr. Barone's tone is what used to be called Pollyanna-ish: his purpose is to show how everything has turned out for the best in the best of all possible countries, and incidentally to deliver a few passing kicks to those who spoil the chorus of self-congratulation by asking awkward questions.
One of his themes is the resolution of the former antagonism between Yankee and Ellis Islander in a contemporary society that he finds, in almost theological terms, at once perfectly unified and infinitely pluralistic. He is less interested in the resolution of other ancient schisms in American life: between North and South, black and white, have and have not.
Such unresolved conflicts would be out of place in his picture of a country ''that emerged confident from years of turmoil and stayed resilient after years of alienation . . . a country that belonged not just to the many different kinds of Americans but to peoples all over the world.'' Such language is neither historical nor reportorial but inspirational and nationalistic.
It is Mr. Barone's contention that after 1947 - that is, after the four years of rapid economic growth that occurred during World War II -the country was so well-off that ''the politics of economic redistribution,'' which had dominated the 1930's, had been swept aside by continuing prosperity. It is true enough that in the United States, as everywhere else, growing prosperity has allowed people to focus less on economic survival and more on other issues, whether pride or prejudice or what are somewhat loosely known as ethics. But you would have had to be a saint to tread the halls of Congress these last 20 years and remain unaware that a considerable amount of economic redistribution has been on the agenda, even if by no means all of it has been from the rich to the poor.
Another of Mr. Barone's organizing themes is the shift from the collective to the fragmented, or, as he puts it, from big units to small units. When Roosevelt took office in the crisis of 1933, Mr. Barone rightly says, ''the country wanted action; it wanted order; it wanted control. . . . Franklin Roosevelt promised these things, and he delivered.'' Moreover, not only was the action collective, the philosophy underlying it was collectivist.
By 1977, however, ''the faith that government could solve all problems was vanishing.'' And by 1980, ''the idea of common effort came to seem absurd.'' From 1940 to 1965, Mr. Barone asserts, most jobs were created by ''big units,'' that is, by major corporate and government institutions, but from 1965 to 1980 they came from ''small units.'' These are just three examples of his willingness to fall into wild generalizations that may be in accord with prevailing political and intellectual fashion, but would need to be supported by far more evidence than he adduces before they could be taken very seriously. Nowhere does Mr. Barone seem aware, for instance, that one reason why so many jobs have been created by small units is because the managers of big units perceived advantages for themselves in subcontracting and shedding overhead.
That is only one example of Mr. Barone's limitations. He has written a thoughtful and energetic account of American history since the Great Depression. But when he looks for the causes and mechanisms of change, all he seems to find are his own convictions, those of a well-informed neoconservative who writes with nostalgia of the old Democratic mainstream and with ill-temper of the new Democratic Left, and who thinks Lloyd Bentsen, had he been at the top of the Democratic ticket, might have won the 1988 election.

729 of 763 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 29, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1196 words

HEADLINE: PAPERBACKS;
WITH A BOOST FROM UNCLE SAM

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. BARTEL; Richard D. Bartel is the editor of Challenge: The Magazine of Economic Affairs.

 BODY:

ENTERPRISE
The Dynamic Economy of a Free People.
By Stuart Bruchey.
645 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press.
Paper, $24.95. Cloth, $49.50.
In ''Enterprise,'' Stuart Bruchey, a professor emeritus of economic history at Columbia University, writes a rich and comprehensive survey spanning four centuries of the American economy. The narrative opens in 1607 with the image of ''three small ships carrying 105 colonists'' sailing into Chesapeake Bay. The well-known epoch then unfolds - colonization, the Revolution, the founding of the Republic, all filled with hope and promise. By the close, however, when Mr. Bruchey reflects on the relative economic decline of the United States, the mood becomes somber as he asks: ''Can America keep [its] heights?'' 
In the intervening 540 pages, Mr. Bruchey presents a wealth of material on American economic growth and development. He enlivens his narrative with the debates of past historians and the findings of contemporary research. He shows how statutes, judicial decisions and government intervention at all levels helped or hindered the workings of enterprise.
Mr. Bruchey also taps important literature from outside the realm of economics to consider the values animating individual and corporate action. (Particularly noteworthy is the evidence from David C. McClelland's book ''The Achieving Society'' about the psychological factors that give rise to motivation in children.) In general, the book proceeds by defining the historical issues, offering the evidence from various sources and weighing the alternative views. The reader, engaged in a kind of Socratic dialogue, is left to make the final judgment. Indeed, Mr. Bruchey's admirable effort at providing objective balance is pushed at times almost to a fault.
From the nation's beginnings, as Mr. Bruchey recounts, businessmen, farmers, merchants and budding industrialists took perilous risks where established corporations feared to venture. At the same time, scarce labor commanded higher real wages than back home in England and on the Continent, a powerful incentive for the United States work ethic that has persisted until very recent decades. Along with political and religious freedom, the Promised Land held out the attraction of privately owned homes, businesses and farms, as well as the lure of membership in a substantial, propertied middle class that dominated society, at least in the North, even before the Revolution.
Yet, as Mr. Bruchey writes, studies have shown that despite high real incomes, vast untapped natural resources and unusually fertile soil, poverty emerged on an ''appalling'' scale in Boston, Philadelphia and New York before 1776. ''Desperately poor'' lived near ''fabulously wealthy.'' Thus, inequities of income and wealth were features of the American scene long before robber barons appeared in the 1880's. Throughout this history, Mr. Bruchey follows income disparities as they widened (notably in the decades around 1900 and in the 1920's) and narrowed (in World War I and during 1930-50) and then sharply grew again in the 1980's.
As Mr. Bruchey progresses from agriculture to commerce, industry and finance, it becomes clear that even enterprising Americans have always readily turned to government for help. And government has responded: to expand markets, sustain competition, promote economic justice and control the business cycle. Agriculture is a prime example, presenting, in Mr. Bruchey's words, ''one of the truly amazing facts of American history'': whereas, in 1790, 85 percent of the American labor force was required to satisfy the agricultural needs of the new nation's four million people, by the 1980's less than 3 percent fed a population exceeding 230 million, while generating huge surplus crops for export that turned the United States into the world's breadbasket. As America's green revolution took off after World War II, Mr. Bruchey writes, the miracles of agricultural science and applied technology often ''completed what government . . . had begun.'' How different this revolution might have been if the Government had not granted homesteads to new settlers (Homestead Act, 1862); established land-grant colleges (Morrill Act, 1862), agricultural research stations (Hatch Act, 1887) and local cooperative services (Smith-Lever Act, 1914); and fostered a partnership with farmers and agribusiness that continues to this day.
What is striking about the role of government, particularly during the 1930's, is how much Presidential decisions, both Republican and Democratic, were determined by the need to make the American economic system work. It was the Republican Herbert Hoover, not the New Dealer Franklin Roosevelt, who pressed for ''a cooperative system in which public and private organizations worked together to achieve national objectives.'' Hoover sounded more Keynesian than did the early Roosevelt: cutting wages, in his view, would only ''deepen the depression by suddenly reducing purchasing power and bringing about industrial strife.'' He pushed for lower income taxes to spur consumption and advocated public works to counter the collapse of business investment. His policy ideas - certainly ''not . . . imprisoned by an ideology of laissez faire'' - eventually became the Federal Farm Board, Home Loan banks and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
''At stake,'' says Mr. Bruchey, ''was the viability of American capitalism.'' The safety net created by the Federal Government during the 1930's caught not only individual farmers and workers, but also endangered financial institutions. The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, for example, lent more than $2 billion to 8,500 banks and invested $1 billion in the capital stock of 6,000 banks - one-third of the system's total capital in 1933. How different from the Reagan philosophy of the 1980's, when government was considered part of ''the problem,'' not part of the solution!
On turning the final page of this book, the reader is struck by what Mr. Bruchey has achieved. His grand pageant of American economic history reveals a powerful private and public ethic that shaped the course of ideas and events. Mr. Bruchey's title, therefore, seems inadequate to the story he tells. Yes, ''enterprise'' per se explains much of the dynamic economy of a free people. But one can only speculate how the United States might have fared without often wise and visionary government intervention that gave impetus to free enterprise in the 1860's, that restrained its excesses in the 1880's and 1890's, that rescued the very capitalist system in the 1930's and that sustained and nurtured growth after World War II. Enterprise and government in partnership describes more fully the historical dynamic of America's economy.
In any event, scholars and students will reap dividends for years to come from Mr. Bruchey's 25-year investment in researching and writing this book. It offers the well-informed citizen an illuminating perspective on how the nation's economic performance in the 1980's strayed from the mainstream of American history, and the challenges that aberration poses for the 1990's.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: ENTERPRISE (BOOK)

PUB-DATE: April 29, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 761 words

HEADLINE: PAPERBACKS;
LOST IN THE MODERN KONTRY

BYLINE: By REGINALD MCKNIGHT; Reginald McKnight's most recent book is ''Moustapha's Eclipse,'' a collection of stories.

 BODY:

THE FAMILY
By Buchi Emecheta.
239 pp. New York:
George Braziller. Paper, $8.95. Cloth, $17.95.
''The writer with the tin ear,'' wrote John Gardner, in his book ''On Becoming a Novelist,'' who is good enough at other things, ''may in the end write deeper, finer novels than the most eloquent verbal musicians.'' It was the writer's facility with those ''other things'' -the development of ''character, action, setting'' and ideas, which Gardner called ''profluence'' - that compelled the reader to turn the page. 
There are, of course many novelists whose prose is both poetic and profluent: Margaret Atwood, Toni Morrison, Nathanael West. But some of the most highly regarded novelists (Balzac, Crane, Orwell), as Gardner suggested, are no poets at all.
Most readers, no doubt, would include the works of the Nigerian writer Buchi Emecheta in the latter category. The prose in her latest novel, ''The Family,'' like that of her earlier works (particularly ''Double Yoke'' and ''The Slave Girl'') is generally vivid, plain and clear - the kind of prose that illuminates rather than buries the characters and settings it describes: ''Winston was everything Gladys said he was, so why did she feel this eel of distrust coiled about [his] memory?'' But there are times when the language is barely firm enough to carry images and ideas: ''Gwendolen was not the cleverest of people. She could be slow, but she was not thick-skinned.''
Nevertheless, occasional lapses such as this do not hinder our being moved and intrigued by the novel's principal character, Gwendolen Brillianton, a young girl from Granville, Jamaica, whose mother and father leave her with her grandmother, Granny Naomi, to seek a better life for themselves in England, the ''Moder Kontry.'' Very soon after their departure, a close family friend molests the 8-year-old Gwendolen. And because ''she did not like Uncle Johnny troubling her at night, and she did not like to see Granny Naomi unhappy,'' Gwendolen flees to the home of her paternal grandmother, Elinor, who lives in Kingston. But before she is even fully reacquainted with her family in Kingston they rebuff her, intimating that because they are fair-skinned and Gwendolen dark, she does not belong. Thus far, less than one-tenth of the narrative has been traversed. Gwendolen will see and feel much, much more once her parents finally send for her.
In this rich, complex and fast-moving novel, one breathlessly follows Gwendolen from Granville to London in her search for love, family and a place ''where she could be herself - happy, trusting Gwendolen again.'' And through this journey we see her suffer rape, incest, racism, teen-age pregnancy and loneliness. She endures the indignities of illiteracy and remedial education, falls in love with a boy her mother describes as a ''dirty white'' and veers toward madness. We witness the social and economic dynamics that force both Gwendolen and her mother to ''remain alive for others. . . . to look after members of their families, to boost the ego of the man in their lives, be the man a father, a husband, or even a son. And they were to nurture and act as agony aunts to their offspring. But to live for themselves was not to be.''
In many ways Ms. Emecheta probably speaks from experience. Not only is she a novelist, a research fellow at the University of Calabar, Nigeria, and a member of Britain's Advisory Council to the Home Secretary on Race and Equality, but she is also a mother of five. She speaks from a vantage point that few of us know. Her London, for example, is a cold, gray, multicultural world, a world made up of Ibos, Anglos, Yorubas, Jamaicans - both fair and dark - Greeks, Indians, the educated, the undereducated, the dispossessed, the alienated. Ms. Emecheta's novel shows us - as do many other important works of African and African-American literature - that a large number of the problems that plague the African diaspora - rootlessness, ''hue prejudice,'' self-hatred and perhaps even some of the sexual violence that nearly destroys Gwendolen - are the direct result of slavery and colonialism. But Buchi Emecheta is no ideologue; her characters do not utter or think words that would not come from them; they are not mere representatives of larger social movements but real, complex human beings, shaped by the vicissitudes of class, culture and sexual politics. She raises the right questions, but never harangues. She writes with subtlety, power and abundant compassion. ''The Family'' is a good book, and one not easily forgotten.

HEADLINE: WHY YOU'RE AFRAID OF THE DOCTOR

BYLINE: By UWE E. RIENHARDT; Uwe E. Reinhardt is a health economist and a frequent commentator on American health policy.

 BODY:
THE MEDICAL TRIANGLE
Physicians, Politicians and the Public.
By Eli Ginzberg.
314 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $27.50.
If anyone can make sense of the mammoth American health system and explain it to a lay person, it is Eli Ginzberg. Director of Columbia University's Conservation of Human Resources Project and the author of this collection of essays, Mr. Ginzberg has been a keen observer of the American health scene since before World War II and continues to be a strong voice in the debate on this nation's health policy. Unlike so many experts pronouncing on that subject today, though, he has never been a captive of a particular ideology or of a well-heeled interest group. He tends to report the truth as he perceives it, and these essays, all of which have been previously and separately published, are no exception. 
In the first part of the book, Mr. Ginzberg harks back to the good old days, when medical care was cheaper and the health system rested firmly on three stable pillars: the dominance of the medical profession in all matters of health policy; reliable local sponsorship of the community hospital as the doctor's free workshop; and the widely accepted principle that the care of poor patients is best financed through hidden cross-subsidies, whereby the premiums paid by insured patients cover the care of uninsured patients. In the past 30 years, though, this idyllic world, so Mr. Ginzberg says, has been increasingly ''destabilized'' by a few major factors: a surplus of physicians and hospital beds (New York City being the one place actually plagued by a shortage); the opening of the health sector to unbridled entrepreneurship; and the collectivization of health care financing under private or public health insurance.
Until the late 1960's, most health care was relatively simple, and much of it could be paid for by patients when they were treated. Because physicians and other providers of health care were then in short supply, they could count on good incomes without having to charge patients anything near what the traffic would have borne. In such a world, doctors and hospitals easily gained the affection of the community and were thus at peace with the world.
Furthermore, because health care was then simpler, kindly acts toward the poor came at a low price. One was not talking about bestowing upon an indigent patient the equivalent of a Mercedes-Benz (roughly the total cost of a coronary bypass in many parts of the country - certainly in New York City) or of a Rolls-Royce (often the cost of helping a premature infant to enter this world or a dying patient to leave it with greater comfort).
But in the 1960's, as the system became flooded with doctors and hospital beds, and third-party health insurance coverage became common, medicine inevitably became more commercialized, which simply meant that fees and the proverbial bottom line preoccupied health care providers more and more. In such a world, there was bound to be growing anxiety on the supply side and deep suspicion on the demand side - in short, rancor all around. What also emerged was a greater reluctance to lower the bottom line through charity care.
Although Mr. Ginzberg does not put it quite this directly, that is what ''destabilization'' is really all about. He appears to deplore this trend and argues that it must be slowed and reversed, but does not say how. To be fair, the answer is certainly not obvious, at least for this country. Unless Americans are willing to countenance the regulatory strictures of the more stable health care systems in Canada and Europe - which they are unlikely to do - destabilization is here to stay, and we had better all get used to it.
After illuminating the general situation at the beginning of his book, Mr. Ginzberg trains his spotlight on selected facets of the health care system. There are essays on academic health centers (medical schools combined with hospitals), on needed reforms of medical education, on the role and fate of community health centers, on the supply of physicians, on the nursing shortage, on the rationing of health care, on health care for the poor and on many more topics.
Throughout the book, Mr. Ginzberg debunks the many myths and contradictions that so often distort the public debate on health policy. In his chapter on nursing, for example, he bluntly reminds nursing's leaders that ''there is something contradictory in a policy that both advocates expanding the supply [of nurses, through subsidies to nursing education] and insists on raising the salaries.'' In an earlier chapter, he quite ably defends the proposition that ''the competitive market [in health care] is an opponent, not an ally, of cost containment'' - a thesis that many economic theorists will find counterintuitive, but that seems compatible with the data. Mr. Ginzberg does not see any prospect for the much-heralded large-scale privatization of American health care beyond current levels, and indeed argues that our increasingly fragile private health insurance system might not even survive a deep recession.
Other observers of American health care might assume a strident tone for such a book, but that is not Mr. Ginzberg's style. His attitude reminds one of an elder who beholds the unruly behavior of teen-age grandchildren with loving and bemused detachment. Throughout the book, he strives to be evenhanded. For example, physicians will be pleased to read that he admires American medicine's many achievements. (After all, he notes, few foreigners come here any more to study how we make cars, cameras or machine tools; but legions still come to learn at the side of America's physicians.) At the same time, physicians will be chagrined that he does not cast lawyers as the chief culprits in the malpractice crisis, and instead chiefly blames medicine for failing to police its own ranks.
Mr. Ginzberg's essays are not aimed at well-read students of American health policy who require the more penetrating analysis he easily could have supplied. Instead, the book seems pitched at the uninitiated - patients and health care providers alike - who so often find our medical system bewildering and, therefore, both frustrating and frightening. For these readers, this volume will illuminate the workings of the institutions that sooner or later will touch them more intimately than even their houses of worship do.

HEADLINE: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

 BODY:

Plenipotent
 During the Revolutionary War, Benjamin Franklin was sent to Paris to woo France for the infant United States. The all-inclusiveness of his wooing irritated John Adams, the future President, who wrote this priggish letter home. It is quoted in ''Mon Cher Papa: Franklin and the Ladies of Paris'' by Claude-Anne Lopez (Yale University).
 The Life of Dr. Franklin was a Scene of continual discipation. I could never obtain the favour of his Company in a Morning before Breakfast which would have been the most convenient time to read over the Letters and papers, deliberate on their contents, and decide upon the Substance of the Answers. It was late when he breakfasted, and as soon as Breakfast was over, a crowd of Carriages came to his Levee or if you like the term better, to his Lodgings, with all sorts of People; some Phylosophers, Accademicians and Economists . . . but by far the greater part were Women and Children, come to have the honour to see the great Franklin, and to have the pleasure of telling Stories about his Simplicity, his bald head and scattering strait hairs, among their Acquaintances. 
 
You Can't Kiss Fame
 Fame and even favorable reviews were not enough for Alfred Tennyson. Here we see the great poet hungering for more homely gratifications. This report by a friend is quoted by Christopher Ricks in the second edition of his ''Tennyson'' (University of California).
 On my way in, paid a visit to Tennyson, who seemed much out of spirits, and said that he could no longer bear to be knocked about the world, and that he must marry and find love and peace or die. He was very angry about a favourable review of him. Said that he could not stand the chattering and conceit of clever men, or the worry of society, or the meanness of tuft-hunters, or the trouble of poverty, or the labour of a place, or the preying of the heart on itself. . . . He complained much about growing old, and said he cared nothing for fame, and that his life was all thrown away for want of a competence and retirement. Said that no one had been so much harassed by anxiety and trouble as himself. I told him he wanted occupation, a wife, and orthodox principles, which he took well.
 
After Love, Give Me Air
 When people make love in Frederick Busch's novels, they breathe up all the air in the room. This is from ''Harry and Catherine'' (Knopf).
 Now I lay me down to sleep, she thought. Thanks for the tomatoes in the pantry waiting to be washed, and the peppers and zucchini, the oregano and thyme. But I have to ask, she thought, pressing her nose and mouth into the side of his neck, its salty taste, what's supposed to happen next? To remind us for sure that we are not supposed to wait a long time and love long-distance and finally hop in the sack to find truth, justice, contentment, and measured form while living sweetly, stupidly, happily forever after?
And what happened was that she woke. Nothing saddened or disturbed her, and the falling temperatures and rising wind, the gentle, expected music of windowpanes shaken, were soothing, not unsettling. But she'd been asleep, in deep, exhausted, grateful sleep, and then she lay with her eyes open, a light sweat on her skin, and her breathing just a little fast. As if he sensed her unsettlement, Harry pulled at her. . . . He was a comforting and greedy man, she thought. But she felt that what she needed more than his needful generosity was air. She heard it outside, and she thirsted for it.
I Can't Imagine You Either
 Teen-agers can also be profound. This is 15-year-old Jimmy O'Neill, who was born with cystic fibrosis. He is one of 14 children in ''How It Feels to Fight for Your Life'' by Jill Krementz (Little, Brown).
 My life is different from those of other kids but because I've grown up with it, it's something I've gotten used to. It's probably as hard for you to imagine what my life is like as it is for me to imagine how some other people live. I can't see how a stockbroker might get up at three-thirty in the morning and not get home until ten at night. . . . I suppose there are all sorts of people who are so used to what they have to do that it doesn't seem weird. It's how they live. I think in some ways I'm better off than some kids who get paralyzed or go blind all of a sudden. It's so much easier if you don't know what you're missing because you've never had it to begin with.
 
Ambling, Not Shambling
 Here's a postcard view of our grandfathers 200,000 years ago. They were handsomer than we generally suppose, says Michael H. Brown in ''The Search for Eve'' (Harper & Row).
 They lived where the rhino took dust baths, where the gazelle gathered, and where the giant buffalo roamed. By day they could be glimpsed making their way across the vast savannah, vague upright forms that were decidedly not animals and yet lithely intermingled with them. They moved from tree to acacia tree, foraging among the ambling giraffe, the skittish, dust-kicking wildebeest, the swollen zebras, sticks in hand, wary of lion, their gait purposeful and yet very cautious - a slow and steady and gliding gait. Certainly it was not the stooped and lumbering image commonly accorded to cavemen. Some carried ostrich eggs and kindling twigs, others water baskets woven with hide and ambary fibers, still others wooden poles or slender stone blades.

HEADLINE: PAPERBACKS;
NELSON ALGREN: THE MESSAGE STILL HURTS

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BANKS; Russell Banks teaches creative writing at Princeton University; his most recent novel is ''Affliction.''

 BODY:
It shouldn't surprise me that Nelson Algren, clearly one of the best novelists of his time, is not much read these days. It's the ''kill the messenger'' syndrome, I suppose, for the news that Algren's works brings us is not good news: if the world he describes is at all like our own, then it's not morning in America, and it hasn't been for a long, long time. In an Algren novel or story, the only thing that trickles down to where most folks live is disdain, violence and sometimes, on a good day, benign neglect; racism, greed, sadism and misogyny are the warp and woof of our social fabric; the workers are not happy and a lot of them are pregnant teen-agers, have no homes, no food, no jobs and no prospects for same.
Of course, he's writing about another time and a faraway place, right? In ''A Walk on the Wild Side'' it's the early Depression, east Texas and New Orleans, old Perdido Street; his characters are pimps and prostitutes, con men, drug addicts and alcoholics, homeless wanderers, illiterate whites and blacks trying to ''make an honest dollar in a crooked sort of way.'' In ''The Man With the Golden Arm,'' it's Chicago's back alleys and mean streets in the 1940's, derelicts and dopers, bitter castaways and undeserving castoffs. 
And what's that got to do with America a half-century later in the go-go 1990's? All too much, I'm afraid. Which may be the reason we'd rather leave Algren unread on the shelf, him and the writers he was influenced by: Theodore Dreiser, Upton Sinclair, Frank Norris, Sherwood Anderson, Richard Wright. We want to think them irrelevant, because if they're not, if the truth they have to tell about America still holds, then we're in deep trouble, friend, so we better kill the messenger.
But Nelson Algren's hard to kill. When he was around, he was feisty, funny, resilient, and until his 60's - when he wearied of the fight to gain the respect that his lesser, more polite contemporaries gathered with ease - prolific. He left us a significant body of work, much of which has been out of print for some time and is being reissued by two presses (see box). But more to the point, he wrote well. He wrote brilliantly, especially in ''A Walk on the Wild Side,'' and ''The Man With the Golden Arm, which are, to my mind, his best, most artistically successful books. His language lasts: the voice of an Algren story or novel is unmistakably his, as permanently, flat-out American as Twain's and Crane's and more authentic than Hemingway's. There's a combination of layered and compressed writing (a truly rare combination of virtues; writers usually have one or the other) that reminds me of Eudora Welty and William Kennedy at their best.
''A Walk on the Wild Side,'' in particular, suggests Mr. Kennedy, who was understandably irritated when told that in ''Ironweed'' his subjects were ''just bums'' - as if his characters were too marginal, too ''simple,'' to care about. I've heard the same thing said about Algren's characters, and in response have felt that if they are marginal, then so are we all. Algren's antiheroic protagonist in ''A Walk on the Wild Side,'' Dove Linkhorn, is an illiterate homeless kid with a broad back and a good sense of humor who tries to make it in a world that has no place for him (a character not unlike Fielding's Tom Jones, say, or Voltaire's Candide, or, in another guise, Salinger's Holden Caulfield - someone losing his innocence by trying to get by in a fallen world). And he's a hell of a lot more like most of us than is Hemingway's Nick Adams or Thomas Wolfe's Eugene Gant, young American males who want only to go home again, romantic heroes longing to leave the real world, boys who dream of a prelapsarian maternal lap and, failing to obtain it, dissolve in elegiac bitterness.
I was lucky enough to know Nelson when I was young. Childless, he took a lot of young writers under his wing (Terry Southern, Bruce Jay Friedman, numerous others), providing fatherly protection, encouragement and example all at once. I was a 23-year-old pipefitter in Concord, N.H., who hadn't gone to college but had written a novel that, despite a few striking paragraphs here and there, was quite simply awful. I took off work for a week and lugged my manuscript to the Bread Loaf Writers' Conference in Vermont, where Algren was on the staff, more or less. (John Ciardi, the director, thought less; Algren thought more.) He read my manuscript, as he was paid to do, quickly located those few striking paragraphs and pointed them out to me and made it clear that I was supposed to do the rest myself (and what more can an apprentice writer ask of a master, anyhow?). But meanwhile, he said, since I had wheels and we were stuck up here on this mountain surrounded by writers drinking sherry with their little fingers in the air, and since he, like Jack Kerouac, didn't drive, why didn't I take him to Middlebury for a beer and then maybe we'd go on to visit his pal Paul Goodman, who had a summer place somewhere nearby? We did, and that was the end of my tour at Bread Loaf, more or less.
Algren in person was a lot like his books - large-hearted, funny, angry, lonely. He spoke the truth to power wherever he met power (and he saw injustice where most people preferred to see only good intentions gone awry, which made him no friend to bourgeois academics and intellectuals: he trusted a brutal, racist Chicago cop more than a suburban Republican banker). To those of us who loved him, he could sometimes seem perversely self-defeating: he was unable to resist any chance to tweak the beard of somber authority.
In the mid-1960's, I helped get him invited to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (where I was at last in college) for a reading and talk. To fatten the embarrassingly thin honorarium, the university had offered to pick up the tab for his expenses while in town, but instead of staying at the Carolina Inn, an antebellum establishment that offended his sensibilities, Nelson chose to stay with me and my wife at our tiny off-campus bungalow. When the university refused to pay for his expenses, Nelson submitted an itemized bill for everything he had eaten and drunk in my home, plus laundry charges, for a total of $62.80. When they still refused to pay, Nelson got a friend in Chicago, who may or may not have been a lawyer, but at least had stationery, to write threatening letters to the bursar, dean and president. And when that didn't work, Nelson wrote letters to all the local newspapers, which they gladly published, until he had a full-blown negative publicity campaign under way. Finally, just to make him go away, the university coughed up a check for $62.80, which, in triumph, he immediately made over to me. That was, of course, the last time I was allowed to invite speakers to the University of North Carolina.
''The Man With the Golden Arm,'' published in 1949, was the winner of the first National Book Award for fiction, and it may be the best book they ever gave it to. Algren never recovered from Otto Preminger's misappropriation of the novel for Frank Sinatra's film - there's always something indecently innocent about a streetwise writer. Only Walt Whitman would have been more offended by a film version of his work. But the novel has outlived the film, as the good ones inevitably do. And I suspect that Frankie Machine will outlive Frankie Sinatra.
''A Walk on the Wild Side,'' which Algren at times seemed to think little of, is to my mind an American classic, a home-grown version of the European Bildungsroman, to be read alongside ''Huckleberry Finn,'' ''The Red Badge of Courage'' and ''Native Son.'' Driven by a permanent democrat's righteous wrath at injustice, informed by unsentimental respect and unabashed affection for the powerless, in language colored throughout by the pain of some unnamed, deeply personal wound whose nature we can only intuit, the novel is at once a radical critique of the American economy and a grief-stricken portrait of its victims. And finally, that's what makes this book so wonderful - the people who live inside it. Dove Linkhorn, the east Texas drifter who, like a youthful Willy Loman taken to his logical Marxist extreme, can succeed as a salesman only by becoming a pimp; Kitty Twist, a 17-year-old runaway who's looking for a good pickpocket to settle down with; all the other women who work on Perdido Street - Five, named for the shape of her navel, and Hallie Breedlove and Frenchy - tough, smart women who survive and love one another and keep on cracking hard-edged jokes, even though ''the courts were against them, the police were against them, businessmen, wives, churches, press, politicians and their own panders were against these cork-heeled puppets.'' Because ''A Walk on the Wild Side'' is a permanent part of our literature, these people, who continue to live among us, will continue to be heard. That's all Nelson ever wanted his work to accomplish, and what writer could want more?
 
 
 
This essay has been adapted from the foreword to a reissue of ''A Walk on the Wild Side,'' to be published next month by Thunder's Mouth Press.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 7, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Derby Love, Same Time Each Year

BYLINE: By WILLIAM MURRAY; William Murray's latest novel about the track, ''The Getaway Blues,'' will be published by Bantam this summer.

 BODY:
''You're going to the Kentucky Derby?'' my friend Angles Beltrami asked me a couple of weeks ago. ''What for? How can you put up with all that aggravation?''
We had bumped into each other at an off-track betting site in Del Mar, Calif., where I live, and had been discussing this year's crop of 3-year-olds, strictly as a betting proposition. Wagering on race horses is the only thing in life that interests Angles, who, like many horseplayers I know, has no visible source of income but somehow manages to stay in action. 
When I revealed to him that I was on my way to Kentucky to see for myself about the 3-year-olds, he was appalled. Why would I get up from my comfortable table facing a large TV screen in the Turf Club at Del Mar, only a short stroll from a parimutuel window, to subject myself to the expense and horrors of modern travel simply to be part of the huge crowd flocking into Churchill Downs on Saturday, May 5?
''You ain't even going to see the race that good,'' was Angles's parting shot.
He's probably right, but does it matter? If you love the game, as I do, then occasionally you have to subject yourself to its realities. You have to be there, with the horses and the people they represent, see all the sights, smell the smells, mingle, become a part of it.
The economic future of horse racing, a sport that is under increasing pressure from having to compete with state lotteries (even Kentucky has one) and other forms of legalized sports betting, probably depends on the spread of the offtrack facilities and the huge pools being created by so-called exotic wagering: triples, double triples, pick-threes, pick-sixes, pick-nines.
These propositions, with payoffs to bettors often in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, create headlines and useful publicity, but they are not what the sport is essentially about. Its soul is still the animal itself, as those of us can testify who have fallen in love with various great horses over the years. And often it's at the Kentucky Derby that the true quality of a contender is established. In every sport, certain events transcend the hype that engulfs them, though I'm not sure I could explain that to Angles.
Last year by this time I was already in love - with trainer Charlie Whittingham's feisty colt Sunday Silence. Most of my friends in the East were committed to Easy Goer, and much was made of the East-West rivalry that dominated the sports pages for months.
I never took it seriously, because, after all, both horses were bred in Kentucky, but the publicity generated tremendous excitement, until Sunday Silence finally settled matters at the Breeders' Cup Classic at Gulfstream Park last fall. Good for the game, as they say.
There have been other great rivalries that have distinguished various Derbies, such as the outstanding one between Affirmed and Alydar in 1978, but a great rivalry doesn't seem to be essential to public interest in the race. Often it's simply the presence in it of a horse who has captured the public's fancy. Secretariat went into the Derby as an odds-on favorite and demolished his rivals, and continued to receive correspondence from admirers until his death last October.
We all retain certain firmly rooted images from every Kentucky Derby, more than from any other Triple Crown race. From recent ones I recall, for instance, the way Bill Shoemaker rode Ferdinand like a cowboy, weaving recklessly through horses down the stretch to bring Whittingham his first Derby victory; the way a plodding outsider, Gato del Sol, suddenly exploded out of the pack to claim his moment of glory with an effort he was never able to repeat, and the way the big roan filly Winning Colors humbled her field, leading every step of the way over Churchill Downs's deep, tiring course, a performance that capped her career, and that she, too, was never able to duplicate.
An equine athlete, like a human one, will sometimes rise to a great occasion and accomplish feats quite beyond himself, like a chorister at the Met suddenly taking center stage to sound like Domingo. Nothing seems to bring this quality out in an animal like the Kentucky Derby.
This year, the 116th edition of the race has acquired a flavor all its own. Most of the best horses seemed to be in the East, but there was no outstanding athlete, and the contest was coming up as a typical scramble, with half a dozen major contenders on the boards, and a host of obscure candidates poised to swoop out of the wings. But over the last couple of months, the field seems to have shaken itself down to two major competitors, Summer Squall and Mister Frisky.
At first glance, there would seem to be some obvious parallels to last year. Summer Squall is royally bred, cost $300,000 as a yearling, and has done all of his racing in the East, having lost only once, in a sprint to a top speed horse and after a long layoff. Mister Frisky cost only $15,000, was sired by a cheap stallion, is undefeated and has been running in California lately.
There, however, the similarities end. Summer Squall is a small colt who was delayed in getting to the track this year by a bleeding episode and has been raced hard to get into condition. Mister Frisky has also been raced hard, a total of 16 times in his brief career, and has beaten no one, as horseplayers put it. Thirteen of his victories were registered in Puerto Rico, and his victories at Santa Anita were over second-raters in unimpressive times.
So although they have lost only one race between them, Summer Squall and Mister Frisky are still not considered dominant by the horsemen, and there will be at least several other animals in the field with a legitimate chance to win.
Among them will be a maiden named Pendleton Ridge, who ran a closing fourth in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct last Saturday, and whose trainer, Bobby Frankel, ought to know better. After all, the last maiden to run in a Derby was a nonentity named Great Redeemer, who finished a distant last in 1979.
Still, you never know. Broker's Tip was a maiden when he won in 1933, and before him two other maidens found themselves draped in roses in the winner's circle, Buchanan in 1884 and Sir Barton in 1919. That's the beauty of the Derby, and it's the main reason I'll be there this year, with a parimutuel ticket in my pocket and a dawning love affair in my heart.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE;
Trouble for Forte

 BODY:
He was a star basketball player and an acclaimed television sports executive, but things have changed for Chet Forte. The former high-scoring guard and playmaker for Columbia, who went on to receive nine Emmy Awards as a producer-director during his 25-year career with ABC, is now broke. He is also suffering from cancer and facing a series of Federal fraud and tax charges carrying penalties upon conviction of more than 70 years in prison and millions in fines.
Among other things, the 54-year-old Forte is charged with fraudulently obtaining $1.47 million in bank loans by overstating his net worth on applications.
At an initial hearing in Newark on Friday, Larry Lustberg, an assistant public defender, told the court that Forte was an unemployed compulsive gambler who had lost millions of dollars at Las Vegas, Nev., and Atlantic City casinos and was now being supported by his wife's family.
Forte, whose television credits include ''Monday Night Football'' and the 1968 and 1984 Summer Olympics, left ABC in 1987 to become an independent producer and director. He was an all-American at Columbia in 1957.
After the hearing, Forte was released on his own recognizance and told to find someone to post $500,000 bond for him by Tuesday. No arraignment date was set.(AP)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Daytona Gets V6 Power

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON

 BODY:
There was a time that I wanted a Dodge. No, that doesn't say it. I lusted after a Dodge. It was 1969 and the car was a Charger R/T hardtop, maybe the most beautiful Dodge ever built.
It was as quick as it was pretty, with a 440-cubic-inch Magnum V8 that put out 375 horsepower. It was quiet and comfortable and I still find that Coke-bottle shape pleasing. 
At the time, though, I was smitten with everything about the car, particularly after a test drive at the dealership.
I put my hot breath and my fingerprints on it and sort of jumped up and down. I worked out a budget and my wife said I could buy it. The bank looked at the budget and said I couldn't.
But even before that sad denouement, while I was still there demonstrating my long-term inability to dicker for an affordable price, I kept casting an eye at the star of the showroom. It was a Charger, too, but it was bright orange, with a long fiberglass nose and a sky-high spoiler on the trunk.
It was spectacular, a cousin of the Plymouth SuperBird, but nobody in his right mind would have driven such a vehicle. And, in truth, no one was expected to. Dodge was heavily involved in Nascar racing then, and the car, one of 505 that were built, was in the showroom solely so it could be raced as a ''production'' model.
It was, appropriately, the first Dodge Daytona.
The car lasted two years and the name didn't surface again until 1983, when Dodge's parent, Chrysler Corporation, showed up at the New York Automobile Show with a 1984 model based on the K-car platform.
In the intervening years, Dodge and Plymouth had pretty much abandoned racing. Formerly proud badges were applied to this or that econobox, many imported from Japan, and the accent went from Magnums to mileage. The Daytona, though, was built in America, and that was big news for a company struggling to survive on the backs of captive imports.
Daytona is still a domestic product, assembled in St. Louis, but it has been around for seven years now and it is long of tooth. In fact, the company gives a nod to that with 1990 literature that says Daytona is ''still an image leader.'' Dodge also hastens to point out that there is new power and a restyled interior.
The new power consists of a 2.2-liter four with variable nozzle turbocharging, and the 3-liter Mitsubishi V6 that was in the test car, a black ES model. The turbo now puts out 174 horsepower, 32 more than the 1984 Daytona, and the V6 pumps out a smooth 141 horses.
Back in 1984, the hatchback coupe left some things to be desired, but by 1987 almost all of the complaints had been answered. The Daytona was a very slick four-passenger front-wheel-drive automobile.
Unfortunately, the latest version is an example of change for change's sake, and the new interior is as bad as the original. The rim of the curving dash panel contains inset and contoured light switches, for example, and they are very hard to find in the dark.
Also, there are four of them, instead of the sensible single knob that used to work so well on every manufacturer's car. Another complaint regards the tiny and impossible horn buttons that flank the airbag in the center of the steering wheel. And then there is the turn-signal flipper, which has moved from the steering column to a less accessible position on the dash.
Seat adjustments are also a bit strange, although not as odd as the originals, which pumped up lumbar support with a squeeze bulb. Now, the seat's lumbar and wing controls are powered. But fore and aft adjustment remains a manual exercise.
The cloth-upholstered seats, buckets front and rear, are flat and offer little real support. As might be expected in a sporty coupe, there is not much room in back or anywhere else. The glove box is tiny, there is a console bin to hold cassettes, and the doors have map pockets that are two inches deep. And that's it.
Still, performance is what Daytona has always been about, and the V6's 141 horses move the 2,750-pound coupe from 0 to 60 in about nine seconds. You can keep track of that on a highly optimistic 140-m.p.h. speedometer, and the instruments include a 7,000-r.p.m. tachometer with a 6,000 redline.
The test car had an automatic transmission, but a five-speed is available for more fun, and the fair-to-middling zoom doesn't cost a lot in terms of gas. Economy is rated at 19 miles per gallon, city, and 27, highway.
In fact, if there is one thing to be said for the new Dodge Daytona, it is that the bottom line is a real surprise. Back in 1984, the base was $10,447, and today's sticker is barely more at $10,995. Unfortunately, options, including the V6 package at $2,415, add up quickly, and the as-tested price was $16,548.
That puts the car into some tough company. It might be that it's time for Dodge to come up with a new Charger.
