LENGTH: 2286 words

HEADLINE: A Troubled Transition for the Ansonia

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
AFTER a five-year struggle, the owners of the Ansonia Hotel, one of the city's architectural landmarks, have put forth a plan to convert the building into a condominium residence.
Of the 462 units in the ornate, turreted structure, which occupies the entire western blockfront of Broadway between 73d and 74th Streets, 50 are available to outside buyers for prices ranging from $101,000 for the smallest studio unit to $939,000 for a 2,700-square-foot apartment.
The conversion of the 86-year-old apartment hotel is possible now because of a settlement reached 15 months ago between the owners, Ansonia Associates, a consortium of three investment groups, and the building's largest tenant organization. The agreement resolved some of the bitter disputes over rent levels, repairs and improvements. For more than a decade the Ansonia's tenants, now split into two groups, have battled the owners over issues ranging from hazards like exposed wires and a leaky roof to the color scheme for new wallpaper in the corridors. 
''The Ansonia is a special place for many reasons,'' said Jesse Krasnow, one of the principals of Ansonia Associates, which has owned the building since 1978. ''People are passionate about it. So problems have been complicated by emotions on all sides.''
Ansonia Associates, which is three separate partnerships headed by Albert Schussler, Stanley Stahl and Mr. Krasnow's father, Herbert, is in the midst of a multimillion-dollar upgrading program for the building. The plans include renovating worn-out mechanical systems and restoring some of the special architectural features.
In many respects the Ansonia today is a faded beauty with both an illustrious and a troubled past. It was conceived and built at the turn of the century as a residential hotel catering to wealthy, part-time New Yorkers. Over the years it has been home to many luminaries, among them Enrico Caruso, Igor Stravinsky, Arturo Toscanini, Billie Burke, Sol Hurok and Babe Ruth.
Still a prized address in its Upper West Side neighborhood, it is now favored in particular by performing artists and music teachers because of the soundproofing nature of its thick walls and proximity to Lincoln Center. Dwarfed by modern residential towers to the south, the Ansonia nevertheless stands out on Broadway because of its lively facade of balconies and limestone figures topped by cupolas.
But these days it owes its notoriety as much to the historic animosity between tenants and owners as to its flamboyant Beaux-Arts design and the fame of its residents. Over the years, tenants have used rent strikes, suits and an unending stream of petitions to city and state housing agencies to protest deteriorating conditions.
ONE such suit, Ansonia Residents Association v. New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, resulted in a State Court of Appeals decision last November reaffirming the right of landlords to permanent rent increases for Major Capital Improvements. The tenants had argued that once landlords recover the costs of a capital improvement the increases allowed to pay for it should be removed.
For years the Ansonia had the fattest case file in Manhattan's housing court, where unresolved complaints await hearings. The State Division of Housing expects to make a determination soon on rent overcharge complaints and the building's former status as a residential hotel. The agency expects that once this issue is settled hundreds of other overcharge complaints can be resolved. Records also show 22 still outstanding Department of Buildings violations. According to a department spokesman, these range from minor repair work to failure to file plans for renovation work done in the building.
Last March, the ceiling in a pastry shop in one of the building's ground-floor retail spaces collapsed, killing one patron and injuring others. The ceiling, Buildings Department inspectors concluded, had been weakened by holes drilled to accommodate pipes and electrical lines for the store.
Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, said an investigation is under way - standard procedure in accidents that involve deaths - to determine if the collapse was a result of criminal negligence. Mr. McKelvey also said the office is looking into charges from some tenants that some tax abatements the owners took in connection with the building's J-51 status were inappropriate.
Despite the often bitter protests over conditions, tenant representatives acknowledge that by the time the current owners took over, greed and mismanagement by previous owners had put the structure in an extremely fragile state. Although the exterior remained basically intact, the interior had been robbed of many details and irreplaceable fixtures.
In many ways the struggles at the Ansonia exemplify the issues that contribute to some of the city's most vexing housing problems.
Many of the residents are there only because of the rent-regulation system. As is often the case in buildings that are as old and as large as the Ansonia, its regulated rents do not cover the costs of maintenance, let alone of modernizing improvements. Apartments there are under both rent control and rent stabilization and rents, as a result, vary from less than $100 to $3,350 a month. Thus it is probable that the Ansonia could never work as a profitable rental property.
It was not an apartment house but a grand hotel that the Ansonia's builder, William E. D. Stokes, had in mind when work began in 1899. To carry out his plan, Stokes, who owned a construction company and was responsible for many other residences in the neighborhood, brought from Paris the architect Paul E. M. DuBoy, who designed a huge residential hotel with 400 suites.
When it was completed in 1904 the Ansonia was, at 17 stories, one of the tallest residential structures in the world. It had nearly every luxury of its period, including two swimming pools, Turkish baths and restaurants decorated in the style of Louis XIV. The generosity of the design extended even to the corridors, which average 11 feet in width and have floor-to-ceiling windows.
Although built to a luxurious scale with elaborate layouts, few of the original apartments had full kitchens. Instead, the residents' meals were prepared in basement kitchens and then whisked by dumbwaiters to serving pantries in the apartments above.
Stokes, who lived in the building, was said to have kept animals on a rooftop garden and filled the lobby fountain with baby seals.
But this level of luxury for the Ansonia was short-lived. By the 1920's a transformation was under way to convert the hotel's suites to the needs of families of more modest means. Kitchens were added and many of the large suites were divided.
For the next several decades the Ansonia struggled to survive as operating costs outpaced rents. Today the building has a mix of apartments in bad repair, with falling plaster and worn wooden floors, and those that have been so lovingly restored and embellished by their occupants that they could be featured in the pages of glossy decorating magazines.
Within the Ansonia's high-ceilinged apartments are such original features as oval living and dining rooms, wood floors laid in herringbone designs, French windows with window seats, frosted-glass lighting fixtures and ornate wood and plaster moldings.
Ansonia Associates say they will put $9 million to $11 million into capital improvements and restoration to public areas and spend the money necessary to make promised repairs and improvements to some apartments. Their budget includes $4 million that will be put into a reserve fund once the conversion has been completed.
According to Mr. Krasnow of Ansonia Associates, completed work includes replacement of the flat roof and repairs to the mansard roof, upgrading of the wiring system, installation of storm windows, replacement of the switchboard with a computer-based internal telephone system and addition of a new boiler. In the last several years the storefront facades on the Broadway side have been restored in accordance with the requirements of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.
Work still to be completed includes installing ducts and fans in kitchens and bathrooms of 250 apartments to improve ventilation, adding kitchens to apartments that still do not have them, further upgrading the electrical distribution system, removing asbestos-contaminated material from all apartments and service areas, refurbishing elevator cabs, redecorating the lobby and sitting rooms and adding a roof deck.
Renovations done on apartments sold to outside buyers will include the installation of new bathrooms and kitchens, the refinishing of floors and the addition of new hardware designed to look like the original doorknobs.
AMONG the most ambitious components of the restoration plan is reconstructing the original main entrance on 73d Street. Work is currently under way to restore the ornate porte-cochere, which had been covered in one of the earlier modernization efforts.
The old entrance had arched windows and terra cotta tiles in its vaulted ceiling. Frank P. Farinella, the architect responsible for the restoration, said that in addition to repair work, lost portions of the architectural detailing will be recast and pieced together with the original work.
According to the owners' conversion plan filed in early February, Ansonia Associates will retain control of the building's retail spaces as well as the garage added in the early 80's in a space once occupied by Plato's Retreat, a nightclub catering to swingers.
IT is not possible to say how many residents will buy their apartments. They were presented with the sponsor's noneviction conversion plan late in February and have until May 29 the exclusive right to buy their units. The offer to the tenants is approximately 50 to 60 percent below the asking price for apartments to outside buyers. One 757-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment, for example, carries an insider price of $122,662 and is $293,000 for outside buyers.
The owners would have to sell about 5 percent of the units - or about 25 units to tenants - to fulfill the 15 percent requirement for a conversion plan to be accepted by the Attorney General's office.
The leadership of both tenant organizations say they are neither for nor against a conversion plan per se, but each has taken its own approach in response to the conversion initiative.
On the one hand, the Ansonia Tenants Association, which represents occupants in about two-thirds of the building, has held that the owners' push to convert offers the best leverage for negotiating any significant improvements and repairs.
But the Ansonia Tenants Coalition, comprising mainly tenants who opposed a 1980 settlement that ended a year-long rent strike, maintains that a conversion is premature as long as there are outstanding violations against the building. Thomas Soja, its president, said a key reason why he feels the conversion is inappropriate now is that he does not believe the owners' stated budget will cover the cost of needed repairs.
''The work done so far amounts to a Band-Aid approach,'' said Mr. Soja, ''when what is required is drastic surgery. The owners are talking about spending approximately $10 million for work, including the $4 million they have promised to put in a reserve fund. Our estimate is that this figure will not cover one-tenth of the problems that exist here.''
In response, Mr. Krasnow said the owners are spending more than legally required.
''The legal requirement is that we spend 3 precent of the value of the apartments' inside price,'' he said. ''That would be about $600,000 in improvements and $1.2 million in cash reserve. As it is we are putting forward over three times as much cash as we have to and doing eight times as much work.''
At one time the New York State Attorney General's office, which has jurisdiction over all proposed cooperative and condominium plans, required that violations be remedied before a plan could be accepted for filing. But landlords successfully challenged the agency's authority to set such policy, which is not part of the state's cooperative and condominium laws. As a result, sponsors are now required only to disclose outstanding violations in the conversion plan documents.
Andrew Hughes, the president of the Ansonia Tenants Association, which negotiated for more than four years before the conversion plan was completed, declined to be interviewed. Kent Karlsson, the group's attorney, said that the timetable provided in the agreement has not been followed.
''From our perspective,'' said Mr. Karlsson, ''work is not proceeding at the pace it should or under the conditions to which we agreed. Our survey indicates that more than half of the work that was supposed to be completed by now remains undone.''
Mr. Karlsson cited as an example the replacement of the roof. The owners said work on the roof has been completed but tenants say that some tenants are still subject to leaks in rainy weather.
FOR their part, the owners concede that some of the contractors working on the building have not met deadlines and add that they have had difficulty getting access to some apartments.
Mr. Krasnow, who characterizes his relationship with the tenants as a marriage that works rather than a romance, said:
''With a project this large and complicated, there are bound to be delays. But there is nothing in the way we have conducted ourselves to suggest that projects that have been scheduled won't be completed. We want to sell apartments here. It is in our interest to make the building the best it can be.''

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Queens Expansion;
T-Shirt Maker Chooses To Stay

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
The balloon over Robin's head in the latest products from the Bowe Industries factory in Middle Village, Queens, might carry the words: ''Holy logo, Batman, we're staying in New York!'' Indeed, after considering a move to the South, the owners of Bowe will remain in New York and expand their T-shirt factory as a result of a $4.1 million bond financing arranged by the city's Industrial Development Agency.
Believed to be the only T-shirt factory in the city, Bowe Industries has grown rapidly in recent years - production doubled last year alone - and will make more than 7 million T shirts this year. 
The co-owners, Daniel Barasch and Marek Kiyashka, were friends who started silk-screening distinctive T shirts by hand in 1973 as a part-time basement business and selling them to classmates at Stuyvesant High School. They incorporated in 1976 and opened a tiny factory in Forest Hills, then moved to a larger facility in Middle Village three years later.
In 1984, they began buying licensing rights allowing the use of film and television characters on their products. These have included characters from Saturday Night Live, the Honeymooners, Mighty Mouse, the California Raisins, Batman and - their biggest seller lately - the Simpsons.
Needing room to expand, the partners approached the Industrial Development Agency and, through the sale of the bonds, were able to buy a building at 70-10 74th Street at Cooper Avenue; it will be doubled in size, to 45,000 square feet, at a cost of $5 million and is expected to be finished in a year.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Noisy Air-Conditioner
Question: I live in an apartment building with casement-style windows. Under the living room window is a metal sill and frame that encase a radiator. The tenant above has a window air-conditioner; whenever the machine is on the window wall of my apartment vibrates. He says he has tried to soften the vibration with foam packing. With warm weather approaching I am searching for ways to rectify this problem. Do I have the right to insist that he or the management find a way to solve the problem or that he refrain from using the air-conditioner? . . . R. M., Brooklyn 
Answer: Yes. You are entitled to a peaceful living situation. ''The landlord of the building is required to provide 'quiet enjoyment' and to insure that there is no breach in the 'warranty of habitability','' said Ronald Sher, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters. ''The conditions described may very well constitute violations of these legal precepts.''
From a practical standpoint, you might suggest that your neighbor get in touch either with the person who installed the air-conditioner, to make sure it has been put in properly, or the manufacturer, who might be a source of information on the correct way to install it so vibration would be minimized.
 
Apartment Paint Job
Question: I own a building that has seven apartments, two of which are occupied by my family. One of our rent-controlled tenants who lived here many years before we bought the building has suddenly started complaining that we have not painted her apartment. She understood that the previous landlord did not include this service in the rent. Are we obligated now to paint her apartment? . . . M. L., Manhattan
Answer: Yes. The city's housing maintenance code requires that landlords paint apartments every three years, and the code supersedes the state's rules governing rent-controlled apartments. In rent-controlled situations, if a landlord did not provide a service as part of the original rental agreement, a new owner may not have to provide it later on. But, according to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the city's code takes precedence.
 
Condo Common Charge
Question: Can the board of a condominium approve a maintenance increase - over 20 percent - and order that the increase be retroactive to cover eight months of the previous fiscal year? . . . G. O., Hoboken, N.J.
Answer: Maybe. The board of managers' right to make such increases retroactive would depend on the terms of your association's declaration of condominium documents. But according to Douglas Kleine, director of research for the Community Associations Institute, it is an unusual tack.
''It sounds like the board was faced with an unexpected shortfall,'' said Mr. Kleine, ''and power is granted to a board of directors so it can respond to things that are unforeseen or uncontrollable. The typical response in such a case would be a one-time assessment for such unforeseen or unusual circumstances as a tough winter or an unexpected payment.''
Mr. Kleine said it would be awkward to administer such an increase. The association may not be made up of the same residents. ''How would it impact on owners who had moved,'' he said, ''or newcomers who were not even in the community eight months earlier?''
A retroactive increase would be more understandable, Mr. Kleine said, if it were instituted early in the condominium's existence because a sponsor had set the original operating budget too low. In that case the sponsor would have to share the burden of any maintenance increase.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Statistics Say It Too Well: All Our Children Need Our Support

BYLINE: By Laura Lee Simon; Laura Lee Simon is chairwoman of the Connecticut Commission on Children.

 BODY:
JUST a few weeks ago, I had the joyous experience of sitting in Yale-New Haven Hospital holding my newborn grandson in my arms. He was just 12 hours old, my fifth grandchild. I thought, how lucky this beautiful little boy is.
He is healthy - a strapping nine pounds - and he has two loving parents and a wonderful brother. His mother had the best in prenatal care, and he was delivered in a world-class hospital. He will be nurtured and safe and secure. He will be well nourished. When his parents are working, he will be in a superb early-child-care program. He will be eager and ready when it is time to go to school. And he will grow and thrive along with his brother. If only all the children in this nation and every child in every town and city in Connecticut - this richest state in the nation - could be assured of the same healthy start in life as my grandchild. 
The State Commission on Children knows that as mounting economic pressures have squeezed the middle class and budget cuts have worsened the plight of many poor people, childhood has become far more precarious and less safe for our children. In our collective experience, it is difficult to identify a time more fraught with peril for our children than now.
The complex problems facing our children as they grow up today are more difficult and changing faster than are our institutions, some of which are reeling under the burden of trying to respond.
We know only too well that reduced budgets and token commitments no longer hold the promise of ameliorating the stress borne by so many of our children and their families.
We know only too well that if we fail to pay adequate attention to the physical, emotional and educational needs of all of our children, everyone will pay dearly.
And still these problems remain:
* More than 90,000 children in Connecticut live in poverty - 11.8 percent of the children in our state. Every other child in Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport lives in poverty. Nearly half of this state's single-parent families live below the poverty line. Thousands of children suffer from poor health, crime-infested neighborhoods, school failure and premature parenthood.
* Approximately 25 percent of Connecticut's pregnant women do not get care until the third trimester.
* Some 10 percent of pregnant women are estimated to be in need of substance-abuse treatment. And 50 percent of pregnant women using the prenatal clinic at Yale-New Haven Hospital have used cocaine during pregnancy, potentially leading to the birth of severely damaged babies.
* Since 1980 the birth rate for girls under 15 has doubled and has increased by 29 percent for young women 15 to 19 years of age.
* Some 94,000 children in Connecticut live in families with no health insurance.
* In one New Haven neighborhood, 25 percent of families with children have serious hunger problems or are at risk of being hungry.
* Only 91 of the 245 schools designated ''severe need'' participate in the school breakfast program.
* Connecticut has the highest infant -mortality rate in New England and ranks 40th in the nation in low birth weight of nonwhite babies.
* About 18,400 citizens sleep in shelters for the homeless; 20 percent of them are employed. And 10 percent of families living in shelters have children under the age of 5.
* The average monthly rates for a two-bedroom apartment without utilities range from $485 in Naugatuck to $615 in Hartford and $1,150 in Stamford. Yet the maximum cash benefit for a single parent with two young children on Aid to Families with Dependent Children in Connecticut is between $534 and $623 a month.
* Among those eligible for nutrition services through the Women, Infants and Children program, 30 to 40 percent do not receive them. There are 4,000 women, 5,000 infants and 14,500 children between the age of 1 and 5 who are eligible to receive these services. For every dollar spent on the program, $3 is saved by reducing prematurity and low birth weight.
* Gun violence has become epidemic among children. Ten American children are killed every day in handgun suicides, homicides and accidents. Children are increasingly manifesting the trauma of such experience.
* Early-childhood services in Connecticut are meeting only a small percentage of the need. Head Start, a program that has proven lasting benefits, serves only one of five eligible youngsters.
* Last year, 20,233 children were referred to the Protective Services agency, about double the number in 1979. These figures do not reflect the number of cases that were not investigated despite reports of abuse or neglect. Caseload ratios in the state exceed national standards by 60 percent.
We are deeply concerned that these hard facts and more cast an alarming shadow over our future. But we know that this is a time of unprecedented opportunity. We are sustained in our efforts by the knowledge that within our reach are tested, truly effective preventive programs and remedies on which to base social policies that will assure a bright future for all our children.
We are heartened by the growing commitment among legislators to children's needs. Much is being done for Connecticut's children, but much more is called for in the light of contemporary concerns.
It is heartening to know that more than 160 organizations representing thousands of voters from all corners of our state have joined with the Commission on Children to form a Coalition for a Children's Platform. Together we support a child and family agenda that has been before our legislature and would address the unmet needs of Connecticut's children. It would promote improved delivery of services and substantial cost savings. If adopted, the agenda will bring in millions of previously unavailable Federal dollars to promote the healthy growth and development of our children.
Underscoring the importance of children's health, the agenda includes measures that will ease access to prenatal care, insure preventive pediatric care and increase the participation of pregnant women and children in essential nutrition programs. It includes support that will strengthen Head Start, increase participation in school breakfast programs and promote the development of early-childhood programs.
We recognize that we cannot afford to lose this generation to guns and drugs. Our agenda highlights comprehensive gun control and nonpunitive services for substance-abusing pregnant women. We also support measures to promote family strength and values and to help all parents - those who work and those who do not - to protect our most vulnerable children.
If we are all committed to equity, decency and a prosperous economy, we must generate the political will to support comprehensive, cost-effective policies that deal with our social deficits. Piecemeal approaches will no longer suffice.
Children's needs must be paramount, as policymakers deliberate about the legislation and budgets before them.
Our children can't vote or write editorials or make speeches or publish reports or meet with their legislators. We must speak with one voice on their behalf. Our responsibility is to translate our knowledge, our numbers and our concerns into public policy to assure our chidren's future and our own.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Is Overpopulation Too Grim a Tale?

BYLINE: By William A. Burley; William A. Burley, principal of the John Pettibone School in New Milford, is a member of the population committee of the Connecticut Sierra Club.

 BODY:
NO problem facing the earth looms larger than the growth in the reproductive rate of the human species. Virtually all degradation of the environment, all exhaustion of natural resources and substantial human suffering can be attributed to the crushing effect of a population that is too numerous for our planet.
The belief among many cultures that children are the equivalent of wealth is a bankrupt social and economic theory. In the last decade of the 20th century, fewer children mean a better life and a healthier environment. 
Consider pollution. It is but one strand in a Gordian knot involving industry, demand for consumer goods, petrochemical use, energy consumption and waste disposal. It knows no national or geographic boundries. Human effluence despoils the beaches of Cannes as well as those of Niantic. The skies are fouled with noxious gasses that haunt us in the form of health-harming particulates, acid rain and ozone depletion.
Increasing levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide contribute to global warming. Landfills spill over with toxic chemicals contaminating water supplies. Nuclear-waste stores are time bombs waiting to detonate.
Like it or not, the nations of the northern hemisphere must assume most responsibility for worldwide pollution. To a large degree, third world people suffer the consequences of first world gluttony.
What about the depletion of natural resources? All people shoulder some blame. The industrialized nations gobble more than their fair share of irreplaceable fossil fuels and mineral resources, but poorer nations, too, are guilty of clearcutting rain forests, overfishing the seas, stripping the hillsides for firewood and exhausting the soil. Perhaps the most valuable commodity of all, fresh water, is being reduced at an alarming rate. In short, the resources essential for sustaining life - food, clean water, energy, shelter and a safe environment - are in imminent peril of becoming eroded beyond repair.
The number of humans is astonishing. World population stands at 5.3 billion in 1990, and will double to 10 billion in 40 years. The earth's population is growing by 90 million a year, the equivalent of the entire population of Mexico.
Many nations, especially in Africa and Asia, are teetering on the edge of social collapse. Wholesale famine in these countries is probable in five years. Tens of millions will starve to death. The United States and other agriculturally rich nations will be unable to prevent starvation, since first world food-producing capabilities are stretched to the limits. In 1988 the United States had to import grain for the first time.
This is grim stuff at any age, so how can it be appropriate to teach to children? How will they react to information about the portent of cataclysmic events?
My experience is that children know something is fundamentally wrong with the world, and they are eager to listen to the message. They do not suffer undo emotional stress. For one thing, they know about pollution, recycling and conservation. They're involved with these activities when they attend Scout meetings or eat at McDonald's. The news is full of stories about toxic hazards, polluted water sources and medical wastes on beaches. They know about global warming and the destruction of the rain forests.
What they don't know are the facts about the other side of the ecology equation, the burgeoning human population. And without a grasp of the details, their knowledge of conservation is only half an education.
What are reasonable things to teach children about the population explosion? First, tell them the numbers, but equate the numbers with more concrete concepts. For example, the population of the United States is growing every year by 2.5 million people, roughly the number of people in Connecticut.
Next, tie population growth to environmental issues. Discuss acid rain and global warming. Talk about the local landfill. Guide them to see that the earth cannot withstand mistreatment by hoards of people. And show them how the American life style is particularly damaging to the environment.
Finally, offer suggestions about how they can become involved and make a difference. Discuss taking political action. Encourage them to write letters to state and Federal legislators asking that they sponsor a bill calling for a national policy on population reduction.
Give them bibliographies of appropriate readings. Provide names and address of organizations working on conservation and population issues. And counsel them that they can make a difference, but they will face some difficult choices in their lives about family planning and consumer habits.
Should we teach children about the population problem? The real question ought to be: can we afford not to educate our young about the realities of their future?

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 1, Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1513 words

HEADLINE: Big Project in Sound Arouses Concern

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
A DESERTED island in Long Island Sound just off the New Rochelle coastline is the focus of a bitter dispute over a proposal to build a $1 billion residential community for 3,700 people.
The David's Island project, the largest ever proposed for Long Island Sound, has pitted development advocates in New Rochelle, an economically stagnant city of 69,000, against environmentalists in nearby communities on both sides of the water. They say that massive building on the island, once the home of Fort Slocum, will turn the already fragile waters of the western part of the Sound into a ''Dead Sea.''
Robert Funicello, president of the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, one of the environmental groups opposed to the project, said ''there are portions of Long Island that are closer to David's Island than parts of New Rochelle,'' noting that Sands Point is only 1.9 miles away.
 
Georgraphy Issue Cited
He added that water quality and the visual qualities of the western Sound would be severely affected by the David's Island project. 
Karen Sesky Propper, a member of the New Rochelle Board of Education for the last 11 years, disagreed. ''There will be no adverse effect on anybody,'' she said. ''The problems of Long Island Sound predate David's Island by about 70 years.
''This project isn't going to add to those problems, and they are problems we shouldn't be blamed for. This project is not a luxury, it's a necessity.''
As advocates for both sides assembled in New Rochelle last week to testify before a joint hearing of the state's Department of State and its Department of Environmental Conservation, the issue was clear:
Can New Rochelle exercise the right to determine its own future or are those coastal development rights limited in a world with no environmental borders?
Advocates of the plan, including a coalition of school, government and business leaders, insisted at the hearings that they were supporting a project that would not harm the Sound. In addition, they said, it will provide a desperately needed, $26 million-a-year boost to the New Rochelle economy, plus 2,000 constuction jobs and a long-awaited stimulus to restore the city's decaying downtown.
The project proposed for the 78-acre former Army post includes 1,750 condominium units, many of which would be in 31-story towers visible on a clear day to residents of Long Island's North Shore; a marina with 800 slips, a heliport and a private bridge to the Westchester County mainland, two-thirds of a mile away.
Xanadu Properties Associates, the proposed developer of Davids Island, is an international partnership of real estate developers and builders that includes Bruce C. Stark, the largest real-estate developer in Hawaii; Gordon Marshall, a New York real estate lawyer and developer; and three Japanese corporations, Kawasaki Steel, Aoki and Kumagai Gumi. The Japanese concerns have provided $10.5 million of the $17.2 million invested in the project so far. ''We're ready to build immediately,'' Mr. Marshall said.
 
Sewage-Treatment Plant Promised
Xanadu plans to build a tertiary sewage-treatment plant on the island that would remove 90 percent of the harmful nutrients and the estimated 500,000 to 700,000 gallons of treated effluent discharged into the Sound each day.
The New Rochelle City Council will require the developer to build such a plant, and Xanadu has agreed to do so if unable to use the existing county-owned facility in New Rochelle.
If, however, a state moratorium on the existing New Rochelle plant is lifted, the David's Island developer would prefer to use the existing plant, which provides secondary treatment only.
The overall project, its supporters say, has been given a ''clean bill of environmental health'' by the Coast Guard.
However, the release of the final environmental statement, which was prepared by the developer, does not constitute approval of the project, both Coast Guard and state authorities said. Questions of public access, building height and density and water quality issues must be addressed by the relevant state agencies before permits for the project can be issued.
New Rochelle development advocates believe that the proposed project for David's Island, which many consider a deteriorated blot on the coastal landscape, will enable their self-appointed ''Queen City of the Sound'' to live up to its billing.
Economic salvation has been long in coming. Despite the success of some commercial developments, including recent approval of a $30 million expansion of the New Rochelle Mall, assessment rolls have increased by only 1 percent in the last decade. The school tax bill has been increasing rapidly and a loss in state aid has added to the city's financial burdens.
 
Quality of Water Cited
Elly Doctorow, who served on the New Rochelle City Council for 12 years and is a sister of the writer E. L. Doctorow, is a strong supporter of the David's Island project. She has a summer home in Sag Harbor. She believes the project has ''passed environmental muster,'' adding: ''It costs money to run a city, and New Rochelle is a city with financial needs. All we are trying to do is solve our own problems.''
Opponents of the project have made it clear that they have little sympathy for a solution that may be good for New Rochelle, but that they consider an environmental disaster for a body of water already filled with sluggish or dead fish.
''David's Island will be very bad for fishing interests on Long Island,'' said Kathryn Clarke, president of the Long Island Sound Task Force.
This Stamford-based organization is directing public education for the Long Island Sound Study, a six-year, federally sponsored research project to develop a plan to clean up the Sound with support from New York and Connecticut.
The project constitutes what Ms. Clarke called ''a direct threat to the livelihood of anyone who earns a living from the marine resources of Long Island sound.''
Researchers, Ms. Clarke said, have documented growing evidence of hypoxia, or oxygen depletion, occurring in the western portion of the Sound as a result of ''nutrient loading'' from treated sewage flowing into the water at the rate of more than a billion gallons a day.
Oxygen levels were so low in l987 and again last summer, she said, that fish life essentially ceased. New information from the Long Island Sound Study indicates that the major hypoxia ''hot spot'' is in an area almost midway between David's Island and Hempstead Harbor, Ms. Clarke said.
A coalition of national and regional environmental groups, including the National Audobon Society, the National Resources Defense Council and the Long Island Sound Task Force recently agreed to join the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County and a group of citizens opposing the project.
Long Island residents who testified at the the public hearing last week, or who submitted written opinions, were unanimous in their opposition to the David's Island project, which the Long Island Regional Planning Board has said would lead to ''the further degradation of water quality in a severely stressed portion of the Sound'' and would harm outdoor recreation opportunities.
The board also contends that the buildings and bridge would be ''totally out of scale with the environment in which they would be located.''
''A project of that size is certainly a concern to us,'' said Ralph J. Naranjo, president of Friends of the Bay, a l,500-member organization fighting development of the Oyster Bay waterfront. The group has submitted testimony opposing the David's Island project.
''We are a microcosm of David's Island,'' Mr. Naranjo said, describing his organization's efforts to prevent the construction of a series of condominiums and hotels proposed for the Oyster Bay harbor area and that its members believe would pollute the North Shore's only remaining oyster beds.
They oppose the David's Island project, Mr. Naranjo said, because it would add more nitrogen to the water, reducing dangerously low oxygen levels still further.
He called the project ''grossly in accord with today's overdevelopment theme,'' but completely contrary to the state's Coastal Zone Management Plan to protect the shoreline.
The public hearings, the last in a series that have been held over the nearly 10-year debate regarding the project, precede a final state study that will determine whether the project will be built.
The Department of State must now determine if the project meets the 44 conditions of its Coastal Zone Management Plan, the nine-year-old document that governs the environmental protection of the state's coastline, and the Department of Environmental Conservation must decide if the plan meets its requirements.
''Is the Department of State going to administer the Coastal Zone Management Plan?'' Mr. Funicello asked. ''Will the Department of Environmental Conservation protect water quality or is this a massive paper-shuffling sham? Are we going to protect Long Island Sound or are we just going to talk about it?''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Life in a Borderless Greenback Empire

BYLINE: By KENICHI OHMAE

 BODY:
The following is an excerpt from ''The Borderless World: Power and Strategy in the Interlinked Economy,'' to be published in August by Harper Business, a division of HarperCollins Inc. Kenichi Ohmae is managing director of McKinsey & Company's Tokyo office.
 
We can all recite the litany. The United States has a serious and, apparently, structurally irremovable trade deficit with several of its major trading partners, especially Japan. For an economy so powerful, export levels for many categories of products are embarrassingly low. No wonder the dollar has fallen to such dismal levels. The only surprise is that it has not gone lower. 
Even so, a formal policy of keeping the dollar weak does not make sense when you consider that in currency-related terms, the United States enjoys a unique position in the world. Because almost all of its trade transactions are dollar-based, the United States has in effect extended its domestic economy across national borders, creating in the process a huge ''greenback empire.'' For Americans, it makes little ultimate difference to their national indebtedness whether they buy oranges from California or television sets from Taiwan. Both amount to much the same thing. Americans in New York don't worry about running up a trade deficit with California. They don't need to worry about Taiwan either.
The dollar is the internationally accepted currency of trade settlement. In fact, it is virtually the only currency the United States uses to settle its external trade.
Other countries have to earn and save dollars one way or another and have to maintain these dollar-based reserves to pay for their various imports. If these countries run out of dollars and cannot borrow them somewhere, they cannot purchase the critical resources they need or the luxuries they want.
But this does not apply to the United States itself. The United States has - or can print - all the dollars it wants. To America's trading partners, this feels like being swallowed up in a single, immense dollar-based empire - which is, in currency terms, merely an extension of the American domestic economy. Simply stated, the United States has no foreign trade. There are plenty of reasons to worry about the health of the domestic economy, but statistical trade balances are not among them.
For the Japanese, the dollars earned by exporting to the United States are less like money to be put in the bank than a promissory note to buy American goods in the future. On the way back, the dollars may well make a detour though the Middle East, where the Japanese need them to pay for oil. Or they may go back home via the London market. Whatever route they take, the point is that they do not stay in Japan. We in Japan would like to be able to treat the yen the same way the United States treats the dollar and deal with all other nations in yen. We would like to trade places with the United States. We cannot, at least not now. But if the dollar continues to decline for the wrong and artificial reason reflecting erroneous political and macroeconomic perceptions, America's trading partners will stop accepting dollars for the goods and services they sell to Americans. At that point, America becomes a Brazil. Why should the United States give up unecessarily the advantage that it now enjoys?
With so many dollars in the hands of other countries, is the United States vulnerable should circumstances prompt these investors to unload? If the American economy really does go sour, all smart money will flee - American money too. When Houston's oil-based economy went into a steep decline a few years back, it was not just the foreigners who pulled out. Americans did too, and just as fast. Money is money. It's the most purely rational thing there is. Foreign capital is in the United States because it is attractive for capital to be there. When that stops being the case, it will go away in a hurry.

HEADLINE: Future Role Still Unwritten For Theater Saved by State

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SEVEN years after the state took over the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, it still has no long-range artistic mission - and no short-range schedule of performances. The managers of the American Festival Theater, as its is now known, are struggling to assemble a brief summer season. But they say they are trying to avoid the problems they encountered last summer, when they hastily reopened the theater for six weeks.
''We're working very hard to put together a season of some sort,'' said Mark L. Schneider, the theater's acting executive director. ''There are no contracts signed yet, but we hope to put together a series of summer concerts and perhaps a fall show schedule for students.''
The theater needs extensive renovations, however, and even after five years of planning, the state is still not ready to seek bids for the work. 
Mr. Schneider, an executive on loan from the International Business Machines Corporation in Stamford, said the earliest he expects a full year-round schedule would be the 1991-92 season.
In 1983, the state bought the bankrupt nonprofit theater and its 11.4 parklike acres of woods, marsh and lawns along the Housatonic River just north of Long Island Sound. The purchase encouraged optimism, but since then, some state residents have accused officials of walking what Shakespeare called a ''primrose path of dalliance.''
''If it was privately owned, the project might be on a different schedule,'' acknowledged Arthur J. Hedge Jr., an I.B.M. vice president who has headed the theater's advisory board since he was appointed by Gov. William A. O'Neill in 1983. ''But there's a set of practices and procedures that have to be followed, because this is a state project. And I think the board is sympathetic to that.'' Mr. Hedge said the board was pleased with the level of community support - more than $700,000 was raised from ticket sales and donations during last year's six-week season, when the theater presented a San Francisco troupe's productions of ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' and ''Saint Joan'' as well as two weeks of concerts by the singer and pianist Michael Feinstein and a one-man reading of ''The Tempest'' - the only Shakespearean words to be heard in the hall since 1982.
Mr. Hedge said he was confident that with design work nearly done, construction could get under way by next year at the latest.
At the State Department of Environmental Protection, which now owns the theater, a program supervisor, Jeanne L. Shelburne, said, ''This whole type of park is a pretty dramatic departure from what we normally manage.'' The department normally runs swimming, hiking or fishing areas, she said, not cultural centers.
''And we've had some unfortunate occurences lately,'' Ms. Shelburne said. The park manager retired last year, as many senior state employees accepted the early retirement package offered as an economy move, she said, and staff shortages have plagued the D.E.P.'s regional office.
The state's fiscal constraints meant that a major renovation plan had to be scaled back significantly. ''The original proposal was really out of line with the resources we had available,'' Ms. Shelburne said. It suggested, among other things, construction of a second theater on the grounds.
The Bureau of Public Works is now preparing a renovation proposal that would include reconfiguring the seating to improve sight lines, slightly reducing the number of seats from the original 1,477. The work is also expected to include fire code repairs, some landscaping improvements and renovation of the lobby.
''Really, what we'll be doing is refurbishing the theater so it will be useable,'' Ms. Shelburne said. ''We're hoping to get into construction within a year.''
Mr. Hedge said that while the project might not be moving forward as quickly as some would like, the state is putting up all the money, ''and nobody ever wants to have construction projects take as long as they do.''
 
History of Triumph
The theater was also promised some support last year from the Town of Stratford, Mr. Schneider said. But that was before cutbacks in state funds affected every town in the state.
''With the budget crisis, they weren't able to do what they had hoped to do, and what we were hoping for,'' Mr. Schneider said.
The theater's history was not always so tragic. Katharine Hepburn, Jack Palance, Raymond Massey and other internationally known stars trod the stage of the gray teakwood building that opened in 1955 solely for the presentation of Shakespearean plays. Several of the theater's productions went on to Broadway, including the 1982 ''Othello'' starring James Earl Jones and Christopher Plummer.
More than three million people, most of them from New York, attended the Stratford performances, bringing an estimated $1.5 million a year in tourist revenues to the town. But the theater always depended more upon private benefactors than box-office receipts to stay afloat.
As donations became harder to attract and time took its toll on the building that had been designed after Shakespeare's own Globe Theater in England, the theater went bankrupt in 1981 and closed with a production of ''Hamlet'' in 1982.
At the time the theater changed hands, state officials said they hoped it would resume a full production schedule within a couple of years. But the closest it has come was last year's six-week run.
The delay in reopening the theater has left Fairfield County without use of the theater.
And theatergoers have apparently found other outlets.
 
'Audience Is There'
''Almost a third of our audience comes up from Fairfield County,'' said David Mayhew, a spokesman for the Long Wharf Theater, in New Haven. The city is also home to the Yale Repertory Theater.
Mr. Mayhew said that Long Wharf's 1989-90 subscriptions fell just 20 short of the 18,343 record of the 1987-88 and that the recent Long Wharf production of ''The Crucible'' broke all attendance records.
Other theaters have survived by developing a varied program. The Shubert, also in New Haven, has seen its subscription base grow to 12,000 from 1,400 five years ago, said a theater spokesman, Morton Langbord. ''Beyond subscriptions, each show is supported well,'' he said. Mr. Mayhew agreed that ''the audience is there.'' ''I think Fairfield County would easily support a regional theater,'' he said.
Mr. Mayhew noted that the four major regional theaters that have survived in Connecticut - Long Wharf, Yale Repertory, Hartford Stage Company and the Goodspeed Opera House - are all about 25 years old. The Shakespeare Theater's age has been one of the reasons given for its problems; after 35 years, it was in need of a massive infusion of cash for long-delayed building maintenance.
 
English Namesake
A $74,000 grant the year after the state took it over went for a new roof, and $100,000 worth of work prior to last year's short season went largely for rigging, lights, a sound system and electrical work.
Last year's season was planned to honor Stratford's 350th anniversary. (The town, named for Shakespeare's home in England, was purportedly founded by a friend of the playwright's family.) But when the theater reopened, the air conditioning system failed, resulting in heat so intense the lead actor in one of the productions fainted.
Mr. Hedge said he hoped to ''keep something happening at the theater,'' but not if it is going to result in problems like that.
Last year's brief season ''was supposed to be a statement that the theater was back,'' Mr. Schneider said. ''And we really rushed it a little.''
This year, he said, there will be no rushing. ''We don't want to ruin our reputation.''
Theater consultants from New York have recommended a phased renovation over several years at a cost of $15 million to $20 million, Ms. Shelburne said. But the Department of Environmental Protection, with its own budget problems, is planning a more modest $4 million to $5 million makeover.
Even once the work is done, however, the theater will probably not return to its heritage.
''To build any kind of theater, you're talking about a number of years, probably more than three, before you build up a large enough subscription base,'' Mr. Schneider said, ''although a lot of that is going to depend on how well the productions are received by the public. And I don't think we're going to be able to do it with a schedule that's all Shakespeare.''

LENGTH: 1666 words

HEADLINE: Optimistic Forecast For Shore

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

DATELINE: BELMAR

 BODY:
LOCAL and state tourism officials, real-estate agents and merchants say they are expecting a better summer season at the Jersey Shore this year than last year.
The optimism, they say, is based on an estimated increase in preseason rentals - 20 percent or more above last year's at this time; an earlier effort at cleaning beaches, the offering of better vacation packages and a trend of vacationing closer to home.
''We have plenty of rentals left,'' said Roy Childers, a real-estate agent and tourism promoter from Lavallette. ''But many of our prime properties have been rented already, which is a very good sign.''
Mr. Childers and others said the optimistic outlook for a successful summer was in part attributable to rental costs that have been stabilized in order to lure back vacationers who stopped coming because of reports of coastal pollution, and to new marketing efforts that feature a variety of Shore vacation packages and attractions. 
Nevertheless, most agreed in recent interviews that it would be difficult to produce the banner season that was predicted as early as March by George Zoffinger, the Commissioner of the state's Department of Commerce, Energy and Economic Development. The last banner season was in 1986, real-estate agents and merchants say.
State environmental and tourism officials say the economic decline in beachfront and related businesses that occurred in Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May Counties in 1987 and 1988 ran as high as 30 to 60 percent each year in some communities. Polluted surf waters and debris-cluttered beaches were blamed for sporadic beach closings.
Although state officials say there has never been a valid economic study of Shore tourism, the downward spiral in the Shore economy has seen more than a billion in tourist dollars lost since 1986, according to the state's Division of Travel and Tourism. Modest increases in revenue last year renewed hope for some, and this year real-estate agents have told Mr. Zoffinger that the general downward turn in the economy will lend an even greater boost to tourism as savings-minded consumers look to the cheapest and closest vacation spot - the Jersey Shore.
Boardwalk arcade owners and tour bookers confirmed that things were looking up for the summer. Michael Dinnebeil, manager of arcades and amusements for Jenkinson's South in Point Pleasant Beach, said that when the weather was good in the last month the crowds were heavy, an indicator, he said, of a good summer to come.
''The signs are good for a strong year,'' he said, adding that so far there have not been the usual reports of ocean pollution or predictions about beach closings.
Denise Putlock, the manager of group sales for Casino Pier and Waterworks in Seaside Heights, said tour bookings were up over last year's. The tourists come mostly from northern New Jersey and Staten Island, and Ms. Putlock said that increases this year had resulted from ''a lot of marketing over the winter,'' including Casino Pier and Waterworks' participation in tourism trade shows.
''It has begun to pay off,'' she said.
 
'If the Weather Is Good'
As always, the proof of a successful summer is to be found in warm, sunny weather, inviting water temperatures and the absence of beach closings. ''If the weather is good and the ocean is good, we will have a good summer,'' said Maria G. Hernandez, the Mayor of Belmar, adding that ''all you need is something like an oil spill, a bunch of hypodermic needles on your beach or a lot of rain and your season is shot.''
Summer rentals in Belmar are up over last year, Mrs. Hernandez said, and the population of this Monmouth County community, 6,200 people, can easily soar to 60,000 on a good weekend.
Roy Childers, a real-estate agent with offices in Normandy Beach, Lavallette and Ortley Beach in Ocean County, said that renters this year included many who had tried beaches in Maryland or Virginia last year but returned to their ''traditional'' vacation spots.
''They tell us that they found that the drive was too long,'' he said, ''and that these other beaches do not have the attractions and facilities that New Jersey has.'' He estimated that summer rentals were up almost 20 percent.
The Anderson Agency in Long Beach Township on Long Beach Island also estimates a 20 percent increase in rentals. There, Larry Peacock, an agent, said business was brisk, with just over 60 percent of available rentals taken so far.
''The season is shaping up pretty well,'' Mr. Peacock said. ''It is going to be a better summer than the last two, no doubt about that.''
Rentals in Cape May and Wildwood have increased over last year's, too, said Richard J. Cammarano, president-elect of the Cape May County/Greater Wildwood Board of Realtors in Lower Township.
 
A Decrease in Rents
Paul Rosengren, a spokesman for the Commerce Department, said a contributing factor in this year's positive rental climate had been a decrease in rents because so many properties had gone unoccupied in the last three years.
''A downward trend in Shore vacation rentals was occurring before the pollution incidents,'' he said. ''Rental prices had skyrocketed, and taking a vacation at the Shore was on a par, costwise, with more exotic vacations on tropical islands. The pollution shock brought prices back down to where they are affordable.''
David Wyrsch, a broker with the Van Dyk Group, a real-estate concern in Long Beach Township, said that rental prices had gone up dramatically each year from 1985 to 1987, but that they have remained relatively stable since then. He said, for example, that the cost of a two-bedroom house or apartment away from the oceanfront, which rented in 1987 for $500 to $800 a week, had changed very little.
''We really have not recommended that our rental owners raise their rates for the last two years or so,'' he said.
 
Economic Surveys Assessed
Asked about the credibility of the economic impact surveys that had been commissioned by the Division of Travel and Tourism since 1987 to gauge the economy of the Shore, Mr. Rosengren acknowledged that the conclusions the surveys reached were not based on accurate information.
''These are not real scientific data,'' he said. ''You have got to take these extrapolatory studies with a grain of salt. It is important to see over time how some things change in the Shore economy, where people are going to vacation, for example. Directional changes can have significance and make the surveys worthwhile, even if we can't be sure of the magnitude of the change.''
Mr. Rosengren and Mr. Childers admitted that the tourism surveys were not true measures of the actual beach-based economy because all the casino revenues and visitors to Atlantic City were lumped together with the rest of the Shore statistics.
''The state does not provide the county-by-county and month-by-month breakdown of the New Jersey state sales tax, so anybody can say anything they want about the Shore economy and get away with it,'' Mr. Childers said. Without such a breakdown, he said, ''it is impossible to report losses or gains.''
Nonetheless, Mr. Childers and others are encouraged by the preseason rentals this year and what they said was a greater cause for optimism concerning clean beaches.
 
Cleanup Programs Continued
Eric Evenson, acting director of the State Department of Environmental Protection's Division of Water Resources, said that two successful programs put in place last year to clean up plastics, wood and other floatables were being continued this season.
One of the programs, Operation Clean Shores, used prison inmates last year to remove 5.9 million pounds of debris from New Jersey beaches. Mr. Evenson said the $1 million program had received an additional $500,000 this year to include river and bay shorelines in northern Monmouth County.
The debris can include medical and other wastes from New York and New Jersey harbor areas and wood from dilapidated piers or sunken barges in northern New Jersey and New York, he said. That kind of debris is monitored from above by a special helicopter that alerts state-leased fishing boats with special scoop nets and collection vessels maintained by the Army Corps of Engineers as floatables are spotted in the New York Harbor area or are heading toward a New Jersey beach. The floatables are skimmed from the surface and disposed of legally.
Mr. Evenson and others in the department said that the health danger of the state's bathing waters had been grossly exaggerated in 1987 and 1988 and that 1989, in fact, had fewer beach closings, 12, than any of the last several years.
The state's surf and offshore waters are tested for bacterial content once or twice a week by a combination of local health officers and officials of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Mr. Evenson said. The testing is more thorough than in most states, he said.
 
Assurance on Beach Safety
''When you go to a beach in New Jersey,'' he said, ''you are assured that it is safe. If it is not safe, all the regional agencies will see that it is closed, so there is not that much reason for concern. Most other states can't say that.''
The percentage of beach closings along the 127-mile oceanfront of New Jersey is ''very small,'' Mr. Evenson said.
Local tourism officials and environmental groups have held numerous Shore community cleanup activities. They began in the middle of this month and were scheduled to culminate yesterday in the New Jersey Marathon/Trash-a-thon, a statewide program of festivities at Island Beach State Park including a massive beach cleanup by participants.
William DeCamp Jr., president of the Ocean County chapter of the Izaak Walton League, said that clean ocean water and the public's perception of it were often two different things.
''Shore tourism is closely related to people's perception of water quality,'' he said, ''and most people's perception of it only remotely corresponds to reality.''

PUB-DATE: April 30, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 967 words

HEADLINE: After 15 Years, Thieu and Ky Offer To Help Bring Down Hanoi's Rule

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 29

 BODY:
Fifteen years after the fall of Saigon, the two most prominent former leaders of South Vietnam - Nguyen Van Thieu and Nguyen Cao Ky - are becoming active again, seeking to find a role for themselves in the future of the country they fled.
Encouraged by the fall of Communist governments in Eastern Europe, they have recently begun touring the United States, Europe and Asia, seeking to build a personal following as they agitate for changes in Vietnam.
Their activities have raised eyebrows among some overseas Vietnamese, who question the credibility of the leaders of the failed Saigon Government.
In separate interviews last week on the eve of the April 30 anniversary of the fall of Saigon, the two men, like seasoned politicians, denied personal ambitions but offered themselves to help rebuild a post-Communist Vietnam. 
The two former political rivals, who now live in the United States, were reached by telephone during their separate travels, Mr. Thieu in Paris and Mr. Ky in Bangkok, Thailand. They made it clear that for them, the Vietnam War is still not over.
''The whole people of Vietnam are ready to stand up against the oppressor and to launch a national revolution,'' said Mr. Thieu, 66 years old, who was President of South Vietnam during its final years and who now lives mostly in Boston. ''I am ready to participate with them in the struggle by any means available.''
He said that if that struggle became violent, he stood ready to offer whatever support he could.
 
Ky Sees 'Final Victory'
Mr. Ky, 60, a former Prime Minister and Vice President who now lives in Westminster, Calif., said, ''With all the changes in Eastern Europe and even in Soviet Russia, we now have more hope, more confidence that soon the Vietnamese Communists will have to accept change.
''I think Americans and Vietnamese can achieve today what we could not achieve during the Vietnam War: a final victory over the Communists,'' he said.
Among overseas Vietnamese who sounded a skeptical note was Dam Phuong Tran, who heads a private group in Washington called the Committee for Human Rights in Vietnam. ''When they were in power, all that money and all those armed forces poured in from this country, and they failed,'' she said. ''What do they think they can do now?''
Both men said they were operating on their own as they re-entered public life, and there was no sign that they were receiving encouragement or support from Washington.
''Is there a buck to be made in Vietnam? That is one possible objective,'' said Douglas Pike, director of Indochina studies at the University of California at Berkeley. ''Another objective could be a maneuvering for what you might call the leadership, the eminence grise, or emperor of Vietnamese abroad.''
Until recently, both Mr. Thieu and Mr. Ky led relatively quiet lives while the highly factionalized and sometimes violent world of Vietnamese emigre politics swirled around them.
After first fleeing to Taiwan, Mr. Thieu lived for many years in London, rarely speaking or appearing in public. His higher profile began only in recent months after he moved last year to join family members in Boston.
His supporters would say little about his activities or his means of support during his years abroad.
Mr. Ky, who said he saw his future role in Vietnam as helping to rebuild the economy, has not found economic success in the United States.
He owned a liquor store from 1977 to 1984, when he declared bankruptcy, and subsequently failed in a shrimp fishing venture in Louisiana. He now lives with a sister in the Vietnamese community in Westminster, near Los Angeles.
In 1984 the columnist Jack Anderson accused him of being involved in Vietnamese criminal gangs in the United States. Mr. Ky heatedly denied the accusation.
The former fighter pilot has been somewhat more politically active than Mr. Thieu, particularly among Vietnamese war veterans. He drew attention a year ago when he called for political and economic pressure on the Hanoi Government, saying the time for armed resistance by guerrilla groups had passed.
That position, which Mr. Thieu now also voices, has in the past prompted violent attacks and even some killings by hard-line Vietnamese emigres who oppose any contacts with the Communist Government.
Doan Van Thoai, a writer and political speaker, was shot and badly wounded in Fresno last August after voicing a similar position. In an interview last month, he said changes in the Communist world and growing cynicism among overseas Vietnamese had led men like Mr. Thieu and Mr. Ky to shift toward his more moderate stand.
Referring to events in Eastern Europe, Nepal and Mongolia, Mr. Thieu described a number of factors that he argued could touch off an uprising in Vietnam, including divisions in the Communist Party and the military and tensions between officials from the northern and southern parts of the country.
''I would like to say that sooner or later there will be an explosion,'' he said.
''I have no political ambition,'' Mr. Thieu said. ''I only want to participate, to do the best I can do to support the movement for democracy and freedom inside Vietnam.''
He said he was determined to return home, possibly even before a change of government.
Mr. Ky, rather than speaking of an uprising, said he advocated diplomatic and economic pressure to force changes by the Hanoi Government.
''The Government is corrupt,'' he said. ''The people are unhappy. They are going out begging for economic aid from the so-called capitalist countries, and my idea is to use that kind of pressure to make changes in Vietnam.''
''As for my personal role, I would like to do something to help in the eocnomic field,'' Mr. Ky continued. ''I am 100 percent sure I will not be involved in politics in Vietnam.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
East German, in Moscow, Calls for Changes in NATO

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 29

 BODY:
East Germany's new Prime Minister called for changes in the ''structure and strategy'' of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev reiterated the Soviet Union's opposition to a united Germany's belonging to NATO.
In his first Kremlin visit since taking office two weeks ago, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany said he and Mr. Gorbachev had ''differences of opinion'' about potential NATO membership for a reunited Germany.
But the Prime Minister expressed optimism that progress on the issue might be possible at the coming negotiations on German unification to be held by the foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the four wartime Allies: the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France.
After Mr. de Maiziere left here following his daylong Kremlin visit, Mr. Gorbachev was quoted on national television as declaring, ''The Soviet Union's attitude toward unilateral, unbalanced proposals of the entry of a future German state into NATO remains negative.'' 
 
Wants 2 Issues Synchronized
At the same time, Mr. Gorbachev stressed his existing position urging a ''synchronization'' of the two issues of German unity and the search for future security structures in Europe.
Within this position, however, the Kremlin previously indicated some flexibility on the unification issue. In a White House visit this month, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze signaled that Moscow was prepared to drop its demand that a unified Germany be neutral. Mr. Shevardnadze confirmed this in an interview Saturday with The Irish Times.
Mr. Shevardnadze had said in his Washington visit April 6 that Moscow was open to any number of proposed pan-European security structures, and even to the idea that a united Germany could belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
In opposing simple NATO membership, Mr. Gorbachev previously had called for radical changes in the roles of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, placing greater emphasis on political and economic missions now that European disarmament was an ongoing process.
 
Wartime Sacrifices Cited
American and West European officials say they believe that Moscow wants to keep troops in the eastern part of Germany for several years after unification, and that Mr. Gorbachev may feel pressure from Soviet veterans and military men not to withdraw quickly from the country that cost 20 million Soviet lives to conquer in World War II.
It remains to be seen in future negotiations whether this position leaves room for progress along the lines proposed today by Mr. de Maiziere for NATO changes that he did not otherwise specify.
The Prime Minister said after his talks with Mr. Gorbachev and other officials that the East German position now was that ''NATO should change its structure and strategy to discuss the issue of our membership.''
''Neutrality is not a solution to the problem,'' he added, without discussing Mr. Shevardnadze's latest mention of a possible nonaligned status for a new Germany.
Mr. de Maiziere said it was important to ''obviate'' the East-West security blocs, not to emphasize them by having neutral states. ''We do not want to play the role of a buffer zone,'' he said.
 
'New Approaches' Sought
In stressing that the Soviet attitude toward a united Germany's membership in NATO ''remains negative,'' Mr. Gorbachev said, ''Such an attitude is dictated by political realism and serious concern about the prospects for Europe and about the prospects for new approaches to its problems.''
He added, ''We favor the synchronization and coordination between the process of German unification and the formation of security structures on the European scale.'' He did not elaborate on how or when such an approach might be managed.
Mr. de Maiziere described his talks as ''important and useful.'' He said East Germany had no intention of entering NATO under its current doctrine, presumably a reference to its cold war roots.
On other issues, the Prime Minister stressed that East Germany intended to live up to existing economic obligations with the Soviet Union and hoped to increase those ties. In this regard, he said, a rapid transition to convertible currencies was needed in particular.
