HEADLINE: In Boston, an Example Of Service and Diversity

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
On the wall of the headquarters of City Year, a youth service program here, hangs a copy of an American Indian prayer: ''Great spirit, grant that I shall not criticize my brother or sister until I have walked a mile in their moccasins.''
The founders of the program say it lets young people walk with, and help out, Boston's most vulnerable residents: the poor, the homeless and the physically and mentally disabled.
And as Congress considers legislation to establish an urban version of the Peace Corps nationwide, the Boston initiative has stirred special interest because its 50 recruits are a racially diverse group, some from affluent suburbs and Ivy League colleges, and others jobless high-school dropouts, from inner city neighborhoods.
''I'm unaware of any other youth corps that brings together so diverse a group of young people,'' said Greg Petersmeyer, director of the Office of National Service, which was created by President Bush to engage Americans in solving social problems in their communities. Mr. Petersmeyer recently came to Boston, where he watched City Year members build a soup kitchen in a Baptist church. 
For City Year members, who are 17 to 22 years old, their ethnic, economic and social diversity is a source of pride, especially in a city that has been repeatedly split by racial tension. Last year, in a case that transfixed and divided Boston, the police carried out extensive searches in black neighborhoods for a suspect in the fatal shooting of a pregnant woman. Weeks later, suspicion turned to the woman's husband, who then apparently committed suicide by jumping off a bridge here.
 
'Race Is a Nonissue'
''For a time we felt we were a last oasis in a city gone nuts,'' said Michael Cheroutes, a 20-year-old corps member from Denver who is on leave from Tulane University. ''We wanted to say, 'Hey, look at us, we've built a world where race is a nonissue' ''
He and Thomas Lowenstein, 20, a Milton Academy graduate, teamed up with Kenny Lopez, 22, and Cory Israel, 19, to share an apartment. The four jokingly boast about being ''two preppies and two inner city guys'' who are living together and forging bonds they expect to outlast their year of service.
It was two other roommates, Alan Khazei and Michael Brown, both 29-year-old graduates of Harvard Law School, who set out in 1987 to create City Year, the country's first privately financed youth corps. They raised $1.2 million from corporations and foundations, enabling City Year to supply a stipend of $100 a week and a college scholarship of $5,000 to each of 50 recruits who completes a year of service.
The two are unabashed in expressing their blue-sky idealism, saying: ''We were searching for a way to change the country for the better. We enlisted each other.''
Mr. Khazei and Mr. Brown say they drew inspiration from President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King. And the framed Indian prayer hangs beside a photograph of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in City Year headquarters.
 
Effort to Fight Poverty
''We started City Year really out of a sense of optimism and hope that together, we can build a better community,'' said Mr. Brown. Mr. Khazei broke in to say: ''And also out of frustration that we have the richest country in the world but also some of the deepest poverty and high infant mortality. Here in Boston, 3,500 homeless likely slept on the streets last night.''
After graduating, both worked in Washington where lawmakers were sifting proposals for a federally financed youth corps. One such bill, pushed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, for a National and Community Service Act with a $125 million pricetag, passed on March 1, and another version has been introduced in the House. Both would provide money for youth service corps that are operating in several cities and for establishing new programs.
The founders of City Year are not holding their breath waiting on Federal money. For now, the group is housed rent-free in a cavernous loft provided by the Boston Wharf Company and renovated without charge by 25 companies and seven labor unions.
Their biggest grant, of $175,000, came from the Bank of Boston. Ira Jackson, a bank senior vice president, calls it ''an investment in an idea whose time has come for Boston and for all American cities.'' He added: ''These kids just make me melt.''
Not all of the corps' experiences went according to plan. Early on, six recruits were dismissed because they could not meet the demands of the rigorous program, and three quit. Regardless of weather, members are expected to show up weekdays at 8:30 A.M. in uniform for an hour of calisthenics in front of the Federal Reserve Building and then work until 4:30 on assigned projects.
 
Corps' Accomplishments
But members prefer focusing on City Year's growing list of accomplishments. The corps created and now manages an after-school program for children at a low-income housing development in Egleston Square. It salvaged and distributed 130 tons of surplus food, painted a shelter for the homeless, and repaired and cleaned the homes of senior citizens in East Boston.
At the Blackstone Elementary School, which has the city's largest percentage of Hispanic pupils, corps members have tutored scores of youths in reading and math, but ''their bigger achievement was serving as role models,'' said the principal, William Ubines.
Before City Year began in September, the organizers ran an experimental summer program, modeled in part on New York's City Volunteer Corps, started in 1984.
Michael Brown, in fact, spent a year working in the New York program, a city-financed undertaking that enrolled 5,000 young people in parttime and fulltime jobs. Unlike Boston, which sought a small, diverse group, New York wanted to put hundreds of young people into service quickly. Black and Hispanic youths make up 90 percent of the group, and white and Asian youths make up 10 percent.
Elsewhere, a consortium of private foundations is promoting urban youth corps in 15 other cities under a program developed by Public/Private Ventures, a Philadelphia-based nonprofit research orgnization, and the National Association of Service and Conservation Corps.
A number of Boston's City Year members aspire to careers in national politics, and Mr. Brown and Mr. Khazie maintain that their community service will give them the ''integrity'' to speak from first-hand experience.
Whatever work he chooses, the corps experience has made Kenny Lopez, who was born in Roxbury, certain of one thing: He will not move away from the city that is his home. ''I know now I can go out and be somebody,'' he said. ''I intend to make it here in Boston.''

HEADLINE: Military Aid vs. Drugs? Yes, but . . .

 BODY:
Washington is finally about to release $230 million in aid money, much of it for military support, to help Andean governments combat cocaine. Is expanded military aid and advice the right way to address the drug problem in Latin America?
The answer is yes, with three conditions: Military aid should be funneled through civilian governments with due attention to supporting democracy. U.S. advisers have to abstain from any combat role. And the aid has to be part of a broader strategy that includes economic development. 
Some argue that the cocaine supply can't be reduced enough to affect drug use on the street. And it's true that only a cut in supply large enough to force a dramatic increase in prices could make a difference. It's also true that Andean coca farmers feeling pressured in one area have plenty of opportunity to plant in another.
But this futility theory is premature. The serious attempt of Andean governments (Bolivia, Colombia and Peru) to reduce cocaine production began only last year. And until now, Washington has provided only minimal support.
Even so, there are some surprisingly positive results. Colombia's campaign against drug traffickers, followed by a less publicized campaign in Bolivia, broke up the production pipeline, making it harder for growers to sell their crop. As a result, the price for raw coca leaves plummeted. The hundred pounds that once brought $60 now sells for around $10, well below the $30 cost of production.
In Bolivia, the market collapse has impelled coca growers to sign up in impressive numbers for a program paying them to tear up coca and plant other crops. In all of 1989, crop substitution eliminated only 2,500 hectares of coca; so far this year the acreage eliminated exceeds 3,000. Meanwhile, U.S. drug officials note that the wholesale price of cocaine in American cities has increased since last September by 10 percent to 25 percent, while purity of cocaine on the street has decreased by 10 percent.
However modest, these are promising signs and reason to welcome the $230 million in new aid money. Yet the prospect of greater military aid still stirs concern about Vietnam-style escalation. Perspective is important: yes, the new aid might double U.S. military advisers in the Andes, but only to about 400 for the three countries. And they would be there to support police, not combat operations.
The Administration also has to be very careful about Peru at a time when the civilian government is in the process of changing hands. The aid ought to be given in a way that does not feed anxieties about supporting the Peruvian military.
Finally, and most important, there is a danger of too much reliance on military solutions. A policy of military pressure alone risks replacing narcoterrorism with severely disrupted economies. Washington officials dismiss such concerns by pointing to plans for $175 million in economic aid next fiscal year. But skeptics worry over the firmness of that commitment given budget pressures.
Reassurance is important, both at home and in Latin America, and there is one obvious way to achieve it: Give Bolivia more money for its expanding crop substitution program right now. Such an investment in agriculture could also yield big dividends in credibility throughout the hemisphere.

HEADLINE: Blacks in College: Numbers and Rate

 BODY:
The number of black students in college increased between 1986 and 1988, after nearly a decade of decline, the U.S. Department of Education reports. It's encouraging news, but there's still cause for concern.
In 1980 the figure for black undergraduates was 1,028,000. It dipped to 995,000 in 1984-85. Since then, the numbers have climbed again, reaching 1,039,000 in 1988. But meanwhile, other numbers present a more dismaying picture. 
One reason concerns college enrollment. In 1988, 75 percent of blacks between the ages of 18 and 24 had completed high school, compared with less than 70 percent in 1980. But the proportion of blacks going on to college remained stagnant, at about 28 percent, and that was down from the peak of 33 percent in 1976. By comparison, the high school completion rate of whites remained at about 81 percent but the proportion going on to college increased, from 32 to 37 percent.
A second reason for concern is variation by sex. Among blacks who do go to college, three in five are women. A growing gap between educated black men and women gives reason for worry about the future of black families and the nation's work force.
Why aren't more blacks going to college? One reason is cost. During the Reagan years, the proportion of Federal financial aid in grants declined relative to loans, and benefits per student did not keep pace with inflation. That helped to discourage blacks - more often poor, less likely to borrow.
For many minority students, however, the problem begins long before college. Despite recent improvements in college aptitude scores, many black high school graduates remain unsure of their academic skills, and many poorer students lack family and community support for a commitment to college.
Those problems add more weight to the case for aggressive early intervention programs to help disadvantaged minority youngsters, particularly boys, do better in elementary and secondary school. In the meantime, colleges could step up outreach programs, especially those that offer a taste of higher education. Private colleges, which accounted for an impressive 7 percent of the latest enrollment increase among blacks, show the worth of aggressive programs to recruit and retain minority students.

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Europe's Borders: Faint - or Fragile

BYLINE: By Leon V. Sigal

 BODY:
Flows of trade and investment can surmount political borders between states. States can raise higher walls, but at a fearsome price. This tension between openness and insularity now arises on Poland's border with Germany. 
Some borders in Western Europe are fast becoming geographers' formalities. As one looks down on the German-Belgian frontier from the air, nothing demarcates one country from another. Trains roll back and forth with barely a pause. Customs inspectors no longer open luggage. Control officers stamp no documents.
But the insecure nations of Central and Eastern Europe may insist on shoring up borders they regard as fragile. Even as the Iron Curtain disappears, past transgressions leave enduring scars. And even as Poles, Hungarians and Czechoslovaks open their markets to international trade, they see their borders as symbols of sovereignty.
That's why Chancellor Kohl's calculated ambiguity about Germany's border with Poland seems so parochial and retrograde. His Germany has an enormous stake in economic internationalism, throughout Europe. By his reluctance to guarantee the Polish border against change by force, he intensified the suspicions of Polish nationalists who want to resist German economic domination.
No thoughtful German today contemplates a military push east. But Germans who thrill to newfound economic power see investment and trade with Poland as a way to extend influence. And Germans who see a need to overcome the legacies of the past want to help Poland prosper.
Poles desperately need foreign trade and investment if they are to pull themselves out of their economic quagmire. For too long, they have had to depend on sales to the Soviet market, a dependence that will continue until the quality of Polish products improves. That's why Poles are eager for foreign investors to help them replace obsolescent plant and equipment.
But Poles worry that Germany's eastern boundary has never been clearly demarcated in German minds, regardless of where the line is drawn on German maps. It's of little consolation to Poles that today's temptation takes economic, not military, form. They regard the border as a barrier to German penetration. They want an international guarantee of the border, and they've allowed the Red Army to remain in Poland until they get it.
To balance German economic influence, the Poles are encouraging trade and investment from others - especially the United States and France. The economic balance of power inside Poland may matter more to them than the military balance of power outside Poland.
Mr. Kohl's neighbors don't believe that Germany intends to transgress borders. But he has missed an opening for Germany to transcend them.

HEADLINE: Costly Homes Foil Hopes Of Buyers

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Despite a recent drop in prices, the goal of home ownership in the New York metropolitan region is far more elusive today than it was 10 years ago.
While median incomes increased by half in the 1980's, the median price of houses and apartments escalated at three times that rate. Economists say the growing gap between housing prices and incomes is among the most serious threats to the region's vitality.
Among those hardest hit by the surge in prices - which was the largest ever in the metropolitan area - were young people seeking to buy for the first time, blue-collar families, households with only one wage earner and those coming to New York from other parts of the country.
Some people were forced to leave the region during the decade for areas where housing costs were lower. Corporations, along with cultural and educational organizations, found it much more difficult to recruit people to New York. Some companies that left the area, including the Mobil Corporation, blamed the high price of housing and the resulting difficulty of recruiting young executives. 
 
'Housing Has Become Unattainable''
Unless incomes rise significantly or housing prices drop further, some economists say, the New York region is likely to become less able to compete with most metropolitan areas in the fight for new jobs and industry.
''Housing has really become unattainable for many people,'' said Rosemary Scanlon, the chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which monitors regional trends. ''Many people at the low- and middle-income level found it impossible to do anything. And my guess is that a whole chunk of young middle-income people, the baby boomers, are way behind people in other regions.''
The statistics paint a stark tableau. The median price of a single-family home in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut areas soared to $183,200 last year from $70,500 in 1982, when the rise began, according to the National Association of Realtors.
Cooperative and condominium prices in Manhattan nearly doubled in the same period, rising to an average of $486,180 in 1989 from an average of $247,700 in 1982, according to a survey by the Corcoran Group, a real-estate brokerage firm. Housing prices peaked in 1988, and have fallen, on average, about 5 to 10 percent since then.
The increases over the decade far outpaced advances in income. Median family income rose to $38,820 last year from $25,500 in 1982 in the 17-county area of New York and northern New Jersey served by the Port Authority, the agency's projections show.
Median income thus went up by 52 percent, compared with a 160 percent increase in the median price of a single-family house. Nationally, the median price of a house went up only 37 percent between 1982 and 1989, reaching $93,100.
''The market simply isn't serving the average family,'' said Bonnie Brower, executive director of the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development, a federation of nonprofit community groups in the city. ''It's a grim picture.''
 
Financial Help From Parents
But many people whose incomes were above the median were able to afford housing, even at vastly inflated prices. So were those who could muster financial help from parents and other family members to pay large down payments, thus limiting the size of their mortgages. And many people who owned relatively inexpensive housing in 1980 saw their equity increase two- and three-fold during the decade.
But for those not yet in the market, the purchase of a house or apartment became ever more unattainable. Experts summarized the severity of the problem this way: In 1980, many families with the median income, $25,500 a year, could manage, with some belt-tightening, to buy the median-price house, at $77,100, even though interest rates were then at record highs.
But in 1989, most families with the median income of $38,820 a year simply could not buy the median-priced, $183,400 house. Economists estimated that fewer than 20 percent of all families in the New York area could purchase a house in the conventional way: with a 20 percent down payment and a mortgage of about $150,000.
 
'It's Barely Existent'
''We face a situation where the housing market exists for a tiny percentage of the population,'' said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that helps develop government subsidized, middle-income housing. ''It's not so much that the market is dysfunctional; it's barely existent.''
The only way that a family with a median income could have bought the median-priced house would be by taking out a mortgage of $100,000 - the largest for which such a family could qualify - and paying a down payment of nearly half, or $83,000.
''How do you do that?'' asked Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, a trade group. ''You either have relatives or you already own a house that you are selling.''
 
Foreclosed That Option
In addition to closing many families out of the home-buying market, the surge of prices had other consequences: it enabled the city to retain many middle-class people who in earlier decades might have left for the suburbs, Ms. Wylde said. The price escalation in the suburbs foreclosed that option for many city residents.
Corporations had increased difficulty recruiting people to come to work in the region. Executives living in large, pleasant houses in places like Chicago, Houston or Detroit had to pay two or three times the selling price of their homes to find comparable housing in New York. Many chose not to make the sacrifice.
An executive from Kansas City recently terminated negotiations for a position with a New York bank after a conversation about the cost of housing. The executive told bank officials that his four-bedroom home, with a backyard pool, in a Kansas City suburb would sell for about $150,000. He asked what that sum would buy in Westchester. The answer: not much.
Cultural and nonprofit groups, from museums to orchestras to social-welfare organizations, had similar difficulties, particularly because those groups do not typically pay high salaries.
Economists say many factors produced the price escalation. Among them were a pent-up demand caused by the huge interest rates of the early 1980's; a slowdown in new construction; demographic shifts that saw many baby-boomers seeking their first house; the rise of the two-income family, and investor confidence fueled by an appreciation in the value of homes that reached 20 percent or more a year.
Ms. Scanlon of the Port Authority said that soaring incomes on Wall Street also helped bid up the price of housing. In 1988, the average wage in New York's securities and investment banking industries was $80,000 a year, while the average for all other workers in private companies was $28,000. Wall Street wages increased four-fold percent between 1977 and 1988, while all other wages rose 87 percent.
It was not coincidental, Ms. Scanlon said, that housing prices began to drop soon after the stock market's collapse in October 1987.
And while many people who purchased a house or apartment at the market's peak have lost money, economists and housing experts said the drop in prices should also bring some benefits. It could make New York more competitive with other regions, and it could begin to make home ownership available to more of the population.
''The price break is beneficial to the region,'' Ms. Scanlon said. ''It breaks the inflationary cycle, but it is still not sufficient to make housing more affordable.''

HEADLINE: Beirut Captors Say They Will Free Second American;
Bush Hopeful but Cautious

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
President Bush expressed hope that the pledge to release Mr. Reed would prove true, but declined to say more.
''I've learned not to speculate on the hostages for the reasons I keep explaining. I just won't say anything,'' said the President, who was asked about the report as he was playing a round of golf on a course at nearby Andrews Air Force Base. ''If that proves to be true, it's wonderful.''

He said he knows of no tradeoffs made or promised to Iran by the United States to secure the freedom of Mr. Reed or Mr. Polhill.
Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, seems to be leading efforts to free the hostages, but other Government leaders are resisting the move.
A leading Middle East political expert, Graham Fuller, said that the spate of hostage actions ''is clearly intended to get the issue finished, to clear the decks for Rafsanjani's own domestic and economic internal agenda.''
''If it was simply the United States'' demanding the hostages' release, ''Rafsanjani could go on without a great deal of concern,'' said Mr. Fuller, a Rand Corporation expert and the top Middle East analyst at the Central Intelligence Agency until 1987.
''But since the European states have also said that the resolution of the hostage crisis is necessary to any normalization of relations, that places much more distinct pressure on Rafsanjani himself,'' he said.
 
Family Encouraged by Report
BOSTON, April 29 (Special to The New York Times) - The daughter of Mr. Reed said today that she was ''very excited but yet apprehensive'' after learning that Lebanese kidnappers in Beirut had announced they would free her father within two days.
Mr. Reed's daughter, Marilyn Langston, said the statement was the first word the family has had about Mr. Reed since he was kidnapped in Beirut in September 1986.
''What's encouraging is that it helps us to see that he is alive,'' said Mrs. Langston, who lives in Malden.

HEADLINE: 36.6% Rise In Orders For Tools

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Rising to their highest level since September, new orders for American-made machine tools increased 36.6 percent in March, with both domestic manufacturers and foreign customers increasing their orders.
A monthly report to be released today by the Association for Manufacturing Technology, the trade association for the machine-tool industry, said that the level of new orders rose to $265.8 million in March, up from $194.55 million in February.
But compared with the March level a year earlier, new orders were down by 8.5 percent, the association said. The level for the first quarter of this year was also down by 17.6 percent from the comparable period in 1989. 
 
Rebound in Spending
The monthly surge in new orders reflected a rebound in capital spending, analysts said, adding that many manufacturers had begun to spend on plant modernization after months in which such programs had been suspended. They cautioned, however, that it was too soon to tell whether a sustained period of more robust capital spending was imminent, since machine-tool orders fluctuate widely from month to month.
''Even though there was an increase in March, the level of new orders is still fairly low,'' said James J. Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith, Polian in Omaha. ''There was weak first-quarter activity in the automobile industry and in other industries.
''We are seeing some buying going on now for new automobile models,'' Mr. Paper added. ''But one month does not make a trend.''
The higher March levels included a 20.6 percent increase in domestic orders, to $189.67 million. Foreign orders more than doubled, to $76.3 million, the association's report said.
 
'Slight Improvement'
Thomas J. Czech, the chief economist with Blunt, Ellis & Loewi in Milwaukee, said the higher tool orders reflected ''slight improvement in the manufacturing sector in the last few months.'' He said the figures indicated ''that the economy is not yet going into a recession.''
''It's a good level of new orders,'' he said, ''but it is not an outstanding reading.''
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials. The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production. Economists consider machine-tool sales patterns to be important indicators of capital-spending patterns by manufacturers.
Albert W. Moore, the president of the trade association, which is based in McLean, Va., said that the March increase was welcome but that he was concerned that much of the gain came from foreign orders.
''America's apparent reluctance to invest in the face of strong global competition contrasts with foreign manufacturers - who are investing, and investing heavily in modern productivity-improving machines.'' he said. ''Foreign manufacturers invest, while we in America sit on our wallets steadily losing competitiveness.''
 
Strong Foreign Orders
John F. Townsend, the vice president of planning and business development for Giddings & Lewis Inc., a machine-tool producer based in Fond du Lac, Wis., said orders had been strong from foreign customers, particularly from the aerospace and construction-machinery industries.
''Our inquiries for new orders are high from foreign customers,'' he said. ''And domestic inquiries have been up also. Things seem to be getting better all around.''
Still, the machine-tool industry has been particularly hurt by the downturn in the American automobile industry, which typically accounts for about a third of machine-tool orders. Consequently, many tool manufacturers have begun to look to Europe, where demand for new tools is growing at a faster pace. $198.2 Million in Orders Orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, were up by 70.4 percent in March, to $198.2 million, the association said. That segment of the industry typically accounts for about three-fourths of machine-tool orders.
New orders for metal-forming tools increased by 2.6 percent in March, to $206 million, from February's level, the association said. The shipments of machine tools were up by 7.8 percent in March, to $288.9 million, from February's $268 million.
The order backlog for March stood at $1.68 billion, down slightly from February's $1.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Push to Link Europe's Markets

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 29

 BODY:
The European Community's program for economic unity has unleashed forces that are driving the community's stock exchanges to create a pan-European market for trading the shares of Europe's biggest companies.
Once again, national self-interest is making European unity much easier to talk about than achieve. And once again, business is driving the recalcitrants forward.
The business opportunities that are expected to flow from the European Community's program for economic unification and the crumbling of Communism in Eastern Europe are pushing large companies to become more pan-European. This is increasing their need for capital and stimulating the interest of international investors in European stocks. 
 
Clamor by Institutions
As a result, big financial institutions around the world are clamoring for an efficient trading and settling system for the shares of the top 100 to 300 European companies.
Salomon Brothers Inc. estimates that about 75 percent, or nearly $40 billion, of the $52.92 billion in new money invested in the international equities market last year was invested in European markets.
And Salomon notes that this figure only takes into account European shares bought in their domestic markets by foreigners and not, for example, turnover in foreign stocks on the London Stock Exchange or in the form of American depository receipts. A.D.R.'s are the equivalent of shares in particular foreign companies and can be traded in stock markets in the United States.
But banks, other investment firms and European multinational corporations argue that many local exchanges are ill-equipped to satisfy the rapidly growing appetite for European equities. They note that liquidity - the ability to buy or sell a large stock holding - varies greatly across Europe as does the quality of clearance and settlement systems.
Some financial institutions are threatening to form an exchange themselves. Companies like Reuters Holdings P.L.C. have the technology and the information systems to enable them to carry out such a plan.
Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. gave the exchanges a scare in March when it sold a large number of Nestle shares by posting the price on Reuters screens and then clearing the purchases of the Swiss company's shares through Euroclear, a system owned by financial institutions and operated by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
''That was the entire purpose: to create a stir and tell the stock exchanges to create something or the free market has shown it is perfectly capable of addressing the problem,'' said Hans-Jorg Rudloff, chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston.
Already worried by what they believe to be a rising amount of off-exchange trading that has been made easier by electronic networks, officials of Europe's leading stock markets agree that the danger of financial institutions creating a blue-chip exchange is real.
''The exchanges have to get together to organize that marketplace as quickly as they can,'' said Andrew Hugh Smith, chairman of the London exchange.
But leaders of the three most important exchanges - London, Frankfurt and Paris - have differing ideas on how to go about it. That is not surprising, given the competition among the three cities to be Europe's pre-eminent financial center.
Regis Rousselle, head of the Paris Bourse, wants the top stocks to be traded simultaneously on any of the European Community's exchanges that choose to do so. Trades would then be reported to all markets through Pipe, a financial-information network that the Federation of Stock Exchanges in the European Community hopes to create.
''If we improve demand for securities in each country and encourage issuers, liquidity will be higher than now and it will not be necessary to create a central market for block trading,'' one of Mr. Rousselle's lieutenants said. Many suspect Mr. Rousselle hopes to win back business for the Paris Bourse, which has lost a large amount of trading in French blue chips to London.
 
'Why Reinvent the Wheel?'
Mr. Hugh Smith wants a central exchange for the top 300 or so European stocks. Although he insists he is flexible, he says it would make sense for such a system to be based on the five-year-old SEAQ International, the computerized, ''screen-based'' price-information system that has made London the leader in trading European equities. ''Why reinvent the wheel when we've got one?'' he said.
Mr. Hugh Smith has approached the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, the biggest of West Germany's eight, about forming an alliance. But Frankfurt officials do not seem eager. Friedrich von Metzler, president of the Frankfurt exchange, would like Pipe to be turned into the central trading and settlement system for big stocks.
''Why should we support a system based in London?'' said Rudiger von Rosen, executive vice chairman of the Federation of German Stock Exchanges. ''How could we have influence in a system that is the backbone of the London exchange?''
Although financial institutions often attack the exchanges for being too parochial, it is unclear whether the West German banks and others that now dominate trading in their domestic stocks will be less parochial.
Noting that institutions are under pressure from investors, Barthold von Ribbentrop, executive vice president of the Deutsche Bank in West Germany, predicts that a central market will be formed.
''There is no national pride left among financial institutions or investors,'' he said. ''And the interests of intermediaries and investors are strong enough to overcome any bickering among the exchanges.''
While Mr. von Ribbentrop called the Pipe proposal ''interesting,'' he said that ''we are far from saying that is the system; we are in favor of any system that would increase liquidity.''
Many companies and financial institutions say one of the main problems is that many local exchanges do not provide sufficient liquidity.
 
Spain and Italy Cited
Mr. Rudloff of Credit Suisse First Boston said big Swiss multinationals like Nestle ''don't get the valuations they deserve'' on the four Swiss exchanges. ''Therefore, it is much more expensive for them to raise capital. The problems are even bigger in the Spanish and Italian markets.''
While the Paris Bourse, which now has market-makers that put up their own capital and make quotes, has made great strides in recent years, some companies say they still cannot depend on it to get a good price for large blocks of stocks. There are similar complaints about the West German exchanges.
Even the London exchange, which is considered the most liquid in Europe, has its critics. Robert B. Horton, the new chairman of the British Petroleum Company, complains that B.P. is too big a stock for the exchange.
Rather than solving the liquidity problem, many bankers and brokers fear Mr. Rousselle's proposal would only compound it. ''If you want to create liquidity, you have to concentrate demand and supply in one place,'' Mr. Rudloff of Credit Suisse First Boston said.
While some financial institutions are less concerned about liquidity, virtually all agree that more efficient clearance and settlement systems are needed. ''Settlement will be the thing that drives markets together,'' said David I. Neeson, managing director of Morgan Stanley International in London.
 
Germans Most Efficient
The West Germans are among the most efficient: deals on their exchanges can be settled in two days. It can take up to three weeks in London and as long as a month on the Paris and Milan exchanges. And Spain's settlement system is so complicated that some big institutions avoid Spanish stocks altogether.
Euroclear, the system operated by financial institutions and operated by Morgan Guaranty Trust, uses a computer to transfer payment and ownership of securities simultaneously between customers' accounts. The securities, which are held in a depository network, do not physically move. Financial institutions also like the fact that the cost of using private clearers for a cross-border transaction is a fraction of the $25 to $100 it typically costs to clear and settle in the local market.
''If we could use them for all our Continental business, it would be much more cost-effective,'' said Nigel Davis, head of market-making in Continental stocks at James Capel & Company, a London-based broker.
For its part, Reuters, the leading provider of price information for stocks trading in Europe, is expanding its capability to execute trades. Its Instinet service acts as an electronic broker for British and American stocks traded in Europe and it plans to add some French and West German stocks.
Reuters is also expanding its Dealing 2000 electronic trading system, which now dominates worldwide foreign-exchange trading. The system, which is expected to soon be able to match the best bids and offers in a matter of seconds, is the basis for Globex, the service that Reuters, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and France's futures exchange, Matif, the Marche a Terme des Instruments Financiers, are setting up for trading financial futures. And John L. Stephens, a Reuters deputy managing director, notes that the technology could be used for trading other financial instruments, including stocks.
 
Wants to Aid Exchanges
Mr. Stephens stresses that Instinet belongs to various stock exchanges and that Reuters does not want to assume the regulatory responsibilities of an exchange. The company is also wary of alienating the exchanges: it hopes to make a big business out of helping them go electronic.
Reuters and Euroclear are the only ones that can offer such services. Euroclear's main competitor is Cedel, which is based in Luxembourg. Other information services include Telerate, which is owned by Dow Jones & Company; Citicorp's Quotron; Japanese-owned Quick and Telekurz, a service owned by Swiss banks.
In what could be just a first step into Europe, the National Association of Securities Dealers plans to begin operating a service in London in September for trading American stocks and foreign stocks in the form of American depository receipts.
So Europe's exchanges had better start moving, Credit Suisse First Boston's Mr. Rudloff said. ''We don't care whether it's this idea or another; what we really care about is that something efficient is developed,'' he added.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Expectations Of Fed Move Are Growing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A growing number of analysts say that the recent sharp rise in bond yields has intensified pressure on the Federal Reserve Board to tighten monetary policy.
If the Fed does decide to act, these analysts said any action would probably come before May 8, when the first leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction is expected to begin.
The case made by these analysts over the last couple of weeks was that a quick move by the Fed to raise the overnight Federal funds rate from its 8 1/4 percent level would not only reconfirm the central bank's credibility as an inflation fighter, but would also help stem any further increase in long-term interest rates.
''Prompt action might stabilize the bond market, while delay would likely foster a further selloff that could push yields to 9 1/4 percent to 9 1/2 percent,'' said Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers. 
Despite a mild rally at the end of last week, the yield on the Treasury's benchmark 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 ended late Friday at 9.02 percent. On Thursday the yield was at 9.04 percent, its highest level in nearly a year.
''The question of whether the Fed might tighten is a very viable one,'' said Leonard J. Santow, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''The Fed has to have been bothered by some of the recent economic statistics, particularly the inflation figures.''
 
Fed May Wait for Economic Data
But given the recent spate of poor economic reports, including the biggest quarterly jump in inflation since 1981, there are some Fed watchers who think that if the Fed has not taken any action by early May, the central bank will wait to see more data on economic activity in the second quarter, particularly the consumer price data due in mid-May.
Reports expected this week will provide market participants with their first look at economic activity in the second quarter. Unfortunately, they do not appear likely to dispel the sour mood of the credit markets.
''We are still in a mode where you should sell on rallies,'' said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. ''There is no reason to think we have found bottom here.''
The odds appear good that the April survey of the nation's purchasing managers, due Tuesday, will show that conditions in the manufacturing sector improved from March.
April employment figures to be released on Friday will be artificially inflated by the hiring of an estimated 250,000 Census workers. As a result, participants are likely to disregard the payroll numbers.
 
Inflation Fears
But a number of analysts said that other key elements of the report, including a possibly sharp rise in average hourly earnings, will be difficult to ignore. Another increase would be the third in a row, and would probably intensify worries about inflation.
Finally, Wednesday's announcement from the Treasury on the size of its quarterly refunding auctions in May could be surprising.
Until recently, most analysts had been anticipating that the Treasury would sell a total of $30 billion of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds at the auctions.
But those estimates have been ratcheted upward recently.
Griggs & Santow estimates the Treasury will sell a total of $30.75 billion worth of new securities: $10.50 billion of 3-year notes, $10.25 billion of 10-year notes and $10 billion of 30-year bonds.
''There is some wishful thinking on the part of the market that the Treasury will sell $30 billion,'' Mr. Santow said. ''When you look at their needs and the kind of money they have to raise, I think our estimates are closer to the mark.''
Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president and chief executive of Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., said that a refunding total ''considerably'' more than $30 billion ''could act as another factor dampening prices'' in the credit markets.
While the amount of new Treasury issues to be sold could increase, investors in the investment-grade corporate bond market are having a difficult time finding new debt securities issued by commercial banks.
 
Downgrading Banks
The reason is fairly straightforward: troubled real estate portfolios, tougher regulatory requirements and generally poor earnings have led ratings agencies to downgrade 44 banking companies so far this year, including Citicorp, the nation's largest.
As a consequence, yields on outstanding issues have risen, in some cases sharply. At current levels, few banks are willing to issue new securities.
So far this year, an average of $169 million worth of new bank issues have been priced each month, according to data from Salomon Brothers. In 1989, by comparison, the average monthly total was $947 million.
Even with serious problems confronting many banks, yields on bank notes and bonds compared with Treasury securities of comparable maturity are very high.
An example can be seen in a recent financing for First Interstate Bank in California, the nation's 16th largest.
Last week the bank priced a $112 million seven-year note through Salomon Brothers. The issue, rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Services and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, carried a 12 3/4 percent coupon and was priced at $100, which was 3.75 percentage points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
''Yield spreads available for bank paper rated BBB or better are certainly outpacing anything else that is out there right now,'' said William J. Downs, a vice president at Keefe Bruyette & Woods.
Mr. Downs and others said that at current levels some issues are beginning to attract speculative investors, a generally unknown element in the usually stable market for bank bonds. Thus far big portfolio managers, however, have remained on the sidelines. Moreover, the bargains have not yet persuaded executives at large commercial banks to start buying back outstanding issues.
''We are not yet past the period of the most intense pressure on the banks,'' said Marshall B. Front, an executive vice president at Stein Roe & Farnham, a Chicago-based investment advisory firm that manages close to $10 billion in fixed-income securities. ''As a consequence, I suspect that yields could go higher over the next couple of weeks. At that time we could well see a better buying opportunity.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Magazine Industry Bracing For Shakeout as Ads Drop

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
After a heady decade in which the number of new magazines soared and advertising revenues more than doubled to $6.6 billion, the magazine industry is bracing for a shakeout.
Many small but highly visible publications are closing or searching for badly needed money, and advertising has begun a decline that media analysts expect to persist through this year and perhaps well into the next.
For the first quarter, the total advertising pages of the so-called consumer magazines, those with a general readership, dropped an average of 3.5 percent from a year earlier, according to the Magazine Publishers of America. Of the top 100 magazines, 60 showed declines. But advertising revenues rose a slim 1.5 percent because of substantial increases in advertising rates. 
''There's no doubt about it,'' said Charles Elbaum, the president of Publishing Economics, a media consulting company. ''It may be a mini-recession, but it's a recession.''
Analysts say there is not likely to be any improvement soon. The second quarter is expected to be even softer. And the second half of the year, at best, may be flat. ''I'm projecting that consumer-magazine advertising spending will be down from 5 percent to 6 percent for the year,'' Mr. Elbaum said. ''And I don't know if next year will be any better.''
Analysts say publishers are getting an early warning signal to make important changes in the industry. There will have to be a substantial reduction in the circulations of many big magazines in order to keep profit margins healthy and an even deeper cut in the total number of titles.
Publishers must also start offering advertisers greater marketing reach through complex media programs that use in-store promotions, books and videocassettes in conjunction with magazine ads.
The declines in advertising at some well-known magazines are significant. Advertising for automobiles, liquor and cigarettes - all important categories for magazines - has been cut back significantly this year.
Car advertising, which accounts for more than 13 percent of all magazine advertising, fell nearly 9 percent, to $184 million, in the first quarter. This cutback significantly reduced the overall ad pages in the weekly news magazines: Time lost 12.4 percent, Newsweek 13.5 percent and U.S. News & World Report 10.2 percent. Cigarette advertising, which has been declining for the last few years, continued to drop and was a primary reason for lower advertising at other magazines: Sports Illustrated was down 17.8 percent, People 18.4 percent and TV Guide 10.1 percent.
A severe slump in retail advertising has hurt city magazines like New York, which was down 16.2 percent. And a dearth of retail and cosmetics advertising caused problems for the fashion magazines: Vogue lost 8.2 percent and Elle 11.7 percent.
 
Drop in Trade Advertising
Trade publications also suffered. Although statistics on first-quarter business-to-business advertising are still being analyzed, many magazines have had declines, said a spokeswoman for MMS-Rome, which tracks ad spending in the business press.
''We're seeing a lot of softness in advertising, too,'' said John Emery, president of the Association of Business Press. But the drop in ad pages for trade publications does not seem to be as drastic as that in consumer magazines, he said, because advertising in the business press has been depressed for the last three years.
As a result of the advertising dropoff, analysts said, some publishers of consumer magazines are offering substantial discounts - sometimes as much as 60 percent - from their published ad rates.
Most media executives point to uncertainty over the economy as the primary reason for the downturn in magazine advertising. ''Advertisers are more cautious than they were last year,'' said Paul DuCharme, the director of print media at Grey Advertising. ''They've already committed a lot of dollars to television, so one of their few options is to hold back spending in the magazine category.''
 
Looking for a Rebound
Publishers are hoping that automotive advertising will rebound in the fall when General Motors is expected to begin an extensive advertising campaign for its new Saturn car and will also start a new corporate campaign focusing on quality, said Jim Guthrie, the executive vice president for marketing for the Magazine Publishers of America.
But analysts said it would take more than a rebound in auto advertising to rejuvenate the industry.
Analysts said that to lure back advertising dollars that have been switched from print to television -especially cable television - or allocated instead to sales-promotion programs, magazines will have to offer integrated marketing packages that get the advertisers' messages out in a variety of ways.
''Magazines are going to have to work harder,'' Mr. DuCharme said. ''Along with advertising in their publications, some media companies will have to offer extras like advertising tie-ins on videocassettes and with books and special point-of-purchase promotions.''
 
'A New Game for Everyone'
That is exactly what some media companies are beginning to do. ''This is a new game for everyone that is going to become very important for magazines in the future,'' said Donald Elliman, executive vice president for marketing at the Time Inc. Magazine Company. Time has proposals pending with advertisers for packages that could include the company's magazines, Warner television projects, books and videocassettes.
The Meredith Corporation has put together a ''custom marketing'' program for Kraft Foods using its well-known Better Homes & Gardens cookbook. The 3.4 million copies of the special Kraft version come, as did the original, with the cookbook's trademark red-plaid cover. To help promote the book, which was offered to consumers in March, Kraft ran eight pages about recipes in The Ladies Home Journal, Better Homes & Gardens and other Meredith magazines.
Special marketing programs like this are being credited with helping magazines to attract more food and packaged-goods advertising, which have usually relied more heavily on television, said Mr. Guthrie of the publishers group.
 
Fewer Magazines Expected
Analysts said that declining advertising would also force many magazines, especially those at such large media companies as Time Warner Inc., to cut costs by trimming circulation to keep future profits healthy.
But the biggest cuts will have to come in the overall number of magazines, analysts said. During the last 10 years, the number of large consumer magazines audited by the Publishers Information Bureau has increased to 166 from 102. These magazines account for 85 percent of all magazine advertising revenue.
In addition, hundreds of smaller publications have been started during the last three years.
''There are just too many magazines now,'' said Nancy Smith, media director at Young & Rubicam. ''You can only slice up the advertising pie so much and still have a piece for everyone.''
 
Awaiting a Shakeout
The best thing that could happen, some analysts say, is a huge shakeout in the magazine industry. It may have already begun. Recently, 7 Days magazine in New York and the Long Island Monthly ceased publishing, and analysts said other magazines might cease publication soon.
''Something has to give,'' Mr. Elbaum said. ''To survive, the industry needs to wash out the most vulnerable magazines.''

HEADLINE: Arab Investment Overseas: A Vast Empire

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
On a chilly morning 10 years ago, Nemir A. Kirdar stood outside the Emir's palace in Bahrain, watching the traditional procession of ministers, ambassadors, supplicants, coffee servers and falcon keepers going into the ruler's ornate hall for the weekly reception, known as the Majlis.
Mr. Kirdar, an Iraqi of Kurdish origin who was then an officer at Chase Manhattan Bank, was about to leave to set up his own investment group and was giving up his only day off merely to shake the Emir's hand. It was time well spent, he told a visitor to the palace, since in the Arab world such gestures help gain trust.
Mr. Kirdar succeeded in earning enough trust from hundreds of wealthy Arab investors to help him start Investcorp Bank E.C., which on Wednesday agreed to purchase the Saks Fifth Avenue retail chain for $1.5 billion. Since its founding in 1982, Investcorp has grown into a large and powerful investment group. In recent years, it has put together deals worth more than $3.5 billion, involving well-known corporate names like Tiffany and Carvel in the United States, Guccio Gucci in Italy and Chaumet, the prestigious French jewelry maker. 
Though notable, Investcorp's spending spree represents a tiny fraction of the vast pool of Arab overseas investments, which total an estimated $680 billion, Arab bankers and economists say. The huge Arab investment abroad is a legacy of the oil wealth that soared beginning in the late 1970's when oil prices jumped sharply.
With oil prices having leveled off, the growth of the Arab investment cache abroad has slowed, but it is still growing briskly, largely because of income from those investments. Kuwait, for instance, now earns more on its overseas investments than it does from its oil exports.
The composition of Arab investment abroad is extremely diverse. It ranges from the enormous holdings of the government investment authorities of oil-rich monarchies like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to the personal nest eggs sent abroad as ''flight capital'' by merchants and laborers in less-developed Arab nations like Egypt, Jordan and the Sudan.
 
Private Arab Investment Groups
Among private Arab investment groups, Investcorp is joined by a handful of large, well-known concerns. One of the most successful is the Olayan Group, headed by Suliman S. Olayan of Saudi Arabia, widely known in Arab circles as the ''dean of Arab investors abroad.'' His multibillion-dollar privately held organization holds stock in many companies, including Chase Manhattan, Occidental Petroleum and CS First Boston.
Hekmat Nashashibi, a senior adviser here for the Arab Banking Corporation and former chairman of the Arab bankers association, said private Arab investors primarily from countries like Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Bahrain hold a pool of about $150 billion.
Yet these private investors are dwarfed by the huge, Arab government investment agencies from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, which have huge investments in the West.
 
Big Government Investments
The Kuwait Investment Authority, for example, holds an estimated $80 billion to $100 billion in foreign investments. Sometimes, its investments have attracted public attention, like when it bought Santa Fe International in 1981 or when it built up a 22 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company two years ago, before Kuwait agreed with London to sell its dominant stake. Similarly, Saudi Arabia raised eyebrows when it bought half of Texaco Inc.'s distribution and marketing system in the East and Gulf Coast regions of the United States.
But for the most part, the government fund managers have put their money quietly and conservatively in investments like United States and Japanese government bonds.
The government fund managers of Saudi Arabia - like the Saudi central bank, SAMA; the Kuwait Investment Authority; the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, and the Governments of Qatar, Oman, and Bahrain - hold an estimated $200 billion in overseas investments.
 
Flight Capital
The pool of Arab money abroad is swelled by the addition of flight capital, much of it from poorer, non-oil-rich Arab nations. These savings go overseas because of a lack of investment opportunities at home and fear of nationalization or political instability. The flight of capital badly needed at home clearly hinders the development of economies of the poorer, debt-burdened countries.
For example, Ali Negm, chairman of the Union de Banques Arabes et Francaises in Paris, who was Egypt's Central Bank governor, estimates that private individuals in Egypt have accumulated roughly $40 billion to $60 billion, much of it held in foreign banks.
''That is equivalent to Egypt's external debt,'' Mr. Negm noted.
Frequently, flight capital represents savings squirreled away by Egyptians, Jordanians, Yemenites and Sudanese, who work as expatriate Arabs in oil-rich nations including Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emriates, Iraq and Qatar. These expatriates build roads, teach in schools and work in hospitals.
 
Perspective on Size of Holdings
When measured against national domestic product, Arab foreign investment is even more striking, Mr. Nashashabi of the Arab Banking Corporation said. Japanese foreign investment, estimated at $400 billion, for example, is relatively small compared with Japan's gross domestic product, which is in the trillion-dollar category. By contrast, Arab flight capital alone often exceeds gross domestic product.
The growth of Arab flight capital has continued even as the debts of many Arab nations pile up. Henry Azzam, an economist at the Gulf International Bank in Bahrain, calculates the official debt of the Arab nations at $140 billion in 1988, up from $68 billion in 1982.
Mr. Azzam said in a recent interview in Bahrain: ''While several Arab governments were borrowing internationally on a larger scale during the 1970's and 1980's, residents of these countries were acquiring foreign assets at a rapid rate, depriving their countries of domestic sources of capital. The pool of flight capital from the indebted Arab countries is enormous by every estimate.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
In Magazine Publishing, Gloom but Not Doom

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Joseph J. Hanson, the publisher of Folio and Publishing News, has an analogy for the current state of the magazine business.
''It's sort of like the music of Richard Wagner,'' Mr. Hanson told the Spring Magazine Publishing Congress in New York last week. ''It's much better than it sounds.''
Despite the gloom cast by a 3.5 percent decline in advertising pages for the first quarter of 1990, magazine executives and media analysts say there are still bright spots in the industry and that the much heralded shakeout may be less drastic than some have predicted. 
 
More New Magazines
Start-ups, for example, are still strong. In 1980, the Publishers Information Bureau listed 102 general consumer magazines. In 1989, there were 166. Six years ago, 171 new magazines were started; last year, the number had risen to 584, according to Samir Husni's Guide to New Magazines.
In addition, editors and publishers are taking innovative steps to increase circulation and develop additional revenues to help them weather the current economic downturn.
The pessimism about the last three months' decline is ''a potentially dangerous reaction to short-term news'' in an industry that is basically strong, said Reginald Brack, chief executive of Time Inc. Magazines.
Ted Kruckel, marketing director for Elle Decor, agreed, adding that magazines are ''rethinking themselves and being more clearly repositioned.''
''A number of publications have folded and some areas of the market have been clearly overextended, but circulation-wise most magazines are doing well,'' Mr. Kruckel said. ''If the readers are there, advertising will follow.''
 
Intensifying Competition
There is no doubt that competition among the thousands of American magazines is intensifying. The fight for space on the newsstand has led magazines like McCall's, Essence, Cooking Light and Self to redesign themselves to stand out from the crowd.
''There was a time when a redesign was sort of secondary to marketing and editorial considerations, but now it really is one of the main things that is considered,'' said Roger Black, a leading magazine designer.
Attempts to lure readers are varied. Articles are shorter. Colors are bolder. In deference to readers' short attention span, whole pages in some magazines contain nothing but one-sentence snippets of information.
To offset the decline in advertising, magazines are offering increasingly generous discounts and even free issues to persuade readers to subscribe or renew. Ms. magazine, which suspended publication in November and is expected to reappear in June, has given up advertising entirely and will try to exist on circulation alone.
 
'Revenue Streams From Readers'
''We are dealing with an industry that was 75 percent dependent on advertising revenues a generation ago,'' said John Veronis, chairman of Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment firm specializing in media properties. ''But publishers in the last couple of decades have developed revenue streams from the readers.''
In general, magazines now derive half their revenue from advertising and half from circulation.
Analysts point out that the magazine industry is particularly resistant to generalizations about its health because it is composed of so many varied publications that have no relation with each other. A decline in revenues for Life or Manhattan,inc. has little bearing on, say, how Skateboard magazine is doing.
''I think there is a lot of confusion; the public and the press tend to lump all magazines together,'' said Dale W. Lang, president of Lang Communications, whose magazines include Working Woman, Sassy and Working Mother.
 
Increase in 'Niche' Magazines
The industry has seen an increase in ''niche,'' or special-interest, publications. Some are hot for a while, then falter. For instance, the market for outdoor magazines and some sports magazines has grown soft recently.
In the last decade, the magazine industry faced and fought off threats posed by cable television and videocassette recorders - somewhat similar to the threat from the advent of television in the 1950's, which cut into the readership of many general-interest magazines.
In addition, the surge of women into the work force has created significant changes in shopping habits that have affected magazines. Instead of having those long waits at supermarket checkout counters with ample time to browse through the magazine racks, more and more women are dashing in and out of convenience stores on their way home from work.
Meanwhile, supermarket chains have cut back on display space to make room for other products. And the proliferation of new titles has meant that more magazines are fighting for a smaller amount of space on the racks.
 
Single-Copy Sales Decline
The result has been a steady decline in single-copy sales, with women's service magazines generally taking the biggest hit. For instance, in 1980 the single-copy sales for Women's Day, which is almost entirely dependent on newsstand sales, were 7.5 million. By the end of 1989, they had dropped to 4.6 million.
''Magazines are off tremendously on the newsstand,'' said Dan Capell, editor of Capell's Circulation Report.''For the most part, this has been offset by subscription gains.''
In 1980, the average paid circulation from single-copy sales of all magazines measured by the Audit Bureau of Circulations was 91 million copies per issue. In 1989 it had decreased to 80 million.
Subscriptions, however, rose during the last decade. In 1980 the average paid circulation from subscriptions averaged 190 million copies per issue. In 1989, they had risen to 288 million copies per issue.
 
Questions About Money
Editors and publishers say that their challenge in the next few years will be how to tighten their budgets.
''Where will the money come from if not from ads - from reduction in editorial costs?'' asked John Mack Carter, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping. ''That is serious stuff.''
The industry is going through a soft period, said Bernard Leser, president of Conde Nast. ''This is a phase that will certainly separate the men from the boys.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Harvesting Exotic Crops To Save Brazil's Forest

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAUS, Brazil

 BODY:
From the wharves of this steamy Amazonian river port, sacks of brazil nuts have started an odyssey that will end this summer at the cookie counters of Macy's and Bloomingdale's.
Also this summer, the Body Shop, an organic cosmetics chain based in Britain, is to start marketing a hair conditioner based on brazil-nut oil. And the Ralston Purina Company is to start test-marketing a breakfast cereal that includes ingredients from the Amazon rain forest.
Packaged to appeal to the heightened environmental consciousness of American and European consumers, the products are part of a new effort to make the rain forest economically productive. By creating a market for the nuts, roots, fruits, pigments, oils and essences that can be regularly harvested here, environmentalists and Indian groups hope to discourage the timber industry and ranchers from further deforesting the region. 
 
A Dozen New Products
''We are trying to use the market to save the rain forest,'' said Jason W. Clay, the research director of Cultural Survival, a Boston-based group. An anthropologist by training, Mr. Clay recently translated his concern for the world's dwindling jungles and native peoples into the creation of a nonprofit trading group, the Rainforest Marketing Project.
Mr. Clay predicts that about a dozen products using ingredients from the Brazilian Amazon will enter the American market this year. Today, the leading client of the new trading company is Community Products Inc. of Montpelier, Vt., which expects to import 350,000 pounds of brazil nuts this year. The company produces a brittle candy, Rainforest Crunch, and resells the candy in bulk to Ben & Jerry's Homemade Ice Cream Inc., also based in Vermont, for the production of an ice cream flavor, Rainforest Crunch.
''It's a moral reason to munch,'' Ben Cohen, the president of Community Products and a founder of Ben & Jerry's, said in a telephone interview. The candy has been so popular that Mr. Cohen is negotiating licensing arrangements with producers in Britain and Canada and on the West Coast of the United States. A new product, Rainforest Crunch cookies, is to go on sale at Macy's and Bloomingdale's in coming months.
Recent studies have shown that systematic harvesting of products from the Amazon rain forest can be more profitable than cutting down the trees for timber and running cattle on the land. About 10 percent of the two-million-square-mile Amazon rain forest in Brazil has been deforested, largely for cattle pasture of low quality.
Over 50 years, harvesting of forest products could provide twice as much money as cattle ranching - $6,330 compared with $2,960 for each hectare - according to a recent study of the Peruvian Amazon by Charles M. Peters of the Institute of Economic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden.
 
Reserve Lands
While figures vary according to region and markets, the idea of ''extractive reserves'' - which guarantee long-term harvesting rights, largely to rubber tappers and gatherers of brazil nuts - is taking hold in Brazil.
Logging is forbidden in these reserves, which were started this year., Since January, Brazil has established four big reserves, covering 8,351 square miles, roughly the size of Massachusetts. Ten more Amazonian reserves are under negotiation.
''They won't solve the problem of deforestation, but they are a good idea and should be established as quickly as possible,'' Philip M. Fearnside, an American forestry ecologist, said in a recent interview here at the National Institute for Research in the Amazon.
The Inter-American Development Bank is negotiating $5.3 million in loans and grants to help establish a series of reserves, including a 3,747-square-mile area in Acre, a state in the western Amazon.
Mr. Clay of Cultural Survival predicts that American consumers will soon be using products based on Amazonian ingredients they have never heard of: assai-flavored sherbet, cupuacu yogurt, babacu oil, patchouli-root soap, copaiba shampoo, priprioca perfume, and condoms made of Amazonian latex.
To date, Mr. Clay has taken 350 product samples out of Brazil to show to about 40 companies in the United States and Europe.
Mr. Clay concedes that he may be creating a surge in demand that the Amazon's rickety marketing system will be unable to meet.
''The Body Shop wants 80 tons of copaiba oil a year,'' Mr. Clay said of a product that could be used for shampoos, face creams, lotions, soaps and massage creams. ''At present, Brazil only produces 60 tons of oil.''
 
Aid for Gatherers
To help the supply meet the demand, Cultural Survival is using grants from international aid groups to help gatherers form marketing and processing cooperatives. The group last year helped to pay for a new factory capable of shelling and packaging 50 tons of Brazil nuts a year.
Shelling increases the value of brazil nuts 10-fold and reduces their shipping weight by 60 percent.
As always, the goal is to make harvesting the rain forest viable. The typical native family that gathers brazil nuts earns 3 cents an unshelled pound. In New York, a shelled pound sells for $1.10 wholesale.
