PUB-DATE: April 30, 1990

LENGTH: 2160 words

HEADLINE: THE RACES IN TEANECK: A SPECIAL REPORT;
Killing Reveals Racial Divide Beneath Model CommunitiesSection A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLEBy JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
The accounts by Mr. Jemmott and Dr. Mack - the physical encounters of a youth, the suspicions of a prosperous adult - are among many angry, and, to many whites, often surprising complaints by blacks in these two suburbs known for their racial integration.
 Both communities are attractive, middle-class towns with sizable minority populations, in large part because whites in both places welcomed integration. Blacks there often live in large homes, drive nice cars and work in the professions. Their circumstances seem to spell triumph, not only for themselves but for an American society that has pledged racial equality. But the story, as some of them tell it, is more complicated than that.
 
Despite Outward Appearances
 In the weeks after the shooting of a black youth by a white police officer in Teaneck, The New York Times arranged informal group conversations with two dozen black residents of varying ages and occupations, and with a separate white group. 
 Because an event like the killing in Teaneck could have a sudden effect on opinions, a discussion group was also arranged in Bloomfield, a similar town but one whose reputation for racial harmony has not been disturbed by a crisis. The opinions by blacks in both towns appeared to be quite similar.
 Despite outward appearances of success, many blacks in both towns described being treated like second-class citizens. No group spoke in unison, but many participants spoke angrily of police harassment, housing discrimination, job bias and social slights.
 
Charges Surprise Whites
 While discussion groups do not scientifically sample public opinion, they can open windows into a community's thoughts and emotions.
 In Teaneck, most blacks said the rioting came as no surprise, and some even called it "inevitable." In Bloomfield, many spoke of a "hidden agenda" by white society to keep blacks down.
 But some Teaneck whites had sharply different racial perceptions. Most of the whites said the rioting, and charges of racism, came as a complete surprise. Housing discrimination, in their view, was nonexistent.
 Members of the white group sometimes spoke more guardedly than blacks and cautioned that they did not want to sound critical.
 By no means was every note one of sourness. Blacks and whites alike told stories of interracial friendships and marriages. Many spoke proudly of their record of integration and promised to rededicate themselves to civic harmony. Blacks and whites were interviewed separately; some people in both groups said they would have preferred to meet together.
 Still, the volume and variety of black complaints in Teaneck and Bloomfield stand out precisely because those communities have seemed so placid. The depth of discontent suggests that racial division in America may be an even deeper wound than it often appears, and ostensible goodwill a limited balm. Teaneck Police
 
Minor Affronts, Bitter Memories
 Teaneck is a town of 39,000 people in Bergen County, eight miles west of Manhattan. Its population is 67 percent white and 24 percent black, In discussions, Teaneck blacks turned first and most heatedly to the town's police department, which is eyed with suspicion by blacks of widely varying age and income. The speakers included students, a teacher, a psychologist, an unemployed man and a nightclub manager.
 Nicky McLaren, a student at Teaneck High School, said he was riding his bicycle home from work one day when the whoop of a police siren sounded behind him. An interrogation ensued: What's your name? Where are you going? Where did you get the bike?
 "I mean, hey, on my bike, you know," he said with a tone of exasperation. "Of course if I was white, I don't think he would have done that."
 Tony McNeil, a 42-year-old New York City bus driver, recalled an encounter that concerned, of all things, a pooper-scooper. As Mr. McNeil tells the story, it is minor yet revealing, a small humiliation but disturbing enough to bear retelling seven years later.
 
Sometimes Overzealous
 Mr. McNeil said he was walking his dog one night, scooperless, when a white police officer stopped him. He admits he was in the wrong, but what disturbed him was the officer's manner: the graphic way he outlined the regulations on excrement.
 Though he collected his dog and went home, he said the incident had the potential to escalate; a wisecrack back could have led to trouble. "I question whether he would have spoken to a white man my age the same way," said Mr. McNeil.
 Many whites, ranging from a college student to a 65-year-old salesman in a hardware store, also described the police as overzealous; until recently, for example, officers had to meet monthly ticket-writing quotas. But some doubted the claims of racial bias.
 "I think I've been stopped as much as anyone else," said Don Ware, the hardware salesman.
 Karen Willick, a student at Muhlenberg College who graduated from Teaneck High School in 1986, said she was not sure whether blacks were hassled by the police more than whites. But she said, "As soon as they hassle the blacks, more is made of it."
 "The white boys will just take it, if it's by a white cop, and go off and say, 'Oh, that stupid cop' or whatever," she said. "The black boys will say, 'They're doing it just because we're black.'
 "I'm not blaming them for saying that," she said, "because if it were me, I'd probably react the same way."
 
Steering Continues
 Can blacks in Teaneck live wherever they wish? All the whites agreed with Carol Otis, a junior-high-school teacher in Teaneck, who said, "If they have the money? Oh yes, I think so."
 But two different groups of blacks spoke of housing barriers. Two families said real-estate agents had urged them to resell after they became the first blacks to move onto a block.
 Jeff Locke, whose mother is white and father is black, said the discrimination showed on his block, where six or seven black families now live, though none lives just several blocks away. "Steering is still going on and I don't think that's any secret in this world," he said.
 Mr. McNeil, the bus driver, said he and his wife, Diane, were the first blacks to move onto their street almost 20 years ago. Several days later, he said, a neighbor put up a fence - but only on the side adjoining his house.
 He said he later helped the neighbor, an elderly white woman, clean her gutters, and she rewarded him with a gift-wrapped bottle. "I said, 'Oh, gee, this is great of this neighbor, she gave me a bottle of scotch,' "
 It turned out to be Thunderbird.
 
Bloomfield

 
Electoral Victory Leaves Bitterness
 Bloomfield is a town of 39,000 where 65 percent of the population is white and 35 percent is black. Just as whites in Teaneck organized a campaign to stem white flight in the 1960's as blacks began moving in, so too did those in Bloomfield.
 The seven blacks in the Bloomfield group - all, like Dr. Mack, adults who worked in the professions - said police harassment was not a problem. But they did talk just as angrily on another topic: town politics.
 Last fall, the town elected its first black mayor, Joseph M. Suggs Jr. While to outsiders, that may seem like a triumph, Bloomfield blacks said the election emphasized racial discrimination rather than disproving it.
 Bloomfield's nine city council members choose a mayor from among themselves. In recent years, Mr. Suggs said, the decision was easy, since the biggest vote-getter in the general election was also the incumbent mayor.
 But last year there was no incumbent and Mr. Suggs received the most votes in the general election. Afterward, he said, there was some discussion of elevating another council member.
 Mr. Suggs said he did not suspect a racial motive. "I do understand how others may have that perception," he said.
 
'Cold, Deliberate, Planned'
 And indeed they do; blacks in the Bloomfield discussion group uniformly characterized the circumstances as evidence of clear racial prejudice.
 Dr. Mack said the election had the same emotional meaning for Bloomfield as the shooting did for Teaneck. If Mr. Suggs had been denied power, he said, "That would have been the stimulating factor to get black people out and raise a lot of hell."
 The mayoral election was just part of what this group described as a larger effort by white society to deny blacks their due. Despite their seeming success as therapists, engineers and administrators, most spoke of stunted professional opportunities.
 A black man "has to be twice as smart to accomplish half as much" as a white rival, said Reginald Smith, a planning analyst for Connecticut. Not all whites would agree, but every member of this group did.
 Jesse Branche, an engineer for the town of Bloomfield, spoke of "charlatans" on the job, colleagues who use "cheap tricks" and "hidden agendas" to insure that blacks fail.
 "There is a discrimination belt that exists that is cold, deliberate, planned, perfect," he said.
 He and others saw similar ill intent in the local school system, which is 70 percent black even though whites are still a majority in the town. Whites, they said, deliver dual insults to the system, first by withdrawing their children, and second by seeking to find blemishes where none exist.
 Laurence Maybin, a psychologist who has raised three children in Bloomfield, angrily described a rite of passage he said has repeated itself: As high school approaches, his children's white friends seek private education.
 Mr. Maybin said he was left speechless when his daughter asked, with vanishing innocence, "Gee Dad, why are all the white kids leaving the school?"
 "It feeds into that sense of, 'We're less than, we're less than, we're always less than,' " he said.
 
Mixed Feelings

 
Teaneck Harmony, Or Hypocrisy
 Not every story told by either race focused on suspicion or defeat. Mr. McLaren, the black high school student flagged down by the police, spoke warmly of an interracial group of friends. So did Ms. Willick, the recent white high school graduate. Mr. Locke, who manages a Manhattan night club, and his brother Ed, who runs a Montauk, L.I., restaurant, both said they found racial tensions much greater in college than they did growing up in Teaneck.
 Bill Kuyper, who is white and plays French horn for the New York Philharmonic, spoke proudly of his children's ease with friendships between the races. Hearing his daughter on the phone joking with a black friend about the need "to get more pigment" into the school yearbook, he said he admired their mutual ease.
 "I had feelings of brotherhood, or goodness, in me, but I never quite knew how to do it," said Mr. Kuyper. "My children, they wouldn't have any problem at all."
 Like all members of the white discussion group, Mr. Kuyper was anxious for the communty's racial situation to be placed in a favorable light. "People should realize we're getting along pretty well here in Teaneck," he said.
 Yet several stayed late and complained privately about reverse discrimination.
 Some blacks said the interracial friendships that come easily as a child grow more difficult with time. Sheena Williams, whose mother is white and father is black, said she had few white friends now that she was in high school. And she was not sure why. Maybe it is interest in different boys that keeps them apart, she said. Or maybe it is different music. Or fashion. Or hair styles. Maybe her white friends began rejecting her, and maybe she began rejecting them. "I don't know," she said. "I just seem to have more -better relations with my black friends." Subtle Injuries
 Racial injury, in the description of Ms. Williams and others, moves in just such mysterious ways. "Subtle" is a word used by both blacks and whites to describe the forces that creep between them. The "media" were often blamed.
 Mr. McNeil said he thought white teen-agers in sweat pants were considered "jocks," while black teen-agers in sweat pants were called "thugs." Kenneth Banks, a black Teaneck man, asked why he heard the clicking of automatic door locks when he approached.
 However numerous its failures, does Teaneck offer more racial equality than most other American communties? Like most questions of race, it depends on whom you ask.
 All the Teaneck whites said it did. So, too, did many of the black Teaneck teen-agers, despite their complaints of frequent police harassment.
 Among the black Teaneck adults, however, opinion was sharply split. "It defintely deserves some credit," said Jeff Locke, who described it as the best place he's lived.
 But others nodded when Fred Greene, an affable former Teaneck police lieutenant, suddenly called the image of racial accomplishment "an exercise in hypocrisy" and "a living lie."
 Mr. Greene, who is black, said members of both races had participated in an illusion of harmony, "when the masses of people are living separate and apart."
